column7: b'The French-Canadian DJ Philippe Aubin-Dionne debuts his long-overdue love letter to the dance floor.'
column8: b'Feel Infinite may be the debut Jacques Greene album, but it\xe2\x80\x99s hardly the first we\xe2\x80\x99ve heard from the project\xe2\x80\x99s 27-year-old mastermind, Philippe Aubin-Dionne. Since his breakout single on the 2010\xc2\xa0Night Slugs Allstars compilation, the French-Canadian DJ and producer has graduated from throwing parties in his native Montreal to touring the world with a steady stream of singles and EPs on indie dance labels.' b'It might seem odd to release your debut LP seven years into an ascendant career. However, for a working club DJ, most money is made on the live circuit and most fans are accustomed to getting all their music for free, so it\xe2\x80\x99s considered a luxury to have the time and resources to produce a full-length. Aubin-Dionne\xe2\x80\x99s contemporaries Kaytranada and Kingdom followed this route, making late, full narratives reflective of their identities.' b'On Jacques Greene\xe2\x80\x99s first LP, the narrative is of an introvert who\xe2\x80\x99s found human connections in the club; he\xe2\x80\x99s found an escape not from reality, but from loneliness. It\xe2\x80\x99s very much of the Montreal scene that birthed his career, one that was inclusive geographically. The Turbo Crunk parties he threw with Rob Squire, Hadji Baraka, and other dance peers were defined by border-busting beats build on Southern bounce, Bay Area hyphy, and Missy Elliott, all laced with a cappella rapping.' b'The songs on Feel Infinite are colorful and melodic, built on simple structures. He uses a minimalist palette\xe2\x80\x94often just a drum track, synthesizer, and vocal sample. Seemingly rooted in house and techno, and punctuated with R&B vocals, the album plays with the building blocks of UK bass music and gives it his own spin. Feel Infinite is the work of an internet autodidact, one who\xe2\x80\x99s culled his collection from peer-to-peer filesharing and admits it freely; he\xe2\x80\x99s a music nerd who follows rabbit holes on Wikipedia and taught himself modular synthesizers by reading message boards. His crate-digging goes down online, from sampling random strangers\xe2\x80\x99 tunes on YouTube to recording an exotic dancer\xe2\x80\x99s vocals on her smartphone, and those samples are at the heart of Feel Infinite.' b'From the first deep breaths of opener \xe2\x80\x9cFall\xe2\x80\x9d to the warbled wobble of \xe2\x80\x9cAfterglow,\xe2\x80\x9d voices set the emotional tone for the entire album. Aubin-Dionne is gifted at chopping up R&B vocals on top of dancefloor thumpers, and more than ever, he seems to be aware of its emotional impact. Feel Infinite is an openly tender album, meant to evoke the liberation of sharing music in a communal space even as you listen at home, alone, with headphones. It\xe2\x80\x99s his 11-song love letter to the club, the place he spent his formative years.' b'Though it\xe2\x80\x99s no longer the premier sales unit it once was\xe2\x80\x94and for dance music DJs, maybe it never was\xe2\x80\x94the full-length album still holds enough cache for Aubin-Dionne to put his touring schedule on hold to hunker down and record it. He tried once before, with the sessions that would ultimately become Phantom Vibrate, but it felt forced, like he was trying too hard to make something serious. That EP felt cold and isolated, most evident in its distant, hollow vocals. He\xe2\x80\x99s escaped that trap by focusing on the self-contained universes in which he\xe2\x80\x99s grown into an adult: the club. Feel Infinite is warm and inviting, a taut mix of R&B love songs to finding your true self on the floor.'

column7: b"Using just a bass and a drum machine, Eva Moolchan's punk is bare and hypnotic. On her first record on Merge, she maintains her raw sound in the powerful space she built for herself."
column8: b"Brevity defines the music that Washington, D.C.\xe2\x80\x99s Eva Moolchan makes as Sneaks. On her new album It's a Myth, Moolchan logs ten tracks across 18 minutes. On her debut Gymnastics, she didn't pass 14 minutes. Her take on post-punk is minimalist and sparse\xe2\x80\x94music that proves there's a virtue in being concise. These details suggest that it would be unnatural for Moolchan to accommodate anything beyond 20 minutes, and the transient nature of her work means there is little to compare her to both past or present." b"It's a Myth represents the first Sneaks record for Merge since the label signed Moolchan eight months ago. Sneaks was born out of the desire for full creative control after playing in the short-lived Shit Stains whose first performance to five people included Katie Alice Greer of Priests. Greer introduced Moolchan into the capital's DIY scene, becoming a fixture in the community, while coming up with Priests themselves, Flasher, and Downtown Boys." b"For It's a Myth, Sneaks recorded the album with Mary Timony (Helium, Ex Hex) and Jonah Takagi, with Timony producing it at her D.C. studio. Extra hands mean more instrumentation and allow for exploring new textures to create a more fluid album. It's a Myth is not a huge leap in sound because Moolchan opts for refinement rather than repurposing the roughness of Gymnastics. According to her Bandcamp tags, they fall within \xe2\x80\x9ccold cut,\xe2\x80\x9d(?) \xe2\x80\x9czing zong\xe2\x80\x9d (??), and \xe2\x80\x9cviolent vibes.\xe2\x80\x9d These descriptors allow Moolchan's music to be flexible in her expression and secure her experimentalism." b'The Sneaks template is no more than bass, a drum machine, and vocals. Despite the minimal approach, Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s voice extends beyond the half-rapping, half-singing approach on Gymnastics. On \xe2\x80\x9cInside Edition,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0she delivers a hypnotic mantra that becomes the song\xe2\x80\x99s groove and uses\xc2\xa0her voice as a melodic tool. That new feature of her work enables the creation of \xe2\x80\x9cPBNJ,\xe2\x80\x9d in which Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s voice sounds distant, and the music behind her sounds like it\xe2\x80\x99s in a trance state. Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics are elliptical and playful, suggesting that she writes them in line with a song\xe2\x80\x99s rhythm or to her voice\xe2\x80\x99s melodic sensibilities.' b'Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s music may not appear to be as overtly political as the acts around her, but that\xe2\x80\x99s not to say she is apolitical. On \xe2\x80\x9cHair Slick Back,\xe2\x80\x9d Moolchan sings, \xe2\x80\x9cYou think you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a lot to say/No you think you need a bigger stage/You think I can\xe2\x80\x99t contain my rage.\xe2\x80\x9d The words could be a taunt at the males that dominate DIY scenes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you go to a show, and it\xe2\x80\x99s filled with all these punk bros,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Moolchan told The Media in 2015. \xe2\x80\x9cWe should be taking up the space, and not these guys.\xe2\x80\x9d Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s presence alone is an act of protest, but with \xe2\x80\x9cHair Slick Back\xe2\x80\x9d she offers a statement to rebut those with privilege who think they need more visibility.' b'Because of Moolchan\xe2\x80\x99s devotion to concision, a three-minute song like \xe2\x80\x9cLook Like That\xe2\x80\x9d is a rare example of when Sneaks expands beyond her realms. It\xe2\x80\x99s unfamiliar territory, and as a result, the song is less taut and impactful. It\xe2\x80\x99s a Myth\xc2\xa0is the natural progression from Gymnastics, and so across the record, Moolchan refines her sound within these limits. Inside and outside of the music, she embraces the self-built space that she crafted for herself.' b'Correction: A previous version of the review misidentified label on which\xc2\xa0Gynmastics was released.'

column7: b'Two virtuosic performances of a Bach composition by the eccentric Canadian pianist brought Baroque music into the modern\xc2\xa0era. Together, they explore\xc2\xa0how art and taste evolve through time.'
column8: b'The press release began: \xe2\x80\x9cColumbia Masterworks\xe2\x80\x99 recording director and his engineering colleagues are sympathetic veterans who accept as perfectly natural all artists\xe2\x80\x99 studio rituals, foibles, or fancies. But even these hardy souls were surprised by the arrival of young Canadian pianist Glenn Gould and his \xe2\x80\x98recording equipment\xe2\x80\x99 for his first Columbia sessions. \xe2\x80\xa6 It was a balmy June day, but Gould arrived in a coat, beret, muffler and gloves.\xe2\x80\x9d The rest of the bulletin detailed the other peculiarities that Gould had brought along with him\xc2\xa0when recording J.S. Bach\xe2\x80\x99s Goldberg Variations for the label.' b'These were many. Instead of nobly holding his head high with a proper recitalist\xe2\x80\x99s posture, Gould\xe2\x80\x99s modified piano bench allowed him to get his face right near the keys, where he would proceed to hum audibly while playing. He soaked his arms in hot water for up to 20 minutes before takes and brought a wide variety of pills. He also brought his own bottles of water, which, for 1955, was still something that seemed like only Howard Hughes would do. It was these initial, broadly trumpeted peculiarities that helped shape the Gould myth throughout his too-short life, the audacious genius who slightly unsettled everyone around him. Fittingly, throughout the 20th century, there would be no more audacious and initially unsettling act of musical reinterpretation than Gould\xe2\x80\x99s debut studio recording.' b'With his 1955 recording of Bach\xe2\x80\x99s Goldberg Variations, the young pianist made a compelling case for a work that, at the time, was considered an obscure keyboard composition by an otherwise imposing master of Baroque music. Gould made his counter-argument for the piece\xe2\x80\x99s rightful prominence by taking wild liberties with the source. In addition to playing the work on a piano instead of on the 18th-century era-appropriate harpsichord, Gould rushed tempos and varied his attack with aggression. His body flailed up and down his creaky chair, displaying melodramatic physical gestures\xe2\x80\x94the very cliche of a young genius at work. But instead of seeming like an impudent youngster, Gould\xe2\x80\x99s innovations signaled a clear love for the source material. He took the piece\xe2\x80\x99s unusual status\xe2\x80\x94a theme-and-variation work so varied that it could be hard for a lay audience to follow\xe2\x80\x94and realized that it could be performed with modernist vigor, full of wild twists of character.' b'Gould drilled his famous technique over time, using an obscure practice known as \xe2\x80\x9cfinger tapping\xe2\x80\x9d to produce muscle memory in his fingers\xe2\x80\x94thereby allowing for dizzying flurries of notes with astonishing control and minimal physical exertion. And at a time when the future members of the Beatles were still obsessing over British skiffle bands, Gould was pioneering the use of the studio as an instrument by splicing together different takes: finding startling collisions of mood that could help drive his conception of a work.' b'In its fervor for relating Gould\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar behaviors, Columbia\xe2\x80\x99s first press release neglected to mention all the substantive ways in which the pianist was revolutionizing the art of interpretation. The critics, however, did notice. Gould\xe2\x80\x99s Goldbergs received a raft of rave reviews from the New York Times, Newsweek, and Musical America, among others. Even writers who were unsure if his was a respectable way to approach Bach\xe2\x80\x99s sublime music counted themselves impressed by Gould\xe2\x80\x99s array of approaches\xe2\x80\x94including his dancing sprightliness, a dashing top-gear of speed, and swooning sense of drama. And Gould proved a forceful advocate for his own ideas about the piece.' b'In erudite liner notes that accompanied the first LP issue in 1956, Gould writes about the strangeness of Bach\xe2\x80\x99s theme-and-variation work:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9c...one might justifiably expect that \xe2\x80\xa6 the principal pursuit of the variations would be the illumination of the motivic facets within the melodic complex of the Aria theme. However such is not the case, for the thematic substance, a docile but richly embellished soprano line, possesses an intrinsic homogeneity which bequeaths nothing to posterity and which, so far as motivic representation is concerned, is totally forgotten during the 30 variations.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"It\xe2\x80\x99s a fascinating read of the piece\xe2\x80\x94even if it seems trollish to accuse Bach\xe2\x80\x99s Aria for adding \xe2\x80\x9cnothing to posterity.\xe2\x80\x9d (At least Gould was consistent in his dislike of obvious, top-line melodies. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t much care for Italian opera, either.) Still, it\xe2\x80\x99s true that the power associated with the culmination of Gould's Goldbergs\xe2\x80\x94when the Aria returns\xe2\x80\x94has something to do with how far the listener has traveled since the opening. If you want to make that Aria really floor people at the end, why not blow out the contrasts between the variations as you play them?" b'Gould makes an argument for his own radical vision of how the piece should be played. He sees his own jagged cadence not in defiance of but as a requisite to Bach\xe2\x80\x99s score. Even listeners who put the Goldbergs on as background music are likely to sit up and pay attention when Gould pours it on during Variation No. 5. With that one far edge of intensity established, his ruminative way of handling Bach\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCanons\xe2\x80\x9d is\xc2\xa0far more seductive. Gould\xe2\x80\x99s lightning-fast runs tend to get all the press, but they cast into sharp relief his poetic handling of the so-called \xe2\x80\x9cblack pearl\xe2\x80\x9d Variation No. 25. The power of Gould\xe2\x80\x99s 1955 Goldbergs comes from the contrasts that Gould chooses to emphasize.' b'Gould\xe2\x80\x99s first version of the Goldbergs reportedly sold 40,000 copies in its first five years: A considerable amount for any classical recording at any time, but particularly notable at the dawn of the LP era. The pop-cultural primacy of Gould\xe2\x80\x99s first take on the Goldbergs also fostered some detractors, among them some Bach specialists like Wanda Landowska who were also interested in rescuing the piece from its relative obscurity. Late in life, Gould joined their ranks, offering some withering criticisms of his 1955 recording. In 1981, the pianist told the critic and biographer Tim Page that the 1955 handling of the \xe2\x80\x9cblack pearl\xe2\x80\x9d variation had become particularly unwelcome to his own ears: \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to say\xe2\x80\x94Please Take Note: This Is Tragedy. You know, it just doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have the dignity to bear its suffering with a hint of quiet resignation.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The idea of judging his famous 1955 recording on the basis of those criteria seems like a category error\xe2\x80\x94or a set-up destined to prompt a negative assessment of his first record. The latter possibility is at least plausible,\xc2\xa0since when Gould offered this self-criticism to Page, he was doing so as part of a new publicity campaign. After being so closely identified with the Goldbergs for decades, Gould had made the rare decision to re-record a work already in his repertoire.' b'His 1981 recording of the Goldberg Variations is still recognizable as Gould: the strutting precision and emphasis on counterpoint apparent. So too is Gould\xe2\x80\x99s famously divisive practice of humming along with his playing (a natural trait of Gould\xe2\x80\x99s that seemed to flower into a deliberate affectation sometime between 1955 and 1981). But in the interim, much else has changed. There\xe2\x80\x99s less swing in Gould\xe2\x80\x99s playing; even when he turns up the tempi, it feels considered and autumnal.' b'Variation No. 5 is played in 37 seconds, the identical span of time Gould needed to burn through it in 1955. But in the 1981 variations, Gould makes good on his desire for dignity. The 1955 rendition of No. 5 has a compelling, nervy energy; the 1981\xc2\xa0version takes a greater sense of self-possession. The ability to find that much expressive room inside a similar tempo resulted in Gould\xe2\x80\x99s second masterstroke with the Goldbergs.This range of musical investigation signals something profound. Two different approaches to the same notes can say a great deal about how one ages\xc2\xa0and how tastes can move over time.' b'Gould died just days after Columbia released the second Goldberg set. His death enhanced the idea of this being a grand, final statement\xe2\x80\x94as though touching the work again had created a fateful resolution for his startling debut. But even if Gould were still with us, the 1981 Goldberg performance would sound necessary. Here, Gould luxuriates in the stately character of the \xe2\x80\x9cFrench\xe2\x80\x9d overture\xc2\xa0(No. 16)\xe2\x80\x94and its pivot away from the prior, minor-key canon\xe2\x80\x94with greater pomp than on his first try. It\xe2\x80\x99s just that the fun never spills over into abandon, as on Gould\xe2\x80\x99s first pass.\xc2\xa0For all his eccentricities, Gould\xe2\x80\x99s most striking trait may have been his ability to revise his own carefully considered understanding of a work that was important to him.' b'Both interpretations have their uses. Along with Bob Dylan\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLove and Theft\xe2\x80\x9d, which I\xe2\x80\x99d purchased at 12:01 am on Sept. 11, 2001, at the Virgin Megastore in Union Square, Gould\xe2\x80\x99s 1981 Goldberg set was the album I played most often in the days that followed. With the ashen smell still in the air, and the streets south of 14th Street devoid of car traffic, most who lived inside the perimeter established by the National Guard spent some portion of each day balancing requirements of mourning and anger with the search for a new equilibrium\xe2\x80\x94a way to feel less anxious that didn\xe2\x80\x99t also involve pretending that something traumatic hadn\xe2\x80\x99t just taken place.' b'I owned both versions of Gould\xe2\x80\x99s Goldbergs because I had been told by guidebooks that this was a prerequisite for caring about classical music (it is.) Until that week, I\xe2\x80\x99d spent most of my time with the 1955 recording\xe2\x80\x94identifying with its direct access to youthful exuberance. Now, however, the high energy of that edition seemed a poor fit to the mood. The dignity Gould had intended to emphasize in 1981 came through clearly.' b'Record collecting and music appreciation often turn on arguments about rankings, peerlessness, and the greatest-of-all-time. Classical fans play this game as aggressively as anyone\xe2\x80\x94so hard that they occasionally seem to rule out the possibility of any worthy new music being made for traditional classical instruments. And we do this with Gould\xe2\x80\x99s Goldbergs, too. Think fast: 1955 or 1981? Sometimes that\xe2\x80\x99s fun. But these recordings\xe2\x80\x99 mutual portrait of variations held in a single mind\xe2\x80\x94one capable of such deliberate differences of opinion with itself\xe2\x80\x94seems not just like something you\xe2\x80\x99re well advised to have in a music collection, but instead like an approach to life worth exploring and emulating.'

column7: b'For their droll, minimal collaboration, Jarvis Cocker and Chilly Gonzales turn their attention towards a famous hotel but end up with a more philosophical examination of these transient spaces.'
column8: b"\xe2\x80\x9cDo you check into a hotel? Or does the hotel condition check into you?\xe2\x80\x9d writes Wayne Koestenbaum in\xc2\xa0Hotel Theory, \xc2\xa0a collection positioning the hotel room as a space for possibility. Consider it a companion piece to Jarvis Cocker and Chilly Gonzales\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0Room 29, a\xc2\xa0meditation on the relationship between hotel and guest, comprised of piano, voice, bits of strings from the\xc2\xa0Kaiser Quartett,\xc2\xa0and sound effects. Of course, these seemingly blank slates still hold memories and emotions, and that\xe2\x80\x99s where this collaboration gets interesting. Sorting through metaphorical traces left behind, Cocker asks on the title track, \xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything sadder than a hotel room that hasn't been fucked in?\xe2\x80\x9d" b'Some of the real-life stories from the\xc2\xa0Chateau Marmont, the infamous Los Angeles hotel where this room 29 is located (with a grand piano, no less), are indeed quite sad.\xc2\xa0In one of\xc2\xa0*Room 29\xe2\x80\x99*s several tabloid tales, Cocker speak-sings of dear \xe2\x80\x9cClara,\xe2\x80\x9d the pianist daughter of Mark Twain, who attempted to rouse the spirit of her dead husband at the Chateau. Memories of old Hollywood types haunt the record just as they do the hotel, like the only slightly veiled allusion to Jean Harlow in Bombshell. If one wishes to know all the references, the immediate concordance machine that is the internet will\xc2\xa0provide all the easter eggs\xc2\xa0for interested listeners.' b'For as mysterious a backdrop the Chateau can be, what\xe2\x80\x99s more intriguing here is how Cocker\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics edge into analytical territory while trying to figure out what it is, exactly, that people do in hotel rooms. Do they figure out relationships? Pretend like everything is okay? Perhaps take comfort in the free breakfast anyway? Lope about the lobby in a state of surreal emptiness while listening to cinematic numbers like \xe2\x80\x9cA Trick of the Light\xe2\x80\x9d? The music and the tone of voice seem\xc2\xa0to suggest this melancholy state. But combined with often laugh-out-loud funny lyrics\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t need a girlfriend, you need a social worker,\xe2\x80\x9d Cocker quips on \xe2\x80\x9cTearjerker\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the clanging rhymes can end up somewhere near a gaudy Tin Pan Alley standard.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that this album (if you can call it that) will be performed at the\xc2\xa0Barbican\xc2\xa0in London, given that it\xe2\x80\x99s all about bringing listeners into the room. But as much as this is supposed to be an experimental and theatrical tour of\xc2\xa0Room 29, both Cocker and Gonzales have way too much pop-song mastery for this to be just a fussy one-time stay.\xc2\xa0Cocker brings his wry Pulp persona to bear on Gonzales\xe2\x80\x99 elegant piano and film-score approach and deep pop tune understanding.\xc2\xa0A few tracks are infectious enough to merit standalone listens.'

column7: b'Vancouver\xe2\x80\x99s the Courtneys capture the shambolic spirt of New Zealand bands like the Clean and write effortlessly catchy songs about heartache and longing.'
column8: b'The Courtneys are charmingly droll. The Vancouver trio includes but one Courtney, n\xc3\xa9e Courtney Garvin, who rips vivid fuzz-guitar riffs alongside bassist Sydney Koke and singer/drummer Jen Twynn Payne. Their music\xe2\x80\x94a bit gray, slightly lopsided\xe2\x80\x94recalls velvety 1980s kiwi acts such as the Clean and Look Blue Go Purple. Crucially, though, the Courtneys bust out of the ramshackle Dunedin sound with bold, driving arrangements and thrilling pop sense. They have covered U2\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI Will Follow\xe2\x80\x9d live and mention the influence of Teenage Fanclub and Big Star. Accordingly, the\xc2\xa0Courtneys feel like a punkish band with clearly-outlined emotions\xc2\xa0and a cheekily arena-rock spirit. On their supremely catchy second album, II, they lock into\xc2\xa0a real groove. They tactfully pair simplicity and strength. They make sad songs sound like a blast.' b'Something about the presence of a singer/drummer always communicates a discernible\xc2\xa0vulnerability. It emphasizes just how badly this person wants a\xc2\xa0voice\xe2\x80\x94enough to carry\xc2\xa0both a tune\xc2\xa0and a beat\xe2\x80\x94and turns a song into an act of conviction. To a degree, this amplifies the reaching emotionality of II.\xc2\xa0Singing in her endearingly nasal tone\xc2\xa0across\xc2\xa0the album,\xc2\xa0Payne is\xe2\x80\x94to borrow a phrase from That Dog\xe2\x80\x94totally crushed out.' b'Payne\xc2\xa0has said II\xc2\xa0is \xe2\x80\x9c75% about crushes,\xe2\x80\x9d which feels like a modest appraisal. Though there are more oblique songs about iron deficiency, the movie Lost Boys, a distant Virgo, and alien abduction, the bulk of II is about longing\xe2\x80\x94the harshest emotion.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t get you out of my head/Even through the miles,\xe2\x80\x9d Payne sings wistfully on \xe2\x80\x9cSilver Velvet.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xc2\xa0feels like driving into a sunset, and the bubblegum sentiment at its heart (\xe2\x80\x9cAnd nothing you say!/And nothing you do!/Can stop me from thinkin\xe2\x80\x99 about you!\xe2\x80\x9d) sounds squarely fit to be shouted into hairbrush-microphones everywhere. Through the many disarming hooks of \xe2\x80\x9cMinnesota,\xe2\x80\x9d she\xc2\xa0pines,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI never wanted you to go/But you had to.\xe2\x80\x9d Likewise, \xe2\x80\x9cCountry Song\xe2\x80\x9d is liminal: \xe2\x80\x9cI know I\xe2\x80\x99m going but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know when,\xe2\x80\x9d Payne sings.' b'Among all of these\xc2\xa0uncertain feelings, the music of II is appealingly concrete. II is a lovesick album, but its songs lift off. There\xe2\x80\x99s a steadiness to its build, a comforting antidote\xc2\xa0to all of the unsteady urges.\xc2\xa0Even the seven-minute jam of \xe2\x80\x9cLost Boys\xe2\x80\x9d is sharp\xc2\xa0and measured, never losing itself. The sun-streaked riffs of \xe2\x80\x9cTour\xe2\x80\x9d pry\xc2\xa0open like a\xc2\xa0window on a long highway\xc2\xa0drive. It sprawls, capturing the restlessness that comes with transience, grounding\xc2\xa0a self-help mantra: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat you are and what you want to be/It takes a long time.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0On \xe2\x80\x9c25,\xe2\x80\x9d Payne fruitlessly\xc2\xa0chases the object of her affection, and she evokes the true emotional horror of a two-sided gemini: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a gemini/And I change my mind/Always change my mind.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'As Payne attempts to cope with heartache, the chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cMinnesota\xe2\x80\x9d is distilled yearning. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you go away/I hope that you will know,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThat I\xe2\x80\x99ll miss you so/Not easy to pretend it\xe2\x80\x99s not hard to let you go.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0These are evergreen subjects within an evergreen sound, to be sure, but II\xc2\xa0proves their cyclical natures\xe2\x80\x94especially given\xc2\xa0its\xc2\xa0remarkable energy. The songs are\xc2\xa0viscerally anguished, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t wallow. There\xe2\x80\x99s an essential, breezy levity to the music; the parts require one\xc2\xa0another. The whole of\xc2\xa0II moves forward and on.' b'The democratic alchemy of the Courtneys makes this music feel humbly triumphant\xe2\x80\x94like they collectively work through the confusion that Payne describes. Speaking with Westender, Garvin\xc2\xa0shared a story that underscores both their wry humor and this\xc2\xa0internal logic. She\xc2\xa0is a 2D animator by day, and once, Nickelodeon asked her to pitch a series. Garvin devised a cartoon based on the Courtneys, but differences with the network kept it in limbo.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIf you have a show with three characters, one needs to be the leader and the other two have simplified characteristics,\xe2\x80\x9d Garvin\xc2\xa0said. \xe2\x80\x9cI just realized right away that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to work for our band. It\xe2\x80\x99s really important that we\xe2\x80\x99re very equal.\xe2\x80\x9d They animate an\xc2\xa0egalitarian spirit on II instead.'

column7: b'The house producer Maya Bouldry-Morrison, aka Octo Octa, both describes and comforts anxiety. On this new LP, her\xc2\xa0candied synths and incandescent songs\xc2\xa0spiral towards infinity.'
column8: b'Several years ago, the producer Octo Octa compiled a mix beginning with one of the earliest house singles, Marshall Jefferson\xc2\xa0as Hercules\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0sinister \xe2\x80\x9c7 Ways.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cVisually touch the body in front of you,\xe2\x80\x9d Jefferson commands, \xe2\x80\x9ccaress it with your eyes, drink it in slowly.\xe2\x80\x9d He savors the words like a cobra does movement. There are enough layers of dominance and submission to delight Throbbing Gristle. Octo Octa\xe2\x80\x99s own work swims the gulf separating dance music\xe2\x80\x99s utopian, transcendental side\xc2\xa0from the bodies grinding up against capitalist demands and social alienation\xe2\x80\x94and perhaps each other, too, if a night\xe2\x80\x99s shape allows. She describes and comforts anxiety.' b'You could call that an acquired skill. Before Maya Bouldry-Morrison was Octo Octa, her solo material drew more from the drums-frenzied school of techno. Her early records often borrowed R&B a capellas, like \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Trying,\xe2\x80\x9d which reduced Amerie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c1 Thing\xe2\x80\x9d to abashed moans. Her use of compression could be subtly disorienting, giving different sounds tangible presence for only a moment, like ghosts.' b'With her new album Where Are We Going?, Bouldry-Morrison\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic has grown more resolved. Her\xc2\xa0candy-bright synths remain, but the songs have grown increasingly circuitous, elaborating on their own structures. \xe2\x80\x9cAdrift\xe2\x80\x9d sends a pulse descending through the depths of murky reverb; \xe2\x80\x9cFleeting Moments of Freedom (Wooo)\xe2\x80\x9d keeps circling back and starting over again, as if spiraling towards infinity. (It would explain the deadpan title.) Unlike earlier Octo Octa records, vocals are rare, often abstracted\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNo More Pain (Promises to a Younger Self)\xe2\x80\x9d distorts Mariah Carey over hip-house drums like a kite in a wind tunnel. This distracted introspection is the kind you only experience while dancing, as when the brooding \xe2\x80\x9cOn Your Lips\xe2\x80\x9d makes a synth\xe2\x80\x99s timbre blush incandescently.' b'*Where Are We Going?\xe2\x80\x94*the question could be asked in rhetorical despair, or outside a club flirtatiously at 3 a.m. This is the first Octo Octa album since Bouldry-Morrison came out as trans, and on the second part of its title track she interrupts the glistening piano melodies with a refrain: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you feel better? Are you going to feel better?\xe2\x80\x9d As she\xc2\xa0turns this interrogation back towards the listener, it reminds me of\xc2\xa0the vocal samples on DJ Sprinkles\xe2\x80\x99 Midtown 120 Blues, which placed beautiful deep house and historical\xc2\xa0grievances in dialectical intimacy. Bouldry-Morrison never feels bound to offer an answer, but through\xc2\xa0the vivid ambivalence of her music,\xc2\xa0you can sense\xc2\xa0a warming\xc2\xa0to new possibility. It\xe2\x80\x99s like someone catching sight of themselves at a mirrored corner of the dance floor, smiling faintly, and returning to the party.'

column7: b'Tame Impala bassist Cameron Avery\xc2\xa0veers away from psych-rock with an album of throwback ballads, a modern twist on the tried and true songwriting of crooners from the \xe2\x80\x9940s and \xe2\x80\x9950s.'
column8: b'Not all albums must strive for greater meaning. Plenty attempt and fall short. A great many seek a comforting adequacy\xe2\x80\x94and even those don\xe2\x80\x99t always pan out. On his solo debut, Tame Impala bassist Cameron Avery\xc2\xa0veers away from psych-rock cosmic revelations in search of a pure musical greatness of times past. Upon the record\xe2\x80\x99s announcement, he made clear his inspirations: Elvis, Sinatra, Etta James, \xe2\x80\x9cthe big band stuff with less metaphorical lyrics,\xe2\x80\x9d as he put it. From the gentle\xc2\xa0guitar plucks of \xe2\x80\x9cA Time and Place,\xe2\x80\x9d Avery\xe2\x80\x99s greatest pursuit is beauty over all else, which he achieves often throughout Ripe Dreams, Pipe Dreams.' b'Avery is best when ruminating on loves lost, found, and desired. The album\xe2\x80\x99s limited musical and thematic palette, however, means the burden for excellence falls on Avery\xe2\x80\x99s songwriting, which ranges from subtle, self-aware inversions of machismo to overt chauvinism, and in its worst moments, it\xe2\x80\x99s just bland. Ripe Dreams, Pipe Dreams is a deliberately pleasant album that occasionally soars but at a relatively low ceiling.' b'In making an album that revels in classicalism, Avery reconciles with the old-timey mores of society. On \xe2\x80\x9cDisposable,\xe2\x80\x9d the record\xe2\x80\x99s jauntiest track, he sees himself as the most ordinary bane of humanity: a dude. It\xe2\x80\x99s effective in its extreme self-deprecation, as he sings happily about being \xe2\x80\x9cjust as shit as any other brand,\xe2\x80\x9d and making a soaring hook out of \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m disposable.\xe2\x80\x9d Avery sees the haplessness of the male pursuit, that of the bumbling fool who sings to the mountaintops about why he just can\xe2\x80\x99t find the right gal. He achieves the endeavor best on\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWasted on Fidelity,\xe2\x80\x9d a track where he is in love, yet is unable to resign himself to the domesticity. On these songs, Avery breathes new life into the male pop figure as someone who sees his flaws but cannot help but do the wrong thing anyway.' b'He runs into trouble when he loses the self-awareness of it all. The subversion is absent on \xe2\x80\x9cBig Town Girl,\xe2\x80\x9d with lines like, \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I\xe2\x80\x99ve never had the time to wait around for a dame/But if I knew that we could make it, I\xe2\x80\x99d wait around for Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d as if trying on a terrible-looking fedora. Platitudes like, \xe2\x80\x9cYou know she\xe2\x80\x99s a lady,\xe2\x80\x9d also highlight this lounge singer mode, but the song is far too conventional for his affectations to land with any honesty. Similarly, his take on Elvis in \xe2\x80\x9cWatch Me Take It Away\xe2\x80\x9d offers little nuance, only chintzy cock rock.' b"Ripe Dreams, Pipe Dreams finds its true comfort zone when it is simply sweet. The opening tracks \xe2\x80\x9cA Time and Place\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDo You Know Me by Heart,\xe2\x80\x9d as well as the closing \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x99est Toi (Extended)\xe2\x80\x9d are tried and true love songs that take their time. They fully embrace the majesty of the American songbook without jamming in any rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll, winkingly or otherwise. His smoky baritone does the songs justice, though he's still more of an imitator of the past than he is a student of the past.\xc2\xa0Hamilton Leithauser + Rostam\xe2\x80\x99s 2016 collaboration, for contrast, added excitement and contemporary sounds to revive bygone trends. Making an album like this, an album of ancient ballads requires subtle innovation.\xc2\xa0Ripe Dreams, Pipe Dreams is a focused record with several wonderful songs. It\xe2\x80\x99s not novel, nor does it attempt to be, just like those old 45s it so fondly recalls."

column7: b'Phil Elverum lost his wife\xe2\x80\x94an\xc2\xa0artist\xc2\xa0and the mother of his child\xe2\x80\x94to cancer.\xc2\xa0His new album is a meditation on her memory, but also on what it means to keep living.'
column8: b'No subject has been more badly exploited by art than death. How often have you found yourself in the middle of a good book or movie, warming up to its world, making the magical passage through which its characters\xe2\x80\x99 lives become temporarily real only to be sped into artificial reverence by someone dying? Gosh, you think: Death: That\xe2\x80\x99s big. This must be a pretty meaningful experience. Death is reduced to a sympathy-extraction device, what the New York Times critic Michiko Kakutani once described as \xe2\x80\x9cliterary ambulance-chasing,\xe2\x80\x9d designed to crowbar into the hearts of an audience just as they were thinking about changing the channel. Real death, meanwhile, moves ominously through the world of the living like a tide, gathering in waves that break without warning or reason, paroxysms of grief followed by yet more shapeless life. Fake death pops. Real death remains a slog.' b'Onto this tightrope walks Phil Elverum, a hermetically introspective songwriter who records under the name Mount Eerie. In spring of 2015, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s wife Genevi\xc3\xa8ve was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, a disease that kills 80% of patients within a year. According to the American Cancer Society, nearly all people with pancreatic cancer are over 45; two-thirds are over 65. Genevi\xc3\xa8ve died three months after her 35th birthday. A year and a half earlier, she had given birth to her and Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s first child, a girl.' b'A Crow Looked at Me, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s ninth album as Mount Eerie\xe2\x80\x94and 13th overall, counting his earlier music as the Microphones\xe2\x80\x94mentions Genevi\xc3\xa8ve in nearly every song, sometimes by name, sometimes through cold, negative space. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost as though Elverum has nothing better to talk about. Which, of course, he probably doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.' b'Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s recent albums\xe2\x80\x942015\xe2\x80\x99s Sauna, 2012\xe2\x80\x99s double feature of Clear Moon and Ocean Roar\xe2\x80\x94were heavy on ambiance and fuzz, sonic embodiments of things through which we can\xe2\x80\x99t see. Crow is spare and clean, mostly voice and some guitar, the sound of coffee in winter. You can almost hear the floorboards creaking. In a recent interview, Elverum called it \xe2\x80\x9cbarely music.\xe2\x80\x9d Given the floss-thin line between his art and experience, you could take it as the album\xe2\x80\x99s intended genre: Barely music.' b'Over the past few years, there have been a handful of albums similar to Crow, or at least with a similarly autobiographical premise: Sun Kil Moon\xe2\x80\x99s Benji, Sufjan Stevens\xe2\x80\x99 Carrie & Lowell, Nick Cave\xe2\x80\x99s Skeleton Tree, stark, diaristic albums haunted by literal death, grief on record. Indie culture tends to prize this kind of undecorated directness as a stand-in for truth, as though nobody has ever spoken clearly and lied.' b'But listening to Crow, the songwriter I kept thinking of was Chan Marshall, whose early music as Cat Power felt confessional but surreal, painfully direct but impossible to pin down. Like Marshall, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s sleight of hand is that standing naked doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make him any easier to see. If anything, Crow\xe2\x80\x99s cold spaces and plainspoken delivery lull the listener into an illusion of solid ground even when it\xe2\x80\x99s not there, laying everything on the same emotional bandwidth, from meditations on geese and forest fires to descriptions of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s jaundiced skin. He never tells you how to feel, or more surprisingly, when.' b'Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s early albums as the Microphones captured the solipsism of one\xe2\x80\x99s 20s, where even small feelings are uncontainable, not the internal flicker of neurons but plate tectonics, the saga of raging rivers and moons and stars. Here, one\xe2\x80\x99s inner world was always swallowing the outer one, not just a life among many but an allegory of heaven and earth. That the music was so obsessively layered, so obviously the product of a single mind only cemented the underlying metaphor: Elverum wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just the center of his universe, he was its creator.' b'Real life\xe2\x80\x94its unpunctuated hum, its customer-service lines\xe2\x80\x94has a way of knocking that out of you. Over the past several years, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s point of view has become earthbound to the point of mundanity. Sauna, from 2015, featured an entire song about walking to the bookstore and seeing a pumpkin. Refreshingly, the pumpkin was not presented as a metaphor for anything; it was a pumpkin. Or, if it was a metaphor, it was only for the accumulation of stuff with no particular meaning or attachment to narrative, for that rare, seamless mindset where things are what they are. Crow\xe2\x80\x99s sharpest line is in its third act: \xe2\x80\x9cConceptual emptiness was cool to talk about, back before I knew my\xc2\xa0way around these hospitals.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Most of the time, though, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s ground isn\xe2\x80\x99t so solid. Crow isn\xe2\x80\x99t so much about sickness or death but the hallucinatory stupor of grief, a state where everything\xe2\x80\x94toothbrushes, flies, crows, and sunsets\xe2\x80\x94flickers with suggestion and memory, as though Genevi\xc3\xa8ve\xe2\x80\x99s spirit had been scattered back into the universe like seeds. One understands Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s temptation intuitively: After all, he can still hold her toothbrush.' b'So simple, so tactile, so deceptively real are these songs. Their cumulative effect is that they become wobbly with metaphor, forcing the listener into the kind of magical thinking that transforms everything in the living world into a sign of the dead, only to snap back into a reality that for better and worse means nothing. Halfway through the album, Elverum\xe2\x80\x99s daughter asks if mama swims, to which Elverum replies that yes, she swims all the time now, because they scattered her ashes over water.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s most breathtaking line is its last. \xe2\x80\x9cSweet kid, I heard you murmur in your sleep. \xe2\x80\x98Crow,\xe2\x80\x99 you said. \xe2\x80\x98Crow.\xe2\x80\x99 And I asked, \xe2\x80\x98Are you dreaming about a crow?\xe2\x80\x99 And there she was.\xe2\x80\x9d In a single moment, the mechanics of these songs\xe2\x80\x94the way dreams refract life, the way grief resurrects the dead without logic or warning\xe2\x80\x94becomes blindingly clear. Then, either because Elverum is polite, or because he\xe2\x80\x99s tired, or because there is nothing more to say, he ends with the image of his wife lingering like something glimpsed through a rainy window, blurry, then gone.' b"It would be easy to hear this album as sad.\xc2\xa0Certainly the facts of Elverum's story are. But\xc2\xa0facts aren\xe2\x80\x99t art and art isn\xe2\x80\x99t real, at least not the way cancer is. For an album so firmly anchored by death,\xc2\xa0Crow\xc2\xa0is suffused with life: The geese, the forest fires, the crows, the grocery-store lines where Elverum stumbles through awkward conversation with people from town. Tragedy hasn't stopped him from noticing the world; if anything, it seems to have pried his eyes open for good. As for the question of sadness, I\xc2\xa0defer to a quote attributed to Anton Chekhov that art should \xe2\x80\x9cprepare us for tenderness.\xe2\x80\x9d I have two very young children of my own; one of them is sleeping on my chest while I write. Listening to\xc2\xa0Crow, I find myself imagining what life would be like if I had to raise them without their mother. Think along these lines for any longer than a few seconds and you, like I, may find yourself rebounding from sorrow to a state of almost infinite gratitude. Take a good look, Elverum says: Most of this is beautiful and none of it is guaranteed."

column7: b"The deep cauldron of metal, prog, and doom influences\xc2\xa0have so far been a key to Pallbearer's greatness, but their third record fails to piece it all together. They have run up against their limits."
column8: b'Rising metal stars Pallbearer have an unlikely fusion of influences: melancholic doom, prog that\xe2\x80\x99s more \xe2\x80\x9980s slick than \xe2\x80\x9970s technical, and a touch of Boston\xe2\x80\x99s hyper-produced hard rock. One couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have predicted they would go from cult metal festivals like Rites of Darkness to Bonnaroo in a few years. Pallbearer should be commended for making it this far with their sound, but Heartless, their third record, shows that they have run up against their limits.' b'Album opener \xe2\x80\x9cI Saw the End\xe2\x80\x9d is\xc2\xa0similar\xc2\xa0to Foundations of Burden\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Ghost I Used to Be,\xe2\x80\x9d Pallbearer\xe2\x80\x99s first realization that they could take their heavy sound and mold\xc2\xa0it into something catchy. Those often opposite attributes\xc2\xa0are sharpened and condensed, especially when guitarist Devin Holt rips into his solo at the end. They covered Type O Negative\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLove You to Death\xe2\x80\x9d on last year\xe2\x80\x99s Fear and Fury\xc2\xa0EP, and in \xe2\x80\x9cThe End\xe2\x80\x9d they\xe2\x80\x99ve mastered Kenny Hickey\xe2\x80\x99s layered, warm goth-metal soloing. Combined with their Pallbearer\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0love of Pink Floyd, they\xe2\x80\x99ve reaffirmed prog\xe2\x80\x99s role into metal, especially Rush\xe2\x80\x99s cerebral rocking.' b'Heartless could use more of that inspiration. They\xe2\x80\x99ve become their own worst enemy by writing meandering tracks that betray their prog loftiness and their innate need to crush. \xe2\x80\x9cThorns\xe2\x80\x9d attempts to light the same fire as \xe2\x80\x9cThe End\xe2\x80\x9d and exhausts itself as it goes on. \xe2\x80\x9cLie of Survival\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDancing in Madness\xe2\x80\x9d are worse offenders, as both build towards nothing and use doom as a crutch, rather than as a starting point. In the past, weighty sorrow poured out; here, it\xe2\x80\x99s strained, slow for the sake of slow. Background synths don\xe2\x80\x99t add anything to these songs, and they also don\xe2\x80\x99t get across bassist Joseph Rowland\xe2\x80\x99s infatuation with krautrock. The beginning of \xe2\x80\x9cDancing\xe2\x80\x9d is ripe for more active electronics, some series of Tangerine Dream-like arpeggios, something to break up the monotony that was once so rich. Pallbearer are not shredders or speed demons; any slight dip in momentum is fatal, and those two tracks shoot Heartless down. It hasn\xe2\x80\x99t worked against them before, as they were adapting doom into prog\xe2\x80\x99s confines, but this record doesn\xe2\x80\x99t move that concept\xc2\xa0forward.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cCruel Road\xe2\x80\x9d awakens Heartless from its stupor by taking a lumbering\xc2\xa0approach to theatrical metal. \xe2\x80\x9cRoad\xe2\x80\x9d moves like a King Diamond song\xc2\xa0in its succession: a brooding intro, rising hysterics, a dip into neoclassical melodies, then another climatic spike to close the song. Overt dramatics are something Pallbearer hasn\xe2\x80\x99t worked with before, and it feels a lot fresher than most of the record.\xc2\xa0The common line between \xe2\x80\x9cI Saw the End\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCruel Road\xe2\x80\x9d is Pallbearer falter less when they break out from their gloomy template. \xe2\x80\x9cA Plea For Understanding\xe2\x80\x9d is the longest and most somber track on Heartless, and perhaps its best, with a lighter take on doom. Holt and Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s shimmering cleans really carry that mournful feeling \xe2\x80\x9cDancing\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLie\xe2\x80\x9d struggle to convey, and Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s vocals have never soared higher. \xe2\x80\x9cA Plea\xe2\x80\x9d is such a chore to get to, and it\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0too bad\xc2\xa0Heartless is more defined by its bookends.' b'I recently saw Pallbearer perform\xc2\xa0in Austin, and Rowland was brimming with energy, acting almost as a hype man, and Holt found a new ecstatic height in his soloing. They brought an arena liveliness to a sound that requires patience. \xe2\x80\x9cThe End\xe2\x80\x9d benefitted from this invigorated band, and there\xe2\x80\x99s good to reason to think it will become a staple of their sets. Bringing it live is still crucial to metal success, and on that front they are ready to ascend to the next level. That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t translate on Heartless, where too much space is squandered.'

column7: b"On the latest of the Toronto band's experimental zodiac EPs, Fucked Up continue to break and rebuild the definition of hardcore, venturing further out into realms of drone, ambient, and psychedelia."
column8: b'Over the band\xe2\x80\x99s 16-year career,\xc2\xa0Fucked Up has alternated between more straight-ahead hardcore on its proper albums and a parallel lane of experimental releases named after the Chinese zodiac. That\xe2\x80\x99s a bit of an oversimplification, but the dichotomy between the two modes is still intact enough where it\xe2\x80\x99s fair to say Fucked Up has operated as two different bands. For perspective, compare how 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Glass Boys\xc2\xa0featured Tragically Hip frontman Gord Downie, while 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Year of the Tiger featured Jim Jarmusch.' b'Like last year\xe2\x80\x99s two-track, 45-minute release, This Mother Forever, Year of the Snake sees Fucked Up venturing further out into realms of drone, ambient, and psychedelia with shades of prog and fusion thrown in for good measure. In fact, the two releases work as companion pieces and make the most sense as a pair. Both feature epic-length songs in the 15-to-30-minute range. But it\xe2\x80\x99s their differences that reveal the full breadth of Fucked Up\xe2\x80\x99s ambitions.' b'Where This Mother Forever sticks to a uniform structure of slow building\xe2\x80\x94its two songs are basically single ideas stretched about as far as they can go\xe2\x80\x94Year of the Snake flows in a less linear fashion, its ideas materializing and de-materializing as if the band could have turned them into separate songs but chose instead to let them bleed into one another.\xc2\xa0Over its 24-minute span, the title track encompasses simplistic riffing that verges on stoner metal, pastoral new-age psychedelia (complete with pan flute, recorder, and prayer bowl), epic hard rock, and a violin section that lands convincingly close to post-rock. Each section has ample time to simmer and it never feels like the band sacrifices flow for the sake of experimentation.' b'About halfway through the title track, when Fucked Up are going full bore channeling 2112-era Rush at their most majestic, the song transitions so that a synth figure bubbles up from underneath. The two parts initially clash, like someone bumping loud music in a car not far away. For that moment, Year of the Snake sounds almost like a mashup, but it\xe2\x80\x99s short-lived. It also exemplifies how carefully considered all of the decisions on Year of the Snake are.' b"On the other hand, nothing feels especially careful about the voice of Damian Abraham, whose\xc2\xa0bark sounds so large and forceful it's like listening to King Kong next to an orchestra. That\xc2\xa0contrast gives Year of the Snake its distinct character. And as Fucked Up have delved into ever more delicate forms of expression, it\xe2\x80\x99s been interesting to see how the band addresses the discrepancy between Abraham's style and the rest of the instrumentation. Abraham doesn\xe2\x80\x99t appear on the second track, drummer Jonah Falco\xe2\x80\x99s six-minute instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cPassacaglia,\xe2\x80\x9d and guitarist Mike Haliechuk composed the title track in a way that employs Abraham as an intermittent texture rather than a focal point. Which isn\xe2\x80\x99t to say that there isn\xe2\x80\x99t plenty of Abraham to go around, but only that if his voice was a dealbreaker for you before, Year of the Snake might be your best shot at appreciating everything that Fucked Up have to offer. (Guitarists Josh Zucker and Ben Cook do not appear on the EP.)" b'At the beginning of \xe2\x80\x9cPassacaglia,\xe2\x80\x9d which functions as a kind of denouement for the title track, the guitars (played by Falco) contain echoes of\xc2\xa0Killing Joke\xe2\x80\x99s groundbreaking 1980 self-titled debut. As revolutionary as Killing Joke sounded at the time, they approached their music as if it was a given that punk\xe2\x80\x99s rules were there to be shattered.\xc2\xa0Likewise, even after decades\xe2\x80\x99 worth of relaxing boundaries, Fucked Up bastardize\xc2\xa0hardcore in a way that gives off the thrill of creative heresy.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0As a creative insurgency waged from within its own ranks,\xc2\xa0Year of the Snake\xc2\xa0makes the genre sound more pliable than ever.'

column3: b'Heroes of the Second Story Walk Up'
column7: b'The new album from the ambient baritone guitar and turntable duo is\xc2\xa0the most fully formed and expressive to date. Its recurring themes and phosphorescent textures evoke an engaging kind of ambiguity.'
column8: b'Think of the Fun Years as Ratatat, only inverted. Like the feline-sampling Brooklyn bros, the bicoastal duo emerged a little more than a decade ago, offering the allure of an oddball instrumental configuration\xe2\x80\x94a baritone guitarist with a sharp melodic sensibility and a crucial producer with a knack for situating that sound in some deeply absorbing context. But where Ratatat favored samples and beats and athletic themes, the Fun Years instead sprawled, sculpting soundtracks for the gloaming and for daybreak, or music to be played between Ratatat\xe2\x80\x99s up-all-night anthems. Isaac Sparks used turntables to create haunted landscapes populated by soft drones, disembodied voices, and textural phantoms, overlaid by Ben Recht\xe2\x80\x99s circular guitar lines, which always suggested some deep, unspoken longing. The Fun Years were a salve for when the lights weren\xe2\x80\x99t quite out, but the party was inarguably over.' b'The engrossing new Heroes of the Second Story Walk-Up at long last perfects that premise and promise. It is the most fully formed and expressive of the Fun Years\xe2\x80\x99 ten albums to date and an immersive emotional Rorschach test, where each moment scans differently depending on what you bring to it. A forty-five-minute suite of seven interwoven pieces, Walk-Up moves like a long piano sonata, where each movement seems to comment on the same subject but never in quite the same way. The approach enables an emotional breadth and accessibility that can be rare in these arcane corners of instrumental music, making Walk-Up the kind of record you want to crawl into and inhabit for a spell.' b'During the second movement, for instance, the guitars chime as though marching toward some grand post-rock climax. Just beneath, though, there\xe2\x80\x99s a teeming bed of strained static and hiss, lurking in wait. The signals grow and eventually overtake those guitars, crawling across them and forcing them into submission, like ivy spreading over stone ruins. By the time Recht\xe2\x80\x99s guitar creeps through the electronics for the third movement, they\xe2\x80\x99re anxious and desperate, with tense minor notes reflecting prior failures. But they begin to harmonize with Sparks\xe2\x80\x99 choir of electronics, shaping a two-player symphony that somehow sounds hellish and heavenly at once. And are those deep bass drum clips pounding beneath part five\xe2\x80\x94aptly dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cDeepest Xylophone\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the sound of approaching thunder or a calming pulse? Walk-Up\xe2\x80\x99s ambiguity is its most rarified accomplishment, an instrument that lets you take your own temperature just by listening.' b'The Fun Years have been working at this admixture for years, devoted to the perfection of a singular sound and form. They\xe2\x80\x99re clear descendants of Touch Records and producer-composers such as guitarist Christian Fennesz and turntablist Philip Jeck, for whom timbre has sometimes seemed like the compositional pinnacle itself. But they\xe2\x80\x99ve learned over time to give these ethereal sounds structure and motion, so that listening to a series of drones and spirals feels more active than merely drifting. On Walk-Up, they unlock what has made Tim Hecker astonishingly popular in recent years\xe2\x80\x94textural phosphorescence that\xe2\x80\x99s occasionally overpowering and always open to interpretation.' b'As the needle or the cursor nears the end of Walk-Up, you may start to anticipate some rhapsodic finish, some radiant climax that pulls all the emotions of the first forty minutes into one honed point. That expectation is understandable, a vestige of the quintessential post-rock and soundtrack scripting that also inform the Fun Years. But Recht and Sparks avoid the temptation of tidiness, choosing instead to stay true to script and let these feelings fade into the middle distance as one. Recht militantly strums one sharp chord again and again, as Sparks\xe2\x80\x99 circuits run their course and empty into a series of fantastic glissandi that stretch, in the end, like an auditory ellipsis. It is a pragmatic conclusion, an honest admission that all these conflicting urges and experiences are only mercury, anyway. There is no triumph, no transcendence, no abject despair\xe2\x80\x94or, depending on your momentary outlook, a little bit of all of it.'

column3: b'We All Want the Same Things'
column7: b"No longer sounding like stripped-down Hold Steady songs, Finn's latest solo album\xc2\xa0is the accomplished work of a wise songwriter\xe2\x80\x94mournful, musically layered, and full of empathy."
column8: b'Craig Finn has never written a song like \xe2\x80\x9cGod in Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d Sure, the plot points should be familiar to anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s followed his work since Lifter Puller or the Hold Steady. There\xe2\x80\x99s kissing in the streets; there\xe2\x80\x99s salvation in an unexpected place; there\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0drugs; there\xe2\x80\x99s a busted boombox playing Led Zeppelin III. But in \xe2\x80\x9cGod in Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d the spoken-word piano ballad centerpiece of Finn\xe2\x80\x99s stunning new album, it feels heavier, like all his songs are contained in this one. Detailing a journey with a near stranger to settle the score for her dead brother, it illustrates the consequences of Finn\xe2\x80\x99s reckless, dangerous characters with a newfound penchant for realism. When the central drug deal goes down, it happens swiftly and silently. \xe2\x80\x9cThis isn\xe2\x80\x99t the movies,\xe2\x80\x9d Finn explains\xe2\x80\x94a distinction that would have been moot in earlier songs, where real life and rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll clich\xc3\xa9 blended into bar-band euphoria.' b'Through much of his career, Finn\xe2\x80\x99s work has come with the coziness of a weekend spent returning to a college town: filled with old friends, inside jokes, and a bittersweet struggle to move forward. While the best moments of his previous two solo albums felt like little more than stripped-back versions of solid Hold Steady songs, We All Want the Same Things is more subtle and strange. Finn\xe2\x80\x99s weathered voice is at its most expressive, tied to songs that take him as far from his comfort zone as he\xe2\x80\x99s ever tread. It\xe2\x80\x99s a remarkable record not for sounding like a return-to-form, but for feeling like entirely new territory without sacrificing its thrill or familiarity.' b'Finn\xe2\x80\x99s writing in these songs often feels like an exercise in empathy, seeking out people who\xe2\x80\x99ve never gotten the spotlight in his work. The male protagonist of \xe2\x80\x9cTangletown\xe2\x80\x9d is a wealthy divorcee who works a boring job, goes to bed early, and surrounds himself with luxuries that poorly mask his inner turmoil. You never learn his name, but it\xe2\x80\x99s almost certainly not \xe2\x80\x9cCharlemagne\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cGideon\xe2\x80\x9d: it might be \xe2\x80\x9cCraig.\xe2\x80\x9d In \xe2\x80\x9cIt Hits When It Hits,\xe2\x80\x9d Finn sounds lonely and lost atop a slow-pulsing rhythm. \xe2\x80\x9cI can tell that today is gonna be a celebration,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeats while the music drags at his words, suggesting that today will, in fact, be just the opposite. His call for hard-won joy is miles away from Hold Steady anthems where celebration felt like a divine right: \xe2\x80\x9cThis summer, grant us all the power,\xe2\x80\x9d he once sang, \xe2\x80\x9cTo drink on top of water towers.\xe2\x80\x9d Here, his characters have a hard time summoning the power just to make it through the day.' b'Finn has referred to these new songs as \xe2\x80\x9cco-dependency jams,\xe2\x80\x9d and the relationships he describes in them are complex and colorful, from the partners-in-crime of \xe2\x80\x9cJester &\xc2\xa0June\xe2\x80\x9d to the grieving road-trippers of \xe2\x80\x9cGod in Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d When people are called by name, he simply affirms their presence in the world, his characters grateful for not being alone. \xe2\x80\x9cJames, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad that you\xe2\x80\x99re here,\xe2\x80\x9d Finn sings through the synthy Kaputt-pop of \xe2\x80\x9cBirds Trapped in the Airport\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cNathan, you\xe2\x80\x99re my only friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he urges in \xe2\x80\x9cNinety Bucks.\xe2\x80\x9d Of course, the sincerity of any of these statements is tenuous. In \xe2\x80\x9cNinety Bucks,\xe2\x80\x9d Nathan responds to his friend by loaning her money, knowing she probably won\xe2\x80\x99t use it for MRI-certification. All the while, a single piano note plods in the background as their monotonous dynamic starts sounding something like stability. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes I can push ahead,\xe2\x80\x9d Finn sings, \xe2\x80\x9cSome nights the wheels just spin.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The entirety of We All Want the Same Things is steeped in a mournful haze that makes the \xe2\x80\x9cwild kind of sadness\xe2\x80\x9d Finn sings about in \xe2\x80\x9cJester &\xc2\xa0June\xe2\x80\x9d come to life, and helps these songs transcend from short stories into action-packed anthems on par with his finest work. Bruce Springsteen, particularly his character-driven early work, has long been a reference point for Finn\xe2\x80\x99s music. But here, he seems more inspired by Bruce\xe2\x80\x99s darker material: the haunting fadeout of \xe2\x80\x9cRacing in the Street,\xe2\x80\x9d the layered vocals in \xe2\x80\x9cStolen Car,\xe2\x80\x9d the muted trumpet in \xe2\x80\x9cMeeting Across the River\xe2\x80\x9d that made its star-crossed drug deal sound doomed before it even happened. In \xe2\x80\x9cPreludes,\xe2\x80\x9d Finn sings about driving\xc2\xa0through a storm, accompanied by flutes that sound like snow against windshield wipers. In \xe2\x80\x9cRescue Blues,\xe2\x80\x9d Stuart Bogie\xe2\x80\x99s horn\xc2\xa0ascends as Finn comes closer to finding a sense of resolution. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess we all/Get by in different ways,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings tenderly, more confident with each repetition. Finally, Craig Finn sounds like he\xe2\x80\x99ll be all right, like he\xe2\x80\x99s got somewhere to go when the party\xe2\x80\x99s over.'

column3: b"You're Not As _____ As You Think"
column7: b'Sorority Noise know brutal honesty can be uncomfortable, but they employ it so well on their latest album, a rafter-reaching emo record about the raw stages of grief and loneliness.'
column8: b'Numerous oft-quoted studies have equated a sleepless night with being legally drunk: you get the lowered inhibitions, impaired decision making, and depressed functionality, all without any of the buzz. And so Cameron Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s first lyric on Sorority Noise\xe2\x80\x99s third LP explains a lot of what\xe2\x80\x99s to come: \xe2\x80\x9cThis last week/I\xe2\x80\x99ve slept eight hours total.\xe2\x80\x9d From that point forward, You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As _____ As You Think tries to rouse itself from that despondency the best way Sorority Noise knows how: towering twin guitar leads, blinding bursts of distortion, instantly quotable lyrics where the vocals jump up an octave. It\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of record that would be called \xe2\x80\x9ctriumphant\xe2\x80\x9d if Boucher was in a position to enjoy any of it.' b'The title of Sorority Noise\xe2\x80\x99s 2015 breakthrough Joy, Departed\xc2\xa0now carries unfortunate foreshadowing. In its wake, \xe2\x80\x9ca lot\xe2\x80\x9d of Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s friends took their own lives by way of heroin or suicide and they were memorialized on 2016\xe2\x80\x99s It Kindly Stopped for Me EP. Sounding like he\xe2\x80\x99d slept eight hours in the past six months, Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s register rarely left a conversational baritone, with offhand lyrics and monologues laid over incidental guitar and piano, almost avant-garde in its unguarded immediacy. Later that year, Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s pre-Sorority Noise outfit Old Gray reformed for the blood-chilling Slow Burn: its scalding, minute-long screamo outbursts were the polar opposite of It Kindly Stopped for Me, but it had the same white-knuckled edge to confronting death and addiction, too emotionally drained to be anything less than direct.' b"You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As opener \xe2\x80\x9cNo Halo\xe2\x80\x9d finds the exact midpoint between these two projects and points Sorority Noise in a bold new direction. Boucher has never been more in command of melody while in his lower register\xc2\xa0or while inhabiting his hardcore roots. But even as the band makes one last surge towards catharsis before collapsing in an exhausted heap, there\xe2\x80\x99s no relief: An organ drone fades out and the next song begins with Boucher muttering, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been feeling suicidal.\xe2\x80\x9d Similar to Modern Baseball and Julien Baker\xe2\x80\x94quoted in succession on \xe2\x80\x9cA Better Sun\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Sorority Noise\xe2\x80\x99s rise in stature has coincided with an increased candor about depression and advocacy for mental health treatment, confronting the sadboy caricature that still threatens to define this scene from the outside. The songs are in part Boucher's attempt to eliminate the distance between himself and the listeners and show they\xe2\x80\x99re all in this together." b'Similar to Modern Baseball\xe2\x80\x99s Holy Ghost, You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As rushes headlong through the outside hype and internal strife, streamlining their sound rather than expanding upon it. Joy, Departed was rife with orchestral swells, florid poetry, and obtuse song titles\xe2\x80\x94the sort of things that pop-punk bands typically adopt to tell fans and the world at large know they\xe2\x80\x99re trying to be taken seriously. But those didn\xe2\x80\x99t play to their strengths, and it was only in a live setting that Sorority Noise discovered their best selves: windmilling on Gibson Explorers, letting the crowd take over during the climactic lyrics of \xe2\x80\x9cUsing,\xe2\x80\x9d creating something close to group therapy.' b"The bulk of You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As is designed for that exact purpose. Boucher nicks lyrics from his friends on \xe2\x80\x9cA Better Sun\xe2\x80\x9d and flatly states, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the part where I did cocaine to impress every one of my mouth-breathing friends.\xe2\x80\x9d And then comes a goddamn pick slide. Out of context, it\xe2\x80\x99s a throwback to any number of post-Weezer ironists flooding the Buzz Bin, but it\xe2\x80\x99s borne of the introspection that reveals how abject misery can become as routine as an office job. A pick slide as a rote gesture. Meanwhile, the midsection of \xe2\x80\x9cDisappeared,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cCar,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Are You?\xe2\x80\x9d eliminate any melody that wouldn't qualify as a hook. They rush as quickly as possible to the part that might give someone a sense of comfort in tragedy, or at least the understanding of what it might feel like to start losing friends in your early 20s. Boucher repeatedly chooses urgency over artifice: \xe2\x80\x9cYou say there\xe2\x80\x99s a god/You say you\xe2\x80\x99ve got proof/Well I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost friends to heroin/So what\xe2\x80\x99s your god trying to prove?\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a lyric he might\xe2\x80\x99ve been tempted to obscure or reword on Joy, Departed, and while the blunt immediacy of You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As can occasionally come off as awkward, the discomfort of honesty is easier to handle than forced poetry." b'In the same way that Joy, Departed tried to remove both the stigma and seduction surrounding depression, death isn\xe2\x80\x99t glamorized in either direction here. All the\xc2\xa0albums about death from Sorority Noise\xe2\x80\x99s peer group (Sprained Ankle, Home, Like NoPlace Is There, Stage Four) tend to be\xc2\xa0really fucking serious. Sorority Noise have that capability; producer Mike Sapone\xe2\x80\x99s impact emerges during the slower numbers, as \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Letter From St. Sean\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLeave the Fan On\xe2\x80\x9d recreate the desolate spaces of Brand New\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cJesus\xe2\x80\x9d in miniature. The song structures become more compact, the concerns more corporeal.' b'You\xe2\x80\x99re Not As might be something closer to emo\xe2\x80\x99s Tonight\xe2\x80\x99s the Night, a matter-of-fact, insomniac wake for those who died too young by their own hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got friends who\xe2\x80\x99ve died, but everything\xe2\x80\x99s going to be be alright,\xe2\x80\x9d Boucher sings on \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Are You?\xe2\x80\x9d and if he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t actually believe it in the moment, the show must still go on. During another restless night in the van on \xe2\x80\x9cCar,\xe2\x80\x9d Boucher muses, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not ideal, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve never felt more alive\xe2\x80\x9d and the glimmer of hope in those words feels earned. Hearing these lyrics yelled back at him as a show of solidarity might finally allow him to rest easy.'

column7: b'On his Sub Pop debut, Seattle rapper Porter Ray unspools wordy verses that delve into personal tragedy, including his brother\xe2\x80\x99s murder.'
column8: b'In 2009, Porter Ray Sullivan\xe2\x80\x99s brother, Aaron, was shot and killed during an altercation he had no stake in; when the Seattle MC\xe2\x80\x99s son was born a few years later, he named him after his late sibling. Much of Watercolor, Sullivan\xe2\x80\x99s airy, classicist debut, pivots between these two Aarons\xe2\x80\x94one a symbol of the graveyard\xe2\x80\x99s call, the other of the future\xe2\x80\x99s persistence.' b'Up until recently, the particulars of Sullivan\xe2\x80\x99s personal life have been asides in the exaggerated, smoke-session retellings of old conquests, as on the jazzy 2015 EP Nightfall. But here, for the first time, he takes the time to evaluate the tragedies that have touched his life\xe2\x80\x94in addition to his brother\xe2\x80\x99s killing, his father died of multiple sclerosis when Sullivan was 16, and the mother of his son recently died in a car crash. His stacks of wordy reflections can be deeply affecting, though they\xe2\x80\x99re also frequently muddled by ineffective execution. More often than not, Watercolor is colorless, a feeble rendering that obfuscates a harrowing coming-of-age tale with undercooked bruiser bars. Sullivan, who bubbled to the top of his city\xe2\x80\x99s talent pool by making the mundane seem luxurious with careful word choices and an eye for detail, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do his own unimaginable story justice.' b'To be fair, the album is tasked with doing a lot at once: putting on for an unheralded Seattle rap scene, earning the expectations that come with being an unusual signee for indie rock stalwart Sub Pop, and compressing nearly a decade of grief and introspection into a handful of tracks. Still, Sullivan often has trouble finding the right words, which can be disastrous for a rapper known for piecing sentence fragments together like a puzzle. He talks with his dad in his dreams and remembers blunted backyard bare-knuckle boxing with his brother on songs like \xe2\x80\x9cPast Life\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mirror Between Us,\xe2\x80\x9d but these stories get bogged down in moment-by-moment narration that lacks his signature ability to magnify and enhance.' b'When Sullivan locks in, he can be a force, effortlessly threading ideas. A song like \xe2\x80\x9cNavi Truck,\xe2\x80\x9d which uses cars as totems for cherished failed loves, showcases his best scene-setting. \xe2\x80\x9cMy Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Words\xe2\x80\x9d turns maternal advice into a new rapper checklist: be wary of drugs, envious friends, and poisonous relationships. It\xe2\x80\x99s fitting that the strongest moments come on \xe2\x80\x9cEast Seattle,\xe2\x80\x9d a song that relives his coldest nights on the city\xe2\x80\x99s streets, including the one when his brother was murdered. \xe2\x80\x9cJust try and visualize losin\xe2\x80\x99 your brother/Make you wonder how it feel inside/Hearing him suffer make me wonder how it feel to die/Seeing him sleeping in his coffin and he still inside,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps, remembering the 911 call he made from Aaron\xe2\x80\x99s phone. It\xe2\x80\x99s the most gut-wrenching moment on the album.' b'Unfortunately, Watercolor doesn\xe2\x80\x99t piece together enough of these moments. And while the productions are animated and spacious, creating openings for his jam-packed phrases, the sound doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take the full step forward that would help spotlight and redefine Seattle rap. For all its wrenching inspiration, Watercolor paints an incomplete portrait of the city and struggles that made Porter Ray one of its most vocal envoys.' b"Correction:\xc2\xa0After publication, a family member informed us that the mother of Sullivan's child had recently died in a car crash. The article has been updated to reflect this."

column3: b'All That Is Solid Melts Into Air'
column7: b'The New York-based composer offers two experimental, evocative\xc2\xa0pieces featuring cello, viola, and double bass to uniquely recreate and interact with the spaces in which they were recorded.'
column8: b'The two compositions on New York-based artist Lea Bertucci\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0All That Is Solid Melts Into Air\xc2\xa0are the product of the two spaces in which they were recorded: ISSUE\xc2\xa0Project Room\xe2\x80\x99s 22 Boerum Place\xc2\xa0theater in downtown Brooklyn, and the cavernous main room of the Knockdown Center in Maspeth, Queens (both cornerstones of New York\xe2\x80\x99s experimental music and performance communities). As an instrumentalist, Bertucci generally works with woodwinds, but here she composes and conducts for strings. These challenging, durational works tease a range of sounds and narratives out of these instruments, experimenting with how they resonate in the distinctive spaces in which they were recorded.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cCepheid Variations,\xe2\x80\x9d with Leila\xc2\xa0Bourdreuil\xc2\xa0on cello and Jeanann Dara on viola, was written for the 22 Boerum Street theater when Bertucci was a resident at Issue Project Room, premiering there in early 2015.It begins as a delicate conversation between cello and viola, conducted initially in sustained, crystalline harmonics. This picks up, occasionally, in miniature palpitations of rushed sound, until Bordreuil and Dara\xe2\x80\x99s instruments meet, ringing out. From there, a sort of dissolution occurs, the sound of bowed strings swallowed by scraping and whining. Bertucci enters the score with live tape manipulations, lending texture but also upending the sense of familiarity and solidity afforded by a richer-sounding and more recognizable string instrument. Her concrete sound moves in space quite differently from the strings, and the juxtaposition of the two instills an unsettling and thrilling sense of multidimensionality.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cDouble Bass Crossfade\xe2\x80\x9d is the more conceptual of the two pieces, relying not just on resonance in space, but on a pair of players\xe2\x80\x99 movement through it. To record, James Ilgenfritz and Sean Ali were positioned at opposite corners of Knockdown Center\xe2\x80\x99s massive main room, their double basses amplified wirelessly. For just over forty\xc2\xa0minutes, we\xe2\x80\x99re told, they moved in the space: first toward one another, crossing paths and then journeying on to the spot opposite from where they started. In a recorded version, of course, such movement is less immediately audible, though there\xe2\x80\x99s something charming about projecting an image of the two musicians traveling and interacting onto this relational performance.' b'They toy with scale, pulling tones from all over the bass\xe2\x80\x99s register, but particularly following the splintering harmonics of \xe2\x80\x9cCepheid,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDouble Bass Crossfade\xe2\x80\x9d maintains a physicality, a sense of weightedness. If the former resembles the auditory equivalent of a sharp graphite drawing, the latter brings to mind rough smears of oil. As the players approach one another, their instruments pick up volume\xc2\xa0and develop textures below their plaintive scrawls. The double basses begin to growl in\xe2\x80\x94well, not really in harmony, but as they hit their respective low ends, their rumbling melts together, producing a totalizing effect.' b'Though these pieces often build to moments of breathless intensity, they both unfold in a distinctly unhurried way. One gets the sense that Bertucci arrives at her work not with an idea to impose, but a question to develop. The groundlessness of the music isn\xe2\x80\x99t altogether surprising, and, as evidenced particularly well in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Cepheid Variations,\xe2\x80\x9d can propel the listener somewhere new (a place that I\xe2\x80\x99m not convinced even Bertucci could, or would want to, put language to). It was strange to be considering site-specificity while listening to these works in no particular place. What does it mean for a recording to hold traces of a location when those traces are largely immaterial? I think, at least, of the fact of venues so willing to be transformed through the introduction of chaotic harmonics and strange resonances, of Bertucci being afforded space to fill and warp.'

column7: b"Drake's course correction to\xc2\xa0VIEWS bursts with energy\xe2\x80\x94more South African house, more grime, more Kanye. It's a long player made for luxuriating and a total immersion into Drake's world-pop lifestyle."
column8: b'Drake\xe2\x80\x99s VIEWS\xc2\xa0was a commercial pinnacle and a creative and personal dead end. He scored the biggest hit of his career with \xe2\x80\x9cOne Dance,\xe2\x80\x9d but the album surrounding it was so aggrieved and solipsistic you felt like you were insulting Drake by listening to it. His telepathic bond with producer Noah \xe2\x80\x9c40\xe2\x80\x9d Shebib had turned stale and over its punishing 80-plus minutes he wrung every last drop of sour grapes from his Beta-Male Conqueror persona. He had crushed his frenemies, seen them driven before him, and heard the lamentations of their women\xe2\x80\x94or at least purposefully ignored their texts. What was next but exile?' b'He seems to be tacitly admitting to this stagnation throughout the warm, pulsing, and generous More Life. His solution is a \xe2\x80\x9cPlaylist\xe2\x80\x9d (not a big old serious Album, the implication goes, nor one of those little \xe2\x80\x9cmixtapes\xe2\x80\x9d other rappers bother with) that forces Drake out into the sunlight again, where he can once again mingle with the people.
