On More Life\xe2\x80\x99s closing track \xe2\x80\x9cDo Not Disturb,\xe2\x80\x9d he acknowledges the bleak spot he was in: \xe2\x80\x9cI was an angry youth\xc2\xa0while I was writing VIEWS/Saw a side of myself that I just never knew.\xe2\x80\x9d He even lets his mother\xc2\xa0pipe in with a voice message two-thirds of the way through the record on \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Have Everything\xe2\x80\x9d as she admonishes her son for the hostile, suspicious streak he was nurturing. \xe2\x80\x9cThat attitude will just hold you back in this life, and you\xe2\x80\x99re going to continue to feel alienated,\xe2\x80\x9d she advises.' b'He doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly drop the attitude, but he does play the background on More Life, implicitly acknowledging that he is often the least appealing element of his massively successful art. Dialing back on his self-pity allows all his skills that have kept him on top to float back to the surface: his ear for melodies, his sophisticated tastes, his curation skills. The more voices he lets into the frame, the fuller and richer the results, and More Life bursts with energy and lush sounds\xe2\x80\x94more guests, more genres, more producers, more life. It is as confident, relaxed, and appealing as he\xe2\x80\x99s sounded in a couple of years.' b'Drake steps back and lets the dusky-voiced 19-year-old British singer Jorja Smith soar over a sinuous club track from the rising South African house producer Black Coffee on the gorgeous \xe2\x80\x9cGet It Together.\xe2\x80\x9d Black Coffee and Jorja comprise at least 80 percent of the song; Drake is mostly relegated to mumbling or doubling the hook. Sampha bleeds his gorgeous hurt over the entirety of \xe2\x80\x9c4422,\xe2\x80\x9d with no one else in sight, and Skepta claims an entire track, boasting that he \xe2\x80\x9cdied and came back as Fela Kuti.\xe2\x80\x9d Young Thug steals not one but two songs, spitting a dense verse with no vocal filter on \xe2\x80\x9cSacrifices\xe2\x80\x9d and yelping along with the roots-reggae horns of \xe2\x80\x9cIce Melts.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Throughout, Drake\xe2\x80\x99s appetite for the music of other cultures remains ravenous. \xe2\x80\x9cI switch flow like I switch time zone,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps on \xe2\x80\x9cGyalchester,\xe2\x80\x9d the song title itself a patois nickname for the neighborhood of Manchester. On \xe2\x80\x9cSacrifices,\xe2\x80\x9d he boasts \xe2\x80\x9cI got Dubai plates in the California state.\xe2\x80\x9d In both reach and sound, Drake may now be one of the most global pop stars in history. He is shrewd and relentless about his globe-trotting on More Life: \xe2\x80\x9cDis a habibis ting, yeah?\xe2\x80\x9d he asks on the intro to a track called \xe2\x80\x9cPortland,\xe2\x80\x9d invoking a vivid zone of confusion where Arabic and Caribbean slang collides with Atlanta\xe2\x80\x99s own Quavo somewhere in the rainy Pacific Northwest.' b'As always, there are moments when it\xe2\x80\x99s unclear what Drake thinks he is borrowing. He tackles \xe2\x80\x9cNo Long Talk\xe2\x80\x9d in an unsteady tough-guy patois\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthings\xe2\x80\x9d turns to \xe2\x80\x9ctings\xe2\x80\x9d but then sneaks back into \xe2\x80\x9cthings\xe2\x80\x9d when he\xe2\x80\x99s not watching it, so he sounds a bit more like a kid with a hairbrush in the mirror than he probably intends. He also proudly shouts out his bodyguard Baka Not Nice, a man who faced human trafficking charges and was imprisoned on domestic assault charges (Drake boasts that Baka\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cquick to let a motherfuckin\xe2\x80\x99 TEC slam\xe2\x80\x9d). It\xe2\x80\x99s a reminder of his unsavory tendency to borrow street credibility from figures like Baka who have paid the price for it, the same impulse that had him pointing to a \xe2\x80\x9cprison visit\xe2\x80\x9d on his song \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Birds, One Stone\xe2\x80\x9d as evidence that he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t some \xe2\x80\x9cprivileged kid.\xe2\x80\x9d Who stunts about visiting a prison?' b'As one of the first rap superstars forged entirely outside the crucible of the American drug war, Drake has always had a confused relationship to the \xe2\x80\x9crules\xe2\x80\x9d of hip-hop. This makes his moments of flexing interesting\xc2\xa0if only for the friction they generate between the role he\xe2\x80\x99s assuming and the figure he cuts. He opens More Life with \xe2\x80\x9cFree Smoke,\xe2\x80\x9d a hard-charging and take-no-prisoners track, the sort of moment on a rap album where you ruthlessly cut down challengers and re-establish your dominance. But he spends it remembering how he used to eat Applebee\xe2\x80\x99s and Outback, or the time he drunk-texted J. Lo (\xe2\x80\x9cIt was an old number so it bounced back\xe2\x80\x9d). He does address his disgraced foe Meek Mill, who fell on a sword trying to expose Drake as a fraud: "How you let the kid fighting ghostwriting rumors turn you to a ghost?\xe2\x80\x9d he taunts. This is a peculiarly self-skewering line of attack, a bit like punching yourself in the face before going for your opponent\xe2\x80\x99s gut. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly elicit the classic, crowd-of-bystanders \xe2\x80\x9cooooh!\xe2\x80\x9d that direct shots are supposed to incite; more of a \xe2\x80\x9cuh...hmmm.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'This pluralistic and self-contradicting identity has always been part and parcel of Drake\xe2\x80\x99s inheritance to hip-hop; it will be a large part of his legacy. Name a pop star who has ever had a clearer picture of their place in the culture, who senses exactly what they can get away with and what they can\xe2\x80\x99t (other than Taylor Swift). He knows himself and his worth, at least as a market entity. \xe2\x80\x9cThey don\xe2\x80\x99t know they gotta be faster than me to get to me, no one\xe2\x80\x99s done it successfully,\xe2\x80\x9d he boasts, truthfully, on \xe2\x80\x9cDo Not Disturb.\xe2\x80\x9d More than anything,* More Life* plays like a just-in-time course correction to the excesses of VIEWS, a remarkable feat of troubleshooting that assures that October\xe2\x80\x99s Very Own\xe2\x80\x94whose catalog passed 10 billion Spotify streams before this release\xe2\x80\x94continues to own several Octobers henceforth.' b'More Life is long, for sure. It is, of course,\xc2\xa0designed to be long, to swallow up all of your streaming bandwidth. Twenty-two songs all but asks you forget other rappers and musicians exist for a while. This is the new power play in an age of digital infinitude. He doesn\xe2\x80\x99t offer insight in return, really\xe2\x80\x94eight years into examining the wages of his success, he\xe2\x80\x99s still stumbling on thoughts like, \xe2\x80\x9cHow you run out of gas on the road to riches?\xe2\x80\x9d and, \xe2\x80\x9cWinning is problematic\xe2\x80\x9d as if they are actual epiphanies. But he does offer immersion. When everything is just right\xe2\x80\x94the mood, the lighting, the production, the melody\xe2\x80\x94that immersion feels total, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine wanting to be anywhere else. The gorgeous \xe2\x80\x9cSince Way Back\xe2\x80\x9d stretches the beat way out, the silences in between yawning wide open so you momentarily lose all sense of time and momentum. It stops the album dead in the best way possible. This is the Drake moment, when you exist inside the bubble of a single drunken thought, where all priorities bend like light through a water glass and you find yourself hanging on your phone, watching the twinkling ellipsis of a responding text message like it\xe2\x80\x99s the answer to all of your prayers.'

column7: b'Barcelona\xe2\x80\x99s John Talabot and Stockholm\xe2\x80\x99s Axel Boman work in tandem to bring house music off the floor and into the air with an invigorating and meditative mix of compositions.'
column8: b'Making electronic music is often a solitary endeavor, and sometimes, after enough lonely all-nighters in the studio, its practitioners find themselves craving company. The annals of electronica are peppered with what we might call \xe2\x80\x9csuperduos,\xe2\x80\x9d pairings where both members first made their names as solo artists. Sometimes these are one-offs, like Mike & Rich (the early-\xe2\x80\x9990s collaboration between \xc2\xb5-Ziq and Aphex Twin) and Supermayer (Superpitcher and Michael Mayer). Sometimes, the new projects become so influential that they threaten to eclipse their members\xe2\x80\x99 solo careers, as briefly happened with TNGHT (Hudson Mohawke and Lunice). Sometimes, these outings give their members an opportunity to veer outside their usual lanes, like househeads Motor City Drum Ensemble and Marcus Worgull dabbling in *kosmische *music as Vermont. More often, they find their participants doubling down on shared traits, like Mumdance and Logos collectively engineering an ultra-reduced, hyper-abstracted form of grime, or Marcel Dettmann and Ben Klock cutting all the meat off techno\xe2\x80\x99s bones.' b'Talaboman are Barcelona\xe2\x80\x99s John Talabot and Stockholm\xe2\x80\x99s Axel Boman, and the goofy portmanteau is strangely fitting. The crosshatched part of the Venn diagram connecting the two artists is actually relatively slim. Both musicians make a kind of house music, both are disco fans, and both are given to bright-eyed reveries (compare Talabot\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDestiny\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cSo Will Be Now\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d with Boman\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c1979\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Dust of This Planet\xe2\x80\x9d). But that\xe2\x80\x99s about it. If the tattooed Boman sometimes comes across as the wily class clown, Talabot is the sensitive kid in the corner, distracted by his colors and his books. Together, though, something interesting happens. Their collective output doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sound much like either\xe2\x80\x99s work; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even necessarily reflect the thin, convex sliver where their interests overlap. Instead, they\xe2\x80\x99ve hit upon something new.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s long, slowly evolving tracks tend to be more mood pieces than club jams, defined less by their beats than by the rounded contours of their synthesizer patches. Album opener \xe2\x80\x9cMidnattssol\xe2\x80\x9d (Swedish for \xe2\x80\x9cMidnight Sun\xe2\x80\x9d) is a scrap of Balearic cosmic disco replete with rain sticks and birdcalls, and it sets a tone midway between ritual and celebration, private contemplation and collective abandon. Half the set hovers around that languid pace. \xe2\x80\x9cSafe Changes,\xe2\x80\x9d an emotional highlight, toys with a Kraftwerkian melody and bubbling dub delay over a measured andante drumbeat; \xe2\x80\x9cSix Million Ways,\xe2\x80\x9d a hair faster, teases a slinky arpeggio out of a murky, slow-motion house groove. The album\xe2\x80\x99s other highlight is \xe2\x80\x9cBrutal Chugga-Chugga.\xe2\x80\x9d As a pitter-pat CR-78 rhythm percolates beneath the keys, their synths gradually stiffen and sharpen; the Knife\xe2\x80\x99s Silent Shout*\xc2\xa0*briefly comes to mind, and the sound of thunder occasionally peals across the background.' b'The musicians have said that embarking upon the project gave them license to buy scads of hardware; fortunately, unlike most kids with new toys, a remarkable air of restraint prevails. All that extra room paves the way for some wild acousmatic effects: Listening through decent headphones, the steady backbeat thump of \xe2\x80\x9cDins El Llit\xe2\x80\x9d (Catalan for \xe2\x80\x9cIn Bed\xe2\x80\x9d) sounds for all the world like it\xe2\x80\x99s situated somewhere in the physical world, just outside the room you\xe2\x80\x99re sitting in. It\xe2\x80\x99s disorienting and damn near magical.' b"The other half of the album kicks along closer to house music\xe2\x80\x99s usual pulse. \xe2\x80\x9cSamsa\xe2\x80\x9d is the album\xe2\x80\x99s clubbiest selection, and\xe2\x80\x94perhaps not coincidentally\xe2\x80\x94its least compelling, flogging dubby organ chords and bass squelch over tambourine backbeats for nearly 11 minutes. Along the way, they flirt with a tremolo synth lead that's strikingly reminiscent of Carl Craig\xe2\x80\x99s classic \xe2\x80\x9cFalling Up\xe2\x80\x9d remix, and while the extended climax might help explain why they stretch out the way they do, they could have managed just as much drama in half the time. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Ghosts Hood\xe2\x80\x9d is more successful, wrapping a cowbell-heavy groove in burbling electronics and periodically unleashing quiet but expressive bursts of reverb. It's small tweaks like these, which subtly but decisively move the energy forward, that reveal the deftness of their touch. On \xe2\x80\x9cLoser\xe2\x80\x99s Hymn\xe2\x80\x9d and the closing \xe2\x80\x9cDins El Llit,\xe2\x80\x9d they keep the pace brisk but downplay the drums, and the results, a kind of dance music with its head in the clouds, are both invigorating and meditative\xe2\x80\x94like the album itself."

column7: b'This electronic collaboration pairs\xc2\xa0Dylan Carlson of pioneering drone metal band Earth with UK producer\xc2\xa0the Bug.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s one man\xe2\x80\x99s sprawling open space versus\xc2\xa0another\xe2\x80\x99s sonic claustrophobia.'
column8: b'Despite the similarities between noise and heavy music, the pairing of the Bug\xe2\x80\x99s Kevin Martin and Earth\xe2\x80\x99s Dylan Carlson still makes for a bit of a curious\xc2\xa0contrast.\xc2\xa0The UK-born Martin\xc2\xa0traffics in chest-compressing beats, drawing on a lineage spanning from dancehall through grime and dubstep. Earth, meanwhile, is a Washington state doom band that trudges with an ambient, codeine-hazed pace. In other words, this electronic collaboration,\xc2\xa0Concrete Desert,\xc2\xa0is one\xc2\xa0man\xe2\x80\x99s looming sonic claustrophobia versus another\xe2\x80\x99s sprawling open space.' b'But dig into the nuances of their catalogs\xe2\x80\x94like the sparse first-half of the Bug\xe2\x80\x99s 2014 album Angels & Devils, or the low-end of Earth\xe2\x80\x99s heatstruck churn on that year\xe2\x80\x99s Primitive and Deadly\xe2\x80\x94and it begins to make sense.\xc2\xa0Forget genre or even structure: Martin and Carlson value pressure.\xc2\xa0They revel in the attack and release of slow-building drone grooves and the contrast between thumping bass and a floating tempo.\xc2\xa0*Concrete Desert *sees them finding common ground, though\xc2\xa0there\xe2\x80\x99s more debt to minimal, tense electronic music than dust-bleached rock. The beats themselves are sparer\xc2\xa0than most of what you\xe2\x80\x99d expect from a producer like Martin, who is so steeped in dance, and Carlson adds a\xc2\xa0pensive quality,\xc2\xa0showing what Martin can build when he makes music to *stop *moving to.' b'Concrete Desert leaves space for the sounds to sink in, and you can really absorb the individual qualities of both artists. The album feels crucially airy\xe2\x80\x94not breezy, but rather a stinging dry heat.\xc2\xa0A few songs let booming basslines take on\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0role of Carlson\xe2\x80\x99s droning riffs, or echo them, like the tense \xe2\x80\x9cSnakes Vs Rats.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Given room to wander, the feedback and reverb become instruments themselves. Lower frequencies heave\xc2\xa0like rusted cellos on \xe2\x80\x9cBroke.\xe2\x80\x9d And a decayed quality brings\xc2\xa0out the static in the beats on \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Walk These Streets\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0and \xe2\x80\x9cHell A.\xe2\x80\x9d When the songs really take advantage of the record\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0dynamic\xe2\x80\x94ambient contemplation jolted by a rattling bassline or scalpel-jab guitar strum\xe2\x80\x94the idea of this music as a doom-metal dubplate sinks in. On a track like \xe2\x80\x9cAgoraphobia,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0the lowrider subs are laced with guitar echo, and it feels less like a meeting of bass music and drone and more like bass music *as *drone.' b"If the album\xe2\x80\x99s title weren\xe2\x80\x99t enough, Martin has stated that *Concrete Desert *is a specifically Los Angeles kind of album, and not just because\xc2\xa0it was recorded there, in Daddy Kev\xe2\x80\x99s studio with DJ Nobody at the console. Even if all the words are in the titles\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGasoline,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCity of Fallen Angels,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cOther Side of the World\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the music itself is laden with a Brit\xe2\x80\x99s half-awed, outsider take on L.A. It feels a bit like the sonic equivalent to English punk iconoclast Alex Cox turning to the grimier outlying regions of L.A.\xc2\xa0to depict a lawless and unpredictable concrete landscape in 1984\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Repo Man. (Concrete Desert\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0spiritual resemblance to\xc2\xa0the film\xe2\x80\x99s score doesn't hurt, either.) It\xe2\x80\x99s neo-neo-noir music that draws you into its discomfort. If its vast expanses\xc2\xa0leave listeners vulnerable, at least there\xe2\x80\x99s more space to let yourself roam."

column7: b'What is the difference between American and Italian\xc2\xa0minimalism? A preeminent example of the latter is this 1979 record, one of the most sumptuous, spiritual ambient albums of any era or provenance.'
column8: b'Italian progressive rock icon and all-around renaissance man Franco Battiato once sought out violinist Giusto Pio for violin lessons. A member of Orchestra Sinfonica Di Milano Della RAI, Pio assisted Battiato as his sound was undergoing a furious metamorphosis, from the prog rock of his earliest albums to a more minimalist sound of the late \xe2\x80\x9970s (in this regard, Battiato is Italy\xe2\x80\x99s Brian Eno). Soon after, the duo would pivot towards pop song, with some of Battiato\xe2\x80\x99s early \xe2\x80\x9980s albums selling over a million copies, which led to the two collaborating on a Eurovision hit by 1984.' b"In 1979, the same year Battiato made L'Era Del Cinghiale Bianco (with Pio handling arrangements), Battiato also produced Pio\xe2\x80\x99s first solo album, Motore Immobile, two diametrically opposed efforts that showcased the duo\xe2\x80\x99s musical range. And while the former marked the tandem\xe2\x80\x99s first foray into pop, the latter stands as one of the towering beacons of Italian minimalism and one of the most sumptuous ambient albums of any era. Recently, there\xe2\x80\x99s been a greater appreciation for that era in Italian music\xc2\xa0with the Milanese label Die Schachtel reissuing stark classics like Luciano Cilio\xe2\x80\x99s Dell\xe2\x80\x99Universo Assente\xc2\xa0and Raul Lovisonni and Franceso Messina\xe2\x80\x99s Prati baganati del Monte Analogo. But Pio\xe2\x80\x99s debut has long been unobtainable. Originally released on the revered Cramps Records label (home to operatic progressives like Area and Demetrio Stratos as well as albums by American composers like John Cage and Robert Ashley), Motore Immobile has been near impossible to track down since its release. And with Pio\xe2\x80\x99s recent passing earlier this year, it\xe2\x80\x99s a fitting tribute to the man to have his greatest work see reissue now courtesy of the newcomer Soave label." b'Motore Immobile is one of Italian minimalism\xe2\x80\x99s most beatific iterations, with an approach that brings to mind Italian cuisine, meaning a concentration on a handful of quality ingredients so as to reveal the profundities contained within such simple material. Though with food it\xe2\x80\x99s to reveal the essence of the earth; with this music, it\xe2\x80\x99s to experience something more celestial. The first side of the album features the seventeen-minute title track, wherein Pio explores the sonorities to be had in two church organs, a hum originating from the soft palette of vocalist Martin Kleist, and Pio\xe2\x80\x99s own violin. A burst of organ opens \xe2\x80\x9cMotore Immobile\xe2\x80\x9d as if the start of a Sunday service, though it soon seems as if the keys are stuck, holding the note well past the breaking point. Ever so carefully, the keys of that chord peel off and the hum of a voice in harmony can be heard alongside that drone. A minute in, Pio\xe2\x80\x99s violin ever so gently sneaks in alongside the two organs.' b'It is then that the piece appears to reach a standstill. There\xe2\x80\x99s not much in the way of an \xe2\x80\x9cevent,\xe2\x80\x9d but that\xe2\x80\x99s beside the point. The held keys of the organs resemble the op-art of Bridget Riley, the drones producing an aural moir\xc3\xa9. Pio\xe2\x80\x99s patience is remarkable throughout, letting the horsehair of his bow move exquisitely slow across the strings, ever so subtly keying a shift in the drones. And so subtle and subliminal are the exhalations of Kleist that if you listen on headphones, you might wonder if you\xe2\x80\x99re actually humming along with these held tones. When the organs again revert back to their opening chord, it gives the impression that \xe2\x80\x9cMotore Immobile\xe2\x80\x9d could just as easily continue on into infinity.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnanta\xe2\x80\x9d which comprises the second side, again uses a similar approach to suspended tones, this time with just piano and organ. With just the sparest of ingredients, Pio makes something delectable. A glissade of piano notes opens the piece before again settling into the sustained drone of the organ. The piano then carefully moves one note at a time against that continuum, to the point of where the piece seems to reach a stasis, only to have the piano break that stillness with a flurry of notes. And with every new cascade, the organ\xe2\x80\x99s drone shifts its center ever so slightly. But again, the piece\xe2\x80\x99s greatest attribute is that it again gives the illusion of suspending the passage of time.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to put a finger one just what distinguishes Italian minimalism from its American counterparts, but to my ears, it ultimately boils down to lineage. While Americans trace back to the rugged and mischievous works of La Monte Young and Tony Conrad, the Italians go back to the compositions of Giacinto Scelsi, whose microtonal sound edges toward the mystic. As a result, Italian minimalism tends to be more crystalline and ascetic (read: pure) than what can be found elsewhere. It\xe2\x80\x99s telling that Pio grounds both of these extended compositions not in his violin work, but in the tones of the church organ. It\xe2\x80\x99s a sound that still resonates during services throughout the duomos of Italy, and one on Pio\xe2\x80\x99s Motore Immobile\xc2\xa0that too evokes a sense of the divine.'

column7: b"Martin Courtney's songwriting adjusts to a revamped band lineup, while together they continue to perfect the singular, warm, and reliable Real Estate sound."
column8: b'When Real Estate named their last album Atlas, it was likely done both in earnest and irony. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a subtle landscape where I come from,\xe2\x80\x9d sang Martin Courtney, as he traced the anxieties contained within the sidewalks, horizons, clocks, and shadows of his suburban hometown. The New Jersey band captured the way that a few square miles can feel like the whole world, but also intensify feelings of isolation. Their softly woven guitars had never sounded more wistful, the perfect accompaniment to Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s ruminations of the divide between post-adolescent uncertainty and watching his life codify into an adulthood that millennials like him were never meant to achieve. He was so overawed by the sight of his wife next to him, and fearful of time slipping away, that you half-worried about how his temperate constitution would handle any truly earth-shattering change.' b'As it happened, Real Estate experienced something like that when founding guitarist Matt Mondanile left to pursue his Ducktails project. The split was seemingly acrimonious, though the details seemed less relevant than the matter of what it would do to their sound. Mondanile\xe2\x80\x99s spacey style gave Real Estate\xe2\x80\x99s compact universe a layer of fantasy\xc2\xa0and teased out the sweetness in Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s flat tones. They replaced him with Julian Lynch, re-enlisted\xc2\xa0Matt Kallman on keys, and went off to L.A. to record. For a reliable band like Real Estate, these are dramatic transformations. But In Mind, the outcome of this revamp, picks up pretty much where they left off, Lynch\xe2\x80\x99s guitar and Alex Bleeker\xe2\x80\x99s bass swishing like windshield wipers around Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s suburban koans.' b'Throughout In Mind, Courtney explores his sensitive relationship to his surroundings. \xe2\x80\x9cThe laughing brook that ran right through this town/Slowed to a smile when the mercury went down,\xe2\x80\x9d he coos on \xe2\x80\x9cStained Glass.\xe2\x80\x9d Plotting the progress from Atlas to the familiar and comforting In Mind is a similarly nuanced process. In the past, Real Estate\xe2\x80\x99s sound hung like a sweet, gormless open mouth, but Lynch\xe2\x80\x99s tougher guitar tone is a little more hard-bitten and yowling. He and Kallman team up on the intro to \xe2\x80\x9cStained Glass,\xe2\x80\x9d knitting a baroque cascade that owes some to the Byrds\xe2\x80\x99 energized arpeggiations. \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Arrows\xe2\x80\x9d starts as a drowsy plod, the effects on Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s voice mimicking the slippery space between sleep and consciousness, but then sidles into a respectful jam, one guitar pinging high, the other disintegrating with each careening phrase. Just as fuzz and hysteria threaten\xc2\xa0to overtake the whole thing, it ends abruptly in a rare moment of humor (and a neat Beatles tribute).' b'If you like Real Estate best when they\xe2\x80\x99re trading in smaller gestures, these moves may seem treacherous, but by and large they crackle with electricity. The frame is fuller here, harking back to the mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s production of bands like Teenage Fanclub, Jellyfish, and on the dreamy bossa nova fizz of \xe2\x80\x9cTime,\xe2\x80\x9d the High Llamas. This newfound density gives In Mind\xc2\xa0a claustrophobic atmosphere that mirrors Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s myopic state of mind. Since Atlas, he\xe2\x80\x99s become a father of two, working from home in Beacon, NY. Any self-employed person will recognize his queasy familiarity with his surroundings: the subtle changes that occur as dusk sets in, the comings and goings of local wildlife, the disorientating similarity of different sounds. \xe2\x80\x9cWas it the rain/Or a southbound train/That woke me up last night?\xe2\x80\x9d he wonders amid the starry swoop of the\xc2\xa0unfortunately titled \xe2\x80\x9cHolding Pattern.\xe2\x80\x9d At once reassuring and stifling, these details give a better sense of Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety than his more literal lyrics on the subject.' b'Of course, one person\xe2\x80\x99s quiet profundity is another\xe2\x80\x99s cruise control. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat this is/Is not real life/At least it isn\xe2\x80\x99t boring,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHolding Pattern.\xe2\x80\x9d For Courtney, his well of lyrics about wistful cul-de-sac malaise never seems to dry up, though the subject starts to grow tired across the record. Likewise, when they wander from the beaten path they end up with \xe2\x80\x9cDiamond Eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d an Alex Bleeker song and\xc2\xa0In Mind\xe2\x80\x99s only total misfire. In the vein of a Pete Seeger fable, or the Grateful Dead writing Sunday school jams, it\xe2\x80\x99s so far outside their suburban comfort zone that it sounds like they\xe2\x80\x99ve been brainwashed by a benevolent cult. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a time to be humble/It\xe2\x80\x99s a time to be free/It\xe2\x80\x99s a time to raise our voices loud and not go quietly,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Bleeker\xc2\xa0sings, like Mr. Rosso on \xe2\x80\x9cFreaks and Geeks\xe2\x80\x9d trying to inspire his burnout students to protest peacefully.' b"In stark contrast, Real Estate's limitations become their greatest strengths. \xe2\x80\x9cServe the Song\xe2\x80\x9d is a warped, wandering introvert\xe2\x80\x99s lament. \xe2\x80\x9cThe chorus only interrupts/I sing to serve the song,\xe2\x80\x9d Courtney sings, in a sort of peaceful Quaker hymnal and insight into the band\xe2\x80\x99s MO. His touching, quiet shock at the disparity between his past and present hasn\xe2\x80\x99t dimmed, as the family man looks back at the slacker and feels an imperceptible connection. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot recall/Where I was at all/But I know what I heard/When I wrote those words/Green river still runs/Under that same sun/I never saw the source/But I know the course,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on \xe2\x80\x9cSame Sun,\xe2\x80\x9d as impish, quizzical guitar chimes play up his bemusement." b'Real Estate seemingly have no greater ambition than to perfect this one thing they do so well. While they live firmly in the middle of the road, they\xe2\x80\x99re also dramatic outliers: neither explicit nor artful, two modes innovated by indie-rock when it had started to seem less relevant than ever. Unlike the effortless Atlas, In Mind exposes a trace of tension between form and content. For all Courtney\xe2\x80\x99s synchronicity with his home environment, he sometimes sounds like he\xe2\x80\x99s spinning his wheels rather than exploring the new contours of the recalibrated band.' b'' b'Correction: An earlier version of this review attributed the song \xe2\x80\x9cDiamond Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d to Martin Courtney.'

column7: b'Like her former band Stereolab,\xc2\xa0Laetitia Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s new\xc2\xa0solo album draws on sounds ranging from French y\xc3\xa9-y\xc3\xa9 to krautrock, though its tone is earthier. It features a duet with Hot Chip\xe2\x80\x99s Alexis Taylor.'
column8: b'In an interview\xc2\xa0surrounding her 2014 album Something Shines, former Stereolab singer Laetitia Sadier laughingly said\xc2\xa0that, since the days of her old group, she\xe2\x80\x99s been \xe2\x80\x9ccultivating the same piece of land, [but] maybe I grow different vegetables.\xe2\x80\x9d The pithy comment stands as a fairly perfect summation of the 48-year-old\xe2\x80\x99s career. Since arriving on the European indie scene back in 1991 with the first Stereolab EP,\xc2\xa0Super 45, Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s vocal and lyrical approach has remained consistent: She\xc2\xa0applies her crystalline alto to lyrics that explore philosophy and political inequality through a Marxist lens. In Stereolab and as a solo artist, Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s musical tastes have tended\xc2\xa0to skew nostalgic, mixing influences of 1960s pop from the U.S. and Brazil, easy listening, and German kosmische.' b'Find Me Finding You, the first album she\xe2\x80\x99s released as Laetitia Sadier Source Ensemble, also relies on these familiar musical elements. French drummer Emmanuel Mario and Brazilian bassist Xavi Munoz, both of whom played on Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s previous solo albums, are present throughout, as is David Thayer, the filmmaker and musician who co-ran the group Little Tornados with Sadier. Opener\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cUndying Love for Humanity\xe2\x80\x9d burbles with intertwining guitar lines, stuttering keyboard signatures, and bouncing vocal harmonies\xe2\x80\x94it recalls French y\xc3\xa9-y\xc3\xa9 45s and the knotty exotica of the Free Design. The rest of the album is dotted lightly with krautrock droning, Latin percussion, and chiming twee.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cUndying Love\xe2\x80\x9d is ultimately an outlier, though, playing with\xc2\xa0those elements that Sadier is\xc2\xa0most associated with before the album moves towards\xc2\xa0earthy tones and a temperate atmosphere.\xc2\xa0Find Me\xc2\xa0maintains a consistent mood better than any other album Sadier has released on her own or with the now-defunct side-project Monade.\xc2\xa0There are minor pulse-quickening moments, like the psych pop interludes within \xe2\x80\x9cPsychology Active (Finding You),\xe2\x80\x9d but everything else sticks to a calm mid-tempo like a resting heart-rate.' b'Still, there\xe2\x80\x99s a wealth of variation to enjoy here.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe Woman With the Invisible Necklace\xe2\x80\x9d somehow connects flamenco rhythms with a post-punk swing\xc2\xa0akin to the Marine Girls. Closer \xe2\x80\x9cSacred Project\xe2\x80\x9d shows off the keyboard collection of Ensemble member Phil F MU, with the rumble of Taurus 3 bass pedals warmly humming below a tinny modular melody and assorted synth squeaks.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cReflectors\xe2\x80\x9d builds confidently around a pulsing marimba and a rich bass tone before temporarily falling hushed, as\xc2\xa0guitar and flute waft around Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s commentary. \xe2\x80\x9cWars cannot overcome our troubles,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, \xe2\x80\x9cStatus, prestige, prominence, don\xe2\x80\x99t mean a thing at this time.\xe2\x80\x9d Though\xc2\xa0Find Me\xc2\xa0was written\xc2\xa0before the Brexit vote and the U.S.\xc2\xa0political disaster, Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0sharp eye for the slowly rolling tides of geopolitics gives these songs\xc2\xa0added resonance.' b'Sadier\xe2\x80\x99s lyrical\xc2\xa0pattern continues on Find Me, as her lines\xc2\xa0revolve around\xc2\xa0tyrants, indoctrination, and states of conflict. This is what makes \xe2\x80\x9cLove Captive\xe2\x80\x9d stand out. A\xc2\xa0duet with Hot Chip\xe2\x80\x99s Alexis Taylor, it\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0a ballad for slow dances, but it finds both\xc2\xa0singers shunning the idea of romantic love, wondering why we \xe2\x80\x9cmake promises of eternity/When really a heart needs to run open and free.\xe2\x80\x9d Instead, they advocate for a broader definition: \xe2\x80\x9cWe are made to love/Not to fall in love.\xe2\x80\x9d The song comes early in the album, but it\xc2\xa0provides a small lyrical breather that feels necessary to the whole.\xc2\xa0In the past, Stereolab\xe2\x80\x99s 2001 Sound-Dust\xc2\xa0tracks\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to Do With Me\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLes Bons Bons Des Raisons\xe2\x80\x9d functioned similarly. Amid\xc2\xa0Find Me\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0otherwise downcast worldview, \xe2\x80\x9cLove Captive\xe2\x80\x9d lets in some light.'

column7: b'The jazz guitarist is more than able to lead both his band and the listener into far-off rhythmic and harmonic places, and crucially finds a way to bring everyone back, too.'
column8: b'As a member of jazz saxophonist Steve Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s bands, guitarist Miles Okazaki has learned a few lessons about teasing. Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s music often skates near the R&B mood, while moving restlessly between frequent changes in rhythm and harmony. At its best, tunes by the MacArthur \xe2\x80\x9cGenius Grant\xe2\x80\x9d winner cycle through the compositional variety with such equanimity, you hardly realize that his ensemble has avoided giving up the straight-ahead funk. On Trickster, Okazaki\xe2\x80\x99s own music proves nearly as ingenious in its play with morphing grooves.' b'Opening track \xe2\x80\x9cKudzu\xe2\x80\x9d begins with a fast flourish: a long, knotty line, played with a clean tone by the guitarist. Then, over the rhythm section\xe2\x80\x99s unusual vamp, Okazaki restates some of this opening music, lingering over the material. Pianist Craig Taborn is in the mix, too, offering some mercurial chords. On a first pass, you might wonder: Where are we, exactly? Is this the main theme? The beginning of a strangely chill avant-garde solo? Before you have time to wallow in the uncertainty, Taborn and Okazaki join forces\xc2\xa0and display the song\xe2\x80\x99s real hook.' b"During performances like these, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that this bandleader is interested in the unstable realm of rhythm and melody, the place where it's easy to get lost. Though he won\xe2\x80\x99t leave you lost for long. On the slowly developing \xe2\x80\x9cThe Calendar,\xe2\x80\x9d Okazaki begins in a contemplative mood. By the end of the track, he solos with fevered inspiration, as if all of time is running out. Like Okazaki, drummer Sean Rickman and bassist Anthony Tidd are also graduates of the Coleman school, which means they make these darting, surprising structures sound fully natural." b'Over the hurtling rhythm of \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Bolt,\xe2\x80\x9d one melodic cell travels through different octaves. You know it can\xe2\x80\x99t go on like that forever. This initial lack of a clear destination point creates a suspense that is resolved when the pianist and guitarist begin racing to complete the other\xe2\x80\x99s lines. After a stretch of roaming around in an attractive darkness, you get one clear payoff after another. During the brisk \xe2\x80\x9cCaduceus,\xe2\x80\x9d the interplay between Tidd, Taborn, and Okazaki results in glorious braids of melody. The execution is obviously complex, the work of virtuosi. But the resulting beauty is easy to appreciate.' b'Some performances on Trickster don\xe2\x80\x99t quite manage to replicate that feat. A few of the obsessive phrases on the album stop just short of turning into memorable compositions (as with \xe2\x80\x9cBox in a Box\xe2\x80\x9d). Fortunately, some of the songs that sound the least like puzzles reveal that Okazaki can craft simpler themes that are just as stirring. \xe2\x80\x9cMischief\xe2\x80\x9d is anchored by a strutting beat, one that fans of the Meters should appreciate. The relative stability of the song\xe2\x80\x99s pulse allows Taborn the freedom to uncork one of his lengthy, exciting solos. And the miniature \xe2\x80\x9cBorderland\xe2\x80\x9d offers the album a lyrical coda. While Okazaki can be plenty entertaining as a master of misdirection, he also has a gift for direct communication.'

column7: b'The eclectic new album from French\xc2\xa0DJ and producer Joakim is unified only in\xc2\xa0its consistent oddity. He avoids conventional song structures, drawing\xc2\xa0inspiration from\xc2\xa0new age, funk, and krautrock.'
column8: b'For much of his career, the French producer/DJ Joakim has primed his audience for jarring stylistic switches.\xc2\xa0Scan his wide-ranging credit list:\xc2\xa0This is a man who has helped\xc2\xa0mix Cassius\xe2\x80\x99 dance music as well as\xc2\xa0a\xc2\xa0tribute to atmospheric soundtrack master John Carpenter, who has reworked both Tiga\xe2\x80\x99s lurid house and J.J. Cale\xe2\x80\x99s adult contemporary. He\xe2\x80\x99s covered\xc2\xa0William Onyeabor\xc2\xa0in addition to\xc2\xa0Neil Young. But despite Joakim\xe2\x80\x99s mutability, the 40-year-old has always returned to a home base in the neighborhood of disco and rock on his recordings, grounding his capricious tendencies with a groove or a backbeat.' b'However, Joakim\xe2\x80\x99s latest trick is to mostly abandon any expectation\xc2\xa0of straightforward dance-rock on Samurai. Some precedent for this could\xc2\xa0be cobbled together from his past albums\xe2\x80\x99 subtler moments, which were occasionally\xc2\xa0overshadowed by overtly adrenaline-boosting tracks. These include the gurgling synth ramp-up \xe2\x80\x9cChapter 1,\xe2\x80\x9d which kicked off 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Tropics of Love, and especially \xe2\x80\x9cPeter Pan Over the Bronx,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cPalo Alto,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTanabata,\xe2\x80\x9d three songs that defined the whimsical side\xc2\xa0of 2007\xe2\x80\x99s Monsters & Silly Songs. Other clues about *Samurai\xe2\x80\x99*s origins were provided by Joakim himself, who put together a Soundcloud mixtape of his influences, which he said \xe2\x80\x9crange from new age to yacht rock, from \xe2\x80\x9980s synth-based funk to Japanese electronic avant-garde, from krautrock to futuristic dystopian electronic music.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Accordingly,\xc2\xa0the producer frequently avoids conventional song structures on Samurai. So\xc2\xa0don\xe2\x80\x99t show up looking\xc2\xa0for\xc2\xa0the reassuring waves of most house or techno, or the comfort of verse-chorus-verse pop. There\xe2\x80\x99s not much singing on the album, and the\xc2\xa0vocals are often hard to make out. This music is placid, uninterested in using speed as an easy gimmick to get\xc2\xa0your attention.\xc2\xa0Instead, dodges and destabilizations are common.' b'In \xe2\x80\x9cMind Bent,\xe2\x80\x9d the synths level up slowly\xe2\x80\x94imagine stretching and pulling Kool and the Gang\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSummer Madness\xe2\x80\x9d to the consistency of taffy\xe2\x80\x94and a long tail of drums clatters and knocks about. This builds suspense, but Joakim never delivers a payoff. \xe2\x80\x9cCannibale Pastorale\xe2\x80\x9d is filled with blipping, chirping noises, like a pack of gossiping dolphins or chattering R2-D2s. These begin to acquire a beauty of their own after a while, but then Joakim interjects a crass barrage of drums, souring the song\xe2\x80\x99s peaceful qualities.' b'Though Samurai can sometimes feel like an art-school exercise in unpredictability, the majority of the music is easy on the ears. And it never stays in one place for long, so anything grating soon passes you by. There are\xc2\xa0rivulets of watery saxophone, and a handful of cheerful, bass-popping funk riffs that could have introduced segments on a local news channel in the \xe2\x80\x9980s. There are claps of distant thunder, bird sounds, and genial, wildly unthreatening metallic noises that suggest wind chimes and dinner gongs. Freed from the desire to make people move, Joakim put together a record that\xe2\x80\x99s unified in its oddity.'

column7: b'Nineteen years after their last album,\xc2\xa0the Jesus and Mary Chain pick up where they left off, offering\xc2\xa0their usual mix of feedback-spiked rockers and stoned\xc2\xa0ballads.'
column8: b'Whether they\xe2\x80\x99re playing 15-minute gigs or taking 19 years between albums, the Jesus and Mary Chain have always put a lot of care into the appearance of not giving a fuck. Ever since they first erected their wall of squall on 1985\xe2\x80\x99s Psychocandy, brothers Jim and William Reid have remained permanent residents of a world where sunglasses never come off, cigarette smoke doubles as dry ice, and the only illumination is provided by strobe light. None of the albums they\xe2\x80\x99ve released since has sounded quite the same, but they all invariably feel the same. As the Mary Chain\xe2\x80\x99s first full-length since the late \xe2\x80\x9990s proves, it will take more than a nearly two-decade recording hiatus to diminish the band\xe2\x80\x99s intrinsic ultraviolet vibe.' b'Despite the epic lag between releases, Damage and Joy feels very much like a logical extension of its predecessor,\xc2\xa01998\xe2\x80\x99s seeming swan song\xc2\xa0Munki,\xc2\xa0because the Reids had been unwittingly leaving a breadcrumb trail between the two records this whole time. Half of its 14 tracks are re-recordings of songs that were previously released in some form\xe2\x80\x94as Jim Reid solo releases or as part of their sister Linda\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Sister Vanilla venture. In the case, of \xe2\x80\x9cAll Things Pass,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s a revved-up revamp of the lone song the Mary Chain have officially released since the Reids buried the hatchet back in 2007 (because, presumably, leaving it for dead on the \xe2\x80\x9cHeroes\xe2\x80\x9d soundtrack seemed too ignoble a fate). Jim recently told Pitchfork\xc2\xa0that\xc2\xa0all those castaway tracks \xe2\x80\x9creally should have been Mary Chain songs,\xe2\x80\x9d if only the brothers\xe2\x80\x99 notoriously combative relationship hadn\xe2\x80\x99t deep-sixed the band after\xc2\xa0Munki.' b'By that time, the Reids had eagerly accepted their destiny as cranky old men. Where Psychocandy used harsh noise to conceal tender feelings, Munki\xe2\x80\x99s streamlined motorik\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll laid the middle-aged Mary Chain\xe2\x80\x99s hilariously hateful lyrics bare. (It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to pick a favorite from \xe2\x80\x9cCommercial\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cMcDonald\xe2\x80\x99s is shit!\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cChildren are fools!\xe2\x80\x9d) They were always an insolent band, but Munki marked the first time the Reids seemed to be having fun with being assholes. And on Damage and Joy, that regression continues apace, with the Reids acting like 50-going-on-15, giddily riffing on drugs, guns, erections, girls with curls, and \xe2\x80\x9cfly\xe2\x80\x9d/\xe2\x80\x9chigh\xe2\x80\x9d rhymes you can spot from miles away.' b'Beyond the blatant\xc2\xa0nods to the group\xe2\x80\x99s past (\xe2\x80\x9cSong for a Secret\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94one of two duets with Isobel Campbell\xe2\x80\x94manages to sound like \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes Always\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cJust Like Honey\xe2\x80\x9d simultaneously), some of the brothers\xe2\x80\x99 lyrics sound here like they were actually salvaged from an early \xe2\x80\x9990s scrapbook. The puerile\xc2\xa0robo-blues romp \xe2\x80\x9cGet on Home\xe2\x80\x9d finds Jim spending a night with a \xe2\x80\x9cblow-up girl,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csome LSD,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe MTV\xe2\x80\x9d; William\xe2\x80\x99s ridiculous\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSimian Split\xe2\x80\x9d rehashes\xc2\xa0a hoary old\xc2\xa0Kurt Cobain murder conspiracy as if the song was written after watching the El Duce interview in Nick Broomfield\xe2\x80\x99s Kurt and Courtney. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFacing Up To the Facts,\xe2\x80\x9d on which Jim unleashes a corker that could\xe2\x80\x99ve easily materialized at any point in the Mary Chain\xe2\x80\x99s history: \xe2\x80\x9cI hate my brother and he hates me/That\xe2\x80\x99s the way it\xe2\x80\x99s supposed to be.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s easy for the Reids to milk that line for laughs, because Damage and Joy sounds bereft of any conflict or tension. The brothers made the record with producer/bassist Youth (with support from touring drummer Brian Young and Lush bassist Phil King), and it feels more like an intimate recording project than a live band document, mostly splitting the difference between routine electro-Stones rave-ups and strung-out ballads. The Reids score most consistently in the latter category, likely because it forces them to keep their adolescent id in check and deal with more adult emotions. The illicit-affair account \xe2\x80\x9cBlack and Blues\xe2\x80\x9d is gilded gospel Americana dressed up in Velvet-y \xe2\x80\x9cba ba bas\xe2\x80\x9d and a winsome guest vocal from Sky Ferreira, who\xe2\x80\x99s thus far batting 1.000 in duets with Scottish rock institutions. And the Spacemen 3-style stoner jangle of \xe2\x80\x9cWar on Peace\xe2\x80\x9d grapples with every aging rebel\xe2\x80\x99s existential crisis\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat if I run?/Where would I run to?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94before issuing a proverbial \xe2\x80\x9cfuck it\xe2\x80\x9d and stomping on the pedal for an adrenalized, fuzz-powered finale.' b'But the biggest eye opener is album centerpiece \xe2\x80\x9cLos Feliz (Blues and Greens).\xe2\x80\x9d This luminous, orchestral acoustic lullaby plays like a misanthropic answer to Tom Petty\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFree Fallin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d its idyllic California scenery\xe2\x80\x94topped with a chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless America!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94undercut by a deep-seated despair (\xe2\x80\x9cIn the land of the free/Wishing they were dead\xe2\x80\x9d). Where they were once defined by a collision of face-melting feedback and soothing melody, the modern-day Mary Chain are governed by a different set of extremes: the pent-up desire to act like goofy, hormonal teenagers and the sobering knowledge those days are long gone. But as the brothers recruit their sister/mediator Linda for a closing reboot of Sister Vanilla\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Stop the Rock,\xe2\x80\x9d the song\xe2\x80\x99s cheery rallying cry\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m falling, and I\xe2\x80\x99m happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94carries the reassurance that now, more than ever, the Jesus and Mary Chain are united in holy acrimony.'

column7: b'Originally released in 1988 on SST, Soundgarden\xe2\x80\x99s full-length debut returns in expanded and remixed form on Sub Pop.'
column8: b'Soundgarden\xe2\x80\x99s ascent from Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s punk scene to rock\xe2\x80\x99s upper echelon wasn\xe2\x80\x99t preordained, but it was probably inevitable. Their first full-length, 1988\xe2\x80\x99s Ultramega OK,\xc2\xa0expands upon the promise offered by their two Sub Pop EPs, the careening Screaming Life\xc2\xa0and the glitchy, funked-up Fopp. The band\xe2\x80\x99s assault is sharper and more focused, their musical ideas borrowing from blues (and blooze), punk, tape-manipulation experiments, and dredged-in-mud riffing. It originally came out on the even-then-it-was-legendary punk label SST, although its 2017 reissue on Sub Pop puts a neat little bow on the band\xe2\x80\x99s long career. Soundgarden\xe2\x80\x99s path led them to arena tours and classic-rock-radio canonization, and Sub Pop has grown from a fanzine into a powerhouse, persisting and thriving through multiple independent-rock gold rushes. Both entities are keenly aware of their legacies\xe2\x80\x94and the fact that they\xe2\x80\x99re worthy of exploration.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cFlower,\xe2\x80\x9d a swirling tale of a woman whose hard-partying lifestyle leads her to an early grave, opens Ultramega OK. Years after more straightforward Soundgarden tracks like the glittering \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Hole Sun\xe2\x80\x9d and the hiccuping \xe2\x80\x9cPretty Noose\xe2\x80\x9d became rock-radio staples, it\xe2\x80\x99s still one of the band\xe2\x80\x99s best pop offerings, anchored by a chug that blossoms out of gauzy reverb, given depth by sonics that recall a muddied-up copy of Physical Graffiti (guitarist Kim Thayil has said that the humming feedback came from him placing his guitar on the floor near his amp, then blowing on its strings). The arrangement is animated by Chris Cornell\xe2\x80\x99s gritted-teeth vocal performance, which only comes into full-voiced yawp briefly. Its appeal to both sides of MTV\xe2\x80\x99s late-\xe2\x80\x9980s late-night rock aisle\xe2\x80\x94Headbangers Ball and 120 Minutes\xe2\x80\x94presaged the eventual cultural dominance of \xe2\x80\x9cthe Seattle sound\xe2\x80\x9d and the alt-rock gold rush that followed.' b'Ultramega OK\xe2\x80\x99s most instructive lesson, though, is how that craved-for aesthetic stemmed from an ever-shifting ideal. The twisted thrash of \xe2\x80\x9cCircle of Power,\xe2\x80\x9d led by a gasping vocal from bassist Hiro Yamamoto, gets extra tense because of its momentary pauses for breath; the creeping-death march of \xe2\x80\x9cBeyond the Wheel\xe2\x80\x9d is sandwiched between the tape-warp interludes \xe2\x80\x9c665\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c667\xe2\x80\x9d and a masterful vocal by Cornell to give it extra eeriness at the height of PMRC-stoked mania about \xe2\x80\x9coccult music\xe2\x80\x9d; the sludgy cover of the blues chestnut \xe2\x80\x9cSmokestack Lightning,\xe2\x80\x9d which pairs Cornell\xe2\x80\x99s wail with the band\xe2\x80\x99s 45-at\xe2\x80\x9333 grind, flips the idea of cocky \xe2\x80\x9980s rockers taking on the blues face-first into a moss-swarmed bog. (\xe2\x80\x9cWe learned the Howlin\xe2\x80\x99 Wolf version,\xe2\x80\x9d Cornell told Sounds. \xe2\x80\x9cWe didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it had been covered a lot.\xe2\x80\x9d Yamamoto deflated Cornell\xe2\x80\x99s insistence: \xe2\x80\x9cI did and I told you not to put it on the record. It\xe2\x80\x99s a bit crass\xe2\x80\x94a bit like getting B.B. King to sit up on stage with you.\xe2\x80\x9d) Humor was also key, as it was for so many of the band\xe2\x80\x99s compatriots; crediting the album-ending patch of tape hiss and amp-unplugging to \xe2\x80\x9cOne Minute of Silence\xe2\x80\x9d (an homage to his and Yoko Ono\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Minutes Silence\xe2\x80\x9d) is one of the album\xe2\x80\x99s more obvious jokes.' b'Skin Yard\xe2\x80\x99s Jack Endino, whose list of \xe2\x80\x9980s production credits could double as an early greatest-hits list for Sub Pop, remixed Ultramega OK for this reissue; Thayil\xe2\x80\x99s liner notes go into diplomatic depth about why the band was ultimately unhappy with the SST-released version of the album. Endino\xe2\x80\x99s tweaks don\xe2\x80\x99t render the album spit-shined, thank God, but they do accentuate certain instrumental details more clearly\xe2\x80\x94the clashing guitars on the loop-de-loop slacker portrait \xe2\x80\x9cHe Didn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d the snap of Matt Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s drums on the paranoiac \xe2\x80\x9cHead Injury.\xe2\x80\x9d (The most notable difference between the two versions is the absence of then-labelmates Sonic Youth\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDeath Valley \xe2\x80\x9969,\xe2\x80\x9d a sample of which served as a radio-static-swathed transition between the sludge of \xe2\x80\x9cSmokestack Lightning\xe2\x80\x9d and the anxiety of \xe2\x80\x9cNazi Driver.\xe2\x80\x9d)' b'Endino\xe2\x80\x99s liner notes delve into the details of crafting the new mix\xe2\x80\x94sourcing the effects unit that made \xe2\x80\x9c665\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c667\xe2\x80\x9d so immediate and freaky, fixing a missing snare hit on \xe2\x80\x9cFlower.\xe2\x80\x9d Endino also recorded the early-stage versions of a few Ultramega OK tracks that round out this reissue; they add to the story by showing how much more precise the band got in the year or so after they recorded the Screaming Life EP, with the two versions of the single-chord grind \xe2\x80\x9cIncessant Mace\xe2\x80\x9d showing how that song\xe2\x80\x99s brimming dread was the result of a fair amount of experimentation.' b'Revisiting Ultramega OK, it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious in retrospect that Soundgarden were going to clamber to an exalted position in rock. They managed to balance their mad-scientist tendencies with an innate savvy about how to craft a rock song\xe2\x80\x94even when they were six minutes long and based around one chord. The album captures the band on the eve of being swept into the major-label system, and it predicts how they would wring rock hits out of unexpected building blocks.'

column7: b'His voice deeper and his aim truer, Pavement\xe2\x80\x99s Scott Kannberg is at his most confident and mellow as he navigates middle age\xe2\x80\x99s ups and downs.'
column8: b'Former Pavement guitarist/vocalist\xc2\xa0Scott \xe2\x80\x9cSpiral Stairs\xe2\x80\x9d Kannberg\xe2\x80\x99s solo career has doubled as an ongoing battle for self-definition\xe2\x80\x94a quest to find space for himself in the firmament of American indie rock. Results have varied. There were guest spots on Kevin Drew and Broken Social Scene LPs. There was his label Amazing Grease\xc2\xa0Records, home to San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s late, great Oranger. Then there was the trio he helmed, Preston School of Industry. At its most memorable, Preston\xc2\xa0doubled down on the wilder-card songwriting role Kannberg played during Pavement\xe2\x80\x99s decade-long, indie-rock reign (the\xc2\xa0spazzy, elastic \xe2\x80\x9cThe Spaces in Between\xe2\x80\x9d) or probed fuzzed-out, country-fried drift (the downbeat \xe2\x80\x9cWhalebones\xe2\x80\x9d). Too often, though, the music floated by, not leaving behind much of an impression. With 2009\xe2\x80\x99s *The Real Feel**\xe2\x80\x94*his first LP as\xc2\xa0Spiral Stairs\xe2\x80\x94he gear-shifted, leaning convincingly and promisingly into folk, blues, and the Clean. Then, without warning, Kannberg effectively went\xc2\xa0silent.' b'Eight years later, *Doris and the Daggers *cracks the equation. His voice deeper and his aim truer, Kannberg is at his most confident and mellow here. Backed by members of the National, Broken Social Scene, Oranger, and singer/songwriter Kelley Stoltz, the album patiently navigates middle age\xe2\x80\x99s ups and downs, setting aside sprawl and fantasia aside to focus on succinctness and autobiography. The players lend a\xc2\xa0patient, casual\xc2\xa0calm to proceedings mid-tempo, sober,\xc2\xa0and pedal-steel soaked; these are indie-rock lite tunes\xc2\xa0playing a long game, in\xc2\xa0no\xc2\xa0rush to peak, freak, or wipe out.' b'With \xe2\x80\x9cThe Unconditional,\xe2\x80\x9d an ode to a growing daughter, Kannberg capitalizes on the song\xe2\x80\x99s elastic nest of guitars, horns, and organs, stretching and savoring each verse. You can feel him fully inhabit this song in a way he never has before;\xc2\xa0when he confides that the \xe2\x80\x9clittle\xc2\xa0girl\xe2\x80\x99s getting older/she\xe2\x80\x99s not telling me what to\xc2\xa0do,\xe2\x80\x9d the prevailing emotion is a rueful sense of wonder.\xc2\xa0Needled with riffs and horn squibs, \xe2\x80\x9cDance (Cry Wolf)\xe2\x80\x9d locates its swing and bounce in lonesomeness. \xe2\x80\x9cAWM\xe2\x80\x9d might be the most chipper, hummable divorce song this decade; its violins and pianos smartly deployed, its vocal outro more reflective than bitter. Less affecting\xc2\xa0is the goofy golf-trip remembrance \xe2\x80\x9cDundee Man\xe2\x80\x9d featuring a synthesizer line part of a wan, jangling whole. Though the album\xe2\x80\x99s stakes may not be very high at all, it\xe2\x80\x99s nice to hear Kannberg\xe2\x80\x99s increasing\xc2\xa0facility for\xc2\xa0arrangements.' b'This isn\xe2\x80\x99t a record you crank in traffic en route to an across-town meeting; it\xe2\x80\x99s a record to unwind with later that night on your second glass of Syrah\xe2\x80\x94a sturdy shrug to cap off the day. Throughout Doris, a very tricky balancing act is at work: the maintenance of a rangey, ragged looseness, without any sense of over-rehearsal. That Kannberg and company are able to sustain this standard throughout\xe2\x80\x94even for synth-funk wonder \xe2\x80\x9cNo Comparison\xe2\x80\x9d and the chanted, semi-punk head rush of \xe2\x80\x9cDoris and the Daggers\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94is a small triumph.'

column7: b'Floridian death metal veterans Obituary remain a beacon of consistency. This self-titled record is their most energetic effort since reforming in 2003, and it proves their vitality.'
column8: b'Of the bands that define Florida death metal, which also\xc2\xa0strongly defines\xc2\xa0American Death Metal as a whole, Obituary remain\xc2\xa0a beacon of consistency. Beginning in 1984 under the Executioner moniker, Obituary built their sound around stripping the Gothic cobwebs off Celtic Frost\xe2\x80\x99s mid-paced riffing. They let the guitars become a\xc2\xa0humid swamp, thick and airy. Singer John Tardy defined death metal vocals by getting as guttural as guitarist Trevor Peres\xe2\x80\x99 rhythms, removing any last vestiges of thrashy snarling. Obituary have been held as models for keeping it simple, and\xc2\xa0for fans, the idea\xc2\xa0of\xc2\xa0a new album from them\xc2\xa0can seem predictable. But their\xc2\xa0self-titled 10th record proves Obituary\xc2\xa0don\xe2\x80\x99t\xc2\xa0suffer for sticking\xc2\xa0to their identity.' b'Peres and drummer Donald Tardy remain at the heart of Obituary and feed off each other in a way few death metal bands do. Peres sounds more mangled when Donald speeds up, and already thick riffs feel impenetrable as\xc2\xa0his drumming slows. As such, Peres\xe2\x80\x99 low, groveling guitar tone is more flexible than it seems. Obituary\xc2\xa0begins with two faster numbers, \xe2\x80\x9cBrave\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSentence Day\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94affirmations that they\xe2\x80\x99re not giving up anytime soon. Both are busy for a band who prefers to let a groovy riff sink in, and John in particular lunges\xc2\xa0with a youthfulness that rivals the band\xe2\x80\x99s heyday in the late \xe2\x80\x9980s and early \xe2\x80\x9990s.' b'Some of Obituary\xe2\x80\x99s best work has come\xc2\xa0from letting flashiness creep in. In 1990, for example,\xc2\xa0Cause of Death\xc2\xa0had its sludge punctured by James Murphy\xe2\x80\x99s divebombs and neoclassically-influenced soloing. That album contained\xc2\xa0their most developed songwriting in terms of leads. Likewise,\xc2\xa0thanks to Ken Andrews\xe2\x80\x99 lead work here,\xc2\xa0Obituary\xc2\xa0is their most energetic record since reforming in 2003 (they originally disbanded in \xe2\x80\x9997). On\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cshredder\xe2\x80\x9d records, the disconnect between the fireworks of the guitarist and the tepid rhythm section can be jarring. But Peres and Donald\xe2\x80\x99s strong foundation keeps that from happening.' b'Andrews can also bow to death metal tradition, as he does with the spaced-out, Death-like leads in \xe2\x80\x9cKneel Before Me.\xe2\x80\x9d Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cSentence\xe2\x80\x9d ends with a one-man guitar battle, as Andrews heralds\xc2\xa0not just the dueling harmonies of Judas Priest\xe2\x80\x99s Glenn Tipton and K.K. Downing but also Slayer\xe2\x80\x99s chaotic interplay between Jeff Hanneman and Kerry King. He\xe2\x80\x99s not just versatile; he sounds like he\xe2\x80\x99s genuinely excited. And that exuberance doesn\xe2\x80\x99t arise from nowhere\xe2\x80\x94Donald and Andrews were once members of Andrew W.K.\xe2\x80\x99s backing band.' b'This record honors all of Obituary\xe2\x80\x99s history by not compromising. Its reliability is peppered with\xc2\xa0unrest. Obituary\xc2\xa0ends the opposite of how it began\xe2\x80\x94slow and yet somehow impatient. \xe2\x80\x9cStraight to Hell\xe2\x80\x9d recalls the dim flickering-light riffs of 1992\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe End Complete,\xe2\x80\x9d resulting in a seediness that\xe2\x80\x99s constantly promised in death metal and rarely achieved. \xe2\x80\x9cTurned Into Stone\xe2\x80\x9d centers\xc2\xa0their Celtic Frost worship, a more gradual unsettling than some of the record\xe2\x80\x99s faster pillages. With these contrasts, Obituary show they\xe2\x80\x99re keenly aware of dynamics in a way most bands could stand to afford. In 2017, the challenge for a veteran metal act is to not relentlessly innovate, but to mine any small new parts of their sound. Kreator and Immolation have proved successful in this regard already, and Obituary, while sticking closer to their roots, have also proven their vitality here.'

column7: b"On their first album in four\xc2\xa0years, the married electro duo curate a highly collaborative record that is richer and stranger than anything they've done before. It's\xc2\xa0unusually electrifying."
column8: b'ADULT.\xe2\x80\x99s Nicola Kuperus and Adam Lee Miller have always had a hermetic aesthetic. Their synthesizers sound like museum pieces; their post-punk production reeks like a leaky dungeon. And their dry sense of humor keeps the listener perpetually off balance, the same way that their creepy cover art steadfastly refuses to meet the viewer\xe2\x80\x99s gaze. You never see a pair of eyes on the duo\xe2\x80\x99s record sleeves\xe2\x80\x94just covered faces, gloved hands, and ambiguously slumped poses, markers of contemporary alienation raised to the level of high art. If you were to describe their music in architectural terms, it would be part hall of mirrors, part Winchester Mystery House.' b'For Detroit House Guests, their first album in four\xc2\xa0years, the married duo\xe2\x80\x94both are visual artists and filmmakers as well as musicians\xe2\x80\x94went the opposite route: Assisted by a $40,000 Knight Foundation grant, they threw open the doors of their 4,000-square-foot compound in Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s New Center neighborhood, inviting a handpicked succession of artists to live and work with them. Some, like Nitzer Ebb\xe2\x80\x99s Douglas J. McCarthy, they had known for years. The Austrian Thereminist Dorit Chrysler, on the other hand, had only a passing acquaintance with the duo before her residency. It was an \xe2\x80\x9cintense\xe2\x80\x9d process, Kuperus has said: \xe2\x80\x9cBecause you\xe2\x80\x99re living together, you\xe2\x80\x99re having breakfast together, and when you\xe2\x80\x99re done with the studio you\xe2\x80\x99re watching Netflix together.\xe2\x80\x9d That kind of intimacy is palpable across the album. While there\xe2\x80\x99s no mistaking ADULT.\xe2\x80\x99s wiry signature, their collaborators\xe2\x80\x99 input is largely indistinguishable from their own, leading to a record that is richer and stranger than anything the duo has done before.' b'All of their usual hallmarks are here: spring-loaded drum programming, clammy reverb, brittle synths that clink like wind chimes in an ice storm. Classic electro remains a driving force, and on \xe2\x80\x9cStop (and Start Again),\xe2\x80\x9d featuring Light Asylum\xe2\x80\x99s Shannon Funchess bellowing over a flanged, high-necked bassline, they return to the hair-raising goth of 2005\xe2\x80\x99s Gimme Trouble. But a majority of the album\xe2\x80\x99s tracks find them foraging far beyond their usual stomping grounds. The opening \xe2\x80\x9cP rts M ss ng,\xe2\x80\x9d with Lichens\xe2\x80\x99 Robert Aiki Aubrey Lowe, is slow and methodical, its modular synthesizers twitching like metal shavings under a magnet. \xe2\x80\x9cBreathe On,\xe2\x80\x9d with Swans\xe2\x80\x99 Michael Gira, extends the meditative mood; Gira\xe2\x80\x99s basso purr verges on ASMR territory, and the same could be said of the woozy third track, \xe2\x80\x9cInto the Drum,\xe2\x80\x9d with its disorienting soup of whispers and vocal fry.' b'In fact, they don\xe2\x80\x99t unleash their usual body-moving assault until the fourth song, \xe2\x80\x9cWe Are a Mirror,\xe2\x80\x9d a chilly slab of death disco enlivened by Kuperus and McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s call-and-response vocals. Just like his hosts, McCarthy sounds like he\xe2\x80\x99s ventured far from his comfort zone. Neither of his songs bear obvious traces of Nitzer Ebb\xe2\x80\x99s abrasive legacy; instead, he seems determined to twist his formidable baritone into the most unexpected shapes. Ironically, it falls to Funchess to deliver the album\xe2\x80\x99s best Nitzer Ebb impersonation: Her \xe2\x80\x9cWe Chase the Sound\xe2\x80\x9d is a dead ringer for the EBM pioneers\xe2\x80\x99 scorched-earth funk.' b'Throughout, ADULT.\xe2\x80\x99s synthetic sound world is unusually electrifying. On \xe2\x80\x9cInexhaustible,\xe2\x80\x9d abetted by Chrysler\xe2\x80\x99s Theremin, they conjure a mercurial fusion of Morton Subotnick and early Depeche Mode. And on \xe2\x80\x9cUncomfortable Positions,\xe2\x80\x9d the conceptual textile artist Lun*na Menoh performs on a modified sewing machine whose darting needle wobbles like a quarter spinning down. Strangest of all is \xe2\x80\x9cThis Situation,\xe2\x80\x9d which sounds like an eight-minute tribute to the Beatles\xe2\x80\x99 notorious musique concr\xc3\xa8te experiment \xe2\x80\x9cRevolution 9.\xe2\x80\x9d Over rumbling abstractions, two snippets of Kuperus\xe2\x80\x99 voice loop in parallel. \xe2\x80\x9cForgive me if I change the usual order of the menu,\xe2\x80\x9d runs one; \xe2\x80\x9cThis situation can\xe2\x80\x99t go on indefinitely,\xe2\x80\x9d goes the other, more or less indefinitely.' b"The album\xe2\x80\x99s most fascinating aspect is the way it affords a glimpse behind the duo's masks. The closing \xe2\x80\x9cAs You Dream,\xe2\x80\x9d in which Michael Gira does his best Tibetan monk impersonation, is a damn-near liturgical take on drone techno\xe2\x80\x94not so much hermetic as immersive, a rising tide spilling out their front door and subsuming everything in its path. ADULT. still do a convincing showroom-dummies impersonation, but they\xe2\x80\x99ve never sounded more human than they do here."

column7: b'As Jamaica stood at a political crossroads in 1980, the Wailing Souls worked with famed engineer\xc2\xa0Scientist on a magical blend of unearthly dub and traditional\xc2\xa0songcraft.'
column8:
b'Jamaica had two realities then: a tropical paradise of sandy beaches, crystal blue seas, and feel-good music; the other, a nation overrun by violent drug posses, permanently scarred by a recent history of CIA intervention and subversion, and a deeper historical legacy of slavery and colonization. The question of which reality would prevail seemed to hang heavy in the air in 1980, as the Wailing Souls recorded their album Wailing\xe2\x80\x94an album shaped by its earthly means and sung to the angelic spheres.' b'At the turn of the new decade, the post-independence euphoria that had defined Jamaica in the 1960s and the strident self-determination that defined the \xe2\x80\x9970s gave way to a new era of\xc2\xa0garrison politics, an unprecedented level of political violence (over 800 people killed in Kingston in the months leading up to the October elections), and the bloody\xc2\xa0consequences of Jamaica\xe2\x80\x99s increasing role in the regional cocaine trade. The utopian vision of Rastafari\xe2\x80\x94the Afro-Jamaican religion that preached a return to nature and repatriation to the ancestral African homeland\xe2\x80\x94was being rapidly eclipsed by the hard local realities of the country\xe2\x80\x99s position as a regional pawn in the Cold War and the effects of global free trade policies.' b'The music scene could not help but be affected by these shifts. If the ascension of Bob Marley and the influence of Rastafari on roots reggae were dramatic developments of the 1970s, the next dramatic turning point occurred in 1984 when producers abandoned the recording of live bands altogether, in favor of the stripped-down, pre-programmed rhythms of cheap Casio keyboards. These producers initially attempted to replicate the old reggae dancehall sound, but once the music went digital, it rapidly evolved into a radically different animal. Of course, the mechanization of Jamaican music followed a pattern that was already well underway in the United States and other parts of the world. But for those who had listened to reggae for its spiritual or political qualities or its earthy, organic sensibility, something seemed irretrievably lost.' b'The pre-digital early 1980s were a period of transition between these two dramatic eras of Jamaican music, an interregnum that symbolically began with the death of Bob Marley in May of 1981. Although many groups of the roots reggae era adapted to the new era and continued to make great music, the new style was largely defined by a younger generation of dancehall deejays with names like Yellowman, Charlie Chaplin, Josey Wales, Eek-A-Mouse, Tiger and others whose \xe2\x80\x9cslackness\xe2\x80\x9d lyrics of sex, ghetto violence, braggadocio and bling helped set the more aggressive tone of the new decade.' b'This new form of reggae, generally called \xe2\x80\x9cdancehall,\xe2\x80\x9d was associated with a number of emerging producers including Sugar Minott, Nkrumah Jah Thomas, Linval Thompson and Thompson\xe2\x80\x99s prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9, Henry \xe2\x80\x9cJunjo\xe2\x80\x9d Lawes. Lawes in particular was on a hot streak during these years, best-known for the string of hits he produced with Yellowman. His unique sound was partially crafted by using the Roots Radics as his session band. The Radics were built around the rhythm section nucleus of Errol \xe2\x80\x9cFlabba\xe2\x80\x9d Holt, drummer Lincoln \xe2\x80\x9cStyle\xe2\x80\x9d Scott, and guitarist Eric \xe2\x80\x9cBingy Bunny\xe2\x80\x9d Lamont (augmented by a number of keyboardists including Winston Wright and Gladstone Anderson), and their sound was stripped-down and stark. Unlike the older, polyrhythmic roots reggae which had developed out of rock steady, the new rhythms tended to be minimalist in construction\xe2\x80\x94at times martially tight and at other times heavy and lumbering\xe2\x80\x94with Scott\xe2\x80\x99s Syndrums garnishing the music with electronic beeps, buzzes and other quirky, futuristic sounds.' b'But the unique vibe of Lawes\xe2\x80\x99 productions was also a result of them being mixed by Hopeton \xe2\x80\x9cScientist\xe2\x80\x9d Brown, a young prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 of King Tubby, the acknowledged master of dub music. Scientist had initially been a mere apprentice at Tubby\xe2\x80\x99s studio, only infrequently mixing until Thompson and Junjo started to use him on a regular basis. But his skills and reputation grew quickly and by 1980, he was mixing most of Junjo\xe2\x80\x99s tunes and dub versions, compiling them on to the series of sci-fi and video game-themed albums that still form the core of his reputation today: Scientist Rids the World of\xc2\xa0the Evil Curse of the Vampires, Scientist Wins the World Cup, Heavyweight Dub Champion, Big Showdown, Scientist Meets the Space Invaders and Scientist Encounters Pac-Man. Unlike the warmer, more tropical sound of King Tubby\xe2\x80\x99s dub mixing which had dominated the 1970s, Scientist\xe2\x80\x99s treatment of the Roots Radics\xe2\x80\x99 sounded as if he were suspended in the cold, stark spaces between planets, its emptiness only occasionally animated by the fleeting movements of comets, asteroids, and space debris.' b'Although dub music developed out of reggae as the latter music\xe2\x80\x99s experimental impulse, the two approaches have generally tended to appeal to different constituencies. Inside of Jamaica, dub was most typically used in the dancehalls as a backdrop for the tale-spinning of the sound system deejays. Outside of Jamaica, it tended to appeal to listeners whose ears had been primed by the spacey soundscapes of psychedelic rock. And producers generally encouraged this bifurcation, placing vocal songs on the A-sides of singles and dub versions on the B-sides. But there were occasions when the idea of the song and the dub mix were not necessarily mutually exclusive, and there is a select group of exalted reggae recordings that unite the sonic experimentation of dub with more traditional conceptions of songcraft. The best-known example of this is probably the Congos\xe2\x80\x99 1977 album Heart of the Congos, a collection of songs gorgeously performed by the Congos and given an equally gorgeous, dubwise production by Lee \xe2\x80\x9cScratch\xe2\x80\x9d Perry at the height of his Black Ark studio.' b'A lesser-known album in the same category is the Wailing Souls album Wailing. The core of the Wailing Souls is the duo of Winston \xe2\x80\x9cPipe\xe2\x80\x9d Matthews and Lloyd \xe2\x80\x9cBread\xe2\x80\x9d McDonald, generally augmented by one or two additional vocalists as the occasion demands. Friends of Bob Marley & the Wailers since their early days singing together in Trench Town, they were\xe2\x80\x94along with the Abyssinians, the Gladiators, and Burning Spear\xe2\x80\x94one of a number of roots vocal groups that began to record for Coxsone Dodd at Studio One in the early 1970s. The Wailing Souls brought a poignant, yearning sound associated on one hand with musical traditions of the Jamaican countryside and on the other, with African-American soul outfits\xc2\xa0like\xc2\xa0the Impressions and the Temptations, who inspired the formation of scores of Jamaican vocal groups. Many of the latter had perfected their gentle harmonizing singing rock steady\xe2\x80\x94the romantic, soul-inspired Jamaican music that, for two or three intense years, set the stage for roots reggae. But by the early 1970s, they had abandoned the smooth crooning of rock steady for a raw, less affected vocal quality, typified by the rough voices of Pipe, Bob Marley, and Burning Spear\xe2\x80\x99s Winston Rodney.' b'Like the other groups, the Wailing Souls typically sung themes of Rastafarian devotion alongside philosophically-tinged love songs. They cut two albums\xc2\xa0for Coxsone before moving on to Channel One studio, where they cut a string of excellent records for the Hoo-Kim brothers. Their career took a major step forward in 1979\xc2\xa0when they recorded the celebrated Wild Suspense album for Island Records. By the time they began to record for Junjo in 1980, their experience enabled them to blend the romanticism of rock steady and the mysticism and militancy of roots reggae with the new, minimalist dub sound Scientist was crafting for Junjo\xe2\x80\x99s productions. Teaming up with Junjo and Scientist when both were at the peak of their creativity, Pipe\xe2\x80\x99s voice has arguably never been showcased to better effect, and Wailing was to be one of the most special albums of the Souls\xe2\x80\x99 long career.' b'In fact, the group was initially reluctant to work with Junjo, wary of the gangster element in the producer\xe2\x80\x99s business, not to mention quality control issues. Junjo was one of the producers that made extensive use of versioning\xe2\x80\x94recycling a rhythm track by overdubbing a succession of deejays on it\xe2\x80\x94but the Souls preferred their music to stand alone so that the messages in their song lyrics remained accessible. Furthermore, while the rhythms that Junjo was cutting with Roots Radics undoubtedly hit hard in the dancehall, they sometimes lacked the inventiveness of the rhythms produced by earlier drum & bass teams like Sly Dunbar\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Robbie Shakespeare (with Peter Tosh and Black Uhuru), Carlton & Aston Barrett (with Bob Marley & the Wailers) and \xe2\x80\x9cSanta\xe2\x80\x9d Davis and Fully Fulwood (with Soul Syndicate). But the Souls\xe2\x80\x99 warm four-part harmonies and Rasta themes (filled out on this album by Garth Dennis and George \xe2\x80\x9cBuddy\xe2\x80\x9d Haye) brought a sonic and philosophical depth to those rhythms that Junjo\xe2\x80\x99s usual deejays never could.' b'From Scott\xe2\x80\x99s opening drum roll, the entire album is suffused with a feeling of the otherworldly, with the pensive chorus of Bread, Haye, and Dennis mixed like phantoms behind Pipe\xe2\x80\x99s lead vocals, juxtaposed against the stark, hard rhythms of the Roots Radics and spaced-out by Scientist in a haze of echo and reverberation. The lyrics are generally understated, tending toward the poetic, the oblique, and the evocative. The album\xe2\x80\x99s centerpiece is\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWho No Waan Come Cyan Stay\xe2\x80\x9d (Who Didn\xe2\x80\x99t Want to Come Can\xe2\x80\x99t Stay), a languid, spacey paean of Rasta repatriation. Anyone doubting the emotional power of dub need only let themselves be transported by Scott\xe2\x80\x99s snare chopping up the soundscape like gunshots, his bass drum kicking up thick clouds of reverberation, and Flabba Holt\xe2\x80\x99s bass ringing out with analog delay like a buoy on the sea while Pipe beckons to non-believers one last time as he departs for a heavenly African Zion:' b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh give us a home
Where the butterflies roam
and the birds sing so sweet\xe2\x80\xa6' b'Who no waan come cyan stay
You can stay, for I am going' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s so long, so long
I\xe2\x80\x99ve been warning you
Yet you\xe2\x80\x99re trying hard not to accept my word
But when the master\xe2\x80\x99s calling
You will find yourself stumbling
I\xe2\x80\x99ll be waiting by the wayside' b'Who no waan come cyan stay
You can stay for I am going\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The other songs continue in the same vein with wistful melodies of love, mystery, foreboding, and Rastafarian devotion. The opener \xe2\x80\x9cPenny I Love You\xe2\x80\x9d is poetic and philosophical, with the Souls professing their love into the echo chamber and setting the stage for the rest of the album. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Be Down Hearted\xe2\x80\x9d is a jaunty, spiritual exhortation for the Rasta faithful. \xe2\x80\x9cRudy Say Him Bad\xe2\x80\x9d is a plea to the gun-toting \xe2\x80\x9crude boys\xe2\x80\x9d of Kingston to heed the advice of their elders and renounce their violent ways, lest they \xe2\x80\x9clay down to stay.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFace the Devil\xe2\x80\x9d is rooted in the Biblical book of Revelation, warning of divine retribution and apocalyptic horrors to come. The album closes with the steady, plaintive \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Big More,\xe2\x80\x9d with Pipe and the Souls calling out the wealthy for their greed\xc2\xa0while bemoaning the plight of suffering masses.
