In true \xe2\x80\x9cshowcase album\xe2\x80\x9d fashion almost all of the songs here are followed by their dub versions, with the vocals entirely removed and Scientist kicking around in the echo chamber, using reverberation and dropping out parts to explore every nook, cranny, and cavern of the soundscape.' b'The juxtaposition of the Roots Radics\xe2\x80\x99 dancehall rhythms and the rhapsodic voices of the Wailing Souls seemed to encapsulate Jamaica\xe2\x80\x99s arrival at the crossroads of 1980, a moment when the violent changing of the political guard foreshadowed a new era for the island as a whole. In a tense and uncertain season when the smooth harmonizing of vocal groups was giving way to the raucous chanting of the dancehall deejays, the team of Junjo, Scientist, and the Wailing Souls managed to carve an exalted dub cathedral out of the hard rhythms of early dancehall. Casting the group as voices in the proverbial wilderness, Wailing sings the glories of love, while bemoaning the violence engulfing their society and the world, an angelically-voiced clarion call as society gradually arcs toward the dark side.' b'__' b'Michael E. Veal is the author of Dub: Soundscapes and Shattered Songs in Jamaican Reggae (Wesleyan University Press, 2007).'

column7: b'Spirit is\xc2\xa0Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s most pointedly topical album, but the synth giants still write\xc2\xa0universal, stadium-sized music.\xc2\xa0These\xc2\xa0songs make you feel like singing in response to today\xe2\x80\x99s headlines.'
column8: b'The 14th\xc2\xa0studio album from synth giants Depeche Mode begins with frontman Dave Gahan declaring that \xe2\x80\x9cWe are not there yet/We have not evolved.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s the first of many admonitions Gahan issues on what turns out to be the most pointedly topical and compassionate effort in the band\xe2\x80\x99s career. Over solemn piano chords and a lockstep electro groove that hints at the cadence of a protest march, Gahan laments how \xe2\x80\x9cwe feel nothing inside\xe2\x80\x9d as we \xe2\x80\x9ctrack it all with satellites\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwatch men die in real time.\xe2\x80\x9d By track two, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the Revolution,\xe2\x80\x9d Gahan begins\xc2\xa0calling for out-and-out revolt, chiding the audience: \xe2\x80\x9cCome on people/You\xe2\x80\x99re letting me down.\xe2\x80\x9d In his golden-throated baritone, Gahan reminds us that we\xe2\x80\x99ve been \xe2\x80\x9cpissed on/For too long,\xe2\x80\x9d our \xe2\x80\x9crights abused\xe2\x80\x9d by governments who \xe2\x80\x9cManipulate and threaten/With terror as a weapon.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Apparently, principal lyricist and songwriter Martin Gore is no longer content to focus all his attention on the spiritual searching that has defined Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s music for more than\xc2\xa030 years. Over that time, few artists have so artfully portrayed the inner dialogue between redemption and indulgence. By the band\xe2\x80\x99s 1990 breakout Violator, Gore had basically invented his own syntax for the human condition as a purgatorial struggle between sinful pleasures and a yearning for higher peace. And Gahan, with his ability to invest urgency, soul, and a feeling of debauched weariness into subjects like S&M and tortured love, has never failed to translate Gore\xe2\x80\x99s restless malaise to the throngs who fill stadiums to connect with it. Gahan turns despair into sex appeal unlike no other. But this time, he\xe2\x80\x99s tasked with looking up from his satin, regret-stained sheets and making us believe that an aging rock star really cares about civil unrest.' b'Gahan delivers Gore\xe2\x80\x99s state-of-world address for three songs in a row before going back to the band\xe2\x80\x99s bread-and-butter obsessions. Later, though, on \xe2\x80\x9cPoorman\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which self-consciously references the spartan electronic gurgle of the Violator hit \xe2\x80\x9cPolicy of Truth\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Gore and Gahan risk coming off as oblivious to the irony when they observe that \xe2\x80\x9ccorporations get the breaks/Keeping almost everything they make\xe2\x80\x9d and ask, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen will it trickle down?\xe2\x80\x9d But Depeche Mode deliver anthems with such proficiency that sincerity barely matters. A song like \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the Revolution\xe2\x80\x9d makes you feel like singing in response to today\xe2\x80\x99s headlines. Depeche Mode still make universal, stadium-sized music that\xe2\x80\x99s limber enough to fit through your bedroom doorframe, as if it had been conceived with your life in mind.' b'In some respects, though, their consistency works against them. The sixth album since the departure of multi-instrumentalist/arranger Alan Wilder, Spirit sees Depeche Mode once again shuffling through the most quintessential components of their sound.\xc2\xa0On \xe2\x80\x9cCover Me,\xe2\x80\x9d Gore\xe2\x80\x99s haunting Lanois-esque guitar twang allows you to close your eyes and picture yourself under the Northern lights Gahan sings about. But aside from \xe2\x80\x9cCover Me,\xe2\x80\x9d Spirit lacks the ambience of Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s most atmospheric material. If only producer/mixer James Ford (Florence and the Machine, Foals, Arctic Monkeys) had disheveled the sounds a bit, Spirit could have better asserted its place in\xc2\xa0Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s body of work.' b'Instead, Ford\xe2\x80\x94who is also one half of the electronic duo Simian Mobile Disco\xe2\x80\x94mimics the vibe of the band\xe2\x80\x99s iconic work with producer Flood. But even Flood didn\xe2\x80\x99t imitate himself when he mixed\xc2\xa0the last DM album, 2013\xe2\x80\x99s far more creatively resolute Delta Machine. Nevertheless, this is\xc2\xa0a band whose effortlessness can misguide you into thinking they\xe2\x80\x99re not trying. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be fooled. In the bridge of \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the Revolution,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Gahan repeats the line \xe2\x80\x9cthe train is coming, the train is coming... get on board.\xe2\x80\x9d You can draw inspiration from that lyric whether or not you take to the streets or petition your elected officials. Gore\xe2\x80\x99s directive is less about activism and more about opening your heart so that it guides your conscience. For him, the term \xe2\x80\x9cspirit\xe2\x80\x9d has come to encompass politics, but it\xe2\x80\x99s fueled by the same eros that\xe2\x80\x99s driven the band\xe2\x80\x99s music since day one. Which is why Spirit is so convincing in spite of its radical shift in tenor. For both the band and audience, that shift couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have come at a better time.'

column7: b'The psychedelic\xc2\xa0mod band were only around for a few years, but as this Numero compilation overwhelmingly proves, they were as self-aware as the Move, as vicious as the Who, and as clever as the Kinks.'
column8: b"The Creation are\xc2\xa0the definition of a cult band. They only existed for a brief spell\xe2\x80\x94formed in 1966, fell apart in 1968\xe2\x80\x94 but during those months, they bore a sound that could\xe2\x80\x99ve made them stars. Adding to the Creation\xe2\x80\x99s mystique is the fact that they weren\xe2\x80\x99t widely heard at the time. In their native Britain, they eked out only one hit, \xe2\x80\x9cPainter Man,\xe2\x80\x9d which scraped the Top 40 at No. 36. But that\xe2\x80\x99s better than they managed in the U.S., where they essentially didn't exist; their four singles stiffed and the haphazard 1967 LP We Are Paintermen never even materialized in America." b'Eurodisco outfit Boney M took their cover \xe2\x80\x9cPainter Man\xe2\x80\x9d into the UK Top 10 in 1979, but that had little to do with the cult of the Creation that was already well underway. The first true flowering of Creation awareness arrived in 1978, when the Jam conspicuously framed a Creation 45\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBiff Bang Pow,\xe2\x80\x9d the flipside of \xe2\x80\x9cPainter Man\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94in their collage of inspiration and self-celebration in the inner sleeve for All Mod Cons. By the early \xe2\x80\x9980s, Television Personalities were covering their songs and the band\xe2\x80\x99s chief advocate Alan McGee formed a label called Creation and named his indie band after \xe2\x80\x9cBiff Bang Pow.\xe2\x80\x9d Fan devotion doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come much clearer than that.' b"By that point, Edsel released How Does It Feel To Feel, the first in a series of Creation compilations created for British Invasion, freakbeat and psych collectors. Many similar collections have appeared over the last three decades, but Numero\xe2\x80\x99s new double-disc Action Painting is the first Creation compilation designed to appeal to listeners who might not already know them. It\xe2\x80\x99s for people who may be aware of the band through the indelible impression \xe2\x80\x9cMakin' Time\xe2\x80\x9d made in Wes Anderson\xe2\x80\x99s 1998 film Rushmore, or perhaps Ride\xe2\x80\x99s cover of \xe2\x80\x9cHow Does It Feel To Feel\xe2\x80\x9d in 1994, or maybe they just trust Numero\xe2\x80\x99s curation of the forgotten corners of our musical past." b'Action Painting certainly contains its own collector bait\xe2\x80\x94the first disc includes remasters of the band\xe2\x80\x99s original mono mixes supervised by their producer Shel Talmy, while the second contains all the previously un-reissued early sides the group cut as the Mark Four along with new stereo mixes\xe2\x80\x94but its value is in presenting the work of this extraordinary band in an easily digestible fashion. The sequencing of Action Painting gives their short, turbulent life some coherence, presenting a narrative where the group keeps kicking against the pricks of their time.' b'For outsiders, Shel Talmy may provide the best gateway to the Creation. Talmy produced the earliest hits of the Kinks and the Who (he\xe2\x80\x99s responsible for the proto-metal blast of \xe2\x80\x9cYou Really Got Me\xe2\x80\x9d and the sneering defiance of \xe2\x80\x9cMy Generation\xe2\x80\x9d) and the Creation benefitted from his blunt touch. On his productions, Talmy ratcheted up the violent pop-art of the Who when they were at the peak of their mod swagger, a move that was only fitting for a band who seemed to exist in an eternal now, simultaneously hoovering up ideas from R&B-besotted mods and mind-bending psychedelia. In that sense, the Creation sometimes flirted with the subversion of the Move, but where Roy Wood often indulged in irony, the Creation were sincere, never raising an arched eyebrow when conjuring waves of noise and grounding their whimsy with truly nasty, gnarled guitar riffs.' b'The creation existed in a hot house between mod and psychedelia, ranging between the fevered stomp of the former and the mind-warping experimentation of the latter. Listen to \xe2\x80\x9cSylvette,\xe2\x80\x9d one of their earliest numbers: it\xe2\x80\x99s essentially a rewrite of Eddie Holland\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLeaving Here\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94notably covered by the Who on their 1965 debut My Generation\xe2\x80\x94but the Creation feels coiled and lethal, as if they were deliberately keeping their full power in check. One of their chief attributes is that they sounded\xc2\xa0almost vicious.' b'Innovation never played into the Creation\xe2\x80\x99s legacy. Guitarist Eddie Phillips sawed a violin bow across his six strings, a move Jimmy Page would steal, but the band embodied their time more than transcended it. The feeling that the band was always on the cusp of a breakthrough is what makes them exciting to this day. Particularly in the mono mixes that comprise disc one, they are vibrant and alive, sometimes hinting at the clean lines and big beat of mod, but usually sounding like the bold explosion of pop art. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pull you into a cerebral undercurrent the way the best psychedelia does, it just detonates. \xe2\x80\x9cBiff Bang Pow\xe2\x80\x9d takes its name from comic art\xe2\x80\x94the title suggests the hyper-stylized Batman series of 1966\xe2\x80\x94and it rampages like the Who on a bender and it never makes a play for the head. Even \xe2\x80\x9cHow Does It Feel To Feel\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a churning circle that suggests psychedelic obsession\xe2\x80\x94pushes brawn over brain.' b'The Creation arrived just as the British Invasion shook off regimented R&B influences, then they departed just as rock started to get deeper and weirder. Certainly, a band that was pushing wailing organs and keening guitars could\xe2\x80\x99ve survived the prog rock era, but that early lack of success pushed the band into a series of personnel upheavals, eventually dooming the band. Yet, their brief, blazing life is also why they remain captivating: they lived minute to minute, pushing out their best ideas because it was likely they\xe2\x80\x99d never survive to another seven inch. Action Painting reflects this urgency, particularly as the singles pile up one after another on the first disc. Here, the Creation often recall their peers\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re as vicious as the Who, clever as the Kinks, as self-aware as the Move\xe2\x80\x94but they seem utterly original, a band with the ideas, sound and songs for the big time, but one that never caught the right break. They are blessed and cursed by existing for a flash.'

column3: b'Ron Trent Presents - Prescription: Word, Sound & Power'
column7: b'Few have taken house music deeper than Ron Trent and his Prescription label, and this new comp gives a moody, silvery snapshot of the label\xe2\x80\x99s mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s heyday.'
column8: b'We\xe2\x80\x99re five or 10 years into the latest deep house revival, 30-odd years since the style first coalesced. Yet in all that time, no one has come up with a precise definition of the style. Deep house is less a set of characteristics as it is a kind of blue, a mood recognizable primarily for its woozy, immersive pull. If house music\xe2\x80\x99s steady thump is the anchor, then everything else\xe2\x80\x94synths, bassline, vocals, effects\xe2\x80\x94tosses to and fro like kelp in the current.' b'Few have taken house music deeper than Ron Trent and his Prescription label, which he co-founded with Chez Damier in 1993. *Ron Trent Presents \xe2\x80\x93 Prescription: Word, Sound & Power *is a snapshot of the label\xe2\x80\x99s mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s heyday, when Prescription developed an instantly recognizable sound rooted in the jacking grooves of early Chicago house, splashed with moody tone color, and crosscut with Afro-Latin polyrhythms. The compilation\xe2\x80\x99s 24 tracks\xe2\x80\x94nearly all by Trent, either solo or in collaboration with artists like Damier and Anthony Nicholson\xe2\x80\x94highlight Prescription\xe2\x80\x99s sweet spot: not too rough, not too slick, and swirled with dusky color.' b'Unlike Trent\xe2\x80\x99s early hit \xe2\x80\x9cAltered States\xe2\x80\x9d and its larger-than-life hook, these tracks tend to conceal more than they reveal. There are few obvious melodies; instead, sounds painted on in overlapping layers create the illusion of unfathomable depth. Trent has described his style at the time as \xe2\x80\x9cdrum-orientated Chicago rhythm tracks with a minimalistic melody,\xe2\x80\x9d and the key word there is tracks: Unlike songs, these tumbling perpetual-motion machines have no verses or choruses, no bridges, no reprises. They roll straight ahead in an unswerving line, climbing upward at a steady, 30-degree grade until, some imperceptible climax having been reached, they begin their descent, shedding layers as they lose elevation. But such simple additive and subtractive arrangements don\xe2\x80\x99t account for the complex ways in which those moving parts interact. Three or four drum patterns\xe2\x80\x94machine sequences, disco breaks, cowbells, congas\xe2\x80\x94might run in parallel at any given moment, each with its own particular sense of swing and syncopation. Similarly, what might sound at first like a single set of chords reveals itself to be four or five different layers of synthesizer, organ, Rhodes, and sampled voice, all fused into one rippling wave.' b'Chez-N Trent\xe2\x80\x99s anthemic \xe2\x80\x9cThe Choice\xe2\x80\x9d is the only selection that grabs you by the lapels, but its charm lies in the details: rimshots so vivid you can practically feel the grain on the sticks; a wheezy ghost rhythm of sampled grunts and hiccups. Trent\xe2\x80\x99s 13-minute \xe2\x80\x9cSeduction\xe2\x80\x9d strikes an impeccable balance between atmosphere and sheer muscle: Shakers and syncopated bassline keep pushing things forward, even as deep blue chords apply a narcotic sense of drag. At their best, Trent\xe2\x80\x99s tunes throw up the faintest hint of a silvery hook, just enough to draw you deeper into their tidal flux.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s very best track is its first: \xe2\x80\x9cMorning Factory,\xe2\x80\x9d which Trent and Damier made in their Detroit studio following the 10-hour drive home from New York, where they\xe2\x80\x99d gone to see Junior Vasquez spin at the Sound Factory. Inspired by the clarity of the club\xe2\x80\x99s sound system and the energy on the dancefloor, the tune samples Kerri Chandler\xe2\x80\x99s *Atmosphere\xc2\xa0*EP, a 12-inch they\xe2\x80\x99d picked up on their trip to the city. Even though the link is clear\xe2\x80\x94those aquamarine chords are a dead giveaway\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMorning Factory\xe2\x80\x9d ultimately sounds nothing like its source material. Where Chandler\xe2\x80\x99s tune is crisp and clearly defined, \xe2\x80\x9cMorning Factory\xe2\x80\x9d is a soft and spongy, with shakers, bells, and synths dubbed into a vaporous haze. Atmosphere was, at the time, about as deep as deep house got. But with \xe2\x80\x9cMorning Factory,\xe2\x80\x9d Trent and Damier blew the dimensions of the style wide open. Today, anyone traversing the outer limits of deep house still follows in their wake.'

column7: b"Detroit's Bonny Doon recline deep in the kind of alternative folk music that gives off its own warmth, wise enough to sit back with some guitars\xc2\xa0and watch the world crumble."
column8: b'With their debut self-titled full-length, Bonny Doon make it seem like Detroit is due for an alt-country revival. *Bonny Doon *is at once jagged and unfinished, languid and detail-oriented, restless and at peace. Perhaps songwriters Bill Lennox and Bobby Colombo, bassist Joshua Brooks, and drummer Jake Kmiecik\xe2\x80\x99s time in local acts like Tyvek and Growwing Pains are to attribute for the streamlining of genres, though even that passes off the kismet their sound stirs up.' b'Bonny Doon recline deep in the kind of folk music that gives off its own warmth, where a drunken evening filled with texts from his mom on \xe2\x80\x9cI See You\xe2\x80\x9d offers a laugh or the confident piano chords in \xe2\x80\x9cEvening All Day Long\xe2\x80\x9d suggest resilience. But underneath their blues-tinged instrumentals is abject loneliness. \xe2\x80\x9c(Crowded)\xe2\x80\x9d is five minutes of Neil Young-style apathy. \xe2\x80\x9cRelieved\xe2\x80\x9d channels Smog and Kurt Vile shrugs. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Time Is It in Portland?\xe2\x80\x9d sees Colombo\xc2\xa0pining after a lost love, detailing friendships he let dissolve and a willful ignorance of how to fix it all. Like any successful singer, he\xe2\x80\x99s introspective even when he sings like there\xe2\x80\x99s no point in carrying on.' b'A sliver of their punk roots slip into Bonny Doon to give their beezy country some rock bite, though it varies in form. There\xe2\x80\x99s cuts like \xe2\x80\x9cSummertime Friends,\xe2\x80\x9d where half-spoken lyrics about mindless relationships recall the deadpan delivery of Parquet Courts. Elsewhere are distorted guitar chases speeding alongside lively drumming, like on \xe2\x80\x9cLost My Way.\xe2\x80\x9d So when a song like \xe2\x80\x9cNever Been to California\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which employs a honky-tonk bass part and shaky organ\xe2\x80\x94plays, the tone change feels like a payoff instead of a downshift.' b"Their best mode is when Bonny Doon take a step back, brush their hands, and accept a role as an observer. The only way to counter a crumbling world with their surroundings moving at full tilt is to create stability. Much of this tone comes from the album\xe2\x80\x99s construction: each member passed the songs around to flesh out instrumentals. Part of Bonny Doon was recorded in Russell Industrial Center, one of the\xc2\xa0city\xe2\x80\x99s biggest arts redevelopment projects, and over the three years it took to release the full-length, outsiders snatched up cheap real estate across the city, placing capitalism's ethics at the forefront of their minds. Bonny Doon aren\xe2\x80\x99t singing about Detroit specifically, but they bear witness to the city\xe2\x80\x99s evolution\xe2\x80\x94or lack thereof\xe2\x80\x94whether they want to or not, and the ways in which it sours their mood is evident. When Lennox\xc2\xa0sings \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re right/Yeah, I gotta grow up,\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cYou Can\xe2\x80\x99t Hide,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s not charged with motivation or promise. It\xe2\x80\x99s empty. He agrees to change but the energy to do so was long ago stripped, hence why he sees himself reflected in the bottom of a wine bottle and fading neon signs.\xc2\xa0They know change will happen, but they also know they have so little to do with the course it takes. Why not watch the madness unfold and shrug its worst parts off?" b'That hopeless undertone to their otherwise easygoing country rock gives them a distinguished voice. Should they continue to hone it, they can carve their own distinctions, stepping away from the Bill Callahan and David Berman similarities to become an RIYL descriptor themselves. An album of sunlit melodies with the shadows of Detroit looming over it delivers more than expected; it\xe2\x80\x99s not easy creating a doleful aftertaste that never quite dampens spirits, but Bonny Doon pull it off. By the time that complexity in their songwriting reveals itself, you\xe2\x80\x99re already on the next listen, fully aware of humanity\xe2\x80\x99s cessation and the band\xe2\x80\x99s decision to cozy up on the porch to watch. Nothing articulates the warmth of their nonchalant despair like the line: \xe2\x80\x9cI was staring at the setting sun and I realized my time had run out/And I was relieved.\xe2\x80\x9d Maybe we should be doing the same.'

column7: b"As a musical companion EP to 2016's\xc2\xa0HOPELESSNES, Anohni makes explicit the connections between gender and ecocide, and asks herself and her audience to recognize complicity and take action."
column8: b'In May 2016, just a few weeks after releasing her powerful record HOPELESSNESS, Anohni\xc2\xa0debuted an accompanying live performance at New York\xe2\x80\x99s Park Avenue Armory. The cavernous drill hall amplified her\xc2\xa0thunderous production to prophetic heights, but the presentation was less a showcase of artistry than it was a persuasive address. Anohni\xc2\xa0herself stood shrouded in a veiled habit beneath a towering screen that showed an assortment of women mouthing along to her songs. Never once was she, nor her collaborators Daniel Lopatin, aka Oneohtrix Point Never, and Christopher Elms, the center of attention. The point was clear: the words coming out of her mouth are so universal and enduring that they are greater than one individual.' b'Nine of the artists, poets, and activists featured in the Armory show reappear on the cover of Anohni\xe2\x80\x99s newest seven-song EP, Paradise. They are shown weeping, drenched in blood, faces weary with pain. These are the people whose concerns Anohni works to vocalize, those who understand that womanhood and the Earth from which we subsist are deeply intertwined. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly an intervention by women around the world,\xe2\x80\x9d Anohni writes in an accompanying piece, \xe2\x80\x9cWith their innate knowledge of interdependency, deep listening, empathy, and self-sacrifice, could possibly alter our species\xe2\x80\x99 desperate course.\xe2\x80\x9d The singer has spoken extensively about gender and ecocide as a member of the Future Feminism collective, but never before has she been so explicit about their cause-and-effect relationship. \xe2\x80\x9cMy mother\xe2\x80\x99s love/Her gentle touch/My father\xe2\x80\x99s hand/Rest on my throat,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on the title track, contrasting the feminine Earth with those who wish her harm. More than simply tossing around blame on Paradise, Anohni takes responsibility herself and urges her audience to do so as well.' b'Once again reunited with her production crew of Lopatin and Hudson Mohawke, Paradise comes off as a HOPELESSNESS companion piece rather than a stand-alone album. Even as her music grows increasingly industrial, the organic remains a constant presence, a subtle reminder that we carry the earth within us. Like a biodome filled with an assortment of ecosystems, Paradise jumps from rocky and volcanic to chirping and tropical with just the slightest change of beat, while each\xc2\xa0song sticks closely to its appointed terrain. On the furious title track, skittering percussion and booming production support Anohni as she describes apocalyptic loss and turmoil. \xe2\x80\x9cStaring at myself/I feel giant and trapped/Seemingly/Without escape,\xe2\x80\x9d she observes, inferring that the Earth\xe2\x80\x99s destruction incites mortal dysmorphia. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m here, not here.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The abrasive \xe2\x80\x9cJesus Will Kill You\xe2\x80\x9d picks up where HOPELESSNESS\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cObama\xe2\x80\x9d left off, a mournful interrogation of those who use their power to destroy the earth and its inhabitants. \xe2\x80\x9cRicochet,\xe2\x80\x9d on the other hand, is a joyful, bouncing promise to \xe2\x80\x9ccurse\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9chate\xe2\x80\x9d the creator for the state of existence.\xc2\xa0Both songs\xe2\x80\x99 invocation of a punitive deity may seem sudden since Anohni tends to explore corporeal matters rather than the spiritual. But in the year since HOPELESSNESS, her rage and pain have transcended human action.' b'The final track, \xe2\x80\x9cShe Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t Mourn Her Loss,\xe2\x80\x9d also closed out the Armory show and was the most powerful moment of the evening. The song itself is a pleading ballad about how the Earth holds her tears and simply accepts change. \xe2\x80\x9cWho will remember her? If not her children,\xe2\x80\x9d Anohni asks. As it was at the Armory, the rhetorical question is again raised by a speech Aboriginal artist Ngalangka Nola Taylor originally presented at the World Economic Forum. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are wondering what is happening to the world. Everything is change, changing,\xe2\x80\x9d she asks in broken English. \xe2\x80\x9cHow are we going to stop and work on it and work together and make the world a better place to live for all of us?\xe2\x80\x9d Anohni provided one solution just days before the release of Paradise.' b'She revealed on Facebook that the EP contains a seventh bonus track called \xe2\x80\x9cI Never Stopped Loving You\xe2\x80\x9d that is available for a small price: \xe2\x80\x9ca gesture of anonymous vulnerability\xe2\x80\x9d communicated over email. By asking her audience to connect intimately in exchange for a piece of herself, Anohni presents a reminder that there is a human behind the materials we consume, just like there is an Earth from which we were born and from which we harm without thought. *Paradise challenges its listeners to emotionally engage with their surroundings in hopes that they develop a conscious understanding that there are consequences to our daily conveniences. *As Anohni continues her resistance, she recognizes the battle is impossible to win without an open heart.'

column7: b"Chicago's NE-HI come out of the basement for their second album, one that sees the band shaping their wiry garage rock sound for larger stages while still honing their musical personalities."
column8: b'Selectivity is the calling card of Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s NE-HI. On the band\xe2\x80\x99s self-titled 2014 debut, which was recorded in one of the many city basements that grew them, they never showed their full hand. Four\xc2\xa0of its nine tracks were a single hook of eight or nine words\xc2\xa0and almost nothing else. Jason Balla\xe2\x80\x99s guitar lines featured plenty of space between each note, and they\xc2\xa0honk, nasal and\xc2\xa0blaring,\xc2\xa0as if their garage indie rock was designed with the express purpose of forcing their way through to the back of an overcrowded basement. The band learned quickly that their overflowing energy is best spent when pouring more into less, and not vice versa.' b"Offers\xc2\xa0is NE-HI\xe2\x80\x99s second album and first on Grand Jury Music, and it reintroduces the band as one who plays\xc2\xa0above-ground. Coming off of multiple tours where they regularly played on proper stages for the first time, NE-HI built these songs accordingly: They sound twice as developed. The co-frontman platoon of Mikey Wells, the more verse-chorus-minded songwriter, and Balla, who on stage assumes the form of a rubber band in flight, dial up the energy between the two. Their ballooning sound is a close approximation of the NE-HI live show*\xe2\x80\x94the band's best foot forward\xe2\x80\x94*and captures the breath\xc2\xa0of the band up close like being inches away from their mics in a moldy basement." b'On the Wells-led highlights \xe2\x80\x9cBuried on the Moon,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cSisters,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Wanna Know You,\xe2\x80\x9d Balla\xe2\x80\x99s guitar buzzes and swerves behind him, forming these hardly logical interactions that make for\xc2\xa0Offers\xe2\x80\x99s most interesting moments. The album\xe2\x80\x99s first single, \xe2\x80\x9cDrag,\xe2\x80\x9d is also the best bridge between basement- and stage-NE-HI, featuring a full structure without sacrificing the shouts. The abrasive instrumental breakdowns that NE-HI leaned on for their loudest early songs aren\xe2\x80\x99t common here, but the one that shows up on \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cOut of Reach\xe2\x80\x9d punctuates one of the least ambiguous lyrics Balla has written: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to get along?/Say the word, I\xe2\x80\x99ll let you right in.\xe2\x80\x9d Neither singer is one to get cheated on a single vowel sound.' b'Offers\xc2\xa0was\xc2\xa0completed on its second studio go-around after the first was scrapped almost entirely. The pressure to deliver\xe2\x80\x94and to fold into the business of building a successful band\xe2\x80\x94seems to have found its way into the songs, which can flirt a little too closely with self-obsession. \xe2\x80\x9cEvery Dent\xe2\x80\x9d reckons with all the glad-handing required to get ahead in the business, and on \xe2\x80\x9cBuried on the Moon,\xe2\x80\x9d Wells takes an even more cynical look at the process: \xe2\x80\x9cWell come on make a record like your dear old dad/Yeah, we\xe2\x80\x99ll give you all the money then make you feel sad.\xe2\x80\x9d The shoegazing title track looks upon the defeat of a missed opportunity with dread: \xe2\x80\x9cOffer\xe2\x80\x99s gone/No response/I\xe2\x80\x99ve been on too long,\xe2\x80\x9d Balla sings, exhaustingly.' b'But\xc2\xa0Offers\xc2\xa0deliberately ends on a more optimistic ode to their roots, a song that feels like NE-HI\xe2\x80\x99s home base. On \xe2\x80\x9cStay Young,\xe2\x80\x9d they talk changing, growing, and resisting age\xe2\x80\x94while all too self-aware of the embarrassment of admitting to resisting age. \xe2\x80\x9cTime gets away from you / And it\xe2\x80\x99s not coming back,\xe2\x80\x9d Balla sings. But time spent pouring energy into work that marks a new chapter, while the energy is still there, is time well spent. NE-HI are comfortable doing as much as they can.'

column7: b'Tom Jenkinson of Squarepusher gathers a live band to\xc2\xa0play fast-and-busy jazz fusion, including versions of some of his early classics. The chops are there, but the broader point is less clear.'
column8: b'Squarepusher\xe2\x80\x99s Tom Jenkinson is not a man prone to inertia. Since his breakout in the mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s with the frenetic avant drum\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99bass of Feed Me Weird Things and Hard Normal Daddy, his career has assumed a sort of pinball trajectory, bouncing\xc2\xa0from prettified electroacoustic music to solo bass noodling to a period spent composing for a robotic band (see 2014 EP Music for Robots), clinging to instrumental virtuosity as a guiding precept. In this respect, the live-band project Shobaleader One is simultaneously a clean break and business as usual, being both the start of a new phase and the point at which a few older ideas fully germinate.' b'The Shobaleader One concept came to life in 2010, with an album titled Squarepusher Presents Shobaleader One: d\xe2\x80\x99Demonstrator. Incorporating elements of R&B, heavy metal, and Jenkinson\xe2\x80\x99s own treated vocals, it purported to be the work of a live band, but was probably just the work of Jenkinson himself. But d\xe2\x80\x99Demonstrator did attract some fellow travelers, and early in 2016, Shobaleader One emerged as a genuine touring entity\xe2\x80\x94Jenkinson on bass, plus three musicians going by the names Strobe Nazard, Company Laser, and Arg Nution, taking on keyboards, drums, and guitar, respectively. At their gigs, this \xe2\x80\x9cspace-pop\xe2\x80\x9d quartet set about reworking a number of Squarepusher standards through the medium of hyperspeed jazz-funk, their identities concealed by masks that look like malfunctioning Tenori-on.' b'While not explicitly presented as a live album, Elektrac seems to be taken in part\xc2\xa0from concert\xc2\xa0recordings, though\xc2\xa0were it not for the light applause that punctuates each track you might not notice. The recordings are crystal-clear, and there is no doubting the chops of the band themselves, who handle their task with virtuoso ease. Some tracks here feel well suited to a Shobaleader overhaul. A sprint through \xe2\x80\x9cCoopers World\xe2\x80\x9d from 1997\xe2\x80\x99s Hard Normal Daddy imagines it as the score to some hardboiled \xe2\x80\x9970s cop-drama, all sticky wah-wah guitar and limber-fingered keyboard runs. \xe2\x80\x9cE8 Boogie\xe2\x80\x9d is pretty much a showcase for Jenkinson\xe2\x80\x99s genuinely startling warp-speed bass plucking. Elsewhere, there\xe2\x80\x99s some entertainment\xc2\xa0in watching the outfit stretch to cover distant corners of Squarepusher\xe2\x80\x99s artistic mien. Company Laser nearly blows a circuit trying to replicate the drill\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99bass flurries of \xe2\x80\x9cJourney to Reedham,\xe2\x80\x9d while the ensemble show impressive restraint on a blissfully centered take on \xe2\x80\x9cIambic 5 Poetry,\xe2\x80\x9d the pretty, vibes-laden standout from 1999\xe2\x80\x99s Budakhan Mindphone.' b'These enjoyable moments are balanced by stretches where you realize you\xe2\x80\x99re not so much enjoying Elektrac as being subjected to it. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Go Plastic\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSquarepusher Theme\xe2\x80\x9d solo interminably, while a mid-album turn towards the heavy turns out low points like \xe2\x80\x9cMegazine\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Daft Punk gone metal gone wrong\xe2\x80\x94and a rather cold and lifeless technical riffer called \xe2\x80\x9cDelta-V.\xe2\x80\x9d Jenkinson has explained he wants Shobaleader One to sound like \xe2\x80\x9can insane band.\xe2\x80\x9d But nothing here verges on the elemental extremity or deranged humor displayed by earlier groups fusing jazz and metal\xe2\x80\x94Lightning Bolt, for instance, or John Zorn\xe2\x80\x99s Naked City. Instead, these tracks balance loudness with a rather fussy and joyless quality; fun to play, probably, not so much to listen to.' b'In a 2016 interview with Q magazine, Jenkinson described Shobaleader One as a reaction to the current state of electronic music production. \xe2\x80\x9cSoftware companies, partly in order to further their business aims, have made it so easy to make electronic music that the format in general is beginning to assume a troubling air of painting-by-numbers pointlessness,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Look closer at Shobaleader\xe2\x80\x99s gleaming metal carapace\xe2\x80\x94can you see the jazz snob poking through? The idea that an album of finicky jazz-funk covers is the answer to anything in 2017 is a little rich. But more broadly, I\xe2\x80\x99d say Jenkinson\xe2\x80\x99s assessment is flawed. The increasing availability of production software has enabled the rise of music-makers otherwise marginalized for geographic or economic reasons\xe2\x80\x94think localized sounds like grime, or gqom, or, if you want to go back further, those early jungle productions that gave Squarepusher its initial impetus. As ever, it\xe2\x80\x99s not so much about the tools, but what you do with them. And while it\xe2\x80\x99s laudable that Jenkinson is always moving, never resting, Elektrac feels a bit of a sideshow: a flexing of technique with little to display but its own shiny spectacle.'

column7: b'On this LP from New York noise-jazz trio GRID, saxophonist Matt Nelson\xe2\x80\x94a collaborator on tUnE-yArDs\xe2\x80\x99 w h o k i l l\xe2\x80\x94puts his tones through pedals and electronics to thrilling effect.'
column8: b'Saxophonist Matt Nelson is one of the more unpredictable virtuosos in New York\xe2\x80\x99s underground. He played with a sense of ecstatic lyricism in a band assembled by Merrill Garbus for the album w h o k i l l. He\xe2\x80\x99s delivered thoughtful supporting work in Battle Trance, a tenor-quartet group that plays compositions by Travis Laplante. And Nelson can also command center stage; his raging solos in Amirtha Kidambi\xe2\x80\x99s Elder Ones invite comparisons to some of experimental jazz\xe2\x80\x99s most admired reed extremists.' b'This kind of performance mobility doesn\xe2\x80\x99t tend to come about casually\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that Nelson enjoys taking on discrete roles in different ensembles. On his first record as part of GRID, a collaborative trio with drummer Nick Podgurski and bassist Tim Dahl, Nelson conceives of a different challenge. This time, he often plays the saxophone covertly. As he puts his tones through a raft of pedals and electronics, the majority of Nelson\xe2\x80\x99s licks sound like the work of a lead guitarist in an avant-rock trio.' b'On the band\xe2\x80\x99s eponymous\xc2\xa0debut, Nelson\xe2\x80\x99s indirect use of the saxophone is the most consistently thrilling element. During the initial minutes of the first movement (titled \xe2\x80\x9c(+/+)\xe2\x80\x9d), you might spend some time re-checking the album credits just to make sure there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a guest guitarist on hand. But those slow-moving, feedbacking melodies are all Nelson. The free-improv pulses from the rhythm section create a compelling, abstract background. And when Nelson allows small bulbs of typical reed-instrument noise to flower, in the fourth minute, the listener gains a greater appreciation of the saxophonist\xe2\x80\x99s command over this unusual terrain.' b'The NNA Tapes label has used the term \xe2\x80\x9cdoom jazz\xe2\x80\x9d to describe the band\xe2\x80\x99s sound, though there are some precedents that predate this\xc2\xa0subgenre coinage. Starting in\xc2\xa0the \xe2\x80\x9990s, Rashied Ali\xe2\x80\x94the ferocious, late-period drummer for John Coltrane\xe2\x80\x94worked with bassist Bill Laswell and the guitarist-vocalist Keiji Haino in the outfit Purple Trap. And Laswell\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9980s partnership with saxophonist Peter Br\xc3\xb6tzmann, in the group Last Exit and on the duo album Low Life, is another touchstone for this school of noise-jazz. But those past ensembles have often been at pains to show how many song forms they can undermine: swinging wildly between clattering ragers, ambient soundscapes, and even some dance textures.' b'The members of GRID take a more stable view of the style. Some passages on the album have slightly more propulsive drive (see: \xe2\x80\x9c(-/+)\xe2\x80\x9d). Others a shade of greater mystery (as on \xe2\x80\x9c(-/-)\xe2\x80\x9d). But over four movements spanning 38 minutes, the differences between these sections are not as stark as on many prior rock-meets-free-jazz outings. The benefit of this more even-keeled approach is its novelty. Though the textures are extreme in nature, and densely layered, GRID doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem primarily interested in bludgeoning listeners.' b'That decision results in an unusually dreamy realization of the underlying aesthetic: one that brings the group\xe2\x80\x99s work more in line with drone composition than with that of Laswell. The risk\xc2\xa0stalking\xc2\xa0such a choice is the fact that\xc2\xa0a\xc2\xa0listener\xe2\x80\x99s attention can drift a bit. But in electing not to close with a dramatic bash of a finale, the members of this gifted trio signal that they may be fine with that reaction. Like much else on this surprising set, the quick fade-out ending creates an idiosyncratic impact that lingers well beyond the album\xe2\x80\x99s running time.'

column7: b'Spoon stay in their well-earned lane but tweak the formula just enough on their ninth album, keeping their reliably great songwriting and adding new, electronic textures.'
column8: b'Despite remaining perennial indie rock favorites over the last decade, Spoon have always been about that small-stakes life. They aren\xe2\x80\x99t going to alter the course of your existence\xe2\x80\x94frontman Britt Daniel would probably smirk at such a claim\xe2\x80\x94but occasionally Daniel\xe2\x80\x99s hyper-specific details will creep into your mind unexpectedly. Is Dorian\xe2\x80\x99s a real place? What\xe2\x80\x99s the corner by Sound Exchange in Austin look like anyway? And why don\xe2\x80\x99t more people talk about how much *Garden State *actually sucked?' b'This is not to say that Spoon\xe2\x80\x99s songs don\xe2\x80\x99t often overflow with sound, as they increasingly have. But there is no tortured myth surrounding the whole ordeal, no idealistic aims to be anything more than career band making themselves happy. Every few years, they put out a record that sounds like Spoon but offers some new little twist, they tour for long stretches after that, and then they go away for a while. Their last album, 2014\xe2\x80\x99s They Want My Soul, was one of their best\xe2\x80\x94soulful and swirling, with just enough teeth showing between the hooks. Their ninth album, Hot Thoughts, picks up that thread and takes it in a funkier and freer direction. There are loads of drum beats that sound indebted to hip-hop and dance music throughout, downbeat electronics, and two five-minute instrumentals, including a moody jazz coda that closes the record.' b'But Spoon also know their lane quite well: punchy, inconspicuously catchy songs, with choruses just vague enough to make them applicable outside of whatever stylized vignette Daniel has yelped out; bonus points if there\xe2\x80\x99s a brief jam session that runs intoxicatingly off the rails for just a moment towards the song\xe2\x80\x99s end. This dichotomy can make *Hot Thoughts *a little uneven, unsure if it\xe2\x80\x99s trying to be arty or poppy while playing around with the drum machines.' b'There are the hit attempts: The repetitive title track, whose jittery energy is practically killed by its surface-level \xe2\x80\x9chot thoughts\xe2\x80\x9d about a sexy girl, nary a hint of clever winking to be found. And there are the clear hits: \xe2\x80\x9cCan I Sit Next to You,\xe2\x80\x9d which proves they\xe2\x80\x99re almost as adept as Phoenix at infectiously anxious dance-rock, and \xe2\x80\x9cDo I Have to Talk You Into It,\xe2\x80\x9d an instant classic that could only come from this band. Jim Eno\xe2\x80\x99s swaggering drums\xe2\x80\x94a key element of Spoon\xe2\x80\x99s sound since the start\xe2\x80\x94and Alex Fischel\xe2\x80\x99s descending piano chords drive the song boundlessly forward, punctuated by Daniel\xe2\x80\x99s selective rasp. It takes a certain kind of 45-year-old frontman to sing the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cknock knock\xe2\x80\x9d and still sound at least moderately cool, not like some phony in his first pair of Ray-Bans.' b'Eno and Fischel also shine on \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Caress,\xe2\x80\x9d a toe-tapping tune about one of those ghosts that linger in Daniel\xe2\x80\x99s head. He shoehorns in one of his Britticisms, a dry parenthetical that somehow captures the whole life of a character: \xe2\x80\x9cCoconut milk, coconut water/You still like to tell me they\xe2\x80\x99re the same/And who am I to say?\xe2\x80\x9d On \xe2\x80\x9cPink Up\xe2\x80\x9d he mumbles about taking a train to Marrakesh while the production\xe2\x80\x94via indie-psych go-to Dave Fridmann\xe2\x80\x94grows hazy and primal. By the end, the looping piano line, eerie strings, and bleeps of gibberish leave Spoon sounding a little like Radiohead. If anything, \xe2\x80\x9cPink Up\xe2\x80\x9d tees up the final track, \xe2\x80\x9cUs,\xe2\x80\x9d which returns to the same motif after dark via saxophone and bells.' b'All this is a far cry from the band who wrote clever little classic-rock paeans to their fathers\xe2\x80\x99 fitted shirts, but even then they were throwing in touches of harpsichord. That\xe2\x80\x99s the trick with Spoon: They make it seem more straightforward than it actually is. Over time, their slowly accumulated sonic excess has led them here, to what could be considered their electronic album. But they\xe2\x80\x99re caught just slightly between who they used to be and where they\xe2\x80\x99re going, and the songs don\xe2\x80\x99t always find a musical common ground. There\xe2\x80\x99s one point in particular where their maximalism serves their attempt at an anthem\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTear It Down\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but what\xe2\x80\x99s funny is that the song\xe2\x80\x99s sweeping *whoa-oh *climax is reminiscent of Arcade Fire, not Spoon.\xc2\xa0The tinkering of the trim Spoon attitude has become the most engaging part of their latter-day career. For a band that seems built on a reliable formula, they remain full of possibilities.'

column7: b"Featuring Heems, Danny Brown, and Wiki, the young New York MC 's first official album feels like a graduation, with bars and beats that feel both fresh and lived-in."
column8: b'In June of 2014, a rapper by the name of Your Old Droog uploaded an eponymous 10-track EP to Soundcloud. Intentionally mysterious, with no photos, videos, or any identifying information, it quickly generated buzz in the rap nerd blogosphere. When he \xe2\x80\x9ccame out,\xe2\x80\x9d he did it in a profile in The New Yorker, and when he sold out the Studio at Webster Hall for his first-ever show, it got written up in The New York Times.' b'So what powered the hype machine? It\xe2\x80\x99s quite simple, really: Your Old Droog sounds a lot like Nas. At times, his fine sandpaper growl sounds similar enough to be unsettling. And before he revealed himself to The New Yorker, plenty of people were convinced that the 20-something Ukrainian immigrant from Coney Island actually was Nas. Once your brain makes the connection, it\xe2\x80\x99s difficult to disassociate, even if the content of his lyrics (self-deprecating cornball humor) and favorite poetic device (punchlines laden with pop-culture references) don\xe2\x80\x99t resemble anything that Nas has released in the last 20 years. But it\xe2\x80\x99s ever-looming, especially for anyone intimately familiar with the Illmatic one\xe2\x80\x99s oeuvre.' b"In the years that followed, Droog dropped a couple EPs (the rock-obsessed Kinison and The Nicest) and a collaborative project with Wiki,\xc2\xa0What Happened to Fire? But as the first collection of songs in his short career packaged and marketed as an \xe2\x80\x9calbum,\xe2\x80\x9d his latest LP Packs feels like a graduation as it connects verses and beats from various collaborators to make a coherent statement. He taps comedian Anthony Jeselnik to provide radio-style interludes throughout; his dry, sardonic wit cements the generally absurdist tone of the LP. And while he\xe2\x80\x99s stacked the deck with features\xe2\x80\x94Heems, Danny Brown, Wiki, Edan, and Chris Crack all contribute verses\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s never overshadowed. No one would've ever confused Your Old Droog with Nas if the bars weren\xe2\x80\x99t hard." b'Packs uses beats from a handful of producers\xe2\x80\x94RTNC, 88-Keys, Edan, the Alchemist, and ID Labs\xe2\x80\x99 E. Dan.\xe2\x80\x94but the palette of sounds is relatively minimal. On the standout track \xe2\x80\x9cBangladesh,\xe2\x80\x9d Droog and RTNC freak an ill Bansuri loop over a simple boom-bap drum beat. Most of the productions are sparse, but colored by thoughtful flourishes: Harp strings, record scratches, distorted vocals and explosions, even a Frank Zappa sample, removed from the context of his posthumous bizarro opus Civilization Phaze III. He\xe2\x80\x99s riding a nostalgic sonic wave currently being surfed by NYC contemporaries Roc Marciano, Action Bronson, and Joey Bada$$, rappers doing their best to embody the spirit of New York hip-hop without getting stuck in its past.\xc2\xa0And if there\xe2\x80\x99s any underlying ethos of the city\xe2\x80\x99s hip-hop scene, it\xe2\x80\x99s the merit-based hierarchy that rewards lyrical skill above nearly all else, whether it be sex appeal, skin color, or \xe2\x80\x9cgangsta\xe2\x80\x9d status. The beats always take a backseat to the bars.' b'Droog\xe2\x80\x99s punchline-driven style evokes the vicious jabs wielded by Big L, were he less concerned with trapping and more into watching \xe2\x80\x9cSeinfeld.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s wholly unafraid to be corny; On \xe2\x80\x9cRapman\xe2\x80\x9d he plays the part of \xe2\x80\x9ca hero with a cape and a mixtape\xe2\x80\x9d with a straight face, earnestly out to save the rap game from whack rappers. \xe2\x80\x9cYo I\xe2\x80\x99m sick of sycophants who want to make their idols proud,\xe2\x80\x9d he declares. \xe2\x80\x9cI want my hero to hear me and shit his pants.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But much like his buddy Wiki, Droog venerates the art of rap storytelling, weaving colorful street tales of hood characters that make up his perspective of New York City. Each of the three verses on \xe2\x80\x9cYou Can Do It! (Give Up)\xe2\x80\x9d tells instantly recognizable stories of people with failed dreams of stardom: The hoop dreamer, the washed up model/actress, the struggle rapper. His tone is dry but empathetic, the hook evincing a perpetual motivational struggle, the drive to succeed (\xe2\x80\x9cYou can do it!\xe2\x80\x9d) competing with self-defeating loathing (\xe2\x80\x9cGive up!\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'And of all the characters in Droog\xe2\x80\x99s raps, New York looms the largest. His rhymes are full of borough references (Funkmaster Flex night, nubuck Timberlands, bodega loosies), and while he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t front as a gangster, he\xe2\x80\x99s unquestionably hood; when his first EP dropped in 2014 he told Rolling Stone\xc2\xa0he paid for the studio sessions with winnings from playing cee-lo. Packs\xc2\xa0is a record by, of, and for New York City, espousing the romantic notion it will never change, no matter how much the world does.'

column7: b'Ambient composer Sarah Davachi departs from her usual mix of instruments and electronics on an album that (mostly) focuses on the sound of single instruments.'
column8: b'The ambient music that Sarah Davachi makes is profoundly thermal. Thick and sonorous, it pushes\xc2\xa0up, welling up from silence, weaving harmoniums, string instruments, and electronics\xc2\xa0together in ways that feel indivisible, if not eternal. And even where her recordings bring slightly different pressures to bear\xe2\x80\x94the soft, rippling\xc2\xa0Barons Court, the sloshy, church-organ languor of\xc2\xa0Dominions\xe2\x80\x94the overall effect is similar: a benign hypnosis, the will to dissipate, a gentle weightlessness. To succumb to any entry in the Vancouver composer\xe2\x80\x99s growing discography is to wade idly into the surf at low tide, only to suddenly find yourself 15\xc2\xa0yards away from the shore.' b'Synthesizers\xe2\x80\x94Rolands, Buchlas, EMSs\xe2\x80\x94have been integral to Davachi\xe2\x80\x99s sound since\xc2\xa0The Untuning of the Sky, her 2013 debut. Now, in an aesthetic dare worthy of two successive flips of an Oblique Strategies card,\xc2\xa0All My Circles Run\xc2\xa0goes synth-free, with each of its five tracks (largely) centered on a separate instrument.' b"Circularity is embraced wholeheartedly here. \xe2\x80\x9cFor Voice\xe2\x80\x9d swirls an angelic multi-track chorus\xc2\xa0into a gorgeously smothering aria, as vocal iterations seize, then relinquish the foreground as if in a slow-motion round; the slow-drawn scrape that opens \xe2\x80\x9cFor Strings\xe2\x80\x9d yields to a braided, harmonized drone. After interlocking a frayed, reverberating series of guitar figures destined to disintegrate over time, \xe2\x80\x9cChanter\xe2\x80\x9d undercuts its own meditative drift with a two-note, interrogative counterpoint. \xe2\x80\x9cFor Piano\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94all aching, pecked tones, enervating whirr, and field-recorded backdrop pacing circuits\xe2\x80\x94recalls Sontag Shogun, a Brooklyn-based trio who commingle elements of classical and carefully-chosen samples into something mournfully beautiful. Even with the new focus,\xc2\xa0this version of Davachi isn't a fundamentally altered one\xe2\x80\x94her meditative warmth remains intact." b"The real shift is one of artistic precision and a sense of amplification. Instead of viewing a passing scene out the window, we're looking now at the world through a microscope. That's especially true on \xe2\x80\x9cFor Organ,\xe2\x80\x9d the\xc2\xa0album\xe2\x80\x99s true centerpiece. Kneading and pitch-shifting wobbly, revolving tones until only a ringing, hypnotic din remains, the song seems to crack itself open and flood with brilliant melodic light; it brings to mind, ironically, Matmos\xe2\x80\x99 synth-opus Supreme Balloon. On that record, Matmos temporarily set aside conceptual pranks to embrace the synthesizer's possibilities; the result was music achingly beautiful and crystalline, winking just slightly. With Circles,\xc2\xa0an insidious, sublime gambit that pays off handsomely, Davachi\xe2\x80\x99s particular asceticism achieves a similar effect by pulling in an alternate direction. Like Brian Eno at his solo best, it's the sort of ambience that doesn't flood, that hovers precariously somewhere between the conscious and the unconscious, barely-there and indisputably present."

column7: b'As an initiate of santer\xc3\xada, the Havana-born jazz singer is in tune with her religious and musical practices, as Cubafon\xc3\xada\xc2\xa0illuminates, pulling from genres within and adjacent to Cuban popular music.'
column8: b'At the top of her brow, underneath her headwrap, Daym\xc3\xa9 Arocena wears a small feather. She\xe2\x80\x99d received a message once from a saint telling her that it would guide her so that she\xe2\x80\x99d never lose her way. As an initiate of santer\xc3\xada, or Regla de Ocha, the Havana-born jazz singer is well in tune with both her religious and musical practices, which are inextricably tied. In her latest project, *Cubafon\xc3\xada, *Arocena illuminates those ties, as well as those that connect different genres within and adjacent to Cuban popular music.' b'After her 2015 debut full-length, *Nueva Era, *and follow-up EP, One Takes, the now-24-year-old took some time to tour. Along the way, she came to realize just how much she missed home, which in turn inspired her sophomore album. Where on her first album, the songs are mostly jazz records with strong Afro-Cuban undercurrents, on Cubafon\xc3\xada, it often tilts the other way too, so that a track might be a rumba or a bolero, but with a distinctly jazz bent. She also makes it a point this time to work almost entirely with Cuban musicians. Leading them, she sounds more confident than ever. The result is a vibrant, bold record that is, at its heart, a love letter to her home country.' b"True to her roots, Arocena opens the album with a chant to Eleggua, the opener of roads. Otherworldly voices pierce through Ethiojazz-y horns, as she belts salutations to the orisha. Highlighting the influence of different African traditions in Cuban music, she follows up \xe2\x80\x9cEleggua,\xe2\x80\x9d which is Yoruba (or Lucum\xc3\xad), with a rumba, which combines various West and Central African musical traditions. \xe2\x80\x9cLa Rumba Me Llamo Yo\xe2\x80\x9d is a lively rumba guaguanc\xc3\xb3 that tells the story of a woman whose mother warns her of a man she doesn't want near her. It ends in an all-out party: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you want them to give you?\xe2\x80\x9d the chorus asks in Spanish. \xe2\x80\x9cRumba, ven ven!\xe2\x80\x9d they answer. Daym\xc3\xa9, for her part, scats her way through a clatter of voices and percussion, coming out the other side unscathed and triumphant." b'Perhaps unsurprisingly, her orisha is Yemay\xc3\xa1, goddess of the sea. Arocena\xe2\x80\x99s voice, like her laughter, is wide and enveloping. She sings with a warm rasp reminiscent of Buika (as on \xe2\x80\x9cLo Que Fue\xe2\x80\x9d), an emotional breadth that recalls Aretha, and an unwavering willingness to lay herself bare. In the first of a three-song run of ballads, \xe2\x80\x9cC\xc3\xb3mo\xe2\x80\x9d is a smooth, \xe2\x80\x9980s-inspired pop song that sits somewhere between Sade and Selena. In a hazy swirl of jazz saxophone, violin tremolo, and twinkling chimes, the artist laments (in Spanish), \xe2\x80\x9cHow do I live with my solitude? How do I begin this end?\xe2\x80\x9d The very next song over, \xe2\x80\x9cTodo Por Amor,\xe2\x80\x9d she is in love again\xe2\x80\x94wholly, fearlessly, maybe a little foolishly. \xe2\x80\x9cEres tu mi salvation, todo por tu amor,\xe2\x80\x9d she practically bleeds. The song is a bolero but with echoes of bachata, underscoring again the fluidity between different Afro-Caribbean music forms. Finally, on \xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\x81ngel,\xe2\x80\x9d a slow, minimalist tango, Arocena\xe2\x80\x99s voice arcs and dips wordlessly, longing after something we cannot see.' b'As unafraid of pain or heartache as Daym\xc3\xa9 seems, so too is she unafraid of joy. \xe2\x80\x9cNegra Caridad\xe2\x80\x9d sounds like it could be the soundtrack to an old spaghetti western with elements of 1950s Benny Mor\xc3\xa9-era Cuban big band music and punchy vocals that recall La Lupe. Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cMambo Na\xe2\x80\x99 M\xc3\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d elides the spirit of mambo with New Orleans swing. Horns creak and chug; Daym\xc3\xa9 cranks her voice like a jack-in-the-box before crying, \xe2\x80\x9cMambo na\xe2\x80\x99 m\xc3\xa1!\xe2\x80\x9d Besides being a good time, it\xe2\x80\x99s also a reminder that Havana and New Orleans are colloquial sister cities with overlapping musical pasts and creole histories.' b'The album feels warm and full, thanks in part to the production. The texture changes, though, on the very last song\xe2\x80\x94the stripped down \xe2\x80\x9cValentine.\xe2\x80\x9d The track is a chang\xc3\xbc\xc3\xad, a folksy song from Guant\xc3\xa1namo, influenced by nearby Haiti. Over the scrape of a g\xc3\xbcira and a smattering of acoustic instruments (marimbula, tr\xc3\xa8s, clarinet), the daughter of Yemay\xc3\xa1 coos, \xe2\x80\x9cMon valentin, mi valentine, my valentine/In a moment, you gave freedom to my heart.\xe2\x80\x9d There is a sense of gratitude in her delivery\xe2\x80\x94and perhaps some relief\xe2\x80\x94to have wandered but finally returned to where her heart is freest, to her valentine, to Cuba.'

column7: b"The band's sixth LP demands more seats at the table. It's a powerful folk concept album from a Nuyorican runaway who grew up obsessed with West Side Story before being liberated by Bikini Kill."
column8: b'Alynda Lee Segarra, the creative force behind Hurray for the Riff Raff, spent her formative years crisscrossing the country on greyhounds and freight trains. She climbed from the streets of New Orleans to the airwaves of NPR with a washboard and a banjo, a Horatio Alger narrative for the Americana set. Her last LP, Small Town Heroes, felt like a thesis presentation from a student of American folk music. She\xe2\x80\x99d spent years studying the form and its practitioners, a product of a community that helped lift her from street corners and coffee shops to international tours and a record contract. While searching for herself, she also imitated others, living inside classic folk, roots, and country songs while shaping her own powerful voice.' b"In that sense,\xc2\xa0The Navigator represents a departure\xe2\x80\x94she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t abandoned those sounds, rather she\xe2\x80\x99s graduated to something singular. It's roots music for the immigrant ID, a folk concept album from a Nuyorican runaway who grew up obsessed with West Side Story before being liberated by Bikini Kill. They lay bare the conceit in the album\xe2\x80\x99s Playbill-themed packaging: The songs are presented in two \xe2\x80\x9cActs\xe2\x80\x9d that\xc2\xa0follow her alter ego, a Puerto Rican street kid named Navita Milagros Negr\xc3\xb3n, who visits a bruja at the end of Act I looking for an escape from the oppressive confines of her city. When she wakes up from the bruja\xe2\x80\x99s spell at the start of Act II (40 years later), everything she knew is gone, and she begins to realize what she\xe2\x80\x99s lost." b'Navi is a character, but she\xe2\x80\x99s also very much Segarra. She puts years of telling others\xe2\x80\x99 stories to work telling her own; in \xe2\x80\x9cLiving in the City,\xe2\x80\x9d she sets the scene for the first act, a snapshot of life in the PJs for a young girl. Navi brushes off casual harassment with a shrug, watches friends self-destruct with drug abuse, and sneaks into stairwells for fleeting moments of intimacy. The city is a thinly veiled but unnamed stand-in for New York, a city and culture Segarra fled from the day after she turned 17.' b'The Navigator is ostensibly a rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll record, but it expands Segarra\xe2\x80\x99s palette beyond the folk/country/blues lane she\xe2\x80\x99s thus far occupied. Her boozy, morning-after croon is still gorgeous, but now there\xe2\x80\x99s elements of Puerto Rican bomba and salsa, son cubano, doo-wop, and even the spoken-word poetry of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe she haunted as a teen. Her band has gone through a variety of lineups, but this one feels like a clean slate. Her longtime creative partners Sam Doores and Yosi Perlstein are nowhere to be seen\xe2\x80\x94in their place, she\xe2\x80\x99s recruited five\xc2\xa0hand percussionists, a trio of doo-wop backup singers, and Yva Las Vegass, a Venezuelan folkie from Brooklyn. She even samples the ghost of Pedro Pietri, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe co-founder whose \xe2\x80\x9cPuerto Rican Obituary\xe2\x80\x9d serves as a bridge between the two movements of her piano ballad showstopper, \xe2\x80\x9cPa\xe2\x80\x99lante.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'In the few moments when she strips away the beer-soaked barroom blues of \xe2\x80\x9cLife to Save\xe2\x80\x9d and the acoustic spiritual \xe2\x80\x9cHalfway There,\xe2\x80\x9d she almost sounds like her old self. But when the bongos break in on \xe2\x80\x9cRican Beach,\xe2\x80\x9d and she begins to list \xe2\x80\x9cour\xe2\x80\x9d things that \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x9d stole\xe2\x80\x94language, names, neighbors, streets\xe2\x80\x94 she\xe2\x80\x99s in a different place. Like many Latin-Americans, she\xe2\x80\x99s somewhere in the middle, colored not just by her ancestors but the stimuli of the diaspora: The places she\xe2\x80\x99s seen, the people she\xe2\x80\x99s met, the music she\xe2\x80\x99s loved. The Navigator, which reclaims folk\xe2\x80\x99s protest roots and marries them to the sounds of the Caribbean, is a statement of that identity.' b"Segarra speaks to a broader reconciliation with the assimilation engrained in the American Dream, an acknowledgment of the limited perspective that comes with the white history taught in schools. She never learned Spanish and admits that for years she carried an inexplicable shame of her heritage.\xc2\xa0While writing this record, she pored through the Fania records back catalog, fell in love with the Puerto Rican poets Julia de Burgos and Pedro Pietri, and learned the history of the Young Lords and their newspaper, Pa\xe2\x80\x99lante. Like Navi, the city Segarra returned to after traversing the country was unrecognizable from the city she left\xe2\x80\x94the culture she once took for granted now fading away. When the \xe2\x80\x9cFourteen Floors\xe2\x80\x9d of her old project building come crashing down, she wistfully remembers her father\xe2\x80\x99s tales of the long journey from Puerto Rico, a haunting whisper of \xe2\x80\x9cit took a million years.\xe2\x80\x9d It's the universal dilemma of the displaced\xe2\x80\x94where do you go when you can\xe2\x80\x99t go home again?" b'Segarra\xe2\x80\x99s first big foray into activism came with the feminist murder ballad \xe2\x80\x9cThe Body Electric,\xe2\x80\x9d the centerpiece of Small Town Heroes; she would later re-release her 2013 Trayvon Martin tribute \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody Knows\xe2\x80\x9d as part of the Our First 100 Days project. But the most declarative statement she\xe2\x80\x99s made yet came in the form of a scathing blog post admonishing the silence of her peers in the folk scene, near demanding that they use their art to join the struggle of their black and brown brothers and sisters whose bodies have been on the front lines of a civil rights movement that never really ended.' b'The Navigator\xe2\x80\x99s activist bent leans mostly towards systemic symptoms of colonization and gentrification, issues at the heart of both Navi and Segarra\xe2\x80\x99s story. If the call to arms of \xe2\x80\x9cPa\xe2\x80\x99lante\xe2\x80\x9d is the spiritual heart of the album, \xe2\x80\x9cRican Beach\xe2\x80\x9d is an angry protest, a condemnation of both the villainous and the apathetic: \xe2\x80\x9cNow all the politicians/They just squawk their mouths/They say \xe2\x80\x98We\xe2\x80\x99ll build a wall to keep them out\xe2\x80\x99/And all the poets were dying of a silence disease/So it happened quickly and with much ease.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'La gente del barrio has always had a voice, but too often it has been silenced. Not unlike Solange did on her stunning 2016 opus, Segarra uses The Navigator to demand more seats at the table for those voices that have always existed, but simply went unheard. And as she rallies the troops for the fight to come on \xe2\x80\x9cPa\xe2\x80\x99lante,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFrom El Barrio to Arecibo\xe2\x80\xa6from Marble Hill to the ghost of Emmett Till\xe2\x80\x9d she unites the struggle of all the survivors of white supremacy, and urges them onward, together.'

column7: b'With their unvarnished style, the music of Detroit electronic duo Drexciya was proudly DIY. On their newly reissued 2002 album, they turned their attention from the sea towards the cosmos.'
column8: b'Over the decade-long stretch between 1992-2002 that Gerald Donald and James Stinson released electronic music as Drexciya, water was a constant fixation. It was as if the ocean was a third member of the band. Their name described the group\xe2\x80\x99s vision of an underwater society built by the children of pregnant slaves thrown overboard during the Middle Passage. EPs and albums bore titles like Neptune\xe2\x80\x99s Lair, Hydro Doorways, and Digital Tsunami, and were littered with clues that outlined a byzantine afrofuturist mythology. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are only two wavejumpers in existence today,\xe2\x80\x9d they creepily intoned on 1995\xe2\x80\x99s riveting, white-knuckled \xe2\x80\x9cWavejumper,\xe2\x80\x9d positioning themselves as the last representatives of a lost tribe. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of things that come through water, all these different molecules\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the way I see the music we do,\xe2\x80\x9d Stinson once said in a rare interview. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so endless.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Each of Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s records\xe2\x80\x94whether collaborating or going solo as Abstract Thought, Lab Rat XL, or Transllusion\xe2\x80\x94had deeply considered conceptual and philosophical premises. Thankfully, Drexciya were never too forthcoming, offering far more questions than answers. Their final album, 2002\xe2\x80\x99s newly-reissued Grava 4, continued to engage in this complex game of world building. It was originally released during a massively prolific 18-month period between 2001-2003, when the duo used various aliases to release seven albums, which they dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cstorms,\xe2\x80\x9d a set of tantalizingly disparate works that hinted at strange new developments in the Drexciyan fable.' b'Grava 4 is an album of stark, brooding introspection, alternately expansive and oblique. It sees Drexciya turning their attention towards the cosmos, as song titles shifted from aquatic themes to \xe2\x80\x9c700 Million Light Years From Earth,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDrexciyan Star Chamber,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAstronomical Guidepost.\xe2\x80\x9d A web of constellations was drawn on the cover. In the press surrounding Grava 4, the group claimed to have \xe2\x80\x9cfinally discovered Utopia (Drexciya Home Universe),\xe2\x80\x9d and they allegedly named a star after themselves on this website.' b'Opener \xe2\x80\x9cCascading Celestial Giants\xe2\x80\x9d casts a solemn, slow-motion tone. A churning rhythm sets a sluggish pace, while majestic choral pads suggest a reckoning with the infinite. (Close your eyes, and it\xe2\x80\x99s not hard to imagine a pair of lonely travelers in a small spaceship drifting into the vast unknown.) This is followed up by the languid thrums of \xe2\x80\x9cPowers of the Deep,\xe2\x80\x9d which cruises at a melancholy clip and is ornamented with slithering, pinging effects. Though the group\xe2\x80\x99s rugged electro drum programming remains intact, everything else sits back in a moody reserve, trading their terrestrial aggressions for something more contemplative.' b'Throughout their career, Drexciya could be by turns nimble, slamming, or willfully obtuse. The one constant was their live chemistry in the studio. Their records feel proudly DIY, with a raw, unvarnished sheen and track structures that could confound all but the most dedicated DJs. While Grava 4 skips the two-minute pipe bombs of their earlier EPs, the arrangements maintain this proud humanity. The gradual congealing and playful dubbing of \xe2\x80\x9cDrexciyan Star Chamber\xe2\x80\x9d feels too spontaneous to be the work of careful computer programming, with a sense of discovery and frenetic focus giving life to its spacious funk. \xe2\x80\x9cGravity Waves,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, has the tense, wiry urgency of a late-night jam.' b'Grava 4 is a grower, to be sure. There are no instant-classic, earworming anthems on the level of \xe2\x80\x9cAndreaen Sand Dunes\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Sea\xe2\x80\x9d here (though the Kraftwerk-saluting \xe2\x80\x9c700 Million Light Years From Earth\xe2\x80\x9d comes close). Nor does the vulnerability Stinson showcased a year prior under the Other People Place moniker rub off on the duo. But Grava 4 opens up to those who give it space and attention.' b'Drexciya were pushing to the outer reaches of their sound on this album, and by the year\xe2\x80\x99s end, Stinson would pass from heart complications. In this context, their final deluge of material was perhaps an attempt to sum up the totality of their vision before time ran out. (Stinson had spent his last\xc2\xa0months in Georgia \xe2\x80\x9cfor health reasons,\xe2\x80\x9d and fans have interpreted his \xe2\x80\x9902 Transllusion title L.I.F.E. to stand for \xe2\x80\x9clife is fast ending.\xe2\x80\x9d) Album closer \xe2\x80\x9cAstronomical Guidepost\xe2\x80\x9d rides a bit of slippery funk, suggesting that space perhaps isn\xe2\x80\x99t so different from the aquatic depths they spent 10 years exploring. Halfway through the track, the music drops out and a metallic voice comes in: \xe2\x80\x9cUse the star chart to fix a celestial navigation point. From there you should be able to plug your path back to Earth using rudimentary astronomical guideposts.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a poignant bit of sci-fi ephemera. At the end of Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s journey, and of Stinson\xe2\x80\x99s life, they\xe2\x80\x99re leading listeners back home to begin the quest all over again.'

column7: b'Brooklyn trio Parlor Walls subvert\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0dichotomy between rock and jazz. They\xc2\xa0approach aggression with an agility that\xe2\x80\x99s rare no matter the\xc2\xa0style of music.'
column8: b'When the Bad Plus made their major label debut with These Are the Vistas in 2003, they generated heaps of praise for their supposed ability to capture a rock band\xe2\x80\x99s energy in a jazz trio format. But their hamfisted mistranslations of \xe2\x80\x9cSmells Like Teen Spirit\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIron Man\xe2\x80\x9d were hardly revelatory. Between, say, the Lounge Lizards in the late \xe2\x80\x9980s up through to Neneh Cherry\xe2\x80\x99s 2012 collaboration with Swedish-Norweigan saxophonist Mats Gustafsson\xe2\x80\x99s trio the Thing, you can point to dozens of artists who have subverted or even nullified the dichotomy between jazz and rock. Brooklyn trio Parlor Walls sit in this\xc2\xa0lineage.' b'On their first full-length, Opposites, Parlor Walls convey urgency with a forcefulness that\xe2\x80\x99s both convincing and sophisticated. Like the Thing, core members Alyse Lamb and Chris Mulligan use repetitive phrases that speak directly to the gut\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9criffs,\xe2\x80\x9d for all intents and purposes. But where the Thing\xe2\x80\x99s meaty sound verges on street tough (in a good way), Parlor Walls approach aggression with an agility that\xe2\x80\x99s rare no matter what style of music you look at.' b'Frontwoman Lamb\xe2\x80\x99s guitar sounds as if it was run through a classic Fender Twin-style amp, a reverb-heavy tone that instantly evokes early rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll and rockabilly/surf twang. But the makeup of her chords has little in common with those forms. Even as Lamb slashes and wails with her guitar strings, her playing hovers at the music\xe2\x80\x99s outer edges, creating a cavernous ambience for Mulligan\xe2\x80\x99s synth parts, which essentially perform the same function as a bass guitar. Mulligan\xe2\x80\x99s drums tumble with the steady clang of a cement mixer\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re loud, assertive, and colorful\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s his synth parts that actually drive the music and sustain its foundational groove. Meanwhile, nimble saxophonist Kate Mohanty plays a role akin to a rock guitarist\xe2\x80\x99s, supplying the most hummable licks in tandem with Mulligan\xe2\x80\x99s synth lines.' b'Likeminded groups like Denmark\xe2\x80\x99s Selvhenter and England\xe2\x80\x99s Get the Blessing have shown over the past decade that it\xe2\x80\x99s still possible to uncover new shades of darkness by using jazz instrumentation in unconventional ways. Parlor Walls follow suit with Opposites and, in the process, lend new definition to the term \xe2\x80\x9cheavy.\xe2\x80\x9d Even without vocals, the album\xe2\x80\x99s mood would stand out, but Lamb\xe2\x80\x99s singing adds weight to the tension and intensifies what the other instruments are doing like a lit match held inches away from a puddle of gasoline.' b'A multifaceted vocalist, Lamb tends to be highly tuneful and dextrous. Still, her phrasing lands somewhere between taunting and alarm, and there are moments where she channels the spitfire edge of riot grrrl-era punk. She matches her vocals with appropriately complex lyrics that can be read a number of ways. Her verses percolate with obvious references to emotional ruptures, but she stops short of spelling them out. Her images pack a punch nevertheless:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCover me/To my knees/Keep me warm/Put me at ease/But you only feed me when you\xe2\x80\x99re full,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on \xe2\x80\x9cCover Me.\xe2\x80\x9d Imagine having amnesia and speaking to someone who, you infer, has a bone to pick with you. At times, that\xe2\x80\x99s what this album feels like.' b'Meanwhile, the guitar and sax flit like moving shadows cast by strobing red and blue siren lights outside your window. All of these elements combine to create a sinister vibe that rides the line between pleasant and imposing. On \xe2\x80\x9cPlay Opposites,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Lamb asks, \xe2\x80\x9cHey, why don\xe2\x80\x99t we go/And play opposites?/Burn it to the ground/There ain\xe2\x80\x99t nothing left.\xe2\x80\x9d And on \xe2\x80\x9cHesitation,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, \xe2\x80\x9cCome through, I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave my light on/Rearrange my shapes/We can imagine partition/Then see it all fall away.\xe2\x80\x9d Lamb probably wasn\xe2\x80\x99t referring to the supposed \xe2\x80\x9cpartition\xe2\x80\x9d between jazz and rock, but it\xe2\x80\x99s just as well that we let it fall away. Other bands have given us reason to do the same for years, but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make Opposites any less extraordinary.'

column7: b'Michael Silver of CFCF teams with pianist Jean-Michel Blais on a sometimes-gorgeous collection of ambient pieces.'
column8: b'Montreal\xe2\x80\x99s Michael Silver maintains an exhausting workload as CFCF. In 2015 alone, he dropped two albums, a Blowing Up the Workshop mix of original material, and an EP. Equally impressive is how Silver strikes\xe2\x80\x94and maintains\xe2\x80\x94a careful balance between charming electronic music and sounds we otherwise look down on: lite-jazz, adult contemporary, Windham Hill-esque new age. In an appreciation of CFCF last year, the New York Times sussed Silver\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic as where \xe2\x80\x9cuncool become[s] cool\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdefiantly corny.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"That balancing act continues into the present with Cascades, Silver\xe2\x80\x99s collaboration with newcomer and fellow Canadian, pianist Jean-Michel Blais. Together, they move into some new genre terrain to mixed results. Blais only just released his debut album last year, but he's\xc2\xa0been making minimalist piano music on his own for two decades while teaching music by day. An album featuring\xc2\xa0piano and electronics is generally an austere exercise, as the resonance between piano keys provides the space in which best to insert electronic washes\xe2\x80\x94see Fennesz and Sakamoto or, more recently, Bing & Ruth.\xc2\xa0This five-track EP finds Silver and Blais\xc2\xa0warily feeling one another other out and then synchronizing to exalted effect by the record's end." b"They open with \xe2\x80\x9cHasselblad 1,\xe2\x80\x9d a restrained piece that showcases Blais\xe2\x80\x99 ability to expand the melodic lines with eloquence, leaving just a few patches of space for Silver to dab in with additional color. It\xe2\x80\x99s lovely, but it feels like they're establishing their respective spaces rather than moving as a single unit. On \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Mirrors,\xe2\x80\x9d Blais hammers a repetitive piano line redolent of Philip Glass, finding new accents and rhythms in it, steadily adding to the theme in the upper and lower registers. Outside of some atmospheric moments, you'd\xc2\xa0be hard-pressed to pinpoint which sounds belong to Silver, as he allows Blais and his piano to dominate.
