Silver\xe2\x80\x99s synths swell and find more space on the gentle \xe2\x80\x9cSpirit.\xe2\x80\x9d At times it\xe2\x80\x99s reminiscent of Boards of Canada, but Blais deftly nudges the piece away from such a tangible aesthetic." b"By this point, they're clicking, and the record has successfully outlined its parameters. But the delicate mix of sounds is derailed by \xe2\x80\x9cHypocrite,\xe2\x80\x9d wherein the duo edge into questionable territory. A rolling melody from Blais provides the drama for the piece. But when Silver enters, it\xe2\x80\x99s with his synths set to \xe2\x80\x9cEDM.\xe2\x80\x9d In this setting, the drama of Blais\xe2\x80\x99 piano pushes the track to the brink of being \xe2\x80\x9cbig tent,\xe2\x80\x9d as if the Piano Guys got a makeover by OWSLA." b'They remedy the situation with Cascades\xe2\x80\x99s longest piece, a stunning rendition of John Cage\xe2\x80\x99s 1948 piece, \xe2\x80\x9cIn a Landscape.\xe2\x80\x9d For those more familiar with Cage\xe2\x80\x99s later work, which embraces silence, dissonance, and chance operations, \xe2\x80\x9cLandscape\xe2\x80\x9d is a melodic composition clearly indebted to ambient godfather Erik Satie. On this version, Blais\xe2\x80\x99 piano moves at a stately pace as Silver adds flickering electronics and a bit of radio chatter in the background (perhaps a sly nod to Cage\xe2\x80\x99s shortwave radio piece, \xe2\x80\x9cImaginary Landscape\xe2\x80\x9d?). Four minutes in, marimba and chimes ripple and synthesized strings quiver to life and it evokes a rolling pastoral scene\xc2\xa0the moment the sunlight lands upon it just so, so that every tree and hill on the horizon seems to glow golden. For all of the uneven and uncertain moments of Cascades, it ends on a very high note, and \xe2\x80\x9cLandscape\xe2\x80\x9d is one of the most unequivocally gorgeous covers imaginable.'

column7: b'For Salutations, Conor Oberst rearranged songs from 2016\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Ruminations\xc2\xa0with a full band and shuffled, expanded tracklist.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0one of his\xc2\xa0most demanding albums, and\xc2\xa0also one of his least ambitious.'
column8: b'Last year\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0*Ruminations *was like no Conor Oberst album before it, and hopefully, none to come. Performed entirely solo, released with little\xc2\xa0fanfare and bearing a distressing, cabin-fever ambience, it offered the\xc2\xa0first and final word on a once-unspeakably rough time in his life. Ruminations\xc2\xa0was Oberst\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0strongest record in years, but no one would want him to make it a second time. Less than six months later,\xc2\xa0Salutations is an even more curious move.\xc2\xa0Oberst re-recorded all 10\xc2\xa0songs with a full band and a host of guests, added seven new ones and hit shuffle\xe2\x80\x94a decision that drags\xc2\xa0*Salutations *down\xc2\xa0and bring its predecessor along with it.' b'After a series of lesser-loved guises\xe2\x80\x94inscrutable mystic, folk-rock yeoman\xe2\x80\x94Oberst has found a more interesting and sustainable point of view. A kind way of putting it would be \xe2\x80\x9cworld-weary raconteur.\xe2\x80\x9d Perhaps a more accurate way would be \xe2\x80\x9ckind of an asshole.\xe2\x80\x9d The prospect of hearing another dude do this for about 70 minutes is a hard sell at a time when Father John Misty, Drake, Mark Kozelek,\xc2\xa0and Future have released approximately 9 hours of music in the past year that wearily postulates from a position of privilege on their dissatisfaction with sex, drugs, and everyone outside of their immediate circle. The difference here is that Oberst only hops on a pedestal for the purpose of knocking himself down.' b'In his post-poster boy phase, Oberst is no longer trapped by expectation or myth; he\xc2\xa0can play his past personas against each other. \xe2\x80\x9cAfterthought\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cOverdue\xe2\x80\x9d respectively caricature the roles he played on his 2005 diptych of protest song\xc2\xa0and smack-addled narcolepsy, presenting the\xc2\xa0narrator as someone for whom extreme politics and heroin are just another fix. On the opener\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cToo Late to Fixate,\xe2\x80\x9d he half-asses his way through transcendental meditation only to find serenity in the luxuries of a hotel feather bed and a mistress to lay upon it: \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind the money/It beats betting on sports/And though it might get expensive/It\xe2\x80\x99s cheaper than divorce.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'These aren\xe2\x80\x99t new topics for Oberst, but he\xe2\x80\x99s never been this flat-out funny, providing a necessarily salty and bitter edge as he reverts back to the tasteful roots rock that has defined his past decade. This approach reflects\xc2\xa0of Oberst\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0status as a Nonesuch recording artist who hangs out with the Felice Brothers and Dawes, but it also shows the dividing line between \xe2\x80\x9ccrowd pleaser\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccult builder.\xe2\x80\x9d Though *Ruminations *was the inverse of the fire-breathing agitpop of his band\xc2\xa0Desaparecidos\xe2\x80\x99 2015 LP\xc2\xa0*Payola**, *both serve as proof of the extreme measures necessary to steer Oberst away from the middle of the road\xe2\x80\x94where *Salutations *spends well over an hour.' b'The most rewarding records of this length carry a mutual assumption of risk. Listeners will indulge the occasional faceplant as long as the artist is making an attempt to reach new personal heights. Though\xc2\xa0Salutations is one of Oberst\xe2\x80\x99s most demanding albums, it\xe2\x80\x99s also one of his least ambitious, even\xc2\xa0before taking these new arrangements into account*.*\xc2\xa0The righteous indignation of \xe2\x80\x9cYou All Loved Him Once\xe2\x80\x9d was devastating when it was Oberst alone; recast now as \xe2\x80\x9cOberst and the Felice Brothers against the world,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s less believable. \xe2\x80\x9cCounting Sheep\xe2\x80\x9d dulls its edge in the most literal way imaginable: On *Ruminations, *Oberst mused on the death of\xc2\xa0two local youths, hoping it was both slow and painful while censoring out their names. He actually reveals them here, but changes the lyric to \xe2\x80\x9cHope it was quick, hope it was peaceful.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Even if *Ruminations *is now rendered a collection of demos, it was unquestionably an *album\xe2\x80\x94*thematically and sonically coherent and perfectly sequenced.\xc2\xa0Salutations muddles that. On\xc2\xa0Ruminations,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cYou All Loved Him Once\xe2\x80\x9d was the penultimate track, settling scores. And it led\xc2\xa0into\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cTill St. Dymphna Kicks Us Out,\xe2\x80\x9d which\xc2\xa0implored those who stuck around\xc2\xa0to\xc2\xa0forget old memories and make new ones. The latter is now stuck right in the middle of Salutations\xc2\xa0and this diminishes the song\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0effect. (Just imagine\xc2\xa0if Oberst had lost his nerve in 2005 and recorded the caustic electro-pop of Digital Ash\xc2\xa0as folk songs and slapped them onto I\xe2\x80\x99m Wide Awake, It\xe2\x80\x99s Morning**.)\xc2\xa0From a songwriting standpoint, Salutations is an undeniable triumph\xe2\x80\x94for people who haven\xe2\x80\x99t heard Ruminations yet. If they exist, I envy them.'

column7: b'With\xc2\xa0Semper Femina, Laura Marling\xc2\xa0uses a\xc2\xa0broad study of femininity to explore complex\xc2\xa0relationships between women.\xc2\xa0The\xc2\xa0album is filled with beautiful observations on the psychology of friendship.'
column8: b'Laura Marling has used conversations surrounding her sixth album,\xc2\xa0Semper Femina,\xc2\xa0to disavow music of \xe2\x80\x9cinnocent creativity\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the kind that\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cnot pointed, not political,\xe2\x80\x9d she says. It\xe2\x80\x99s an intuitive concept\xc2\xa0that sounds relatively\xc2\xa0novel coming from this folk songwriter. In the late 2000s, Marling emerged from London\xe2\x80\x99s Communion scene, a coterie of authenticity fetishists who wore wounded\xc2\xa0hearts on tweed-jacket sleeves. Marling was herself\xc2\xa0embroiled in \xe2\x80\x9cinnocent creativity,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0but she released masterpieces of the form. Her identity evolved from romantic pragmatist to underdog sage to mystic troubadour; her voice became distant and supercilious, baring just enough soul to reassure you one was there. Radical honesty is now common among\xc2\xa0young songwriters, but Marling can harbor guilt, fear, arrogance, deceit, or triumph\xc2\xa0in a bottomless deadpan. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to invest in her evasion.' b'Semper Femina\xe2\x80\x94Latin for \xe2\x80\x9cAlways a woman,\xe2\x80\x9d and taken from Virgil\xe2\x80\x99s epic poem The Aeneid\xe2\x80\x94is no revolutionary screed. But the album\xe2\x80\x99s characters, who are all given female pronouns, tiptoe\xc2\xa0outside Marling\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0world of heartbreak and personal redemption. There are signs of\xc2\xa0a broader project at play. With lyrics about\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cwarning signs\xe2\x80\x9d that we\xe2\x80\x99re conditioned to \xe2\x80\x9cignore diligently,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNext Time\xe2\x80\x9d appears to preach\xc2\xa0a maternal fondness for Mother Earth: \xe2\x80\x9cI can no longer close my eyes/While the world around me dies/At the hands/Of folks/Like me,\xe2\x80\x9d she trills. While her composure hasn\xe2\x80\x99t wavered since 2010\xe2\x80\x99s I Speak Because I Can, there\xe2\x80\x99s something new\xc2\xa0in songs like \xe2\x80\x9cNext Time\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Pass Me By.\xe2\x80\x9d Both remind me, in their reserve and understated melancholy, of mid-career Elliott Smith\xe2\x80\x94a chaotic and vulnerable individual anchored by a preternatural understanding of melody, using compassion to navigate horror.' b'As\xc2\xa0Semper Femina\xe2\x80\x99s questions deepen, answers\xc2\xa0rarely materialize. The gorgeous \xe2\x80\x9cAlways This Way\xe2\x80\x9d mourns a friendship cut short in unexplained circumstances. As sorrow\xc2\xa0triggers a bout of soul-searching, Marling confesses, \xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-five years and nothing to show for it/Nothing of any weight.\xe2\x80\x9d Over pastoral guitar twirls, the narrator soothes herself with a mantra, though not a satisfying one: \xe2\x80\x9cAt least I can say/That my debts have been paid.\xe2\x80\x9d The conciliation feels a little flimsy.\xc2\xa0A songwriter as meticulous as Marling doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to innovate, but she\xe2\x80\x99s most intriguing on songs like \xe2\x80\x9cSoothing,\xe2\x80\x9d when her cryptic lyrics snowball without scrambling for\xc2\xa0narrative closure.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cSoothing\xe2\x80\x9d is also the record\xe2\x80\x99s only really\xc2\xa0ambitious composition. Interlocked basslines quarrel under Marling\xe2\x80\x99s magisterial tones. Its image of a \xe2\x80\x9ccreepy conjurer\xe2\x80\x9d whose \xe2\x80\x9chands are in the door\xe2\x80\x9d hangs elegantly unresolved. She sings\xc2\xa0her sendoff\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI banish you with love\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94through luscious minor notes that, instead of sugarcoating the rejection, transfigure it. Banishment becomes liberation, a generous act. The philosophy\xc2\xa0develops on \xe2\x80\x9cWild Fire\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cThere no sweeter deed may be,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, \xe2\x80\x9cThan to love something enough/To want to help it get free.\xe2\x80\x9d As is Marling\xe2\x80\x99s trademark, the line blossoms\xc2\xa0as both a revelation\xe2\x80\x94the narrator takes pleasure in her wisdom\xe2\x80\x94and a reprimand to a clingy partner, someone unsuited\xc2\xa0to her passionate independence.' b'Where Semper Femina might have sketched a feminist utopia, Marling instead uses her broad study of femininity to explore flawed, sometimes devastating relationships between women. The full Virgil quote\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA woman is an ever fickle and changeable thing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94could seem patronizing, but Marling quotes it fondly on \xe2\x80\x9cNouel.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0She is tirelessly\xc2\xa0nuanced, and the result is an album filled with beautiful, searching observations on the psychology of friendship and occasionally romance. \xe2\x80\x9cI think your mama\xe2\x80\x99s kinda sad/And your papa\xe2\x80\x99s kinda mean,\xe2\x80\x9d she sneers on \xe2\x80\x9cWild Fire.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI can take that all away/You can stop playing it out on me.\xe2\x80\x9d Marling\xc2\xa0proposes here that love is\xc2\xa0a defense\xc2\xa0against our parents\xe2\x80\x99 pathologies\xe2\x80\x94yet she acknowledges that the traits\xc2\xa0we inherit are\xc2\xa0stubborn, determined to sneak in\xc2\xa0and mangle beauty. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fitting parallel to how Marling\xc2\xa0wrestles with, and masters, her ever more malleable folk idiom.'

column7: b"The Buzzcocks' newly reissued demo Time's Up is an invaluable document of punk snarls and yelps. Likewise, the more polished\xc2\xa0Spiral* Scratch* was at least as important to punk as the Sex Pistols\xe2\x80\x99 rise."
column8: b'In 1981, with disco medleys of former pop hits like \xe2\x80\x9cStars on 45\xe2\x80\x9d climbing the charts around the world, a cluster of British punk rockers recorded their own medley of old favorites. The Friendly Hopefuls\xe2\x80\x99 Tribute to the Punks of \xe2\x80\x9976\xc2\xa0begins with the standard looped clap track and a slick, professional-sounding chorus singing: \xe2\x80\x9cHey hey/Remember that day/In 1976/When the music scene was boring/Until along came\xe2\x80\x94this!\xe2\x80\x9d And the guitar riff from the Buzzcocks\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cBoredom\xe2\x80\x9d kicks in.' b'*Spiral Scratch\xe2\x80\x94*the four-song debut EP on which \xe2\x80\x9cBoredom\xe2\x80\x9d appeared\xe2\x80\x94was a revelation. British punk rock was brand new at that point: when Spiral Scratch\xc2\xa0was released on January 29, 1977, the Sex Pistols\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cAnarchy in the U.K.\xe2\x80\x9d was barely two months old, the Damned, the Vibrators, and the Stranglers had some singles out, and that was it. All those bands were signed to at-least-sort-of-legitimate record labels. Meanwhile, the Buzzcocks scraped together the funds to have 1000 copies of Spiral Scratch pressed themselves, and called their otherwise nonexistent label New Hormones.' b'The masterminds behind the band at that point\xe2\x80\x94singer/guitarist Howard Devoto and guitarist Pete Shelley\xe2\x80\x94weren\xe2\x80\x99t Londoners like the earliest wave of UK punks. They were from unfashionable Manchester, a couple of hours\xe2\x80\x99 train ride north. In the fall of 1975, Devoto and Shelley read about the Sex Pistols, traveled down to London to see them, and came back inspired to start a band of their own. The Buzzcocks\xe2\x80\x99 first complete set was opening for the second of two legendary Pistols shows in Manchester during the summer of 1976.' b'*Time\xe2\x80\x99s Up\xe2\x80\x94*initially a bootleg in 1978, and officially released in 1991\xe2\x80\x94is an invaluable document. It\'s the demo Buzzcocks recorded on October 18, 1976\xe2\x80\x94all snarls, yelps, and distortion, while also sounding entirely joyful. They revel in rock bands\xe2\x80\x99 newly-won right to present themselves as mean and aggressive and to say "fuck" out loud. Devoto sings as if Johnny Rotten is the only other vocalist he\xe2\x80\x99s ever heard, and always seems about to break into giggles. \xe2\x80\x9cYou tear me up, you bloody swine!\xe2\x80\x9d he yells with adenoidal delight. \xe2\x80\x9cOrgasm Addict,\xe2\x80\x9d which they\xe2\x80\x99d re-record as a single a year later, isn\xe2\x80\x99t quite fully formed yet, but Devoto\xe2\x80\x99s rhymes about stained jeans, as well as his whining gasps, were genuinely transgressive for their moment.' b'The band is still finding its feet on *Time\xe2\x80\x99s Up, *especially\xc2\xa0as\xc2\xa0teenage drummer John Maher slowed down the tempo every time he attempted to play a fill. Still, they worked out how to vigorously\xc2\xa0shove their songs forward. The two covers that were part of their live set at the time revealed a bit about where Buzzcocks were coming from: A sped-up version of the Troggs\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cI Can\xe2\x80\x99t Control Myself\xe2\x80\x9d anticipates the love of popcraft that would shortly surface in their own songs and a heavily rewritten take on Captain Beefheart\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI Love You, You Big Dummy\xe2\x80\x9d (which Devoto would take with him to his subsequent band Magazine) hints at the odder, artier side of their later records.' b'Two months after the Time\xe2\x80\x99s Up demos, they re-recorded four of those songs with producer Martin Hannett as Spiral Scratch. A few more weeks of practice had done wonders for the Buzzcocks\xe2\x80\x99 sound: now they were fast, strong and acrobatically tight. They powered through \xe2\x80\x9cBreakdown\xe2\x80\x9d in two minutes flat\xc2\xa0and started to sound more like themselves than like the Pistols or the Ramones. In fact, the Ramones would ape the two-note guitar solo gag in \xe2\x80\x9cBoredom\xe2\x80\x9d for their own on \xe2\x80\x9cI Wanna Be Sedated.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"The great joke of Devoto\xe2\x80\x99s performance here is that, on the first record by a new band at the vanguard of a new musical movement, he presents himself as utterly over everything\xe2\x80\x94including punk in general. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m already a has-been,\xe2\x80\x9d he sneers. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know the scene is\xe2\x80\x94very humdrum!\xe2\x80\x9d He wasn't kidding\xc2\xa0because less than a week after Spiral Scratch\xe2\x80\x99s release, Devoto quit the Buzzcocks, and Shelley took his place as the band\xe2\x80\x99s frontman." b'By the time they stopped re-pressing the EP in the summer of 1977, Buzzcocks had sold 16,000 copies of it. In its way, Spiral Scratch was at least as important to punk as the Sex Pistols\xe2\x80\x99 rise, because it was the first record of its kind to erase the axioms that the art and business of pop music were necessarily separate, and that a band could never be important until it signed to a \xe2\x80\x9creal\xe2\x80\x9d record label. Buzzcocks said fuck it and decided to just do it themselves.'

column7: b'The Chicago rapper moves away from his recent commercially-minded exploits and embraces a more mature style of writing.'
column8: b"Will Lil Durk get another chance to be a rap star? He's the last great hope of the class of 2012,\xc2\xa0back when drill music first crumbled the city\xe2\x80\x99s pavements to dust. Chief Keef\xe2\x80\x99s indiscipline killed his momentum. Lil Reese sank under the weight of a charge sheet. King Louie is still around, making the kind of graphene-tough drill that sledgehammered its way into hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s collective conscious a half-decade ago. But only one rapper calls himself the Allah of Chi-Town." b'Durk Banks was still in his teens when he signed to Def Jam in 2012, ostensibly becoming one of drill\xe2\x80\x99s great crossover hopes. He dropped two commercially-minded albums on the label and scored minor hits with \xe2\x80\x9cLike Me\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMy Beyonc\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d syrupy jams that made good use of the rapper\xe2\x80\x99s pop instincts. But he\xe2\x80\x99s never been able to parlay any of these achievements into large-scale embracement. Or even, say, Meek Mill-esque sales. The final few steps always elude him.' b'Love Song for the Streets doesn\xe2\x80\x99t concern itself with mainstream acceptance. Instead, we get no false starts or unwise experiments, just Durk unfiltered: nine shots of garbled Auto-Tune vocals, punchy lyricism, goofy sex jams, and hooks that stick.' b"Unshackled from any kind of outline, Durk\xe2\x80\x99s pen game shines. His rise was dotted with blood-soaked tales that summarized much of drill\xe2\x80\x99s appeal: ground-level glimpses at Chicago's South Side that colored in the outline offered by grim murder statistics. Love Song for the Streets, though, finds the father-of-two in a more mournful mood. He\xe2\x80\x99s still only 24, but he raps with the weariness of someone who has seen too damn much." b'\xe2\x80\x9cPick Your Poison\xe2\x80\x9d is a robust smack down of so-called friends that abandoned him when goings got tough. \xe2\x80\x9cHell yeah I hold a grudge,\xe2\x80\x9d Durk spits over Will-A-Fool\xe2\x80\x99s dark production, \xe2\x80\x9cthese niggas ain\xe2\x80\x99t show no love.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Later, he offers some open-book revelations: \xe2\x80\x9cI used to chew on them xannies to get me through the times.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s a touch of Curtis Mayfield in Durk\xe2\x80\x99s gloss-free depiction of urban living\xe2\x80\x94hard times in this crazy town.' b'In Durk\xe2\x80\x99s world, viciousness is a part of life\xe2\x80\x99s mundanity. Moments of youthful innocence are precious in the \xe2\x80\x9ctrenches\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cMy uncle died in a stabbing/I moved to the A now I\xe2\x80\x99m dabbing,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps on \xe2\x80\x9cHandouts.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s about finding something to cling onto, a thin sliver of light\xe2\x80\x94in this case, a dab\xe2\x80\x94in the vast darkness. Durk\xe2\x80\x99s ugly-beautiful vocals punctuate\xc2\xa0one of\xc2\xa0coldest visions of Chicago.' b'As a front-to-back production job, Love Song for the Streets feels raw, dinky, and inexpensive. The gritty orchestration melds itself inseparably from Durk\xe2\x80\x99s synthetic vocals. \xe2\x80\x9cNo Love,\xe2\x80\x9d produced by S Breezy, is built on some twisted guitar notes, a thumping bass line, and lots of dead space for Durk and guest Young Thug to fill. Tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cMood\xe2\x80\x9d have more in common with Thugger\xe2\x80\x99s favored future-cop production style than the horror movie\xc2\xa0theatrics of drill, while Durk\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0strong sense of melody shines on the\xc2\xa0sleazy ode to his girl, \xe2\x80\x9cUzi.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Drill was largely built around incredibly young rappers burdened with many of the troubles listeners found so thrilling. Five years later, Durk is reporting from the firestorm while trying to grow up within it. Love Song for the Streets\xc2\xa0lacks the kind of breadth required of a classic release, but as a table setter to Durk\xe2\x80\x99s next episode, it gets the message across.'

column7: b'Self-produced and recorded, Heartworms is\xc2\xa0the most hermetic LP\xc2\xa0James Mercer has released since 2001\xe2\x80\x99s Oh, Inverted World. His gift for making fussy arrangements seem effortless remains unparalleled.'
column8: b'Dismantling the old Shins lineup must have been a bittersweet trade-off for James Mercer. On one hand, it freed him\xc2\xa0from the interpersonal conflicts inherent in running a band like a democracy, which surely\xc2\xa0was a relief to a songwriter who never prided himself on his people skills. But it also placed a weight on his shoulders. The sole burden of the band\xe2\x80\x99s music and image now falls squarely on Mercer, including formalities that never seemed to come to him as easy to him as the songs did. During the band\xe2\x80\x99s mid-\xe2\x80\x9900s peak, for instance, Mercer often positioned himself toward the side of stage in concert, happily outsourcing traditional frontman duties like joking and bantering to his gregarious sideman Marty Crandall.' b'We can\xe2\x80\x99t know whether Mercer\xc2\xa0laid off his bandmates for creative reasons, as he\xe2\x80\x99s judiciously insisted, or if Crandall\xe2\x80\x99s arrest for domestic assault left him no choice. Either way, he no longer has a real band to help him carry the load, and it takes a toll on him. While the Shins\xe2\x80\x99 music hasn\xe2\x80\x99t changed markedly since that purge in 2008, its image has. The press photos tell the whole story. Remember those old pics of colorful indie dudes horsing around? They\xe2\x80\x99ve been replaced by shots of a lone, forlorn middle-aged guy, trying and utterly failing to look like he\xe2\x80\x99s enjoying himself. The songwriters Mercer most looks up to\xe2\x80\x94icons like Morrissey, Ian McCulloch, Lennon and McCartney\xe2\x80\x94were stars born for the stage, but Mercer never shared their comfort with the limelight. In an interview with NME this winter, he relayed these pressures. \xe2\x80\x9cIt comes at weird moments in life,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained. \xe2\x80\x9cLike we went for this big meal the other night because the Shins are releasing a new record, and then I realized that it\xe2\x80\x99s just me in the Shins so all those people were there for me.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'That may be why, for his 2012 Shins reboot Port of Morrow, he created a sort of shadow band, inviting guests like Janet Weiss, Joe Plummer, and Eric Johnson to help carry the weight. As if to suggest\xc2\xa0that the Shins were still a band,\xc2\xa0Mercer posed in promo photos with his touring lineup. Heartworms, however, is the first album where he fully embraces the reality that he is the Shins. Self-produced and recorded with a smaller cast than its predecessor, it\xe2\x80\x99s the most hermetic\xc2\xa0LP he\xe2\x80\x99s released since 2001\xe2\x80\x99s Oh, Inverted World, the last album he recorded himself. At times it overtly calls back to that debut. With its psychedelic patter, \xe2\x80\x9cDead Alive\xe2\x80\x9d is an almost direct sequel to \xe2\x80\x9cOne by One All Day,\xe2\x80\x9d drawing out that song\xe2\x80\x99s reverb-soaked outro into its own romp, like some kind of self-written\xc2\xa0fan fiction.' b'For as openly as Mercer discusses his anxiety (he dedicates Heartworms\xe2\x80\x99s final song, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fear,\xe2\x80\x9d to it), he still\xc2\xa0adheres to a disciplined, \xe2\x80\x9cnever let them see you sweat\xe2\x80\x9d approach in the studio. He creates the illusion that songs come to him quickly, as if pulled from thin air, even if the five year gaps between the last few Shins albums argue otherwise. His gift for making fussy arrangements seem effortless remains unparalleled. Heartworms\xe2\x80\x99 chipper title track is all weightless wonder, as free and euphoric as anything on Inverted World. Opener \xe2\x80\x9cName for You,\xe2\x80\x9d a sweetly encouraging piece written for his three daughters, plays as if he\xc2\xa0raced to the studio to record it while it was still fresh in his mind. And the most Chutes Too Narrow-esque number, \xe2\x80\x9cMildenhall,\xe2\x80\x9d shares the same live looseness as that album\xe2\x80\x99s country tunes. An unabashedly autobiographical origin story, it details Mercer\xe2\x80\x99s evolution\xc2\xa0from military brat to indie rocker: A classmate passes him a Jesus and Mary Chain cassette; he starts fiddling with his dad\xe2\x80\x99s guitar; his dad teaches him some simple chords and, yada yada yada, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s how we get to where we are now.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s often been a tension, albeit only a mild one, between Mercer\xe2\x80\x99s classicist pop impulses and his more progressive leanings, and some of that creeps in here, too. The nervy, acid-washed \xe2\x80\x9cPainting a\xc2\xa0Hole\xe2\x80\x9d plays like something Kevin Barnes might concoct after several sunless days sequestered in a studio\xe2\x80\x94its groove is heavier and nastier than any Danger Mouse has cooked up for him in Broken Bells. \xe2\x80\x9cCherry Hearts\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFantasy Island\xe2\x80\x9d each call attention to themselves with grimy keyboard tones and deep, almost 808-esque low ends. In the past, Mercer has tripped over these kinds of experiments (\xe2\x80\x9cSea Legs\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel any less clumsy today than it did a decade ago), but here he lands them with the confidence of an old pro aware of\xc2\xa0his limitations.' b'Like many of the indie bands from his era, including fellow pop true believers the New Pornographers and\xc2\xa0Death Cab for Cutie\xe2\x80\x94one of the few other acts from the mid-\xe2\x80\x9900s indie boom still on a major label\xe2\x80\x94Mercer has survived by staying the course. He has largely resisted trends or any temptation to drift too far from his established sweet spot. The thrill of discovery may be gone\xe2\x80\x94really, it disappeared with Wincing the Night Away\xe2\x80\x94yet it\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable how little rust he\xe2\x80\x99s showing. And although Heartworms never quite conjures the magic of those first couple Shins albums, it\xe2\x80\x99s further\xc2\xa0proof that they weren\xe2\x80\x99t a fluke. This guy always did, and still does, know how to write a song that sticks.'

column7: b"The Japanese composer\xc2\xa0Midori Takada's newly reissued album is an\xc2\xa0assimilation of musical modes from around the world. It belongs in the pantheon alongside Steve Reich's most notable works."
column8: b'In a perfect world, Japanese composer Midori Takada and her works for percussion would be as revered and renowned as that of Steve Reich. Much like that world-renowned American composer, Takada drew influence from a study of African drumming and Asian music, and surmised how these sensibilities dovetailed with that of minimalism, serving as means to break with the Western classical tradition (she originally was a percussionist in the Berlin RIAS Symphonie Orchestra at the Berlin Philharmonic). But with only a handful of works to her name and all of it long out of print\xe2\x80\x94be it with her groundbreaking percussion trio Mkwaju Ensemble, the group Ton-Klami or the three solo albums she released across nearly two decades\xe2\x80\x94her music has been impossible to hear since the early 1990s.' b'Only last year did two pieces from Takada\xe2\x80\x99s Mkwaju Ensemble appear on last year\xe2\x80\x99s crucial More Better Days compilation, revealing Takada\xe2\x80\x99s singular approach to spartan yet euphoric percussion pieces. Touching on gamelan, kodo, and American minimalism (Takada founded the trio in part to perform the works of Reich, Terry Riley, and other 20th-century percussion pieces), each one built carefully to sublime effect. When Visible Cloaks\xe2\x80\x99 member Spencer Doran released his influential mixes of Japanese music, selections from both Mkwaju and Takada\xe2\x80\x99s solo percussion pieces appeared at crucial junctures.' b'The rarest of all of Takada\xe2\x80\x99s works though was her 1983 solo effort, Through the Looking Glass, never released on CD and fetching ludicrous sums online for an original vinyl copy. Unable to financially sustain Mkwaju, Takada disbanded the ensemble and entered the studio by herself to realize this music. Over the course of two days, she put to analog tape all four of the extended performances here as well as laying down the overdubs, producing and mixing (with help from an engineer) the album on her own. An astonishing feat in and of itself, Looking Glass is one of the most dazzling works of minimalism, be it from the East or West.' b"\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Henri Rousseau's Dream\xe2\x80\x9d is an assured opening, one that moves at its own slow, hushed pace. Takada astutely layers marimba, gongs, rattles and other ambient bits of chimes, recorder, tam-tam and mimics bird calls with an ocarina. In its understated pulsing of marimba, it brings to mind Gavin Bryars\xe2\x80\x99 work from the same era, most notably Hommages on the Les Disques Du Cr\xc3\xa9puscule imprint. There appears to be little in the way of linear development as Takada instead crafts and sustains an entire landscape of these small sounds, letting them all levitate in mid-air for twelve heavenly minutes." b'With \xe2\x80\x9cCrossing,\xe2\x80\x9d a bit of momentum builds up from a single struck cowbell. Takada goes back over the original clonk and starts to layer interweaving lines on marimba, each successive line increasing the complexity of the lines. More cowbell comes in and suddenly Takada begins to simulate the ornate polyrhythms of Reich\xe2\x80\x99s Drumming all by herself in the studio. And with the introduction of a crossing marimba pattern and the drone of a harmonium some five-and-a-half minutes into the piece, it moves into its own rarefied space.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cTrompe-L\xe2\x80\x99oeil\xe2\x80\x9d moves at a more relaxed pace, with Takada\xe2\x80\x99s harmonium lines swaying like an accordion and her use of a Coke bottle as both reed and percussion giving the piece a playful air about it. It\xe2\x80\x99s a breather before the finale of the album, the fifteen-minute pressure cooker of percussion, \xe2\x80\x9cCatastrophe \xce\xa3.\xe2\x80\x9d Using the harmonium to create a darker mood, Takada focuses on tom-tom, bongos, cymbal and a bit of piano to ratchet up and sustain tension over the course of the piece. There\xe2\x80\x99s a breathlessness to the piece as it gathers momentum that makes it one of the most thrilling percussion pieces of its kind.' b'While her American influences always had an exploratory aspect to their most famous works, there\xe2\x80\x99s never a moment on, say, \xe2\x80\x9cMusic for 18 Musicians\xe2\x80\x9d where you feel like Reich lets loose his rein even a millimeter. There\xe2\x80\x99s something about Takada and the joy of creating this album that fully emerges in this last quarter-hour, as she builds energy up with her drums, her harmonium and that ever-present cowbell. In the liner notes to this reissue, Takada explained just what she learned in her studies of African and Asian music that led her to abandoned Western classical music as a pursuit way back when. \xe2\x80\x9cAs a performer, this music asked you to personally examine your own physical transformation and to confirm and share this transformation with your counterpart, group or tribe,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe music stops short of imposing sovereignty or nationality.\xe2\x80\x9d And even as the finale builds to a glorious climax, it too stops short. Takada pulls it all away at the last possible moment, a thrill that allows her listeners\xe2\x80\x94nearly thirty-five years on\xe2\x80\x94to soar to a space well within themselves. It\xe2\x80\x99s a space well worth rediscovery.'

column7: b'On their new\xc2\xa0album, the duo of Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore\xc2\xa0continue channeling the retro warmth of \xe2\x80\x9970s pop. But their lyrics can\xc2\xa0drip with sarcastic self-effacement, adding bite to their sound.'
column8: b'If you know just one thing about the duo Tennis, it\xe2\x80\x99s probably that they were born at sea. Their craft is called Swift Ranger, it\xe2\x80\x99s 30 feet from stem to stern, and it inspired Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore\xe2\x80\x99s first album, 2011\xe2\x80\x99s Cape Dory. For their latest, Yours Conditionally, Tennis clambered back onto the boat for an ocean jaunt\xe2\x80\x94from San Diego to the Sea of Cortez\xe2\x80\x94and, they hoped, for artistic rejuvenation.' b'But whether they are landlocked or bobbing at sea, Tennis remain devoted to a specific span of musical history, drawing on the beautifully rendered tunes that emerged between pop\xe2\x80\x99s Wall of Sound era and the eruption of punk\xe2\x80\x99s unkempt energies, give or take a few years. Think along the lines of Evie Sands\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cI Can\xe2\x80\x99t Let Go,\xe2\x80\x9d a stringless version of the Carpenters\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cThey Long to Be (Close to You),\xe2\x80\x9d Dusty Springfield\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEasy Evil,\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cAngel\xe2\x80\x9d side of Fleetwood Mac\xe2\x80\x99s catalog. These are unimpeachable reference points\xe2\x80\x94plenty of other acts would do well to study similar benchmarks\xe2\x80\x94but they also pose a forbiddingly high bar.' b'On 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Ritual in Repeat, Tennis rose above pastiche and wrote a few sturdy tunes that stood apart from the history they channelled. The group achieves this again two or three times on *Yours Conditionally, *displaying a keen appreciation for harmony, balmy keyboards, and analog-sounding bass. When the guitar doubles and then embellishes the primary progression on the outro of \xe2\x80\x9cBaby Don\xe2\x80\x99t Believe,\xe2\x80\x9d or when Moore arcs her singing downward without warning on \xe2\x80\x9cModern Woman,\xe2\x80\x9d the band\xc2\xa0lifts off.' b'Lyrically, the album seesaws between portraits of perfect love and something decidedly more ambivalent. \xe2\x80\x9cMy Emotions Are Blinding\xe2\x80\x9d drips with sarcastic self-effacement: \xe2\x80\x9cIf the night goes exactly as planned,\xe2\x80\x9d Moore sings, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be giving all my attention/To the world\xe2\x80\x99s most interesting man.\xe2\x80\x9d She delivers sweet nothings in the next song, \xe2\x80\x9cFields of Blue\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI really love you, I cannot help myself\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94milking the contrast between tone and message.' b"\xe2\x80\x9cLadies Don't Play Guitar\xe2\x80\x9d is more pointed. Here, Moore offers a send-up of female-as-male-muse, adding bite\xc2\xa0and an incisiveness\xc2\xa0that feels new for this band. \xe2\x80\x9cLadies don\xe2\x80\x99t play guitar/ Ladies don\xe2\x80\x99t get down down to the sound of it,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe we can play pretend?\xe2\x80\x9d Moore, of course, does play guitar; on Yours Conditionally, she also contributes keys, piano, and some percussion. As she\xc2\xa0presents a caricature of a woman on the sidelines supporting her rock-star-lover\xe2\x80\x99s dreams\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLadies just need your love...\xc2\xa0I can be the archetype of whatever you\xe2\x80\x99re feeling\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she\xc2\xa0undermines it immediately with her presence in the song." b'Despite the lyrical punch, Yours Conditionally is hamstrung by Tennis\xe2\x80\x99 drums. The keys and bass on the album are unfailingly warm, but the shabby percussion is one-note, almost the work of a different band. This feels like an eyesore amid an otherwise splendid view, an indie affectation that causes the duo to fall just short of their tasteful influences.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s a shame, because Tennis\xe2\x80\x99 return to Swift Ranger furnished them with some of their best material yet.'

column7: b'The collaboration between members of Broadcast and Focus Group creates lovingly rendered ambiance\xc2\xa0born of library music and musique concr\xc3\xa8te, steeped in eeriness and sweetened with wonder.'
column8: b'For those attuned to Broadcast and the Focus Group\xe2\x80\x99s wavelength, the 2009 collaborative album Investigate Witch Cults of the Radio Age\xc2\xa0was a hallowed union. Throughout the 2000s, Broadcast had reimagined psych-rock in a way that mirrored the Focus Group\xe2\x80\x99s adventures in library music and musique concr\xc3\xa8te\xe2\x80\x94both artists\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0warped nostalgia and movie-music mania\xc2\xa0dealt in\xc2\xa0temporal freefall, with spectral production\xc2\xa0that exhumed ghosts\xc2\xa0from radio static. On Witch Cults, these hauntological peas in a pod simultaneously peaked: In Trish Keenan\xe2\x80\x99s daydream deadpan, the\xc2\xa0Focus Group\xe2\x80\x99s Julian House found an anchor for his abstractions, while Broadcast\xe2\x80\x99s oneiric detail flourished anew, unmoored once and for all from rock\xe2\x80\x99s retro\xc2\xa0swing.' b'Six years after Keenan\xe2\x80\x99s death, it\xe2\x80\x99s the spirit of\xc2\xa0Witch Cults\xc2\xa0that pervades Children of Alice, James Cargill\xe2\x80\x99s new post-Broadcast project with Julian House and Broadcast keyboardist Roj Stevens. Their debut\xc2\xa0ventures further into sonic\xc2\xa0wormholes\xe2\x80\x94the structures are byzantine, melodies vanishingly sparse\xe2\x80\x94but has the same buzz of eccentric minds dialing into a familiar frequency.' b'The trio, named in honor of Keenan\xe2\x80\x99s beloved\xc2\xa0Alice in Wonderland, make music steeped in eeriness and sweetened with wonder. Children of Alice\xc2\xa0opens with \xe2\x80\x9cThe Harbinger of Spring,\xe2\x80\x9d in which a strangled hum mingles with birdsong and children\xe2\x80\x99s laughter. Beneath it all looms a three-note bass pulse, sounding faintly ominous, but it\xe2\x80\x99s soon reborn in a palatable key. The record\xc2\xa0never settles into\xc2\xa0its unease. When a cuckoo clock heralds the hour, you notice the \xe2\x80\x9cboing\xe2\x80\x9d of its spring, a perfectly innocent technology.\xc2\xa0Jump-cuts splice the scenes into disjointed vignettes, but it feels less like psychic overload than the beguiling minutiae overheard by a baby between naps.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s intrigue lies in its prelinguistic response to a hyperactive world. \xe2\x80\x9cInvocation of a Midsummer Reverie\xe2\x80\x9d collages a furious scurry of warped raga drones, distressed whistling, and erratic tabla. It ought to overwhelm, but the music, often aglow with Cargill\xe2\x80\x99s warm synths,\xc2\xa0seems determined to\xc2\xa0witness mayhem with wide eyes rather than bloodlust. Even the faintly erotic skin-slapping sequence\xe2\x80\x94with yelps and maniacal laughter\xe2\x80\x94takes on a dreamy, aqueous quality, as if it were part of an arcane meditative ritual.' b'Between the field recordings and concr\xc3\xa8te collage, moments of grand\xc2\xa0beauty waft out of the ether. Eleven minutes into \xe2\x80\x9cThe Harbinger of Spring,\xe2\x80\x9d an uneasy silence settles, then bursts into a celestial F-major 7th, scattering melodies\xc2\xa0like sunlight through cracked glass. More tamely rendered, the movement could transmit epic yearning, but its purpose here seems spiritual, admitting a sublime moment into the chaos. The group proceeds with irreverence\xe2\x80\x94groaning brass, whirring static-gusts, murmuring speech\xe2\x80\x94but can\xe2\x80\x99t disguise\xc2\xa0the air of sanctity.' b'Throughout Children of Alice, intermittent flute lines evoke the alien, swannee-whistle voices of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Clangers,\xe2\x80\x9d the strangely poignant late-\xe2\x80\x9960s TV show that encouraged kids to imagine \xe2\x80\x9cless fortunate stars\xe2\x80\x9d than Earth, where life \xe2\x80\x9cmight be very different, very bleak and dull.\xe2\x80\x9d Our fond nostalgia for the show feels somehow bound to its creepiness\xe2\x80\x94slightly too-long silences, eerily calm\xc2\xa0narration\xe2\x80\x94which is\xc2\xa0the hauntologist\xe2\x80\x99s bread and butter. But Children of Alice\xc2\xa0is different from its predecessors. Its nostalgia\xc2\xa0feels less escapist than therapeutic, and its composure amid the mundane\xc2\xa0and deranged is more of a\xc2\xa0promotion for\xc2\xa0mindfulness. Unlike Broadcast, there\xe2\x80\x99s no friction here between their daydreams and our reality; those worlds collapse into one, harmoniously intertwined. From its soundworld\xc2\xa0of\xc2\xa0small terrors rises something unterrifying, a mis-en-sc\xc3\xa8ne\xc2\xa0too lovingly rendered to haunt.'

column7: b"The underground New York rapper's noisy, corroded new mixtape is also uniquely attuned to melody and song structure. It's thoughtful, spiritual, and above all, ambitious."
column8: b'When he was growing up, Chaz Hall\xe2\x80\x99s parents dragged him to church every Sunday\xe2\x80\x94back-to-back services in the morning, and a third after a brief reprieve at Old Country Buffet. At some point, he started skipping dinner, slinking to the back of the sanctuary, teaching himself how to operate the equipment at the mixing board. Soon he was recording himself, alone in a empty room.' b'Over the course of the aughts, Hall\xe2\x80\x94aka Elucid\xe2\x80\x94embedded himself in the labyrinthine world of underground rap in New York. His music can be difficult to find: much of it came out under short-lived or one-off artist names, as collaborations with producers, other rappers, or both. But in the past few years, Elucid\xe2\x80\x99s name has come to the forefront, both as a solo artist and as one-half of the duo Armand Hammer, with his Backwoodz Studioz label mate, billy woods.' b'Elucid\xe2\x80\x99s music can also be difficult, or at least seem unapproachable. It\xe2\x80\x99s full of knotty, dense writing and supremely technical passages. Yet unlike plenty of underground rappers (and major-label artists, for that matter), he\xe2\x80\x99s uniquely attuned to melody and song structure. Even when he breaks convention, his intent seems to be clear; his delivery is an intoxicating blend of the gruff and guttural and something more melodic. His LP from last year, Save Yourself, was a collage of heartbreak and ambition that takes dozens of listens to properly unpack; it grappled with love, gentrification, and the corrosive nature of religious institutions.' b'His latest work, a half-hour dispatch called Valley of Grace, has songs titled \xe2\x80\x9cself care is a revolutionary act\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cstrength is admired humanity is denied.\xe2\x80\x9d Where Save Yourself\xc2\xa0was in certain ways inextricable from New York (Elucid has made camp in Brooklyn, Queens, and elsewhere over the last couple of decades), Valley of Grace was written and recorded in Johannesburg and Cape Town, and taps into something more ethereal. It\xe2\x80\x99s thoughtful, considered, and among the most ambitious rap records to come out this year.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cColonizers corpse,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, sounds straightforward and up-tempo, but is written in a way that throws Elucid into a series of scenes where the spiritual stakes keep increasing: at first, roadside vendors are running after escaped chickens with cleavers, later a \xe2\x80\x9cgunned-down\xe2\x80\x9d child\xe2\x80\x99s soul runs with the same desperation. He ends the song with \xe2\x80\x9cSelf-appointed poet laureate of the Niggerati/hard copy/I am not my body,\xe2\x80\x9d allowing those words to give way to forty seconds of ear-splitting distortion that open the next track before hopping back in: \xe2\x80\x9cWatching America burn from distant shores/I learned to walk hot coals before I left the East coast.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Valley also features some of Elucid\xe2\x80\x99s most adventurous production: see \xe2\x80\x9ctalk disruptive for me,\xe2\x80\x9d which sounds like the climaxes of three different movies played on top of one another. \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99d rather be a cyborg than a goddess,\xe2\x80\x9d which accounts for fully one-third of the tape\xe2\x80\x99s running time, flits back and forth between (and occasionally merges) cold, industrial textures with warmer tones, the latter coming via very lo-fi samples.' b'Along with frequent appraisals of America\xe2\x80\x99s current state and deeply entrenched hypocrisy on race, the topic that Elucid returns to most is the state of his body. From the hot coals under his feet to the \xe2\x80\x9cclear and present danger\xe2\x80\x9d to his physical form (\xe2\x80\x9cno release\xe2\x80\x9d), Valley of Grace frequently feels, by its very existence, like an act of defiance. Perhaps he says it best himself: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m no prisoner/Your indifference and silence speaks volumes/I pray the wrath of my ancestors surrounds you.\xe2\x80\x9d With this record, Elucid has taken sharp, maximalist writing, music that\xe2\x80\x99s very nearly avant-garde, and distilled each down to its core elements.'

column7: b"Featuring John Coltrane, Art Blakey, and Coleman Hawkins,\xc2\xa0Monk's Music was the world's introduction to the pianist's most famous songs. It helped define the future of jazz and the mind of Monk."
column8: b'The summer of 1957 would seem to mark the redemption of Thelonious Monk, the summer he made\xc2\xa0Monk*\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xc2\xa0*in one night.' b'He was then a 39-year-old New York jazz pianist of great repute who hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been able to work at most jazz clubs in New York for the past six years. His\xc2\xa0cabaret card, a relic of New York law enforcement since prohibition, had been revoked in 1951 after a spurious narcotics charge. And so he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been easy to see, which means he might have seemed elusive. He was introverted and sometimes guarded; such behavior has never been unusual in jazz. In fact he lived with bipolar disorder\xe2\x80\x94undiagnosed at the time, though we know about it now, especially through the work of the scholar Robin D.G. Kelley, whose book\xc2\xa0Thelonious Monk: The Life and Times\xc2\xa0of an American Original*\xc2\xa0*is the principal source of much biographical information here.' b"At the end of 1955, Monk\xe2\x80\x99s mother, Barbara, had died. In early 1956, an electrical fire destroyed his New York apartment on West 63rd Street, totaling his piano and resulting in his family of five, basically destitute, having to stay for months with friends\xe2\x80\x9415 people in a three-room apartment. At the beginning of 1957, Monk spent three weeks in Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, taken there by a policeman he'd been unresponsive to after a car accident. (What else was going on in his bloodline? Kelley\xe2\x80\x99s book, at this period, contains a chilling sentence: \xe2\x80\x9cThelonious did not know that his own father had been living in a mental asylum for the past fifteen years.\xe2\x80\x9d) In May, his wife Nellie developed an illness which resulted in a thyroidectomy, leaving her frail and depressed, which had a relay effect on Monk. Also during this time, Monk got himself a manager, began a close musical relationship with John Coltrane, made several albums for Riverside records including\xc2\xa0Monk*\xe2\x80\x99s Music,\xc2\xa0*regained his cabaret card, and started a six-month job at the Five Spot Caf\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x94a gig which would re-establish his performing career, serve as Coltrane\xe2\x80\x99s finishing school, and be described thereafter as a high point in New York jazz culture." b'This is all a relatively easy story to tell. There is a reversal of fortune; Monk makes a great album; he wins. Like any cliche, it only applies badly to Monk.' b'As a pianist, Monk, who would have turned 100 this year, was not a dazzler-virtuoso like Art Tatum or Oscar Peterson. He phrased in a wide circumference around the beat, leaving a lot of silence in an improvisation, enough for you to notice. He made polytonal clonks on the keyboard by playing the desired note as well as the key adjacent to it. The assumption, often, was that either he didn\xe2\x80\x99t have much technique, or was withholding it because he didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to be understood or known too quickly, and why would someone do that?' b'A common initial reaction to Monk was skepticism. The pianist Randy Weston, then 18, first saw Monk playing in Coleman Hawkins\xe2\x80\x99 band. \xe2\x80\x9cWho is this cat on piano?\xe2\x80\x9d Weston remembers thinking, in his memoir\xc2\xa0African Rhythms.*\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI can play more piano than this guy!\xe2\x80\x9d In other words:\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99*s unclear what this person knows.\xc2\xa0Another reaction was humility. The drummer Art Blakey described in a 1973 interview how Monk had been his sympathetic guide through what Blakey called the \xe2\x80\x9ccliques\xe2\x80\x9d in New York jazz when Blakey first arrived from Pittsburgh in the early \xe2\x80\x9940s. Blakey watched Monk defend his own music and insist on the right way to play it. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was very outspoken,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe knew what he wanted to do, and he did it.\xe2\x80\x9d In other words:\xc2\xa0this person knows a lot.' b'Much of the talk around jazz, and around Monk, turns on ideas of knowing and not-knowing. (I keep the hyphen, as for related reasons did Donald Barthelme in his essay of that name\xc2\xa0as well as various Buddhists and psychotherapists, because by \xe2\x80\x9cnot-knowing\xe2\x80\x9d I mean flexibility, working without a fixed outcome, trusting oneself to find a new vocabulary, as opposed to what I would mean without the hyphen: ignorance, lack of awareness, incuriosity.) By one understanding, jazz is a consensual language of rhythm, harmony, and form, and a consensual repertoire accumulated over the last hundred years. That\xe2\x80\x99s about knowing. If you want to work in jazz, you have to get the basic songs under your fingers. Those songs\xe2\x80\x94including, say, \xe2\x80\x9cAll the Things You Are,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDonna Lee,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFootprints,\xe2\x80\x9d and about ten by Thelonious Monk\xe2\x80\x94are a part of what holds the tradition together.' b'The larger part is the fact that jazz is essentially African-American in musical vocabulary and disposition. Jazz is cultural memory. For many African-American musicians, to know is also to be aware of the values and dangers; to know is not to forget. Monk\xe2\x80\x99s music suggested the cumulative past as a wider present: something older from within jazz\xe2\x80\x94boogie-woogie or early Ellington\xe2\x80\x94along with other vernacular traditions adjacent to it: rumba, gospel, or rhythm and blues.' b'Jazz is further defined by the discipline of improvising, which some say is an express-lane to thinking through time progressively and allowing possibility, the greater idea of not-knowing.' b'***' b'From the first seconds of \xe2\x80\x9cWell, You Needn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d the second track on\xc2\xa0Monk*\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xc2\xa0*and the record\xe2\x80\x99s greatest eleven minutes, much control is in evidence. You hear Monk, with only the bassist Wilbur Ware thrumming in the back, working upward from the C below middle C over an F pedal in half-steps: C, Db, D, Eb, E. Monk is playing in an implied three-beat rhythm, and punching out his notes a little roughly, as you might imagine yourself punching an elevator button. But he is doing it in between the beats, with style and purpose. He climbs his five notes twice, each time bringing you one step away from resolution in a perfect cadence; he is building tension and expectation in a classical and idiomatic way, alerting you that something is going to take place here, and it\xe2\x80\x99s going to be an\xc2\xa0event. Then it arrives: the song\xe2\x80\x99s hard opening, with John Coltrane, Coleman Hawkins and the rest of the septet piling in, Art Blakey\xe2\x80\x99s drumming shoving it forward.' b'The band plays the theme together and Blakey crashes on its last beat. Now it\xe2\x80\x99s Monk\xe2\x80\x99s turn. He doesn\xe2\x80\x99t start until the cymbal quiets down, and so for the first measure and a half there is silence. His solo begins as a restatement of the song\xe2\x80\x99s melody, according to convention, but picks it up like a sentence started in the middle. He speeds up and slows down, experimenting, stamping his foot a little, testing the strength of the rhythm and his own relationship to it. Three times he brings his hand down on a strange five-note chord: a stack of fourths, all black notes. Each time he lets it ring for six beats. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, You Needn\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x9d was not a particularly famous song in 1957\xe2\x80\x94Monk had recorded it ten years before for Blue Note, also with Blakey\xe2\x80\x94but it sounds colossal here.' b'*' b'Monk wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an album artist per se. Monk*\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xe2\x80\x94produced by Orrin Keepnews, recorded at Reeves Sound Studios on East 44th Street,\xc2\xa0released on Riverside Records\xe2\x80\x94is contradictory: strident, reassuring, fractured, centered. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t perfect, whatever perfect means. Here and there it sounds like a rehearsal or a jam session. Some solos wander, particularly on \xe2\x80\x9cEpistrophy,\xe2\x80\x9d and the trumpeter Ray Copeland and alto saxophonist Gigi Gryce are comparatively weak links. But\xc2\xa0Monk\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xc2\xa0also\xc2\xa0sounds loose and deep and urgent. At its best it suggests a party in a specific room; you come to know the room. After Monk finishes his solo in \xe2\x80\x9cWell, You Needn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he shouts \xe2\x80\x9cColtrane! Coltrane!\xe2\x80\x9d to signal who\xe2\x80\x99s up next. Ravi Coltrane, John\xe2\x80\x99s son, told me that when he first heard\xc2\xa0Monk\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xc2\xa0*he was 21, listening in a university library with headphones on. At Monk\xe2\x80\x99s shout, he startled, thinking someone was looking for him.' b'The band includes the saxophonist John Coltrane, Monk\xe2\x80\x99s new student, who sounds dry, driven, searching; the saxophonist Coleman Hawkins, Monk\xe2\x80\x99s old mentor, with a gallant and knowing affect that he puts to special use on Monk\xe2\x80\x99s ballad \xe2\x80\x9cRuby, My Dear\xe2\x80\x9d; and Blakey, a kind of younger brother, pro-active, explosive, rendering the dance impulse in super-titles. Monk himself does nothing strange by his own standards. He is brusque and vatic and intimate, moving through funny, orderly, supremely affective songs. The first track is the exception in several ways: it is only a melody, played in straight rhythm by the horns alone; it is a hymn called \xe2\x80\x9cAbide With Me,\xe2\x80\x9d also known as \xe2\x80\x9cEventide,\xe2\x80\x9d composed in the middle of the 19th century by the English composer William Henry Monk. Destiny\xe2\x80\x99s Child liked to put their gospel songs at the end of their records; Monk put his at the beginning.' b'Monk*\xe2\x80\x99s Music\xc2\xa0*includes the first renderings of a harmonically rich song that would become one of Monk\xe2\x80\x99s standards, \xe2\x80\x9cCrepuscule With Nellie,\xe2\x80\x9d written for his wife at a fragile time. Monk plays it unnervingly slowly, and bids the band to do the same with him. (One of his drummers at the time, Frankie Dunlop, in an interview from 1984 extraordinary for the secret knowledge about rhythm it reveals, as well as for Dunlop\xe2\x80\x99s imitation of Monk\xe2\x80\x99s speaking voice, called Monk\xe2\x80\x99s approach to tempo \xe2\x80\x9ca different musical category altogether.\xe2\x80\x9d) Really, it\xe2\x80\x99s a radical slow dance. During the Five Spot gig, while others soloed, Monk began the practice of dancing on stage: a soft lurch, turning in a circle, imitating the greater circle around the beat.' b'*' b'A lot came together for Monk in 1957. Shortly thereafter, starting in the 1960s, he shifted up to touring theaters with a steady band. His records became elegantly repetitive and often staid. He appeared on the cover of *Time *magazine in 1964; from then on, till his withdrawal from playing in the 1970s and his death in 1982, he was \xe2\x80\x9cknown.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'You can make fun of jazz writers from the distant past all day, but some of their early published ideas about Monk in the \xe2\x80\x9940s, especially in\xc2\xa0Down Beat*\xc2\xa0*and\xc2\xa0Metronome, were only as na\xc3\xafve as Weston\xe2\x80\x99s. If they liked him, they were describing a European-style avant-garde hero, desiring to cut loose from the known. If they didn\xe2\x80\x99t like him, they were describing music they found incomplete or antisocial. They described him as \xe2\x80\x9ctoo too,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfor the super hip alone,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cneurotic,\xe2\x80\x9d and\xe2\x80\x94worst of all\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbad, though interesting.\xe2\x80\x9d All these reactions imply Monk\xe2\x80\x99s fecklessness or lack of control. They are the reactions of people encountering a critical intelligence and not knowing what to do with it.' b'Monk\xe2\x80\x99s story is a story of relationships. Born in Rocky Mount, NC, he grew up among Southern and Antillean families at 234 West 63rd Street in Manhattan, on a block now called Thelonious Monk Circle. A couple doors down, No. 224, was the Columbus Hill Neighborhood Center, his social hub and the site of his early gigs. His engagement in the jazz culture of Harlem through the \xe2\x80\x9940s, alongside Dizzy Gillespie, Bud Powell, and Kenny Clarke, created several new languages in jazz, collectively and roughly described as bebop. All his interviews, all the anecdotes, illustrate that Monk, to a great degree, knew his own value and had no interest in being strange on purpose. (\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like the word \xe2\x80\x98weird,\xe2\x80\x99 anyway,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Nat Hentoff.) He knew who he was, and that knowledge allowed him the freedom of not-knowing.' b'One of the best lines in Kelley\xe2\x80\x99s book comes in a secondhand story told by the poet Ted Joans. Be skeptical, but here it is. At some point in the second half of 1957, during a set at the Five Spot, Monk wandered off stage as the band continued to play, out the doors of the club, and walked for a few blocks. One of the club owners chased him down and found him looking at the sky. He asked Monk if he was lost. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I ain\xe2\x80\x99t lost. I\xe2\x80\x99m here,\xe2\x80\x9d Monk is said to have responded. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Five Spot\xe2\x80\x99s lost.\xe2\x80\x9d'

column7: b"Tango in the Night is the final album the band would record as an infamous quintet.\xc2\xa0It's a pop and production masterpiece,\xc2\xa0yet remains this\xc2\xa0monolithic, lucrative idea of a Fleetwood Mac record."
column8: b'It started with \xe2\x80\x9cSara.\xe2\x80\x9d The first two Fleetwood Mac albums to feature Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks\xe2\x80\x94the self-titled album and Rumours\xe2\x80\x94featured production typical of the pop-rock generated in Los Angeles in the \xe2\x80\x9970s. They were professional and pristine, exhibiting an instrumental and emotional warmth that was, in terms of the actual recording technique and the cerebral atmosphere of the people making the records, a product of isolation. On their next record, Tusk, Buckingham shifted the balance of Fleetwood Mac\xe2\x80\x99s studio pop. He deliberately produced his songs so that they sounded trebly and makeshift\xe2\x80\x94as if they were translated from brain to tape as quickly as possible\xe2\x80\x94and produced Nicks\xe2\x80\x99 and Christine McVie\xe2\x80\x99s songs with a lush and carefully-sculpted dimensionality. \xe2\x80\x9cSara,\xe2\x80\x9d a song Nicks wrote to a daughter she never had, is so gently shaped that every instrumental and vocal materializes in the song like vapor in the atmosphere. At the Blockbuster Music Awards in 2001, Nicks said that when she writes songs, she tries to \xe2\x80\x9cmake little worlds\xe2\x80\x9d for the listener. Whether intentional or not, this sensibility invaded Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s production of the song; \xe2\x80\x9cSara,\xe2\x80\x9d as it appears on Tusk, is its own world, a complete environment, a beach house built out of sighs.' b'The follow-up to Tusk, 1982\xe2\x80\x99s Mirage, was a kind reflexive scaling back; both Warner Bros. and Buckingham wanted to regenerate the success and the coherent atmosphere of Rumours. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t take. The band members had already drifted too far from each other: Nicks sang country-western and synth-pop songs; Buckingham quoted Pachelbel\xe2\x80\x99s Canon; McVie\xe2\x80\x99s formal romanticism began to take on a crystalline quality; the production flowed in the direction of their individual fascinations. After a brief tour, the band went on hiatus. Nicks released two successful solo albums; McVie and Buckingham put out one each. In 1985, Buckingham had begun work on an additional solo album, when Mick Fleetwood suggested Buckingham fold his new songs into the more monolithic, more lucrative idea of a Fleetwood Mac record.' b'The resulting album, Tango in the Night, is exactly that: a monolithic, lucrative idea of a Fleetwood Mac record. It was recorded over eighteen months between 1986 and 1987, mostly at Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s home studio in L.A. Buckingham devoted himself to the record, laboring intensely over its songs, its sounds, and the integrity of its design. Recording technology had advanced substantially since the early \xe2\x80\x9980s, and Buckingham found the methods by which he could determine the shape and temperature of a Fleetwood Mac song had expanded.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cMost of the vocal parts were recorded track by track,\xe2\x80\x9d he told the *New York Times *in 1987. \xe2\x80\x9cThe voices used in the textured vocal choirs were mostly mine. I used a Fairlight machine that samples real sounds and blends them orchestrally.\xe2\x80\x9d Out of these newly available materials, he could practically build an entire band, which was useful at the time. Mick Fleetwood was almost entirely consumed by his cocaine habit, and the band had been experiencing an internal drift for years. \xe2\x80\x9cConstructing such elaborate layering is a lot like painting a canvas and is best done in solitude,\xe2\x80\x9d Buckingham added.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s artwork, \xe2\x80\x9cHomage a Henri Rousseau\xe2\x80\x9d by Brett-Livingstone Strong,\xc2\xa0is so\xc2\xa0lush and romantic that it walks a fine line between formal elegance and kitsch, blending the terrestrial with the celestial. It\xe2\x80\x99s an accurate illustration of Tango in the Night\xe2\x80\x99s sound design, of the glitterings and humid shimmers that Buckingham placed in the songs. He made each track on Tango just as he produced \xe2\x80\x9cSara\xe2\x80\x9d: less an arrangement of bass, guitar, drums, and vocals than a complete world, a living panorama. There\xe2\x80\x99s a phenomenal wholeness to the recordings on Tango that seems like a superficial compensation for how deeply fragmented the band was at the time.' b'After Nicks resurfaced from her cocaine addiction at the Betty Ford Clinic, she visited Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s studio for a few\xc2\xa0weeks. Three of her recordings figure into the finished Tango, only two of which were written by her. Her voice, invariably hoarse after years of cocaine abuse, often warps or fails the already incomplete material. She howls her way through \xe2\x80\x9cSeven Wonders,\xe2\x80\x9d a song written mostly by Sandy Stewart. (Nicks receives credit because she misheard \xe2\x80\x9cAll the way down you held the line\xe2\x80\x9d as \xe2\x80\x9cAll the way down to Emmiline\xe2\x80\x9d; for Nicks\xe2\x80\x94and I don\xe2\x80\x99t disagree\xe2\x80\x94sometimes accident and authorship are indistinguishable.) For all of its bluster, the song is not only enhanced by the incidents of its arrangement but is the incidents of its arrangement; try to imagine the song without its synth hook and hear the rest of it evaporate. On \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I See You Again,\xe2\x80\x9d Nicks\xe2\x80\x99 voice almost crumbles and shatters into atoms. \xe2\x80\x9cStevie was the worst she\xe2\x80\x99s ever been,\xe2\x80\x9d Buckingham told Uncut in 2013. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t recognize her...I had to pull performances out of words and lines and make parts that sounded like her that weren\xe2\x80\x99t her.\xe2\x80\x9d Fittingly, each verse and chorus that Nicks sings sounds generated by a different uncanny assemblage of Stevie, among them one who sings in a kind of mutilated whisper. After the bridge, Nicks completely disappears. Buckingham finishes the song.' b'Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s songs on *Tango *are less knotted than they were on Tusk and Mirage, newly permissive of space. The first single, Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBig Love,\xe2\x80\x9d is a song that inadvertently simulates the essential failure of the album. It is devoted to a totally abstracted and imaginary form of love, while Tango in the Night is devoted to a totally abstracted and imaginary form of Fleetwood Mac (neither of which could be assembled in reality). The song\xe2\x80\x99s arrangement feels austere and detached, a byproduct of the narrator\xe2\x80\x99s alienation, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also decorated with overlapping, pointillist guitar phrases. Even the empty spaces on Tango feel like deliberately-wrought emptinesses\xe2\x80\x94for instance, the airy synths that hover over the verses of McVie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d or Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s title track, which through its sense of space imparts the feeling of rowing through fog and mystery.' b'Still, it\xe2\x80\x99s McVie whose work is most realized by Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s impressionism. Her \xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere\xe2\x80\x9d is the best song on the record. Like \xe2\x80\x9cBig Love\xe2\x80\x9d it too is about encountering an idea too big to contain within oneself (love, again). But where \xe2\x80\x9cBig Love\xe2\x80\x9d apprehends it with icy suspicion, \xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere\xe2\x80\x9d responds with warmth, empathy, and buoyancy, describing a kind of devotion so deeply felt that it produces weightlessness in a person. Its incandescent texture is felt in almost any music that could be reasonably described as balearic. Elsewhere, \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t It Midnight,\xe2\x80\x9d McVie\xe2\x80\x99s co-write with Buckingham and her then-husband Eddy Quintela, seems an inversion of the values of \xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d a severe \xe2\x80\x9980s guitar rock song that gets consumed by a greater, more unnerving force by its chorus, as if it\xe2\x80\x99s succumbing to a conspiratorial dread. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember the face of a pretty girl?\xe2\x80\x9d McVie sings, and Buckingham echoes her in an unfeeling monotone (\xe2\x80\x9cthe face of a pretty girl\xe2\x80\x9d) while behind him synths chime in a moving constellation, UFOs pulsing in the dark.' b'This is the essence of Tango in the Night: something falling apart\xc2\xa0but held together by an unearthly glow. More of a mirage than Mirage, it is an immaculate study in denial (its most enduring hit revolves around McVie asking someone to tell her \xe2\x80\x9csweet little lies\xe2\x80\x9d). It\xe2\x80\x99s a form of dreaming where you could touch the petals of a flower and feel something softer than the idea of softness. In this way, Tango seems to emerge less from Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s pure will and imagination than from a question that haunts art in general: How can one make the unreal real, and the real unreal?' b'The remaster of Tango in the Night isn\xe2\x80\x99t as topographically startling as last year\xe2\x80\x99s Mirage, where new details seemed to rise out of the mix as if in a relief sculpture; it sounded good on CD in 1987. The reissue does sound warmer and brighter, and the instruments feel less digitally combined, which lifts background elements to the surface, like the seasick drift of the bass notes in \xe2\x80\x9cCaroline\xe2\x80\x9d and the coordinated staccato harmonies in the title track. The reissue also includes two discs of b-sides, demos, and extended remixes, several of which were previously unreleased. \xe2\x80\x9cSpecial Kind of Love\xe2\x80\x9d is described as a demo but sounds like a completely developed Buckingham song, gentle and simple, with every edge expressively filigreed; it could\xe2\x80\x99ve been a potential second sequel to \xe2\x80\x9cYou and I.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cSeven Wonders\xe2\x80\x9d appears in an earlier, more relaxed arrangement, with Lindsey\xe2\x80\x99s guitar warmly swanning between the notes that would eventually be reconstructed in perfect digital isolation by a synthesizer.' b'The demos also reveal the ways in which the songs could fold into and out of each other. On the \xe2\x80\x9cTango in the Night\xe2\x80\x9d demo you can hear Buckingham, at the edge of every chorus, begin to invent the trembling choral part that opens \xe2\x80\x9cCaroline.\xe2\x80\x9d Nicks\xe2\x80\x99 eventual solo track \xe2\x80\x9cJuliet\xe2\x80\x9d is present in two of its primordial forms\xe2\x80\x94as the instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cBook of Miracles\xe2\x80\x9d (credited to both Buckingham and Nicks) and as a five-minute \xe2\x80\x9crun-through.\xe2\x80\x9d The run-through is especially curious, reducing \xe2\x80\x9cBook of Miracles\xe2\x80\x9d to a formulaic blues-rock over which Nicks\xe2\x80\x99 voice produces a just-barely musical static, full of wobbles and distortions and exclamations. After the take she says, ecstatically, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought that was wonderful! I didn\xe2\x80\x99t play! I did not play because I am so smart!\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Nicks exhibits a strange, dissonant giddiness in this moment that isn\xe2\x80\x99t present in any of the band member\xe2\x80\x99s memories of the recording process. At the time, in his interview with the Times, Buckingham imaginatively described Tango in the Night as a restorative process. \xe2\x80\x9cThis album is as much about healing our relationships as Rumours was about dissension and pain within the group,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe songs look back over a period of time that in retrospect seems almost dreamlike.\xe2\x80\x9d Twenty-six years later, Buckingham summarized the experience to Uncut in more severe terms: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was done with the record, I said, \xe2\x80\x98Oh my God. That was the worst recording experience of my life.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The jealousy and resentment he felt toward Nicks for the success she experienced in her solo career, and the prevailing feeling that his architectural work on the band\xe2\x80\x99s records went unnoticed and unappreciated, had built to a flashpoint. Later in 1987, the band met up in anticipation of the promotional tour for Tango, for which they had already secured dates and signed contracts. At the meeting, Buckingham announced he was quitting the band. \xe2\x80\x9cI \xef\xac\x82ew off of the couch and across the room to seriously attack him,\xe2\x80\x9d Nicks told Classic Rock in 2013*.* \xe2\x80\x9c...I\xe2\x80\x99m not real scary but I grabbed him which almost got me killed.\xe2\x80\x9d They spilled out of McVie\xe2\x80\x99s house and into the street. Buckingham ran after Nicks and threw her up against a car. She \xe2\x80\x9cscreamed horrible obscenities\xe2\x80\x9d at him, and he walked away, from the moment and the band. What\xe2\x80\x99s left, after these harsh fragments of reality are swept away, is Tango in the Night: a remarkably complete album, a lavish garden growing out of negative space. Just a dream.'

column7: b'The fourth LP from the tireless, master technician from Long Island stays making the case for Marciano as a vicious, creative, and vastly underrated MC.'
column8: b'In professional terms, Roc Marciano comes from nowhere. This website\xe2\x80\x99s review for his staggering 2010 debut, Marcberg, refers to him as \xe2\x80\x9ca rapper associated with Busta Rhymes\xe2\x80\x99 Flipmode Squad,\xe2\x80\x9d a descriptor that was barely reductive at the time. Roc Marciano the person\xe2\x80\x94that would be the 39-year-old Rakeem Calief Myer\xe2\x80\x94comes from Ed Koch\xe2\x80\x99s New York, a place that informs his work by way of syntax, slang, and a catalog of grainy samples that sound like they were lifted out of rainwater. It gave him train-rattling drums, too, but lately he\xe2\x80\x99s been stripping those away.' b'The character that Marci has created on wax, the one with Isaac Hayes shades and Kevin McHale-colored fishscale, has been everywhere: Burkina Faso, Venezuela in his best dress clothes, chubby on a sunny beach, his gun in reach. Rosebudd\xe2\x80\x99s Revenge, the long-awaited proper follow-up to 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Reloaded, carries each piece of his style toward the extreme, which makes this his most confounding, and maybe his most singular work to date.' b'Impressive as it is on a formal level, Rosebudd\xe2\x80\x99s Revenge also raises interesting questions about the inner workings of Marci\xe2\x80\x99s mind. On \xe2\x80\x9cGunsense,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps: \xe2\x80\x9cMotherfucker, this is art, you can\xe2\x80\x99t just pick this apart/This not a hobby, this is therapy.\xe2\x80\x9d Those lines, defiant as they are, would be unremarkable coming from any number of rappers. But Roc Marciano records seldom feel like confessionals, at least in any recognizable sense; you don\xe2\x80\x99t picture a pimp slumping into his therapist\xe2\x80\x99s couch to talk about how flying in shooters from Jamaica makes him feel.' b'Marci\xe2\x80\x99s trafficking in something more circuitous than a linear line from trauma to psychic baggage. Unlike his longtime collaborator, Ka\xe2\x80\x94who appears here on the excellent \xe2\x80\x9cMarksmen,\xe2\x80\x9d and whose own solo work also explores just how lean New York can sound\xe2\x80\x94Marci doesn\xe2\x80\x99t write in monologue. Instead, he tends to stack images on top of one another, building it higher and higher until it can scrub blood off of Nikes or get the mink out of storage. See \xe2\x80\x9cAlready,\xe2\x80\x9d where he raps, \xe2\x80\x9cMahogany woodgrain all in the five-speed/Silk lay on me, pray for me/Eight million stories in the naked city/The humidity\xe2\x80\x94it made the titties oil.\xe2\x80\x9d Later on the same song, he says that his jeans fit him like Springsteen, that his shoes cost as much as an MF DOOM verse, and \xe2\x80\x9cFans demand new work, but I\xe2\x80\x99m a man of few words.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'In each and every case, the point of view is slippery enough that you\xe2\x80\x99re never quite sure who the speaker is, how literally a line should be taken, and whether its connection to subsequent lines is superficial, deeply important, or altogether non-existent. You don\xe2\x80\x99t need to answer any of these questions to appreciate Marci\xe2\x80\x99s Technicolor virtuosity. to follow him to murder scenes in Wichita (\xe2\x80\x9cPimp Arrest\xe2\x80\x9d) or to Israeli\xc2\xa0hotel rooms (\xe2\x80\x9cBetter Know\xe2\x80\x9d). But answering them might help to bridge the gap between Rakeem Myer and Roc Marciano\xe2\x80\x94to see which of his too-vivid details are things he aspires to and which he sees as necessary evils.' b'As a writer, Marci\xe2\x80\x99s gift is his ability to make evil seem impossibly slick; on \xe2\x80\x9cBurkina Faso,\xe2\x80\x9d he ends an armed robbery by telling his victim, \xe2\x80\x9cKeep the Dunks, I\xe2\x80\x99m not a hipster,\xe2\x80\x9d then heads home and listens to Michael Bolton in the jacuzzi. Rosebudd\xe2\x80\x99s Revenge isn\xe2\x80\x99t as seamless as Marcberg or Reloaded, suffering from some fidelity issues and perhaps being a bit back-loaded, but it\xe2\x80\x99s endlessly, almost impossibly entertaining. Even as he approaches middle age, Marci remains one of rap\xe2\x80\x99s most brilliant stylists, the kind of artist who can make you wear out your rewind button despite being old enough to remember when you could wear out a rewind button.' b'Maybe the most aspirational line on the record is: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just having fun with this, I live in comfort.\xe2\x80\x9d For all the death threats, all the cartoon luxury that Marci rattles off with a sneer, the underlying truth is that he\xe2\x80\x99s a master technician who\xe2\x80\x99s worked tirelessly, for years on end to hone an unmistakable style as a rapper, producer, and auteur. Maybe the most peaceful thing he can imagine\xe2\x80\x94the beach where he can get chubby, as it were\xe2\x80\x94would be fading back into the ether, content to know that after years of obscurity, he became one of the greatest, most influential rappers of the decade.'

column7: b'Fuck Buttons\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0Benjamin John Power shows his teeth on his new\xc2\xa0LP as\xc2\xa0Blanck Mass.\xc2\xa0*World Eater *is suitable for casual noise fans\xc2\xa0who have some curiosity for extreme music and a decent threshold for pain.'
column8: b'Benjamin John Power has always been typecast as one of the\xc2\xa0nice guys of noise. With Fuck Buttons, he\xe2\x80\x99s played sun-worshipping primitivist, screamadelic raver, and something close to arena rocker on 2013\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Slow Focus.*\xc2\xa0*His solo project Blanck Mass maintains similar posi-vibes while working within mesmeric repetition and industrial dance.
