At the current moment, however, it\xc2\xa0may be hard to find much truth in \xe2\x80\x9cOkay, Let\xe2\x80\x99s Talk About Magic\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSweet Love for Planet Earth\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0(both 2008 Fuck Buttons titles). The cover\xc2\xa0of Power\xe2\x80\x99s latest Blanck Mass album seems to nod in agreement.\xc2\xa0At a time when global politics is just one man\xc2\xa0after another showing his ass, the only sensible reaction is to show your teeth.' b'*World Eater *finds\xc2\xa0one of electronic noise\xe2\x80\x99s most popular and populist artists making his heel turn. Specifically, it happens after the oblong music box melody of opener \xe2\x80\x9cJohn Doe\xe2\x80\x99s Carnival of Error\xe2\x80\x9d goes into double time, generating the promise of euphoric lift-off that typified Fuck Buttons\xe2\x80\x99 2009\xc2\xa0Andy Weatherall-abetted album *Tarot Sport**. But it\xe2\x80\x99s a classic supervillain trick of lulling its victims with a disturbing, playful calm before unleashing indiscriminate destruction. *A nine-minute blitzkrieg like \xe2\x80\x9cRhesus Negative\xe2\x80\x9d needs no nuance; the only operative principle here is *loud.\xc2\xa0*Brutal kick drums compete\xc2\xa0with twin-turret guitars for dominance in the mix before a return to the black metal shrieking last heard on 2008\xe2\x80\x99s Street Horrrsing. While Power\xe2\x80\x99s prior work offered\xc2\xa0the possibility of meditative headphone listening or even dancefloors, \xe2\x80\x9cRhesus Negative\xe2\x80\x9d is awesome\xc2\xa0in the most literal sense, meant to paralyze with both admiration and fear.' b'But it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like\xc2\xa0an endurance test\xe2\x80\x94instead, the brickwalled production of \xe2\x80\x9cRhesus Negative\xe2\x80\x9d recalls industrial-arena monoliths like Nine Inch Nails\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cWish\xe2\x80\x9d or Cold Cave\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Pan Is Dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Like anything under the Fuck Buttons or Blanck Mass names, *World Eater *is suitable for casual listeners who have some curiosity for extreme music and a decent pain threshold. The difference here is that Power looks back on the past decade of electronic music and finds how *all of it *is capable of showing the kind of domineering aggression that people might only otherwise get from Fuck Buttons, heavy metal, or Tunnel bangers.' b'World Eater evokes\xc2\xa0everything\xc2\xa0from his own up-with-people breakout single \xe2\x80\x9cBright Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x9d to\xc2\xa0Purity Ring\xe2\x80\x99s EDM-indie, from witch house\xc2\xa0to the trap music populating millions of SoundClouds and Vegas nightclubs. The undulating, pitched-down vocals and skittering drum patterns of \xe2\x80\x9cPlease\xe2\x80\x9d bear the echo of Holy Other and any number of Tri Angle acts, though it sounds murderous rather than haunted. It\xe2\x80\x99s a rare instance of *World Eater *showing menace and finesse rather than brute strength. Similarly, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Rat\xe2\x80\x9d runs \xe2\x80\x9cRock n\xe2\x80\x99 Roll Pt. 2\xe2\x80\x9d through TNGHT\xe2\x80\x99s blown subwoofers.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSilent Treatment\xe2\x80\x9d is Power going \xe2\x80\x9cPOWER,\xe2\x80\x9d chopping a choir into a war cry and\xc2\xa0weaving it through a labyrinthian grid of footwork-inspired percussion.' b'Just about anything is going to be interpreted as an act of protest in 2017. On World Eater, the coexistence of melody and belligerence, of fragility under an invincible veneer, speak to the constructive and destructive capabilities of man. Power is completely honest about which instinct is winning right now. Nearly every reference on World Eater\xc2\xa0sounded utopian at one point, and had the album\xc2\xa0been released during a less turbulent time, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Rat\xe2\x80\x9d could have feasibly been used for the London Summer Games alongside Fuck Buttons\xe2\x80\x99 own \xe2\x80\x9cOlympians.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0World Eater does not seem\xc2\xa0like\xc2\xa0a doomsday device by design, though.\xc2\xa0It might sound like one now, but Power leaves open the possibility of it being his darkest transmission before the dawn of a *new *bright tomorrow.'

column3: b'Love In a Time of Madness'
column7: b"On his fourth album for the Blue Note label, James deftly underlines jazz's flexibility in relation to new pop trends, the way Louis Armstrong and Miles Davis did in the past."
column8: b'Modern jazz fans have a right to feel possessive about the singer Jos\xc3\xa9 James. In the last decade, he\xe2\x80\x99s been one of the suavest vocal improvisers on the scene. His 2015 album devoted to songs made popular by Billie Holiday, Yesterday I Had the Blues, sounded to me like the most soulful tribute to come out during Lady Day\xe2\x80\x99s centennial.' b'Steeped as he is in jazz, James has also shown a restlessness with strict genre categorization. He\xe2\x80\x99s described his love of funk, R&B and hip-hop in interviews. And when Blue Note announced his new album, the label\xe2\x80\x99s press release bore a striking quote from the artist: \xe2\x80\x9cI could make jazz albums the rest of my life, but I want to reach people, man. I like Jamie xx as much as I like Miles Davis, you know?\xe2\x80\x9d' b"You could practically hear the well-drilled corps of Jazz Defenders grinding their teeth in response. But on this new record, James doesn't discard his old skill set. He\xe2\x80\x99s merely doing his part to underline the music\xe2\x80\x99s flexibility in relation to new pop trends\xe2\x80\x94much as Louis Armstrong and Davis himself did in decades past. (Clive Davis once wrote that Davis asked Columbia to stop labeling him as a \xe2\x80\x9cjazz man.\xe2\x80\x9d)" b'James knows all about this history. And so does Blue Note. So while there are indeed trap-music snares in a few songs on Love in a Time of Madness, there are also plenty of James\xe2\x80\x99 more typical textures. On opening track \xe2\x80\x9cAlways There,\xe2\x80\x9d a\xc2\xa0stark synth line\xc2\xa0presents a useful contrast with the light-touch smoothness of James\xe2\x80\x99s baritone. During\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cCloser,\xe2\x80\x9d he responds to a looped, low-pitch sample by cutting back on melodic filigree\xe2\x80\x94save for a brief escape, on the line \xe2\x80\x9cshow you I can be the only one.\xe2\x80\x9d In the context of the song, it\xe2\x80\x99s a standard line about romantic prowess. At the level of arrangement, it reminds the listener that James has more to offer when singing over a rhythmic grid.' b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re dead cold to trap beats or the dolorous mood of the Weeknd\xe2\x80\x99s R&B, the subtle but real changes James works on these styles won\xe2\x80\x99t be radical enough to win your affection. But there might be something else for you here, since the core strength of Love in a Time of Madness is its range of dance-pop appreciation. In the middle of the record, James includes a trio of songs that sound like an EP Prince could have produced for the Time in the early \xe2\x80\x9980s. Uptempo standout \xe2\x80\x9cLive Your Fantasy\xe2\x80\x9d contains call-and-response funk and the kind of synth chords Jamie Starr snatched from earlier waves of jazz fusion. \xe2\x80\x9cTo Be With You\xe2\x80\x9d is the sultry ballad. And on \xe2\x80\x9cLadies Man,\xe2\x80\x9d James flashes his newly drilled falsetto voice. Hewing this close to the Purple Formula is as risky as anything else James tries on the album, but he executes the play.' b'There are a couple of songs that simply assist us in identifying this set as a 21st-century pop-crossover record on Blue Note. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember Our Love\xe2\x80\x9d looks at a failed romance, and counsels sweetness. The downtempo \xe2\x80\x9cLet It Fall\xe2\x80\x9d has just a hint of social commentary, but stays tranquil. These are the most easily forgotten tracks. James initially envisioned Love as a double-album set, in which social themes could alternate with intimate ones. Even without the protest music, the 12-song version can sound as though caught between imperatives: eager to test the boundaries of a contemporary pop and jazz, but not ambitious enough in scale to do all the work the singer can envision. Still, he\xe2\x80\x99s clearly got the range to make a \xe2\x80\x9cbig statement\xe2\x80\x9d record seem plausible. If he can put everything together, he\xe2\x80\x99ll have more at his disposal than most singers in any tradition.'

column7: b"Melina Duterte's careful, wise, and excellent album is the rare debut that expands the borders of a genre. It's not bedroom-pop because it sounds a certain way, but because it feels so intimate."
column8: b'Virtuous though it may be, patience is a difficult quality to capture in guitar rock, a medium that much prefers boldness, concision, and urgency. Perhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s why Bay Area multi-instrumentalist Melina Duterte\xe2\x80\x99s reverence for the human capacity to wait and think and grow comes across as a revelation on Everybody Works, her first official album as Jay Som. \xe2\x80\x9cTake time to figure it out,\xe2\x80\x9d she advises on lead single \xe2\x80\x9cThe Bus Song.\xe2\x80\x9d In its context, she\xe2\x80\x99s caught between relationship statuses, assuring the object of her fixation that she\xe2\x80\x99ll \xe2\x80\x9cbe the one who sticks around.\xe2\x80\x9d As an introduction to an album full of reminders not to rush things, though, the line is a relief, enough to make you involuntarily exhale.' b'Bedroom pop is a genre designation that loses meaning by the year\xe2\x80\x94not just as technology creeps closer to erasing any distinction between studio production and home recording, but also as the musicians associated with it develop tastes more varied and less retro than, say, Ariel Pink\xe2\x80\x99s. Twenty-two-year-old Duterte made the fuzzy, dreamy, plaintive aesthetic her own on Turn Into, nine self-recorded tracks she uploaded to Bandcamp on a tipsy whim over a year ago and re-released with Polyvinyl in late 2016, billing the makeshift debut as a collection of \xe2\x80\x9cfinished and unfinished songs\xe2\x80\x9d rather than a proper album. Although she made *Everybody Works *alone in her bedroom studio, its repertoire ranges from folk to funk to chart pop. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a bedroom-pop album because it sounds a certain way, but because it feels so intimate. Most of Duterte\xe2\x80\x99s elaborate songs could be mistaken for full-band compositions, yet her preference for writing and recording in solitude imbues each one with an introspective quality.' b'Liberated from the obligation to conform to any one sound, Duterte investigates new styles with purpose. She\xe2\x80\x99s smitten with Carly Rae Jepsen\xe2\x80\x99s E\xe2\x80\xa2MO\xe2\x80\xa2TION, and it shows in the hooky choruses of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Bus Song\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRemain,\xe2\x80\x9d two tracks steeped in exuberant longing. With its smooth keyboards and slinky bass line, \xe2\x80\x9cBaybee\xe2\x80\x9d comes on like an R&B slow jam, but instead of steaming up the windows, it\xe2\x80\x99s about seducing yourself into seeing your beloved through a rough patch: \xe2\x80\x9cIf I leave you alone/When you don\xe2\x80\x99t feel right/I know we\xe2\x80\x99ll sink for sure,\xe2\x80\x9d Duterte coos\xc2\xa0on top of the music, like a layer of pure calm. \xe2\x80\x9c1 Billion Dogs\xe2\x80\x9d submerges anxious lyrics in a cloud of feedback that melds shoegaze, indie pop, and grunge as if it were a forgotten gem from the *DGC Rarities *compilation.' b'But the most arresting songs are the ones that defy categorization entirely. The first minute of the album, on \xe2\x80\x9cLipstick Stains,\xe2\x80\x9d sounds the way orchestra instruments might upon waking from an afternoon nap, blinking and stretching in the sunlight. When the vocals kick in more than halfway through the track, Duterte\xe2\x80\x99s murmur is just as drowsily blissful: \xe2\x80\x9cI like the way your lipstick stains/The corner of my smile,\xe2\x80\x9d she breathes. Everybody Works closes with \xe2\x80\x9cFor Light,\xe2\x80\x9d an epic, seven-minute ballad that transforms a whispered promise\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be right on time/Open blinds for light/Won\xe2\x80\x99t forget to climb\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94into a sing-along prayer by adding in the voices of backup singers. The mood of weary resilience is reminiscent of Nick Cave\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPush the Sky Away,\xe2\x80\x9d another album-closing message of encouragement that fully acknowledges the herculean effort it takes, sometimes, to merely keep going.' b'As that comparison suggests, Duterte has absorbed more of life\xe2\x80\x99s hard lessons than most of us do by age 22. The patience that suffuses *Everybody Works *doesn\xe2\x80\x99t reflect the na\xc3\xafvet\xc3\xa9 of a kid who\xe2\x80\x99s sure she has unlimited time to chase her ambitions and find love; it comes out of an emotionally mature view of relationships and the 10\xc2\xa0years of work she has already put into her songwriting, taking shitty jobs and enduring family strife to become the musician she is today. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll remain under your moon,\xe2\x80\x9d she pledges on \xe2\x80\x9cRemain,\xe2\x80\x9d an anthem of (perhaps one-sided) commitment. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody Works\xe2\x80\x9d registers Duterte\xe2\x80\x99s resentment at how easily success seems to come to the \xe2\x80\x9crock star\xe2\x80\x9d who make her wonder, \xe2\x80\x9cDid you pay your way through?\xe2\x80\x9d But empathy wins out in the end; she makes \xe2\x80\x9ceverybody works\xe2\x80\x9d a mantra, repeating the phrase as though to remind herself of the way other people\xe2\x80\x99s painstaking efforts can be invisible to us.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll of my songs are so different, but you know it\xe2\x80\x99s me,\xe2\x80\x9d Duterte remarked in a recent Pitchfork profile. She\xe2\x80\x99s right, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no better indicator that a songwriter has found her voice than the ability to explore new styles and still sound like the same artist. Just a few years into her adult life, and only one album into her recording career, Melina Duterte has swept past a milestone many musicians never even get in their sights.'

column7: b'Ed Sheeran sells trite innocence by the pound. He uses bland wisdom and unimaginative\xc2\xa0music to ponder the basic good and bad in people around him, without once looking inward.'
column8: b'Ed Sheeran needs you to know that he did not go to university. Instead, he spent his teens slogging around the UK pub circuit, and by the age of 20, he was on his way to becoming Britain\xe2\x80\x99s biggest male pop star. Still, he likes to come back to the uni thing. He sings about not having a degree twice on his new album, \xc3\xb7, after at least three earlier instances in his catalog. He\xe2\x80\x99s fashioned this weighty chip on his shoulder into an arrow in his quiver, using it to shore up his everyman image and personable nature, while distinguishing himself as a bit of a cheeky system-shunning maverick who\xe2\x80\x99s made it this far on chops alone. His shtick is aspirational: All you need is free will, a little song in your heart, and perhaps you too could one day be playing for 270,000 people across three nights at Wembley Stadium.' b'Innocence is key to the Ed Sheeran brand. His self-proclaimed uncoolness is what makes him both cool and impervious to bad-tempered criticism. He regularly describes his true love as an angel, refers to his father\xe2\x80\x94a perpetually lingering prophet\xe2\x80\x94as \xe2\x80\x9cdaddy,\xe2\x80\x9d and sings tenderly about his grandparents. On \xc3\xb7\xe2\x80\x99s release day, he sold copies of his record in an HMV superstore, and looked indistinguishable from the full-time staff. There\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt that Sheeran is calculating, but then he told you as much in his album titles (\xc3\xb7, 2014\xe2\x80\x99s x, and 2011\xe2\x80\x99s +). Like Sia, the Chainsmokers, and Charli XCX, he marvels at his ability to turn out generic hooks like nobody\xe2\x80\x99s business\xe2\x80\x94so many, he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even remember writing them when they hit No. 1 in 17 countries.' b'This is the genial, antiseptic frame through which we\xe2\x80\x99re to view Ed Sheeran. But considering he is among the most successful songwriters in the world, a lot of his lyrics do not even scan. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just a boy with a one-man show, no un-er-ver-si-tee..., just a song I wrote,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings in \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Do I Know?\xe2\x80\x9d like a teenage boy trying to knot a cherry stem with his tongue. When he raps, as he does on \xe2\x80\x9cEraser,\xe2\x80\x9d his words fit together with the elegance of Stickle Bricks. Good taste is of no concern: He lets John Mayer sleaze all over the tender ode to his girlfriend \xe2\x80\x9cHow Would You Feel? (Paean)\xe2\x80\x9d with his guitar. Although you can practically hear Rihanna\xe2\x80\x99s laugh after being offered the tropical house concession \xe2\x80\x9cShape of You,\xe2\x80\x9d the song generally fares fine until Sheeran, the seventh richest British musician under the age of 30, admits to his dating style: \xe2\x80\x9cYou and me are thrifty so go all you can eat/Fill up your bag and I fill up a plate/We talk for hours and hours about the sweet and the sour.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'There is no greater evidence of Sheeran\xe2\x80\x99s commercial power than his label acquiescing to keep Corrs tribute \xe2\x80\x9cGalway Girl\xe2\x80\x9d on this album. Set to bodhr\xc3\xa1n and uileann pipes, it\xe2\x80\x99s the latest of many Sheeran barnstormers about meeting a great gal (who is definitely real) on a boozy night out. A check from the Irish tourist board for him name-dropping Guinness, Jameson, John Powers, and Van Morrison may be forthcoming, which would certainly cover any forthcoming lawsuit from B*Witched for infringing on their 1998 hit \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x99est La Vie.\xe2\x80\x9d Sheeran traveled the world for a year before making this record, and considering his cultural takeaway from County Galway, we should be thankful his travels didn\xe2\x80\x99t also inspire him to write a song about lassoing une mademoiselle with a string of onions beneath the Eiffel Tower, or how love sprang eternal with a girl in a dirndl in Austria.' b'On his past records, Sheeran often painted himself as a drunken mess, at the mercy of bad girls and dark situations. Whatever you made of them, they felt, to use a dirty word, honest. Here, \xe2\x80\x9cEraser\xe2\x80\x9d feels like the only true reflection of his psyche, where he acknowledges his unrelatable predicament (\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t nobody wanna see you down in the dumps/Because you\xe2\x80\x99re living your dream, man/This shit should be fun\xe2\x80\x9d). For the rest of the record, he switches to a mode of bland wisdom that allows him to ponder the good and bad in people around him rather than look inwards. The lack of honesty doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really matter\xe2\x80\x94nobody\xe2\x80\x99s going to Sheeran for gritty soul-searching. But the lack of imagination does. As with Adele, who was also told by Rick Rubin to go back to the drawing board, you suspect that more interesting songs may have been left off the record for commercial reasons.' b'If there\xe2\x80\x99s a personal touch to Sheeran\xe2\x80\x99s generic sentiments, it\xe2\x80\x99s his unwavering belief in love. He\xe2\x80\x99s often burned for it, he\xe2\x80\x99s desperate for kids, he sees the future in his girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. Over the simpering groove of \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Do I Know?\xe2\x80\x9d he talks about how his \xe2\x80\x9cdaddy\xe2\x80\x9d told him, \xe2\x80\x9cSon, don\xe2\x80\x99t you get involved in politics, religion or other people\xe2\x80\x99s quarrel.\xe2\x80\x9d Instead, like a Disney woodland creature, he just wants to pass on \xe2\x80\x9cthe things my family\xe2\x80\x99s given to me: just love and understanding, positivity.\xe2\x80\x9d His feeble message falls apart when the self-confessed careerist sighs at someone surely in his same tax bracket for talking \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98bout exponential growth, and the stock market crashing and their portfolios/While I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sitting here with a song that I wrote.\xe2\x80\x9d Sheeran\xe2\x80\x99s conditional optimism flashes back into view, and shows his judgmental ass: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m all for people following their dreams/Just remember life is more than fit-tin\xe2\x80\x99 in your jeans,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, in a chummy, winking dig at the basic, vapid women who do not share his own basic, vapid worldview.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s one of several striking lyrics about appearances on \xc3\xb7, which is where the Nice Guy fa\xc3\xa7ade comes undone. Sheeran has always loved to neg and to position himself as an innocent victim. If you thought he\xe2\x80\x99d got all that out of his system when he co-wrote Bieber\xe2\x80\x99s risible \xe2\x80\x9cLove Yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d you were wrong. \xe2\x80\x9cPerfect\xe2\x80\x9d is \xe2\x80\x9cUnchained Melody\xe2\x80\x9d by way of Westlife, and a tender assurance to his beloved that she\xe2\x80\x99s not a mess, but a beauty. The barely suppressed creepiness of \xe2\x80\x9cHappier\xe2\x80\x9d is his attempt at post-breakup maturity, but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even last into the next track, \xe2\x80\x9cNew Man,\xe2\x80\x9d a wounded sketch of his ex\xe2\x80\x99s new boyfriend who has \xe2\x80\x9chis eyebrows plucked and his arsehole bleached,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwears a man bag on his shoulder but I call it a purse.\xe2\x80\x9d One nil, Sheeran. He turns his attentions to his ex. What happened to that sweet, sylvan girl who used to read and eat crisps by the river? \xe2\x80\x9cNow she\xe2\x80\x99s eatin\xe2\x80\x99 kale/Hittin\xe2\x80\x99 the gym/Keepin\xe2\x80\x99 up with Kylie and Kim.\xe2\x80\x9d You mean, when she could be listening to Sheeran rap about his daddy?' b"This is not to say that anyone should expect Sheeran\xe2\x80\x94who is popular at weddings and funerals for a reason\xe2\x80\x94to present a nuanced interpretation of gender politics within his songs (though his fans deserve more than depictions of women as angels or traitors). But more than his weak balladry, it's this disingenuous side that rankles. In the nostalgic vein of Lukas Graham\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c7 Years\xe2\x80\x9d and Drake\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWeston Road Flows,\xe2\x80\x9d Sheeran\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCastle on the Hill\xe2\x80\x9d yearns for a childhood idyll. It\xe2\x80\x99s pure sentimentality,\xc2\xa0another\xc2\xa0key to how he uses humblebraggadocio and innocence to shore up his moral high ground over shallow girls and unfair beauty standards. On \xe2\x80\x9cEraser,\xe2\x80\x9d Sheeran sings, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m well aware of certain things that will befall a man like me.\xe2\x80\x9d He means booze and drugs, but it\xe2\x80\x99s his inability to reconcile his early underdog status with his titanic popularity that\xe2\x80\x99ll ensnare him. Sheeran wants it both ways: artist and celebrity, nice guy who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to alienate his fans with political convictions, anti-consumerist while gagging to dominate pop\xe2\x80\x99s arms race. He\xe2\x80\x99s the guy she told you not to worry about, and he\xe2\x80\x99s wearing your clothes."

column7: b'Made\xc2\xa0mostly on an iPhone, the first project from 18-year-old producer Steve Lacy\xe2\x80\x94also a member of the Internet\xe2\x80\x94sparkles with classic Southern California funk and soul.'
column8: b'There are only 13 minutes of music on Steve Lacy\xe2\x80\x99s debut project, but that\xe2\x80\x99s enough time for him to make a serious impression. Over the course of six tracks that sparkle with classic Southern California funk and soul, the producer, just barely out of high school, offers up a dazzling number of musical ideas. Steve Lacy\xe2\x80\x99s Demo is all the more remarkable for the fact that most of the record was produced on an iPhone.' b'Lacy, 18,\xc2\xa0joined his school\xe2\x80\x99s jazz band in ninth grade, where he met Jameel Bruner, the younger brother of superstar bassist, Thundercat. When Bruner was recruited to play keyboards on the Internet\xe2\x80\x99s third album, Ego Death, he invited Lacy to join the group in the studio. The band must have been impressed: Lacy ended up earning himself individual production credits on six\xc2\xa0of the album\xe2\x80\x99s 12 tracks and an executive producer credit, becoming a full-on member. The album was a breakthrough success for the Internet, occasioning rave reviews, winning the group a Grammy nomination, and reminding the world again that its young members\xe2\x80\x94Syd, Matt Martians, and now Lacy\xe2\x80\x94had massive potential.' b'All three have released solo projects in early 2017. Lacy has classified\xc2\xa0Demo as a \xe2\x80\x9csong series\xe2\x80\x9d rather than an album or EP, a modesty belied by the fact that he has called the songs \xe2\x80\x9cperfect.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s not far off\xe2\x80\x94the music here is startlingly mature, full of dimension and depth, as if Lacy were accompanied by a full band rather than doing everything, right down to the mixing, by his lonesome. The opening song, \xe2\x80\x9cLooks,\xe2\x80\x9d kicks off with drums, adventurous bass, a wobbling synth, and gorgeous falsetto harmonies\xc2\xa0that lead in to the solitary verse. All those layers are in service of a song that\xe2\x80\x99s, of all things, a rejection of superficiality. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat if I got with you and turned out to be a total dick,\xe2\x80\x9d Lacy cautions. \xe2\x80\x9cWould you be happy \xe2\x80\x99bout that?\xe2\x80\x9d The song is all too brief\xe2\x80\x94it melts in your mouth before two\xc2\xa0minutes are up.' b'Talented musicians often lean on their chops, noodling at their instruments at the expense of tight songcraft. If anything, Lacy has almost the opposite problem: Many of the outstanding musical moments here feel teased rather than fulfilled. The verse that opens \xe2\x80\x9cRyd\xe2\x80\x9d could easily become a hook anchoring a full song\xe2\x80\x94instead, it\xe2\x80\x99s merely a bookend, a sliver of something great. But Lacy\xc2\xa0is so multitalented in his vocal range and his creative percussion (check the drums on \xe2\x80\x9cHaterlovin\xe2\x80\x9d), in his ability to wring soulfulness out of guitar and bass alike, that\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to isolate one\xc2\xa0single element at which he most\xc2\xa0excels.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cDark Red\xe2\x80\x9d is the clear standout, the only song in which each part\xc2\xa0lingers for the appropriate amount of time. The swirling melodies on the chorus float atop the beat as a melodic counterpoint, an effect Lacy has said was influenced by David Longstreth\xe2\x80\x99s work with Dirty Projectors.\xc2\xa0And the aching quality of the music, complemented by the Motown harmonies that round out its back half, matches the song\xe2\x80\x99s theme, a plea lobbed at a partner who\xe2\x80\x99s beginning to turn away.' b'Despite its brevity,\xc2\xa0Demo is reminiscent of another auspicious debut, one that emerged more than 15 years ago. Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo had already made their mark as producers with the Neptunes, but their first\xc2\xa0album in\xc2\xa0the band NERD, In Search Of\xe2\x80\xa6**, was stronger and stranger than anything they had come up with before. And as\xc2\xa0its songs became cult classics,\xc2\xa0In Search Of... announced\xc2\xa0Pharrell as someone who could star in front of the camera, not just behind the boards. Steve Lacy\xe2\x80\x99s Demo evokes that record in its charisma and musical ability. Given that it\xe2\x80\x99s not even 15\xc2\xa0minutes, the record can\xe2\x80\x99t be said to be anything more than a particularly tasty appetizer. But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine the listener who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t yearn for the next course.'

column7: b'Working from an old, dog-eared indie rock blueprint, this\xc2\xa0Melbourne trio\xc2\xa0delight in redrafting the lines. The French Press\xc2\xa0shines just as bright as their last EP, but the songs\xc2\xa0cast darker shadows.'
column8: b'With their debut 2015 EP, Talk Tight, Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever proved to be one of those special bands that arrives seemingly out of nowhere with a fully realized aesthetic. No tentative baby steps or half-formed experiments for this lot; Talk Tight\xc2\xa0exuded confidence and purpose, yielding five\xc2\xa0propulsive, jangly pop gems that felt instantly familiar. And its appeal was cross-generational. If you were raised on \xe2\x80\x9980s college rock, you could revel in nostalgic nods to the Feelies, the Clean, the Go-Betweens, and countless other Velvets revisionists. Younger fans\xc2\xa0could hear the sort of band the Strokes might have turned into had they aged more gracefully, or imagine what Real Estate might sound like after downing a case of Red Bull.' b'But while working from an old, dog-eared indie rock blueprint, the Melbourne band take great delight in redrafting the lines. With three distinctive singer-guitarists\xe2\x80\x94Tom Russo, Fran Keaney, and Joe White\xe2\x80\x94at the helm, Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever don\xe2\x80\x99t operate so much like a traditional rock band as an improv theater troupe riffing on a pre-established theme. The locomotive rhythm may be locked in, but each member is free to ride it wherever they please. A Rolling Blackouts song rarely retraces its steps, often eschewing standard verse/chorus/verse structure for a parade of changing melodic motifs that are passed around the singers like hot potatoes. In the case of Talk Tight highlights like \xe2\x80\x9cClean Slate,\xe2\x80\x9d that meant you essentially got three great songs for the price of one.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a trick that (the now abbreviated) Rolling Blackouts C.F. still pull off with great aplomb on follow-up EP The French Press.\xc2\xa0Its six songs shine just as bright as those on Talk Tight, but they cast longer, darker shadows. You can sense the subtle change in temperament within the first 30 seconds of \xe2\x80\x9cFrench Press,\xe2\x80\x9d where the band work a taut motorik build reminiscent of Broken Social Scene\xe2\x80\x99s anxious anthem \xe2\x80\x9cCause = Time.\xe2\x80\x9d Taking full advantage of their Forster/McLennan-style dynamic, Russo and Keaney play the roles of brothers\xe2\x80\x94one traveling abroad, the other stuck at a miserable desk job\xe2\x80\x94as they try to converse over a patchy Skype connection. But as the song\xe2\x80\x99s incessant forward motion intensifies, the technological divide comes to symbolize the emotional one at the core of their relationship: \xe2\x80\x9cBrother don\xe2\x80\x99t you know,\xe2\x80\x9d Russo sings, \xe2\x80\x9cthat jealousy\xe2\x80\x99s a curse, and what\xe2\x80\x99s worse is the silence/Strange\xe2\x80\xa6 you\xe2\x80\x99re moving out of range.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'\xe2\x80\x9cFrench Press\xe2\x80\x9d sets the tone for a record filled with seemingly innocuous scenes that suddenly turn tense. Even the songs that more readily evoke Talk Tight\xe2\x80\x99s carefree kicks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJulie\xe2\x80\x99s Place,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cColours Run\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94bound about at a more furious clip, powered by blurry-handed acoustic/electric strums liable to leave blood on the pick-ups. Just as Rolling Blackouts\xe2\x80\x99 music provides an instant sense of comfort through its \xe2\x80\x9980s indie-pop signifiers, lyrically, they make you feel right at home by dropping you in the middle of intimate scenes populated by first-name-basis characters. But that also means we\xe2\x80\x99re sometimes privy to conversations we\xe2\x80\x99re not supposed to hear. Atop the twitchy twang of \xe2\x80\x9cSick Bug,\xe2\x80\x9d White\xe2\x80\x99s yearning reminiscence of an old flame (\xe2\x80\x9cI close my eyes to take you back/She touched my leg\xe2\x80\x9d) triggers a frantic torrent of \xe2\x80\x9cI want you! I want you! I want you! I want you!,\xe2\x80\x9d crystallizing that moment when the decorum of romance gets steamrolled by the indignities of desire.' b'Even as The French Press mellows out, it never really settles. The casual lope of \xe2\x80\x9cDig Up\xe2\x80\x9d puts a sunny, soft-focus filter on a portrait of a relationship\xe2\x80\x99s painfully slow demise (\xe2\x80\x9cThe walls are closing in all around us/I feel the moment\xe2\x80\x99s passing us by\xe2\x80\x9d). And the swooning, harmony-rich chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cFountain of Good Fortune\xe2\x80\x9d offers a precious taste of honey to chase Russo\xe2\x80\x99s bitter-pill critique of organized religion: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been washed, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been anointed/I\xe2\x80\x99ve eaten the body of the Lord/It\xe2\x80\x99s from the fountain of good fortune/Brings dirty, cloudy water/That pollutes the mind of anyone around.\xe2\x80\x9d Like Talk Tight, The French Press is brimming with vim, vigor, and open-road abandon. But what makes it an even more compelling listen is that, this time, we get a clearer glimpse in the rear-view mirror of the stressors they\xe2\x80\x99re trying to escape.'

column7: b'Waxwork Records\xc2\xa0goes all out with its\xc2\xa0deluxe vinyl reissue of Ennio Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s minimal score\xc2\xa0to John Carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0The Thing\xe2\x80\x94a 1982 box-office stiff that has only this century become\xc2\xa0a\xc2\xa0horror classic.'
column8: b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe quintessential moron movie of the \xe2\x80\x9980s\xe2\x80\xa6 too phony looking to be disgusting.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAbout as impersonal as a movie can be.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cA great barf-bag movie.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt qualifies only as instant junk.\xe2\x80\x9d Such was the critical consensus surrounding John Carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s 1982 The Thing, about a shape-shifting alien coated in \xe2\x80\x9ccreamed corn, Jell-O, mayonnaise, microwaved bubblegum, and five-gallon pails of K-Y Jelly.\xe2\x80\x9d Opening the same weekend the world met a more benevolent beer-gut alien in E.T., The Thing was a box-office stiff at the time. Only in this century has pop culture thawed to its Antarctic plot. The Thing is now perceived as a classic of the paranoid Reagan era, and since bombing in theaters, the movie has led to a comic book, amusement park ride, action figures, prequel, video game, and Hugo-nominated short story.' b'After years of operating on shoestring horror movie budgets, The Thing gave Carpenter approximately $15 million for its gory effects and blustery locations. It also meant that\xe2\x80\x94for the first time in a feature\xe2\x80\x94Carpenter didn\xe2\x80\x99t need to whip up his own score at the last minute. Unable to handle composing duties in addition to everything else The Thing required, Carpenter outsourced the music to the Maestro, Ennio Morricone.' b'Following decades of success in Europe and his iconic scores for spaghetti westerns, Morricone was only just making inroads into Hollywood. Despite having hundreds of credits to his name, Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s scores remain instantly recognizable, be they the yips of The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, the stinging surf guitars of Danger Diabolik, or the romantic orchestral swells of The Mission. Watching the film when it screened at BAM a few years ago, it was startling when Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s name emerged on the credits for The Thing\xe2\x80\x94so minimal, restrained, and atmospheric is his score.' b'Waxwork goes all out with this deluxe vinyl reissue of The Thing, an exquisite package, right down to a breakaway \xe2\x80\x9cice\xe2\x80\x9d slipcase. But those hoping to hear the telltale bum-bum that thuds throughout the film and chills the blood might be perplexed at first\xe2\x80\x94those were instances where Carpenter and his frequent collaborator Alan Howarth added extra cues, and don\xe2\x80\x99t emerge until late in the soundtrack. Instead, this reissue opens with Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHumanity (Part 1),\xe2\x80\x9d a gossamer motif on violin and harp that appears nearly 20 minutes in, which then edges into a more foreboding low-end. It\xe2\x80\x99s a stark piece, one as compositionally cold as the Antarctic landscape itself.' b'Revisit the film, and it\xe2\x80\x99s the extra patina of electronics that remains most foreboding\xe2\x80\x94the slow drones that make the skin prickle. (Cue the Thing\xe2\x80\x99s arachnid emergence in the dog kennel and tossing a flare onto the tentacular Bennings, for instance.) At times, though, Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s themes sound like the alien himself attempting to recreate Carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s iconic analog synths. The relatively unmemorable \xe2\x80\x9cShape,\xe2\x80\x9d with its bowed cello and brass, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t bring to mind a particular scene from the film\xe2\x80\x94nor does the frantic pizzicato of \xe2\x80\x9cContamination.\xe2\x80\x9d And the bombastic lurches of \xe2\x80\x9cBestiality\xe2\x80\x9d feel too pompous in the context of the minimalist film. Given that Morricone composed suites while only looking at an early rough cut of the film, it makes sense that his cues (some of which went unused) seem out of sync with the film\xe2\x80\x99s frigid aesthetic. Separated from Carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s Antarctic imagery, Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s cues sound unfamiliar; one would be hard-pressed to recall their corresponding sequences.' b'Midway through, Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s themes strike a balance between acoustic, human sounds and cold electronics. The strings of \xe2\x80\x9cSolitude\xe2\x80\x9d oscillate between anxious and vertiginous. Keys twinkle like melting icicles on the electronic-tinged \xe2\x80\x9cEternity,\xe2\x80\x9d soon joined by a church organ line that seems to be perpetually in descent, ratcheting up the tension and creating a sense of the inevitable. A meandering synth piece, \xe2\x80\x9cSterilization,\xe2\x80\x9d shows Morricone not altogether comfortable mixing these two distinct palettes together.' b'Only on \xe2\x80\x9cHumanity (Part 2)\xe2\x80\x9d do those forlorn electronic throbs emerge, paired with a desolate theme across woodwinds. It\xe2\x80\x99s on this motif that the film\xe2\x80\x99s frost-tipped dread is most closely felt\xe2\x80\x94so it\xe2\x80\x99s a shame that, after four minutes, it suddenly lurches back into an overstated organ theme. In emphasizing the seething electronics and excising all but crucial bits of Morricone\xe2\x80\x99s original score, Carpenter proved that his vision for the film remained intact. History has bore that out and, unlike this original soundtrack, such barf bag junk has now attained its rightful place as a frightful horror classic.'

column7: b'Today we commemorate the 20th anniversary of the death of Christopher Wallace with a review of his 1994 debut\xc2\xa0Ready to Die, an unparalleled piece of rap history.'
column8: b"New York City doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sell drugs anymore. Sure, there are bike messengers that peddle weed packed in plastic jars and Russian mobsters who launder money through Coney Island auto-shops, but the kind of trap-house, dope-boy, Robin Hood archetype that still carries in cities like Atlanta has been wiped clean from tri-state folklore. This is undoubtedly a good thing\xe2\x80\x94entrepreneurial city teens today hustle fashion trends to ogling editors instead of baggies to scraggly addicts. But the shift has fossilized a certain kind of rap album, like The Notorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s debut\xc2\xa0Ready to Die, released in 1994. The lawlessness it describes\xe2\x80\x94robberies at gunpoint on the A train, open-air hand-to-hand crack deals on Fulton St., shootouts with the NYPD\xe2\x80\x94land unfathomably to most New Yorkers today. Young transplants and natives alike would rather hear old tall tales than experience anything near it firsthand; distinct from nostalgia, it's more like moving into a home where a murder occurred. The thrill is a combination of fear and gall, rooted in the security that the scene will likely never repeat itself." b'But there may be something habitual in New York\xe2\x80\x99s craned gaze backward. Note that B.I.G. opened Ready to Die by complaining about changes in the city around him over 20 years ago. Even then, the album was a reflection: an over-the-top, fisheye union address of the city\xe2\x80\x99s waning crack era, and a reeling admission that something must have gone terribly wrong for it to have happened. Its intro maps B.I.G\xe2\x80\x99s life against the sounds of various eras\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9970s \xe2\x80\x9cSuperfly,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9880s \xe2\x80\x9cTop Billin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9890s Doggystyle\xe2\x80\x94before the 21-year-old launches into \xe2\x80\x9cThings Done Changed,\xe2\x80\x9d an opening monologue that sets the chaotic scene. Life used to be about funny hairstyles, curbside games, and lounging at barbecues, he says, but \xe2\x80\x9cTurn your pagers to 1993,\xe2\x80\x9d and the story has taken an inexplicably dark turn. It goes unmentioned here, but hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s region of choice had changed too: New York\xe2\x80\x99s first generation of rap inventors had given way to the West Coast, so it\xe2\x80\x99s Dr. Dre\xe2\x80\x99s voice we hear between verses, dispatching from Compton. \xe2\x80\x9cThings done changed on this side,\xe2\x80\x9d the sample declares, a savvy appropriation that characterized a rise in violence across coasts, and a shift in sound that B.I.G. hoped to correct.' b'In 1992, \xe2\x80\x9ca whole lot of niggas want[ed] Big to make a demo tape.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99d been battling around Fulton St since he was 13, and was known in Bedford-Stuyvesant as a force, in music and otherwise. The demo he recorded, \xe2\x80\x9cMicrophone Murderer,\xe2\x80\x9d along with a few other cuts, made it\xe2\x80\x99s way to The Source\xe2\x80\x99s Unsigned Hype column, then influential in hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s walled off media environment, and then to Bad Boy, where Sean \xe2\x80\x9cPuffy\xe2\x80\x9d Combs would sign him. But as the demo\xe2\x80\x99s opening line specified, it was only at the nudging of his close friends that he pursued music\xe2\x80\x94B.I.G. was splitting time between Brooklyn and Raleigh, where he\xe2\x80\x99d set up a profitable drug operation. When his record advance didn\xe2\x80\x99t land quickly enough, he went back to N.C. to pick up the slack, and Puffy called him, alternately begging and demanding the rapper stop hustling and return to New York, devoted to music for good. The day that he left, the Raleigh house he\xe2\x80\x99d operated out of was raided by police officers.' b'What made Christopher Wallace pop-palatable amid such a gruesome backdrop was his humor, personality, and wit. He was a gruff, neurotic alternative to the ice-cool Snoop Dogg: if Snoop had bitches in the living room till six in the morning, B.I.G. was getting paged at 5:46, wiping cold out his eye. If Cali crossed over with low-rider funk from Parliament, New York would ride on block-party boogie from Mtume. And if taut flows were giving way to languid hooks, B.I.G. would tighten everyone back up. \xe2\x80\x9cUnbelievable\xe2\x80\x9d was the antithesis of \xe2\x80\x9cJuicy,\xe2\x80\x9d a love-letter to underground rap radio shows like Stretch & Bobbito, and to anyone with an oversized Land Cruiser (another change to consider\xe2\x80\x94New Yorkers used to drive). \xe2\x80\x9cThose that rushes my clutches get put on crutches, get smoked like dutches, from the master\xe2\x80\x9d; you can hear the roots of \xe2\x80\x9cpunchline rap\xe2\x80\x9d forming in Big\xe2\x80\x99s puns and internal rhyme, and the ironic turns of phrase that kids like Cam\xe2\x80\x99ron would intensify years later: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I thought he was wack!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Oh come, come, now, why y\xe2\x80\x99all so dumb now?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'At the time, the album was praised for its honest portrayal of the drug dealer\xe2\x80\x99s internal conflicts, as opposed to sunny glorification of gang violence imported from L.A. Songs like \xe2\x80\x9cEveryday Struggle\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSuicidal Thoughts\xe2\x80\x9d showed Big\xe2\x80\x99s depth, frequent references to his mother showed his rearing, and casual dropping of words like \xe2\x80\x9cplacenta\xe2\x80\x9d showed his coy love of language. B.I.G. was a smart kid that had (or liked) to do dumb things, the record suggested, itself a comment on the how genius gets sharpened when faced with obstacles, and an affirmation of rap as a platform for such genius to be realized, and monetized.' b'Despite its author\xe2\x80\x99s youth, *Ready To Die *shows its age with its production. The beats already paled in comparison to the high-definition score of Life After Death, B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s follow up album, and the tinny drums and swampy samples on tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cMe and My Bitch\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRespect\xe2\x80\x9d probably played better on cassette than they do on Apple Music. At the time of the album\xe2\x80\x99s release, more nimble producers were doing interesting work on neighboring albums\xe2\x80\x94one could say Illmatic dried everyone in New York up of their best material. The major tracks on Ready to Die\xc2\xa0had to be heavy-handed, and the filler was just an excuse to hear Big keep rapping. \xe2\x80\x9cBig Poppa\xe2\x80\x9d was inseparable from Ron Isley\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBetween the Sheets\xe2\x80\x9d and snuck in a trendy, post-regional synth line that would perk up West Coast ears. The \xe2\x80\x9cOne More Chance\xe2\x80\x9d remix became a smash crossover hit; the original included on the album is expectedly disposable. Even strong exhibitions of songwriting like \xe2\x80\x9cThe What\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cGimme the Loot\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94one a duet with Method Man, the other with himself\xe2\x80\x94are weighed down by loops from Easy Mo Bee, a dated producer who Puffy might\xe2\x80\x99ve been smart to have axed shortly after.' b'Which brings us to the true triumph in Ready to Die\xe2\x80\x94Sean Combs, who\xe2\x80\x99s been able to spot a dollar hidden in the most unlikely places ever since, finds proof-of-concept for New York hip-pop that can carry from street corners to school dances, with the right sonic contexts, visual branding, and occasional ad-libs, a formula he\xe2\x80\x99d apply to Mase, Shyne, and his own material thereafter. The sounds may have shifted, but the thesis remains: drug dealers have stories for days, and Americans want to hear them. We revere the salesman more than the politician, and B.I.G. could sell the hell out of the life he lived. Maybe not all that much has changed after all.' b''

column7: b"Today we commemorate the 20th anniversary of Christopher Wallace's death with a review of his 1997 sophomore album L**ife After Death, released 16 days after he was murdered."
column8: b"Life After Death, The Notorious B.I.G.'s second and final full-length studio album, which also serves as his first posthumous release, begins where its predecessor, 1994's Ready to Die left off: with the narrator dying from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. The blast comes courtesy of a large-bore cartridge from a high-powered revolver, while his best friend and confidante\xe2\x80\x94played by label boss and possible svengali, Sean \xe2\x80\x9cPuff Daddy\xe2\x80\x9d Combs\xe2\x80\x94listens in disbelief, possibly willing him back to life, possibly imagining an alternate reality where Christopher Wallace remains alive." b'Ready to Die, Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s previous album, also began with heart-pulling cinematic flourishes, featuring a decade-spanning montage that played as a mini saga telling the tale of a small-time street thug who was raised in a dysfunctional home and turned into a formidably successful rapper. But where the first album started with a feeling of hope arising from the muck and mire of urban poverty, Life After Death announces itself in much starker fashion.' b"The proper arrival of this album comes on \xe2\x80\x9cSomebody's Gotta Die,\xe2\x80\x9d a pure revenge tale. It begins sometime within the last record\xe2\x80\x99s timeline, with Big \xe2\x80\x9csittin' in the crib dreamin' about Learjets and coupes, the way Salt 'shoops', and how to sell records like Snoop,\xe2\x80\x9d when a fellow small-time drug dealer and jailmate informs him that a mutual friend has been shot for robbing a crack dealer in a most ruthless manner (\xe2\x80\x9cpistol whipped his kids and taped up his wife\xe2\x80\x9d). Big's reaction is immediate: \xe2\x80\x9cIs he in critical? Retaliation for this one won't be minimal \xe2\x80\x99cause I'm a criminal; way before the rap shit, bust the gat shit\xe2\x80\x94Puff won't even know what happened.\xe2\x80\x9d We\xe2\x80\x99re settling into a bloody noir, complete with well-developed minor characters harboring demented pathos and subtle foreshadowing\xe2\x80\x94all this before any hints of a radio single." b"This feat of storytelling is repeated two more times on the first disc of this double album alone. On \xe2\x80\x9cNiggas Bleed,\xe2\x80\x9d Big is a bagman sent to secure a large drug transaction, but his greed has him thinking about a double-cross: \xe2\x80\x9cI kill them all, I'll be set for life,\xe2\x80\x9d he imagines. He decides to call up his friend\xe2\x80\x94a flashy and hard-hearted cutthroat from the Southwest who was once featured on America's Most Wanted\xe2\x80\x94to partake in a heist that involves a female Puerto Rican hotel worker who used to be drug boss, and a Jamaican with long dreadlocks and a taste for Asian women. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tour de force\xe2\x80\x94a time-shifting tale that devotes a whole verse to the backstory of a murderous misfit straight from an Elmore Leonard short who substitutes kerosene for gasoline because \xe2\x80\x9cfuck it, it's flame-able.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"But \xe2\x80\x9cI Got a Story to Tell,\xe2\x80\x9d the recount of an after-hours creep with an NBA player\xe2\x80\x99s girlfriend that culminates in physical assault and robbery, may be the most absurd tale of the bunch, because it's reportedly true. \xe2\x80\x9cStory\xe2\x80\x9d highlights Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s gifts as a raconteur. Inside his braggadocio, cars are colored with verve: a \xe2\x80\x9ccherry M3\xe2\x80\x9d BMW, a \xe2\x80\x9cmarine blue 6 coupe\xe2\x80\x9d Mercedes, a \xe2\x80\x9cchampagne Range\xe2\x80\x9d Rover. For his fictional tales, names and locales are doled out like characters in hardboiled pulp fictions: \xe2\x80\x9cArizona Ron from Tuscon,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cGloria from Astoria,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDarkskin Jermaine\xe2\x80\x9d who \xe2\x80\x9cnearly lost half his brain over two bricks of cocaine, getting his dick sucked by Crackhead Lorraine.\xe2\x80\x9d But, when it comes to the truth, he's shy on specifics. No names, no states, no boroughs, or other signifiers are mentioned. When pressed by his friends as to the identity of the cuckold, he brushes it off: \xe2\x80\x9cOne of them 6' 5\xe2\x80\x9d niggas\xe2\x80\x94I don't know.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"Double albums tend to be overblown, self-indulgent cash grabs, but Life After Death warranted the approach. Beginning with the 1994 Quad Studios shooting of Tupac Shakur in New York City, the Notorious B.I.G\xe2\x80\x94along with Combs, Shakur, and Suge Knight\xe2\x80\x94was at the center of a multifaceted rivalry. It was a struggle between N.Y.'s Bad Boy and L.A.'s Death Row records that surpassed label affiliation to become about coastal loyalty, arguments about commercialism vs. art that spread from the music industry to the public, whispers of motives and allegiances ran from the streets to the urban criminal underworld. Big easily had more than one album's worth of material to talk about." b"Not only did he have more drawn on, he had more ways to talk about it than anyone else. More than anyone one else in rap ever, Big was able to break language and bend syntax to speak about things in ways that were unforeseen yet seemingly unavoidable in hindsight: \xe2\x80\x9cAt last, a nigga rappin' 'bout blunts and broads, tits and bras, m\xc3\xa9nage \xc3\xa0 trois, sex in expensive cars, and still leave you on the pavement,\xe2\x80\x9d he rapped on the No. 1 radio single \xe2\x80\x9cHypnotize.\xe2\x80\x9d He continued: \xe2\x80\x9cCondo paid for, no car payment. At my arraignment, note for the plaintiff, 'Your daughter's tied up in a Brooklyn basement.' Face it: not guilty\xe2\x80\x94that's how I stay filthy.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"Big was a master of flow, sounding unforced and unlabored over a bevy of pristine, hi-fidelity maximalist beats that seemed to always bow to his intent. His voice was that of a gentle giant; a sumo ballerina who could deashi and pas de bourr\xc3\xa9e, henka and plie. Few terms in any tongue can capture the way Big was light on his words while heavy on thought. He made his slams look like pirouettes even over the most grating pop moves like \xe2\x80\x9cMo Money Mo Problems,\xe2\x80\x9d which showcased Combs' predilection for turning \xe2\x80\x9880s R&B hits into \xe2\x80\x9890s rap tunes\xe2\x80\x94a push and pull between producer and artist that remains unmatched in hip-hop to this day." b"This infamous tug between Combs' pop predilections and Big\xe2\x80\x99s gully tendencies is all over Life After Death: the way the sequencing goes from the Herb Alpert-sampling \xe2\x80\x9cHypnotize\xe2\x80\x9d to DJ Premier's Screamin' Jay Hawkins chop on \xe2\x80\x9cKick in the Door\xe2\x80\x9d to a boudoir ballad with the R. Kelly-assisted \xe2\x80\x9cFuck You Tonight\xe2\x80\x9d to black glove tough talk with The Lox on \xe2\x80\x9cLast Day\xe2\x80\x9d to lavish ballerism on the Ren\xc3\xa9 & Angela remake \xe2\x80\x9cI Love the Dough\xe2\x80\x9d with Jay Z. It's a wrenching of the ridiculous that Big wins at every turn by being on \xe2\x80\x9cthat Brooklyn bullshit\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cHypnotize\xe2\x80\x9d; by making \xe2\x80\x9cFuck You Tonight\xe2\x80\x9d unprofitable without a heavily-edited radio version; by squeezing so many words and skillful mispronunciations and imagery like wearing precious stones \xe2\x80\x9cin beards and mustaches\xe2\x80\x9d into \xe2\x80\x9cI Love the Dough.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"Despite being 24 cuts deep, the album never wears on\xe2\x80\x94the quick twists, deep moods, dark humor, and mastered artistry more than hold your attention. But, still: Like even a good movie, you're ready for it to end when it ends, and it climaxes with songs that deliver on the promise of the era of conflict (and death and rage and extremism) that surrounded Big in 1997. Due to his assassination 20 years ago on March 9th, the last three songs\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMy Downfall,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cLong Kiss Goodnight,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cYou're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You)\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94were never enjoyed by the public at large while Big was alive. Today, it's almost impossible to hear them as anything other than war songs for the dead and those about to die. These numbers are both a declaration of intent and pauses for remorse; clarion-song and elegy alike, heavy instrumentation for the trenches and pews, all hymnals of well-earned paranoia and odes to a dawn of violence." b"And, though the ending is undoubtedly full of salvos from a reluctant warrior, there's a glimmer of hope that says that the young heart of Christopher Wallace from Bed-Stuy\xe2\x80\x94not the Notorious B.I.G. from Bad Boy\xe2\x80\x94was still beating beneath all that armor. On \xe2\x80\x9cYou're Nobody,\xe2\x80\x9d he's mingling with \xe2\x80\x9cthorough bitches\xe2\x80\x9d who rode around in a fruit-colored two-door Acura and\xe2\x80\x94in a telling, but coded move\xe2\x80\x94he hearkens back to the determined aspiration of his breakthrough hit \xe2\x80\x9cJuicy,\xe2\x80\x9d rapping his perceived future into existence: \xe2\x80\x9cAs my pilot steers my Lear,\xe2\x80\x9d he drops seemingly apropos of nothing but rhyme and boast. But, looking deeper, further back, past the blood on his friend's sneaker from the opener, you recall how this all began:" b'He was sitting in the crib, envisioning Learjets, visualizing coupes, lusting the way Salt \xe2\x80\x9cshooped,\xe2\x80\x9d and wanting to sell records like Snoop Dogg. Big may not have been around to see it, but he saw it before it happened. He created an alternate reality and lived it until his death and after.'

column7: b"Puff Daddy's luxurious 1997 debut plays as both a cautionary tale and an affront to mortality.\xc2\xa0We examine its history on the 20th anniversary of the death of Christopher Wallace."
column8: b'As folk singer-songwriter Shawn Colvin shuffled out of the wings to collect her Grammy for Song of the Year in 1998, chaos was already brewing. Wu-Tang Clan\xe2\x80\x99s Ol\xe2\x80\x99 Dirty Bastard\xc2\xa0made a beeline for the stage, beating Colvin to the mark. He appeared suddenly in front of millions in a brand new maroon suit, delaying her acceptance speech to protest Puff Daddy\xe2\x80\x99s earlier Best Rap Album win for his debut, No Way Out, which defeated the Clan\xe2\x80\x99s Wu-Tang Forever and The Notorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s posthumous Life After Death. Bad Boy had dominated the rap Grammys that evening with wins in two of the three categories, landing nominations in each one, and scoring seven nominations total. Puffy, Faith Evans, and 112 were all winners. Biggie and Mase were both nominees. ODB had enough. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know how y\xe2\x80\x99all see it, but Wu-Tang is for the children,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cPuffy is good, but Wu-Tang is the best.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The scene is among the most memorable images in Grammy history, despite the fact that the rap Grammys themselves were not televised that year. As if getting the last laugh, two new Bad Boy collaborations were in the Hot 100 Top 20 when the charts went live three days later: Puffy\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBeen Around the World\xe2\x80\x9d with Mase and Biggie and Mase\xe2\x80\x99s collaboration with fellow Bad Boy signee Total, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat You Want.\xe2\x80\x9d The week underscored a key point about the label then: despite its opponents and skeptics, Bad Boy Records was a machine, and all it did was win.' b"Bad Boy's near-sweep at the Grammys capped a year of successes for the hit factory and for Puffy, who dominated the charts, the clubs, and the award ceremonies. But those fleeting highs were sullied by a far greater loss: the murder of Christopher Wallace. The specter of death hangs eerily over No Way Out, through near prescient verses delivered by Biggie from beyond the grave (\xe2\x80\x9cNiggas wanna hit me, if they get me, dress my body in linen by Armani\xe2\x80\x9d) and reflective odes bared by those living in the aftermath of his slaying. Puff explores paranoia, grief, and self-awareness in the wake of losing a dear friend, an icon at the peak of his powers. It's\xc2\xa0an album as much about celebrating and surviving as it is mourning, but more than anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s a label compilation that bound its participants together, one marked by a refusal to stop winning\xe2\x80\x94even when under the gun." b'When Biggie was shot and killed in a drive-by weeks before the release of his sophomore album, it instantly made the Bad Boy modus operandi obsolete. They were a posse built around a transcendent star. Everything revolved around Biggie. He appeared in several Bad Boy videos. He appeared on singles and notable tracks for Craig Mack, Total, and 112. He was their face. He was the brand. In the long term, his death would create a power vacuum in rap Mecca\xe2\x80\x94starting a turf war between would-be kings like Nas and Jay Z\xe2\x80\x94but the immediate aftershock was felt more subtly within his camp, which was searching for a way to sustain without one of the most heavily felt presences in all of popular music. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter Big died, we were searching to see who was gonna carry the torch,\xe2\x80\x9d Mase remembered in GQ\xe2\x80\x99s oral history of the Bad Boy run. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody would\xe2\x80\x99ve had the right to get out of contracts because of the violence. Instead, we rolled together. If I had a verse or beat that was better for you, I\xe2\x80\x99d just give it up.\xe2\x80\x9d Mase\xe2\x80\x99s verses for No Way Out were written in his Harlem bedroom long before he was signed. \xe2\x80\x9cI gave them to Puff, because he was the one with the hot hand.\xe2\x80\x9d Starting with Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s Mase-featuring smash \xe2\x80\x9cMo Money Mo Problems,\xe2\x80\x9d Puff\xe2\x80\x99s hot hand would continue to deal hits at an unprecedented rate.' b'By \xe2\x80\x9997, Sean \xe2\x80\x9cPuffy\xe2\x80\x9d Combs had already established himself as one of the finest producers and talent scouts in the country. After cornering the rap market with Big and Craig Mack (with Mase and the LOX waiting in the wings), he diversified into R&B, signing new acts like 112, Total, Mario Winans, and Carl Thomas. He executive-produced Mary J. Blige\xe2\x80\x99s My Life and co-produced Usher\xe2\x80\x99s self-titled debut, and he scored credits on TLC\xe2\x80\x99s CrazySexyCool. Along with his in-house production team, the Hitmen, he cut records for everyone from Jodeci to Mariah Carey to Aretha Franklin. Not long before his death, Biggie convinced Combs to try his hand at rap, and with his team surrounding him production began on Puffy\xe2\x80\x99s debut. Taking the name Puff Daddy, he would adopt an uber glamorous image, helping to coin the term \xe2\x80\x9cghetto fabulous.\xe2\x80\x9d Combs wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a naturally gifted rapper by trade, but he had remarkable taste and a clear vision. His Bad Boy bio, shared in a \xe2\x80\x9898 Vibe story, exposed his solo rap career as merely a means to further his roles as a premier impresario and tastemaker in true Puffy fashion: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not an MC,\xe2\x80\x9d it read. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a vibe giver.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'In January \xe2\x80\x9996, Puff Daddy set the tone for No Way Out with the Mase-featuring single \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Nobody Hold Me Down,\xe2\x80\x9d a body-roll-friendly jam that heavily sampled \xe2\x80\x9cThe Message.\xe2\x80\x9d The video was a crash course in \xe2\x80\x9cnew money\xe2\x80\x9d extravagance\xe2\x80\x94silk pajamas, pristine white jumpsuits, action movie pyrotechnics, Eddie Griffin, driving through the desert in a drop top Rolls Royce, rapping about rocking Versace and Hawaiian getaways. The album was originally headed in a fun, glitzy direction, in the vein of \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Nobody Hold Me Down\xe2\x80\x9d and the forthcoming single \xe2\x80\x9cBeen Around the World.\xe2\x80\x9d But Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s sudden death caused Puffy to redo half the album, creating a party record spotted with bouts of depression and sorrow; coupling words from the deceased with remembrances of his life and the impact of his passing. \xe2\x80\x9c[The album\xe2\x80\x99s] more serious now than when I first got into it,\xe2\x80\x9d Puffy told SPIN that September. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are still days where I just wake up and feel like I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do this anymore. But it\xe2\x80\x99s become a situation in which I have no choice. This is what I do. I have no way out.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"No Way Out is a living document of the most tumultuous period in Bad Boy\xe2\x80\x99s run. It embodies the complex mix of emotions felt while persevering through great trauma amid triumph. It's\xc2\xa0a record that splits itself in two trying to capture a gaudy lifestyle and the devastation of loss all at once, equal parts funeral pyre, signal fire, and beach luau. One minute they\xe2\x80\x99re jet-setting around the globe with Big in tow, the next Puff is alone peeking over his shoulder for armed assailants, contemplating his final hour. Samples of Marvin Gaye\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIf I Should Die Tonight\xe2\x80\x9d and New Edition\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIs This the End?\xe2\x80\x9d become vehicles for distress and alarm, as he prepares his last will and testament. But a song like \xe2\x80\x9cI Got the Power\xe2\x80\x9d reestablishes control: \xe2\x80\x9cI be\xc2\xa0that nigga that yo niggas can\xe2\x80\x99t fuck wit,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps. \xe2\x80\x9cThat nigga that'll die for his main man/That nigga with the gettin' money gameplan.\xe2\x80\x9d For its somewhat whiplashing nature, everything the album does is packaged neatly, spotlighting Puff as its star while exalting a slain legend and comrade and reassuring Bad Boy culture stockholders that the remaining roster was ready to carry the mantle. This is the all-conquering rap debut of a production and marketing guru." b'With production from the Hitmen aces\xe2\x80\x94Puffy, Stevie J, D-Dot, and Amen-Ra, in particular\xe2\x80\x94and a host of talented role players, namely Big\xe2\x80\x99s widow Faith Evans, his mistress Lil Kim, the star-to-be Mase, The Lox, and more, No Way Out crafted a near perfect Bad Boy time capsule, capturing the label\xe2\x80\x99s highs and lows of \xe2\x80\x9897. From the agony of \xe2\x80\x9cPain\xe2\x80\x9d to the celebrity-critiquing \xe2\x80\x9cDo You Know?,\xe2\x80\x9d it chronicles every natural reaction to Big\xe2\x80\x99s shooting dutifully and without fully compromising Puffy\xe2\x80\x99s Bad Boy mission statement: make feel-good music that tops the charts.' b"Puff Daddy proves himself to be a more than capable leading man, talking his shit with supreme confidence one minute and humbling himself at the altar of his fallen friend the next. He\xe2\x80\x99s among the most believable boasters in rap history\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYou ain\xe2\x80\x99t gotta like me, you just mad/\xe2\x80\x98Cause I tell it how it is, and you tell it how it might be,\xe2\x80\x9d he raps on \xe2\x80\x9cVictory\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he\xe2\x80\x99s his own best hype man who\xe2\x80\x99s equally enthusiastic stumping for others. But for the most part, No Way Out pivots on its exceptional Biggie cameos. His aura lingers. There\xe2\x80\x99s a slickness to his bars that\xe2\x80\x99s unparalleled, that fills up all the surrounding space with brio. He makes a seam-splitting Jay Z verse seem pedestrian (\xe2\x80\x9cYoung G\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d) and brings half the fun to \xe2\x80\x9cBeen Around the World\xe2\x80\x9d with his goofy rendition of Lisa Stansfield's \xe2\x80\x9cAll Around the World.\xe2\x80\x9d On the slow-building \xe2\x80\x9cVictory,\xe2\x80\x9d he trades verses with Puff, backing his play. (The song\xe2\x80\x99s final verse, the last Big ever recorded, is believed to be a reference track for Puffy.) The remix to \xe2\x80\x9cAll About the Benjamins,\xe2\x80\x9d a chief among posse cuts once deemed by XXL the second best rap song of the \xe2\x80\x9990s, is among the last truly great artifacts of the Bad Boy era: the perfect blend of varying personalities and top notch performances all winding around the same axis: Biggie and the mutual appreciation of stunting." b'\xe2\x80\x9cStatistically, this was one of the best years of my life,\xe2\x80\x9d Puffy told Rolling Stone in December \xe2\x80\x9997, \xe2\x80\x9cbut personally, it was one of the worst. I would rather not have this. I would do anything\xe2\x80\x94I would turn the hits into negative hits if I could just be with Biggie again.\xe2\x80\x9d Biggie was gone, though, and the hits kept coming. Puff Daddy\xe2\x80\x99s first two singles topped the charts and his next two peaked at No. 2. No Way Out set the stage for Mase\xe2\x80\x99s hugely successful debut Harlem World later that year, and the next year it was the LOX\xe2\x80\x99s turn. As the run continued and the accolades kept mounting, Puffy became rap\xe2\x80\x99s unexpected celebrity executive, notching more No. 1\xe2\x80\x99s than any rapper in history to that point. But there\xe2\x80\x99s something singular about No Way Out, which somehow feels like both a cautionary tale and an affront to mortality: The Notorious B.I.G. had been assassinated by his enemies, but his legacy was eternal. The album remembers him, not as man but as myth.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s something fascinating about following a song as mournful and self-serving as \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll Be Missing You\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which turns \xe2\x80\x9cAdagio for Strings\xe2\x80\x9d and the Police\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEvery Breath You Take\xe2\x80\x9d into a rousing eulogy with Puff and Big at its center\xe2\x80\x94with a song as triumphant as \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Nobody Hold Me Down.\xe2\x80\x9d The transition seemed to build the strength necessary to overcome tragedy. With or without Biggie, their superstar and genius, the Bad Boy machine would continue to roll. Nobody\xe2\x80\x94not even the ghost of an all-time great\xe2\x80\x94could hold Sean Combs down. When the dust settled and No Way Out was on its way to going septuple platinum, SPIN ran a January \xe2\x80\x9898 feature titled \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mourning After,\xe2\x80\x9d taking stock of the post-Biggie Bad Boy climate and wondering at what point public grieving became shameless promo. \xe2\x80\x9cMarketable mourning,\xe2\x80\x9d as Sia Michel called it, contributed at least in part to the ongoing sales spike. Martyrdom is misery porn for some. But No Way Out is more than just the commissioning of lifeless tributes or some flagrant attempt to merchandise tragedy; it\xe2\x80\x99s an attempt to do the most difficult thing in adversity\xe2\x80\x99s wake: keep going.'

column7: b"The half-baked 1999 release\xc2\xa0Born Again\xc2\xa0reeks of a posthumous\xc2\xa0cash-grab. We look back on its place in the Biggie canon on the 20th anniversary of Christopher Wallace's death."
column8: b'Born Again commences Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s posthumous disemboweling. It\xe2\x80\x99s the first project bearing his name that was conceived, produced, and completed after the Brooklyn icon had gasped his last breaths. By now, rap fans are deeply familiar with this baleful, unlovely creature\xe2\x80\x94the posthumous collection of reworked demos, outtakes, and leftovers cobbled together by executives and hired guns, paired with a list of guest artists and of-the-moment producers. They reek of boardroom meetings. They usually fill you with a hollow, complicit feeling for even hitting \xe2\x80\x9cplay.\xe2\x80\x9d It is hard to think of five such records in pop-music history that justify their existence after their first-week sales figures have posted.' b"In the two years since Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s death, his mentor and corporate svengali Puff Daddy had already found several ingenious ways to siphon cash and attention from his dead prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9. Puffy's solo album, long in the works, was retitled No Way Out from working title Hell Up In Harlem and overhauled after Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s death, emerging full of gothic dread and intimations of ready-to-die-ness. Its biggest single was his Police-sampling, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll Fly Away\xe2\x80\x9d-interpolating \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll Be Missing You,\xe2\x80\x9d a maudlin tribute to The Notorious B.I.G. that spent 11 weeks at No. 1." b'The following year, he released the debut album from The Lox, a hardheaded trio of Yonkers rappers with a deafening street buzz. Puff decked them in shiny suits and dropped them in front of Hype Williams\xe2\x80\x99 fish-eye lens, where they looked about as comfortable as middle schoolers stranded at prom. The album included the less-heralded, equally maudlin tribute, \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll Always Love Big Poppa.\xe2\x80\x9d In the video, baby-faced Jadakiss, Sheek Louch, and Styles P poured their hearts out to their dead friend, while Puff Daddy stood behind them, pointing meaningfully at the camera. It was clear that whatever Puff thought of the grief process, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t see much need to keep it behind closed doors.' b'Somewhere in there came the announcement for Born Again. Initial reports promised a sort of Biggie bildungsroman, pairing narration from Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s mother Voletta Wallace with unheard demos and unreleased material. Rap listeners had been busily copping and sharing Biggie exclusives from a steady stream of mixtapes, freestyles and unfinished cuts dating back to 1993, but those traveled in rarefied circles, and the idea of a studio album bringing this stuff to the masses was enticing. But the story changed quickly, and often; a full-page ad in the September \xe2\x80\x9899 issue of The Source promised some intrigue, including a track\xc2\xa0that would posthumously reunite Biggie and 2Pac and a\xc2\xa0new remix of \xe2\x80\x9cParty & Bullshit\xe2\x80\x9d that foretold an appearance from Will Smith. For better or for worse, this never came to pass, and what ended up being released was a jumble of some older, less well-known verses and some recycled material from already-available releases.' b'Born Again wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s story. Sure, it spawned one or two lasting cuts: the flashy, Duran Duran-sampling \xe2\x80\x9cNotorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x9d and the vicious early pre-Ready To Die demo \xe2\x80\x9cDead Wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d But the real story it tells is about Puff Daddy\xe2\x80\x94how he flailed into the spotlight after Big\xe2\x80\x99s death, how he treated his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s legacy. He immediately sought to cast himself as Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s equal: You can see the video for \xe2\x80\x9cVictory\xe2\x80\x9d as a sort of prelude. Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s verse play is just background music for shots of Puff Daddy running slow motion in front of explosions in the rain.' b'This is the kind of Biggie album Puff made without the stubborn, strong-willed Wallace present in the room to dig in his heels and say \xe2\x80\x9cno.\xe2\x80\x9d The production for the album makes no sense\xe2\x80\x94it made no sense for a Biggie album in 1999, and it makes even less sense in 2017. The dank, chaotic original \xe2\x80\x9cNiggas\xe2\x80\x9d from 1993, produced by Mister Cee and gloriously scarred up with frenetic scratching, gets cleaned up and \xe2\x80\x9cupdated\xe2\x80\x9d all the way to 1999, sounding tame and inert. The Timb-boot funk of that basement session evaporates completely, and the song loses all of its meaning transferred into major-label sunlight.' b'Similarly, it\xe2\x80\x99s nice to think about Mannie Fresh and Biggie in the same room with Biggie alive\xe2\x80\x94they were both inventive, antic minds that loved surprising word choices and unpredictable flows. But hearing Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s second ferocious verse stripped from the original version of \xe2\x80\x9cDead Wrong\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a song, remember, that appears elsewhere on this album\xe2\x80\x94laid over Fresh\xe2\x80\x99s bouncy instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cHope You Niggas Sleep,\xe2\x80\x9d and followed by verses from all the members of Hot Boys and Big Tymers, only underscores how dead Wallace was.' b'His verse from \xe2\x80\x9cDangerous MCs,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, was meant to appear on a song from Busta Rhymes\xe2\x80\x99 The Coming, produced by J Dilla. It was scrapped purportedly because of some veiled threats at 2Pac lurking in it and the album\xe2\x80\x99s makers were leery of tossing any more powder into the keg. With them both dead, Big\xe2\x80\x99s incendiary lines detonate harmlessly over an airless, functional beat from Nottz: \xe2\x80\x9cCatch my drift/Or catch my four-fifth lift/At least six inches above project fences/Turn meat to minces/Jumps turn to flinches/When I rain I drenches/Cleared your park benches.\xe2\x80\x9d Hearing one dead man launch subliminals at another dead one is perverse, particularly since the producers arranged some East Coast/West Coast unity kabuki elsewhere on the project, bringing Ice Cube to rap a verse on \xe2\x80\x9cIf I Should Die Before I Wake\xe2\x80\x9d saluting Biggie as the \xe2\x80\x9cKing of New York.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"Is any of it worth it? Tough to say. Without this album, you might have never heard \xe2\x80\x9cRelax and take notes while I take tokes of the marijuana smoke.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s a canonical line, and it introduces \xe2\x80\x9cDead Wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d the only near-classic here. The original, produced by Easy Moe Bee, is a giggly and profane game of Dozens, Biggie indulging his filthy imagination for all its worth: broomsticks get used for unspeakable purposes and Lucifer is laughed out of the room. On the new version, the stakes are higher, and the music sharper, a sideways-jerking, always-falling-off-the-beat thing that samples the Rev. Al Green, of all people. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t even fuck it up by including a new verse from a pissy white kid named Eminem on it, a rapper Big had never heard of who had mostly become famous at that point for making fun of his mom and boy bands. It all sounds a little tired in retrospect\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ccannibals and exorcisms, animals havin' sex with 'em\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but at the time, it was a revelation." b'The decision to bring Eminem in said a lot about Puffy\xe2\x80\x99s shifting priorities. Mark Pitts, an executive producer on Born Again, likened the project to \xe2\x80\x9cbuilding Frankenstein.\xe2\x80\x9d Even shortly after working on the project, he sounded queasy about it: \xe2\x80\x9cThe only thing that bothered me was the [guests artists] on the album. He would\xe2\x80\x99ve respected them all, but he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have worked with them all. Just because they\xe2\x80\x99re hot doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean they mesh.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Soon, he would accompany artists he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even respected: Korn comes to mind. The trail of artists who can technically claim to have appeared alongside the Notorious B.I.G. has only grown more disheartening with time. \xe2\x80\x9cI did real songs with Big, no made-up shits,\xe2\x80\x9d Jadakiss sneered at 50 Cent in their 2006 battle. By then, having recorded a song next to Biggie Smalls was no longer rarefied air, and these were the first unreal songs with Big. In that sense, they inaugurated a long and sad tradition.' b'From Hendrix to Elvis to Nirvana, none of this death-industry stuff is new. But in hip-hop, a music tied so closely to the inhuman ravages of the drug war and the carceral state, the charge pulsed a little hotter. Nineties gangsta rap always smelled of sulfur, of various deals cut with sundry devils, and its most potent tracks gave those who confronted them a mortal thrill. Alive, Big could inhabit this archetype and artfully squirm out of it in the same line, and it only took his presence\xe2\x80\x94no more, no less\xe2\x80\x94to set this animation in motion. \xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, flows just grow through me/Like trees to branches, cliffs to avalanches,\xe2\x80\x9d he deadpanned on a throwaway line from Ready To Die\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe What.\xe2\x80\x9d You could lose an hour, or a year, thinking about the imagery there, plumbing the mind that casually bundled those two thoughts together. \xe2\x80\x9cWe dress up like ladies and burn \xe2\x80\x98em with dirty .380s,\xe2\x80\x9d he proposed on the Life After Death cut \xe2\x80\x9cNiggas Bleed.\xe2\x80\x9d These lines are well-worn by repetition that they should, by all rights, have lost their strangeness. And yet they have not: Imagine Big, all 300 pounds of him, packing heat, dressed in woman\xe2\x80\x99s clothes; once your mind\xe2\x80\x99s eye has seen that, you won\xe2\x80\x99t ever lose it. It\xe2\x80\x99s indelible.' b'On Born Again, he is immobilized, and can thus perform none of these tricks. You can feel the absence of his animating touch\xe2\x80\x94his hot breath, his shrewd eye, his capacious ear.
