This is when the mortification of his body was complete, and he was rendered as just a voice that others could manipulate without his consent. He has nothing to do with the music and no way of playing against his environment. As a result, there\xe2\x80\x99s no inner music at work, nothing much to listen harder for. A good artist leads you into their genre from some other, outside place, showing you the familiar shapes through the warping lens of their mind. Their individual predilections and quirks become\xc2\xa0elemental laws of physics, rules. Biggie\xe2\x80\x99s voice is all over Born Again, but you feel the absence of his mind. Here, he is just a gangsta rapper, the nimblest one that ever lived.'

column7: b'A decade after their last album, Grandaddy pick up where they left off, for better and for worse.'
column8: b'Some Grandaddy songs are about technology. Nearly all of them are about junk: Alcoholic robots and broken household appliances outlive\xc2\xa0their usefulness and are left to rust. But the same basic fate awaits lost kittens, lonely spacemen, forlorn miners, and hollowed-out cities of rural California, eulogized by a band whose fuzz\xc2\xa0pedals, analog synths, and withered harmonies\xc2\xa0always sound like they\xe2\x80\x99re about to give out. And much like Jed the Humanoid, Grandaddy themselves fizzled and popped, and then they just stopped with 2006\xe2\x80\x99s Just Like the Fambly Cat, essentially a Jason Lytle solo album. Given their dedication to documenting entropy, a \xe2\x80\x9ctriumphant comeback\xe2\x80\x9d isn\xe2\x80\x99t the sort of thing one expects from this band. But as Last Place makes clear, the creeping sense that we\xe2\x80\x99ll all just end up in a pile of our emotional and physical baggage never goes out of style.' b'Lytle had kept busy since disassembling Grandaddy a decade ago: After moving to Montana to escape the relative bustle of the Central Valley, he released two solo\xc2\xa0LPs, produced Band of Horses, hooked up with Monsters of Blog Rock supergroup BNQT, and found a sensible benefactor in new label head Danger Mouse. But Grandaddy are still a state-of-the-art 2000 band, the sum of slack-motherfucker indie rock, the mid-fi experimentalism of Sparklehorse, and just enough of Mercury Rev and Flaming Lips\xe2\x80\x99 late-\xe2\x80\x9990s prog sweep. Most crucially, The Sophtware Slump countered the pre-millennial tension of trip-hop, Timbaland, and Radiohead with Y2k\xe2\x80\x99s definitive \xc2\xaf\\(\xe3\x83\x84)/\xc2\xaf album, speaking to people who came of age during the tech boom and felt like the 21st century could only promise shinier distractions from the same old pervasive suburban boredom.' b'If Last Place doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly sound happy about that fate coming to pass, at least Lytle\xe2\x80\x99s learning to deal. \xe2\x80\x9cWay We Won\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x9d begins the record with him\xc2\xa0accepting loss as some schmo living atop a box store, enjoying the \xe2\x80\x9ctropical smells and back-to-school sales,\xe2\x80\x9d the best most people can hope for in adulthood. This unusually zippy pop song is immediately followed by \xe2\x80\x9cBrush With the Wild,\xe2\x80\x9d also patterned after the closest thing Grandaddy had to a crossover hit (\xe2\x80\x9cNow It\xe2\x80\x99s On\xe2\x80\x9d), making for the most vigorous eight-minute stretch of music they\xe2\x80\x99ve ever committed to tape. At least musically, that is; lyrically, the trademark\xc2\xa0weariness remains. \xe2\x80\x9cWe had a thing, whatever it\xe2\x80\x99s called,\xe2\x80\x9d Lytle moans, which is the most Grandaddy way possible to depict a busted romance. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Boat Is in the Barn\xe2\x80\x9d continues the theme: he\xe2\x80\x99s just another hoarder of junk, hanging onto their shared possessions and memories\xc2\xa0in hope of keeping the past alive, while the ex gingerly deletes pictures from her phone.' b'Last Place\xe2\x80\x99s first side sounds familiar, but it also promises a new kind of Grandaddy album: an uptempo collection of skewed pop songs without any kind of higher conceptual calling, music that is laid back but not insensate. While \xe2\x80\x9cChek Injin\xe2\x80\x9d is Grandaddy at their most punk rock, that surge in energy only goes so far, placing them somewhere in the orbit of Wilco\xe2\x80\x99s Star Wars. As Lytle yells, \xe2\x80\x9cplease keep going, please keep fucking going,\xe2\x80\x9d like he\xe2\x80\x99s trying to siphon one last drop of gas with his mouth, it becomes an unintentionally meta moment, as it\xe2\x80\x99s the last time Last Place strives for any kind of forward momentum.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cI Don\xe2\x80\x99t Wanna Live Here Anymore\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s What You Get For Gettin\xe2\x80\x99 Out of Bed\xe2\x80\x9d are pleasant, tuneful throwbacks to a pre\xe2\x80\x932k indie rock sarcasm, but they spend several minutes reiterating the point immediately made by their titles. The rest of Last Place just ties up loose ends: \xe2\x80\x9cYou know it\xe2\x80\x99s all a\xc2\xa0metaphor for being drunk and on the floor,\xe2\x80\x9d Lytle sings on \xe2\x80\x9cJed the 4th,\xe2\x80\x9d over-explaining prequels\xc2\xa0that couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly be interpreted any other way. \xe2\x80\x9cA Lost Machine\xe2\x80\x9d aspires to the same Floydian excess as \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s Simple, He\xe2\x80\x99s Dumb, He\xe2\x80\x99s the Pilot,\xe2\x80\x9d but unlike \xe2\x80\x9care you giving in, 2000 Man?,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ceverything about us is a lost machine\xe2\x80\x9d generates less meaning with every repetition.' b'Taking the long view, Last Place might actually be a concept record about Grandaddy itself, as it recreates the trajectory of their previous four albums in miniature: quirks slowly congeal into banality, back roads are avoided in favor of familiar scenery. And then it ends like Grandaddy once did, with what essentially amounts to a Lytle solo project (\xe2\x80\x9cSongbird Son\xe2\x80\x9d). They sound exhausted, right where we left them.'

column7: b'The new\xc2\xa0album from New York\xe2\x80\x99s Immolation is a\xc2\xa0masterclass in death metal songwriting. It pairs\xc2\xa0a queasy feeling of gloom with melodies\xc2\xa0you can actually hum along to.'
column8: b'In the early \xe2\x80\x9990s, death metal luminaries like Death\xe2\x80\x99s Chuck Schuldiner and Morbid Angel\xe2\x80\x99s Trey Azagthoth introduced technicality to the raw, guttural template they\xe2\x80\x99d pioneered a few years earlier. At that point, death metal became a haven for artists who not only placed a high premium on chops but also thought of themselves as capital-C composers. (Gorguts bandleader Luc Lemay, for example, actually took private lessons in composition from a nun.) But over the genre\xe2\x80\x99s 30-year creep from the fringes to respectability, we still don\xe2\x80\x99t think of it as a songwriter\xe2\x80\x99s artform. That\xe2\x80\x99s not necessarily fair, as it takes enormous skill to wrest hooks from such harsh tones.' b'On Atonement, the 10th\xc2\xa0long-player from the New York-based second wave death metal outfit Immolation, guitarist Robert Vigna delivers a masterclass on songwriting in this framework. A cohesive listen from start to finish, Atonement contains twists, turns, peaks, and valleys galore\xe2\x80\x94a remarkable achievement considering that Immolation haven\xe2\x80\x99t modified their approach all that much since their 1991 debut Dawn of Possession. Atonement, in fact, begins with a short, detuned clean guitar phrase that reacquaints listeners with Vigna\xe2\x80\x99s preference for scales that sound as if they\xe2\x80\x99re warping under his fingertips.' b'As with\xc2\xa0so many of his peers, Vigna likes to play squealing leads that he double-tracks in discordant harmonies to create a\xc2\xa0queasy feeling of gloom. But he also possesses an unparalleled knack for injecting melody into his riffs without watering-down the heaviness or resorting to the inflated bombast of symphonic death metal. (Though former Goreaphobia/Incantation guitarist Alex Bouks joined Immolation last year, Vigna still plays all of the parts on the album, as he\xe2\x80\x99s done for much of the band\xe2\x80\x99s history.) Vigna crafted the album as a batch of songs you can actually hum along to. Looking back, how many of the genre\xe2\x80\x99s all-time classics can we say that about?' b'Even when compared to Immolation\xe2\x80\x99s back catalog, you\xe2\x80\x99d be hard-pressed to find a more riveting string of transitions between songs. After a series of blast beats and double bassdrum rolls, second track \xe2\x80\x9cWhen the Jackals Come\xe2\x80\x9d opens out onto an epic climax where Vigna guitars wail like a chorus of air raid sirens. Here, in a drawn-out ending that takes nearly as long as the song\xe2\x80\x99s main section, the music lends itself to the apocalyptic scenery the album cover depicts. \xe2\x80\x9cTheir war is already won,\xe2\x80\x9d sings vocalist/bassist Ross Dolan, \xe2\x80\x9cyour world will end when the jackals come\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a typical death metal lyric about societal collapse that takes on an unusually profound sense of tragedy thanks to the dolefulness in the music.' b'In a great sequencing move, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen the Jackals Come\xe2\x80\x9d simmers down onto the eerie drone that introduces \xe2\x80\x9cFostering the Divide,\xe2\x80\x9d which hints at Vigna and Dolan\xe2\x80\x99s affinity for the gothy ambient darkness of non-metal acts like Dead Can Dance. And though the drone component remains quite subtle throughout the album, mixer Zack Ohren\xc2\xa0leaves ample room for drummer Steve Shalaty\xe2\x80\x99s intricate cymbal patterns to come to the front and color even the most dense passages. Ohren\xe2\x80\x99s mix is beefy but not outsized or over-processed like so much modern metal can be. The music reveals endless contours over repeat listens.' b'Immolation have recorded with producer Paul Orofino since their third album, 1999\xe2\x80\x99s Failures for Gods. By this point, the band\xe2\x80\x99s work flow is well entrenched. Likewise, Dolan\xe2\x80\x99s preoccupation with religious and political institutions as agents of evil is still as fervent as it was from day one. At times, Dolan breathes a contemporary edge into his lyrics. \xe2\x80\x9cJackals\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0was inspired by John Perkins\xe2\x80\x99 book Confessions of an Economic Hit Man, while \xe2\x80\x9cFostering the Divide\xe2\x80\x9d aligns perfectly with the contentious tone of American politics (even if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explicitly address the recent presidential election). Mostly, though, Dolan isn\xe2\x80\x99t saying anything he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t said before. In a sense, neither is Vigna. But\xc2\xa0in death metal, consistency is the name of the game, and it\xe2\x80\x99s harder than it looks. If a band can \xe2\x80\x9csay\xe2\x80\x9d the same thing for 30\xc2\xa0years while\xc2\xa0delivering it with more flourish than they ever have, as Immolation have done with Atonement, then that\xc2\xa0really\xc2\xa0says something.'

column7: b"The 20th anniversary remaster of Smith's final solo album before his major label debut highlights its inimitable sound and style: a magical, alchemical mix of intimacy and bombast."
column8: b"About two minutes into Either/Or opener \xe2\x80\x9cSpeed Trials,\xe2\x80\x9d Elliott Smith\xe2\x80\x99s seamlessly double-tracked lead vocal splits into a two-part harmony.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s a very subtle gesture, and only lasts for a few seconds\xe2\x80\x94but contrasted with the tight, hushed unison of Smith\xe2\x80\x99s prior solo output, it feels as dramatic as The Wizard of Oz shifting from sepia to technicolor. This moment plays out like a microcosm of Either/Or at large, the sound of Smith conjuring something far bigger than himself and coming into his own as a songwriter, arranger, and performer. The final album in Smith\xe2\x80\x99s catalog before the major label-backed XO and Figure 8, *Either/Or *marks the last time Smith\xe2\x80\x99s instincts would outpace the studio resources to execute them. It's extraordinary how he embodies a magical, alchemical mix of intimacy and bombast." b"By the time *Either/Or *was released in 1997, Smith was no stranger to the cynical machinations of the post-grunge major label gold rush. A year prior, his former band Heatmiser had been put through that very ringer, an experience captured in Either/Or standouts \xe2\x80\x9cPictures of Me\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAngeles.\xe2\x80\x9d Either/Or sounds like the work of somebody who has zero interest in either conforming to or directly transgressing the \xe2\x80\x9ccommercial\xe2\x80\x9d sounds of the day. It\xe2\x80\x99s too ambitious to read as \xe2\x80\x9clo-fi\xe2\x80\x9d and too gritty to read as straightforward pop classicism. Thankfully, this 20th anniversary remaster doesn't smooth out too many of those rough edges\xe2\x80\x94if anything, it brings the unique sound of the record into even clearer focus." b'The sounds and words of Either/Or often conjure very specific images, textures, and situations. And yet, Smith\xe2\x80\x94as with many truly great songwriters\xe2\x80\x94used this specificity as a way to explore emotional themes that resonate both deeply and broadly. Nowhere is this clearer than \xe2\x80\x9cBetween the Bars,\xe2\x80\x9d the closest thing to a modern-day standard Smith ever wrote and covered by everyone from Metric to Madonna. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a love song, exactly, and it\xe2\x80\x99s not a song about addiction, exactly. \xe2\x80\x9cBetween the Bars\xe2\x80\x9d is about the ways in which protecting somebody you love turns into the need to control that person. The fact that Smith was able to build this much emotional complexity into a song that sounds at home in a stadium or at a Starbucks speaks to his irreplaceable gift as a songwriter.' b'Elsewhere, Smith amplifies his well-honed songwriting chops with more fleshed-out arrangements. \xe2\x80\x9cBallad of Big Nothing\xe2\x80\x9d propels itself forward with bubbly McCartney-esque bass lines and background vocals that sound like they might have been string arrangements if there were an orchestra handy. \xe2\x80\x9cAngeles\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCupid\xe2\x80\x99s Trick\xe2\x80\x9d provide a back-to-back study in Smith\xe2\x80\x99s versatility as a guitarist, going from intricate fingerpicked pattern to lopey electric riffs. By the time album closer \xe2\x80\x9cSay Yes\xe2\x80\x9d rolls around, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that the solo acoustic approach is a specific and purposeful choice, and no longer Smith\xe2\x80\x99s default mode.' b'This reissue is framed as an \xe2\x80\x9cexpanded\xe2\x80\x9d edition, and the bonus materials included fit the bill nicely. Rather than aiming for comprehensiveness or definitiveness, the bonus tracks provide interesting glimpses into Smith\xe2\x80\x99s growing strength as a live solo performer (some excellent live recordings of album and non-album cuts), sense of humor (a sketch of New Moon\xc2\xa0track \xe2\x80\x9cNew Monkey\xe2\x80\x9d that sounds like it was played on a baseball organ), and where he would go with his next record (a formative version of XO cut \xe2\x80\x9cBottle Up and Explode!\xe2\x80\x9d that shows just how much thoughtful editing and revision went into the final version). And then there\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI Figured You Out,\xe2\x80\x9d a longtime fan favorite that Smith gave to his friend Mary Lou Lord to record because it \xe2\x80\x9csounds like the fuckin\xe2\x80\x99 Eagles.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI Figured You Out\xe2\x80\x9d would have been the most straightforward and polished song on Either/Or, and its omission speaks volumes about how determined Smith was to find his own voice and chart his own path.' b'In the years that followed the release of *Either/*Or, Smith managed to do just that, performing \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Misery\xe2\x80\x9d at the Academy Awards and releasing an uncompromising major label debut. For some of his fans, Either/Or marked the end of Smith\xe2\x80\x99s career as a direct and intimate folk singer-songwriter. For others, Either/Or marked the beginning of Smith\xe2\x80\x99s career as a one-man classic pop band. In truth,\xc2\xa0Either/Or marks the one moment in Smith\xe2\x80\x99s career when he was truly both.'

column7: b"Yoni Wolf's prog-rap project is rejuvenated, and\xc2\xa0Moh Lhean is a bracing, clear-eyed album that still sounds uniquely like WHY?. It's the most\xc2\xa0strangely beautiful thing Wolf's made in years."
column8: b'The end of WHY?\xc2\xa0had never been too far from Yoni Wolf\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts. On 2008\xe2\x80\x99s *Alopecia, *Wolf brought his finest album to a peak by confessing to \xe2\x80\x9ccoffin rehearsal\xe2\x80\x9d and ended it with his neck in a telephone cord noose. He repeated the trick on *Mumps, etc.\xe2\x80\x99s *closer \xe2\x80\x9cAs a Card,\xe2\x80\x9d and it felt like a grim confirmation of WHY?\xe2\x80\x99s suicide note\xe2\x80\x94Wolf spent most of it airing out his most noxious personal baggage and speaking about his \xe2\x80\x9crap career\xe2\x80\x9d like a job from which he was begging to get fired so he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have to quit. With nothing left to burn\xe2\x80\x94himself included\xe2\x80\x94Wolf commissioned WHY? fans for inspiration and wrote about their social media\xc2\xa0pages on Golden Tickets. Four years later, there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a lot of fight left in WHY?\xe2\x80\x94and yet, the project sounds completely rejuvenated for that very reason on Moh Lhean.' b'The remarkable thing about WHY? is that they neither needed a return to form nor a total reinvention. To the same degree *Mumps, etc. *turned\xc2\xa0Wolf\xe2\x80\x99s strengths\xe2\x80\x94excessive candor, a keen ear for melody\xe2\x80\x94into indefensible liabilities, *Moh Lhean *expands on the quiet inventiveness of *Alopecia\xe2\x80\x99s *less-heralded companion album\xc2\xa0Eskimo Snow. Previously, \xe2\x80\x9cpost-rock\xe2\x80\x9d just meant \xe2\x80\x9chip-hop\xe2\x80\x9d for WHY?, but they took on the late-\xe2\x80\x9990s Chicago sense of the term on Eskimo Snow, favoring neatly layered guitars, mallet percussion, mixed time signatures, and exquisite production values alongside Wolf\xe2\x80\x99s layering of obtuse metaphors and lurid self-disclosure.' b'If the genre-agnosticism of WHY? is no longer novel, it\xe2\x80\x99s still stunningly unique.\xc2\xa0The arrangements are dazzling in their coherence, especially given the diversity of instrumentation and textures whizzing throughout. The most striking aspect of *Moh Lhean *is how *beautiful *it is, even more so since this is their first self-produced album since 2003\xe2\x80\x99s *Oaklandazulasylum**, *one of the definitive documents of the Anticon\xe2\x80\x99s confrontational prog-hop. But\xc2\xa0*Moh Lhean *is built to withstand any live show where the triggers and synths malfunction. Acoustic guitar plays a surprising leading role\xc2\xa0in\xc2\xa0songs that could be covered as a sturdy blues (\xe2\x80\x9cThis Ole King\xe2\x80\x9d), steely folk (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Water\xe2\x80\x9d) and a straight-up power ballad (\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge Washington\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'Unlike the pointedly organic *Eskimo Snow, Moh Lhean *contrasts all of its lush sounds with brash drum programming that mimics the\xc2\xa0ungainly motion of the human body, shifting in and out of rhythm with intricate math-rock layering or juddering non-quantized beats. Of course, these are the kind of playing fields where Wolf\xe2\x80\x99s unconventional vocals best operate. Though he\xe2\x80\x99s long proven capable of carrying a tune, Wolf\xe2\x80\x99s still no one\xe2\x80\x99s idea of a pretty vocalist. His imperfections\xe2\x80\x94the odd timbral grain of his high notes, his taste for self-deprecation (\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be white, weak and blind/the opposite of oxen\xe2\x80\x9d)\xe2\x80\x94provide the edge even though *Moh Lhean *is anything but belligerent.' b'Wolf underwent a non-specific \xe2\x80\x9chealth scare\xe2\x80\x9d during the past few years and calls Moh Lhean a \xe2\x80\x9cbreakup album.\xe2\x80\x9d No longer psychosexual neuroses personified, Wolf exhibits a kind of post-traumatic calm, using situations as an opportunity to reflect on how to love and be present. *Moh Lhean *is rife with scenes that raise the possibility of WHY? having been\xc2\xa0a covert emo band all along\xe2\x80\x94watching shooting stars in the parking lot, writing love letters from the road, sitting in a boat with his brother after a hospital trip. Past albums relied on the shock value of confession for payoff, but Wolf trusts the emotional contours of his delivery to express the state of being in a moment across in concise, affecting phrases like \xe2\x80\x9cThis one thing,/There is no other,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m on fire,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to submit to whatever it is in control.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Artistic restraint is a new concept for WHY? and it\xe2\x80\x99s understandable if *Moh Lhean *as a whole feels slightly tentative at points\xe2\x80\x94two of its ten tracks are interludes no more than a few seconds, the second of which serves as a preface to \xe2\x80\x9cGeorge Washington\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cI wrote a song called \xe2\x80\x98The Longing Is All\xe2\x80\x99 instead of calling you/I\xe2\x80\x99d hoped that\xe2\x80\x99d solve me.\xe2\x80\x9d Such a line would\xe2\x80\x99ve sounded like an admission of defeat on *Mumps, etc., *which didn\xe2\x80\x99t lack for lyrics that ruminated on the futility of music. But on *Moh Lhean, *it\xe2\x80\x99s indicative of a promising new outlook. With his health and his band fully recovered, Wolf is starting to realize what matters with the clarity of someone who\xe2\x80\x99s seen a glimpse of the beyond.'

column7: b'The Brazilian songwriter Erasmo Carlos remains beloved at home, but he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been widely heard outside Latin America. These\xc2\xa0three\xc2\xa0early \xe2\x80\x9970s LPs\xc2\xa0have been given new life thanks to Light in the Attic.'
column8: b'Over the last half century, few countries have had as many international recording stars as Brazil. The famed names of its rich musical traditions have the same renown as its rock-star soccer players: Gilberto Gil, Caetano Veloso, Gal Costa, Milton Nascimento, Tom Z\xc3\xa9, Elis Regina, Flora Purim, Jorge Ben, Carlinhos Brown, Seu Jorge, Marisa Monte to name just one possible dream-team XI. An artist\xc2\xa0who didn\xe2\x80\x99t quite resonate abroad\xe2\x80\x94who never glittered in the yellow national-team jersey, so to speak\xe2\x80\x94is Erasmo Carlos. At 75, Carlos remains beloved at home, but he\xc2\xa0hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been\xc2\xa0widely heard outside Latin America, which is a shame. As we\xe2\x80\x99re reminded by\xc2\xa0these\xc2\xa0reissues of his work from the early 1970s, his talents were enormous.' b'Three of his albums\xe2\x80\x94Erasmo Carlos E Os Tremend\xc3\xb5es (from 1970), Carlos, ERASMO...\xc2\xa0(1971), and Sonhos E Mem\xc3\xb3rias 1941\xe2\x80\x931972 (1972)\xe2\x80\x94have been given a new life thanks to Seattle label Light in the Attic. A smart essay by Allen Thayer, along with his detailed liner notes and translated lyrics, provides valuable context for the package.' b'Born in 1941, Erasmo Carlos first gained fame with Roberto Carlos as co-hosts of the musical television\xc2\xa0show \xe2\x80\x9cJovem Guarda\xe2\x80\x9d (young guard), which debuted in 1965 and was aimed at teenagers enamored with American rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll and the British Invasion.\xc2\xa0Erasmo, no relation to Roberto, was a heartthrob; he sported a new haircut on every magazine cover he graced. In 1968, though, \xe2\x80\x9cJovem Guarda\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0was canceled. Times were a changing and Erasmo was at sea. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one wanted to know me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a 2006 interview that Thayer cites.' b'But Carlos\xc2\xa0still had his guitar and his voice, a fantastic and versatile one. He left S\xc3\xa3o Paulo and returned to his\xc2\xa0hometown, Rio de Janeiro, where the new M\xc3\xbasica Popular Brasileira and Tropic\xc3\xa1lia\xe2\x80\x94a creative movement to counter the CIA-sponsored military junta that grabbed power in 1964\xe2\x80\x94were fomenting. Despite his teeny-bopper reputation, Carlos\xc2\xa0still had street cred among the new, edgier players on the scene, like Caetano Veloso. This was in part because of his Rio roots and in part because he had talent, much of it still undeveloped at that point.' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s where the story of these records begins. And what a new beginning it was. Though these albums were\xc2\xa0among the least commercial and least \xe2\x80\x9csuccessful\xe2\x80\x9d of Carlos\xe2\x80\x99 career, he is\xc2\xa0in full soul-baring mode during these years, as if he has nothing to lose. He mixes\xc2\xa0all the genres of the place and time (pop, rock, folk, samba, bossa nova, psychedelia, soul, funk) within a feijoada\xc2\xa0of horns, flutes, strings, distorted guitars, and vocal harmonies.' b'His 1970 effort Erasmo Carlos E Os Tremend\xc3\xb5es starts out soft with \xe2\x80\x9cEstou Dez Anos Atrasado\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Ten Years Too Late\xe2\x80\x9d), which has a\xc2\xa0goofy bombast not unlike the theme from the original \xe2\x80\x9cBatman\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0series. But the remaining\xc2\xa0tracks on the album are magnificent, filled with surprising twists and vocal leaps. \xe2\x80\x9cGloriosa\xe2\x80\x9d boasts\xc2\xa0a catchy melody and\xc2\xa0full string arrangement, organ, flutes, and fuzzy guitar, while the gentle ballad \xe2\x80\x9cEspuma Congelada\xe2\x80\x9d ends up in distorted Tropic\xc3\xa1lia territory by way of Sgt. Pepper\xe2\x80\x99s. The effervescent \xe2\x80\x9cCoqueiro Verde\xe2\x80\x9d reflects Erasmo\xe2\x80\x99s umbilical attachment to samba. \xe2\x80\x9cTeletema,\xe2\x80\x9d a simple ditty written for a telenovela, is a quiet showcase for the wonderful textures of Erasmo\xe2\x80\x99s voice, a gift that carries all three of the recordings. He almost whispers though it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSoft/Celestial body/Goal, half/My sanctuary/My eternity/Illuminated/My way finally\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and reveals a vulnerability and depth.' b'The slow tempos of \xe2\x80\x9cMenina\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cVou Ficar N\xc3\xba Para Chamar Sua Aten\xc3\xa7ao\xe2\x80\x9d are perfect vehicles, too, for his keen sense of phrasing. Carlos\xc2\xa0does a gorgeous version of \xe2\x80\x9cSaudosismo,\xe2\x80\x9d penned by Veloso\xe2\x80\x94who, by 1970, was in exile in London after a short prison stay in Brazil. (The song could be read as\xc2\xa0a middle finger to government authorities, who, as Thayer writes\xc2\xa0in the notes, would surely have been made aware of its existence.) It\xe2\x80\x99s juxtaposed, oddly, with the familiar and patriotic \xe2\x80\x9cAquarela do Brasil,\xe2\x80\x9d which could work as well in a documentary on the pro footballer Pel\xc3\xa9 or a Varig airline commercial. Still, Erasmo\xe2\x80\x99s rendition is irresistible.' b'Carlos, ERASMO..., out the following year, saw a slight shift from Erasmo\xe2\x80\x99s 1970 effort. It was co-produced by\xc2\xa0Manoel Barenbein, who had helmed the landmark\xc2\xa0Tropic\xc3\xa1lia album just a few years prior, and featured\xc2\xa0several\xc2\xa0of its backing musicians.\xc2\xa0Carlos, ERASMO...\xc2\xa0also included\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDe Noite Na Cama,\xe2\x80\x9d written specifically for Erasmo by Veloso\xc2\xa0while still in exile. \xe2\x80\x9cMasculino, Feminino\xe2\x80\x9d is a beauty, a slow duet with the angelic-voiced Marisa Fossa that has the feel of Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden\xe2\x80\x94if there were red wine and Marlboro Lights. In \xe2\x80\x9cE\xcc\x81 Preciso Dar Um Jeito, Meu Amigo\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cGotta Find a Way, My Friend\xe2\x80\x9d), written with his old partner Roberto Carlos, Erasmo has drive and urgency in his voice: \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed/With the things I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen/But I will not be silent/Accommodated in comfort/As so many out there.\xe2\x80\x9d Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cAgora Ningu\xc3\xa9m Chora Mais\xe2\x80\x9d is a Jorge Ben original that\xe2\x80\x99s reinvented as a driving, plugged-in, harmonized group chant: \xe2\x80\x9cThe whole world cried/But now no one cries anymore/Cry more, cry more.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Sonhos E Mem\xc3\xb3rias 1941\xe2\x80\x931972 is the most focused and measured of the three albums and serves as a kind of personal diary (Carlos was born in \xe2\x80\x9941). There are photos of Jimi Hendrix, Mick Jagger, John Lennon, and Andy Warhol on the cover, and (perhaps more importantly) a team shot of Rio\xe2\x80\x99s Vasco da Gama soccer club. In \xe2\x80\x9cBom Dia, Rock\xe2\x80\x99N\xe2\x80\x99Roll,\xe2\x80\x9d Carlos\xc2\xa0references Elvis, the Beatles, Chuck Berry, and Carole King and James Taylor. The music\xc2\xa0is anchored by a rhythm section that would become the jazz fusion trio Azymuth, who gained momentum later in the \xe2\x80\x9970s and into the smoother jazz \xe2\x80\x9980s. With exceptions like \xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\x89 Proibido Fumar\xe2\x80\x9d and the second half of \xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xa1bado Morto,\xe2\x80\x9d which takes an unexpected vocal turn, Sonhos E Mem\xc3\xb3rias 1941\xe2\x80\x931972 feels less chance-y than the previous two albums.' b'After all, it was risk that got Carlos\xc2\xa0to this point. On his\xc2\xa01970 album, when he was at his lowest, he recorded what became a hit song*,* one that brought him renewed notice and enabled future work and creative freedom. \xe2\x80\x9cSentado \xc3\xa0 Beira do Caminho\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cSitting on the Side of the Road\xe2\x80\x9d), perhaps a\xc2\xa0wink to an American classic, is majestic. Erasmo, backed by little more than an organ and an acoustic guitar, sings as if he\xe2\x80\x99s speaking directly to us, and, in the process, reassuring himself: \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here anymore and wait/That one day suddenly you will come back to me... I\xe2\x80\x99m sitting on the side of a road that has no/end.\xe2\x80\x9d And then this, a fulfilled wish: \xe2\x80\x9cI need to get this over with/I must remember that I exist/I exist, I exist.\xe2\x80\x9d'

column7: b'Led by singer Eno Williams, Uyai\xc2\xa0becomes a wildly diverse mix of global sounds whose focus this time has turned\xc2\xa0to themes of liberation, power, and beauty\xe2\x80\x94specifically that of women.'
column8: b'If you crossed \xe2\x80\x9970s Nigerian highlife with LCD Soundsystem, you might get something like the opening track of Uyai. On \xe2\x80\x9cGive Me a Reason,\xe2\x80\x9d highlife trumpets and talking drums punch through buzzy synth lines and metallic drum machine effects. Like most dance music, it seeks liberation. Unlike most, it also laments: \xe2\x80\x9cAs the story goes, they got sent to a house of wisdom/To learn all that the world can offer/But on setting out, they got lost,\xe2\x80\x9d Eno Williams sings in Ibibio, a language of southeast Nigeria. The song speaks about the 276 Chibok girls who were abducted three years ago, the vast majority of whom are still missing.' b'Led by London-born, Lagos-raised singer Williams, Ibibio Sound Machine are an eight-piece band whose music draws on Nigerian highlife as much as new wave, South African jazz as much as techno, Cameroonian makossa as much as disco. Besides being a nod to the Ibibio language and region that Williams\xe2\x80\x99 family comes from, the band\xe2\x80\x99s name is also a wink at Miami Sound Machine, whose \xe2\x80\x9980s pop exuberance and cultural mash-up are approaches that Ibibio shares. The band\xe2\x80\x99s new release, Uyai,\xc2\xa0meaning \xe2\x80\x9cBeauty,\xe2\x80\x9d is their first since their self-titled debut in 2014. Accompanying a switch from the more vintage-oriented Soundway Records to indie rock label Merge, their sound has expanded to include more electronic and rock influences but has also grown more introspective. They still incorporate the kind of Ibibio storytelling\xc2\xa0that\xc2\xa0was at the center of\xc2\xa0Ibibio Sound Machine, but their focus this time has turned\xc2\xa0to themes of liberation, power, and beauty\xe2\x80\x94specifically that of women.' b'Throughout the album, Eno draws on the presence of the women in her life, highlighting the experiences and histories that link them. Her sister and friends join her on several tracks as backing vocalists. On \xe2\x80\x9cThe Chant (Iquo Isang),\xe2\x80\x9d her mom even makes a cameo chanting an improvised prayer, whispering and growling over shakers and a four-on-the-floor thump. Williams too recounts a chant from her schoolgirl days\xe2\x80\x94the chorus from \xe2\x80\x9cZangalewa\xe2\x80\x9d (originally by Cameroonian makossa group Golden Sounds; a couple decades later lifted by Shakira for the 2010 World Cup anthem). In writing \xe2\x80\x9cJoy (Idaresit),\xe2\x80\x9d an experimental techno-rock track, Williams was inspired by an older woman she saw dancing who reminded her of her own mother. By contrast, \xe2\x80\x9cLullaby\xe2\x80\x9d shows\xc2\xa0the singer as the mother figure. It\xe2\x80\x99s one of the gentler tracks, colored by atmospheric reverb, tinkly EKG blips, and bubbling talking drum.' b'As grounded as Williams is in her own roots, her and Ibibio\xe2\x80\x99s vision also taps into music across the\xc2\xa0African Diaspora.\xc2\xa0On \xe2\x80\x9cThe Pot Is on Fire\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGuide You (Edu Kpeme),\xe2\x80\x9d Ghanaian keyboardist Emmanuel Rentzos, of Osibisa fame, contributes playful synth-work. On tracks peppered with swiveling robot sounds and cowbells, percussionist Anselmo Netto plays Afro-Brazilian percussion, like the squeaky cu\xc3\xadca (as on \xe2\x80\x9cGuide You\xe2\x80\x9d) or\xc2\xa0the conga-like atabaque and boomy surdo (as on \xe2\x80\x9cPower of 3\xe2\x80\x9d). Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cOne That Lights Up (Andi Domo Ikang Uwem Mi)\xe2\x80\x9d is a love song that sounds like watercolors, where the horns reference\xc2\xa0South African jazz, and distorted mbiras recall Kinshasa\xe2\x80\x99s Konono\xc2\xa0N\xc2\xba1.' b"With all these musical influences and elements at play, Uyai could easily be a\xc2\xa0chaotic mess. For the most part, it's not, but every element doesn\xe2\x80\x99t always feel necessary. On \xe2\x80\x9cPower of 3,\xe2\x80\x9d there\xe2\x80\x99s a solid 30-second passage of laser gun sounds. The album as a whole has a lot of laser gun sounds. It also has frequent sudden shifts between high energy songs and mellower songs, so that even though the record\xc2\xa0has a unified\xc2\xa0sound, it sometimes feels\xc2\xa0disjointed. During the last two songs, however, that contrast\xc2\xa0works.\xc2\xa0On the tenderest moment of the album, \xe2\x80\x9cCry (Eyed),\xe2\x80\x9d Eno intones the word \xe2\x80\x9ccry\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0over and over again\xc2\xa0over a muted balafon-esque pattern, as if by way of slow repetition we could find some release.\xc2\xa0On album closer \xe2\x80\x9cTrance Dance\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94in a whirl of syncopated rhythms, chiptune blips, and guitar fuzz\xe2\x80\x94we finally do."

column7: b'On this 5-disc musical memoir, Stephin Merritt has penned\xc2\xa0a song for each of the\xc2\xa0first 50 years of his life. His writing\xc2\xa0suggests that our deepest wisdom can be located in our most personal thoughts.'
column8: b'Following his late-1990s triumph 69 Love Songs,\xc2\xa0Stephin Merritt\xc2\xa0began\xc2\xa0cannily organizing\xc2\xa0his Magnetic Fields songs. There was 2004\xe2\x80\x99s alphabetic\xc2\xa0i, followed by the genre filters of\xc2\xa02008\xe2\x80\x99s *Distortion\xc2\xa0*and\xc2\xa02009\xe2\x80\x99s Realism. In 2012, Merritt took on a slightly defeatist project\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe concept is there is no concept!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with Love at the Bottom of the Sea, an album whose lack of thematic unity resulted in a disappointingly uneven listen. Now, the Magnetic Fields return with a\xc2\xa0record\xc2\xa0that, like 69 Love Songs, forces Merritt to get focused and inspired.\xc2\xa050 Song Memoir is easily the best gimmick Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s stumbled upon since the turn of the century.' b'Arranged chronologically with a song for each of the first 50 years of Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s life, *50 Song Memoir *is a conceptually satisfying work, spanning five discs and two-and-a-half hours without feeling repetitive or samey. If there\xe2\x80\x99s one thing Merritt has learned over his three decades as a songwriter\xe2\x80\x94besides how to seamlessly insert limericks into songs\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s how to pace himself on record, keeping his quasi-showtunes from becoming cloying, his jokier ones\xc2\xa0from turning precious, and his ballads from sounding melodramatic.' b'Of course, for anyone turned off by the idea of Merritt\xe2\x80\x94an escapist pop descendent of Bacharach and Sondheim\xe2\x80\x94getting all Benji on us, you will be relieved to know that the story of his life sounds a lot like a Magnetic Fields album, and a very good one at that. There are some deeply revealing moments here. The opening songs, in particular, pinpoint\xc2\xa0the origins of Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s career-spanning themes of placelessness and unrequited love\xe2\x80\x94how they began with\xc2\xa0his parents\xe2\x80\x99 wanderlust and a childhood cat, respectively.\xc2\xa0But\xc2\xa050 Song Memoir\xc2\xa0often takes a less literal route through Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s life. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9976 Hustle 76\xe2\x80\x9d illustrates its time period by mimicking the then-inescapable sound of disco. Judy Garland\xe2\x80\x99s death gets its own song, as does the rise of synthesizer music in the early \xe2\x80\x9980s. For a songwriter who once formulated an entire record around the first-person pronoun, *50 Song Memoir *is more selfless than its title indicates. Here, Merritt seems more interested in exploring the moments that mark time\xe2\x80\x94where we\xe2\x80\x99ve lived, who we\xe2\x80\x99ve loved and lost\xe2\x80\x94than tracing his own particular narrative.' b'As a result, *50 Song Memoir *is an immersive, incisive listen, despite its avoidance of traditionally memoiristic details (we never, for example, learn the names of Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s parents, whether he has siblings, what it was like trying to follow-up a breakthrough album, etc). The themes that Merritt addresses over multiple songs become the album\xe2\x80\x99s guiding lights. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the young dudes of 25/Caught diseases, few survived,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings in \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9990 Dreaming in Tetris,\xe2\x80\x9d before explaining, \xe2\x80\x9cWe expected nuclear war/What should we take precautions for?\xe2\x80\x9d The AIDS crisis influences many of these songs, adding an ominous shadow to the darker tracks and a mournful tone to the love songs.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s something jarring about Merritt singing so directly about his fears\xe2\x80\x94even his bleakest work used to come bundled with the naivety of a hopeless romantic. It helps that most of the album sits squarely in Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s musical comfort zones. Like\xc2\xa0Love at the Bottom of the Sea, *50 Song Memoir *draws inspiration from the sounds of each of his records, from the psychedelic synth pop of *Holiday *to the indie-film-trailer twee of i, even making room for genre exercises in dance music\xc2\xa0(his Future Bible Heroes\xc2\xa0records) and surf-rock (Distortion).' b'By the album\xe2\x80\x99s end, though, the songs begin to lack the cultural context that distinguished the earlier ones, and\xc2\xa050 Song Memoir\xc2\xa0borders on morphing into just\xc2\xa0Several More Love Songs. But among these sit some of his finest tracks. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess\xc2\xa0there\xe2\x80\x99d be other fish in the sea/But I don\xe2\x80\x99t want fishes and you don\xe2\x80\x99t want me,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings in the exquisite \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9905 Never Again.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s the exact kind of song that would turn to putty in the hands of a lesser writer, but Merritt knows how to wring it for emotional resonance. In fact, its place near the end of the album almost signals\xe2\x80\x94more than the impact of the breakup\xe2\x80\x94his growing mastery as a songwriter. It suggests that our deepest wisdom can be located in our most personal thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had something better to do,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, \xe2\x80\x9cBut even my own clothes remind me of you.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Just one song later, Merritt gets a little too specific, showing\xc2\xa0what the album might have been if he took its title more seriously. In \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9906 \xe2\x80\x98Quotes,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Merritt dredges up an old controversy that involved several music critics accusing him of racism. The subject matter has him sounding slightly bitter and self-righteous, but even worse, it simply\xc2\xa0doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make for a good Magnetic Fields song. Merritt\xe2\x80\x99s work has always been less confessional and more \xe2\x80\x9cThings Fitting Perfectly Into Other Things\xe2\x80\x9d: you listen to his songs and marvel at how effortlessly he packs his thoughts into verse, one rhyme parlaying into the next. The best of *50 Song Memoir *plays to his gifts (\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the time I began, I was mostly vegan,\xe2\x80\x9d he boasts in an early song), but with an extra layer of urgency, tied to the task of representing an entire year in a tightly structured pop song. \xe2\x80\x9cI am the least autobiographical person you are likely to meet,\xe2\x80\x9d Merritt admitted with typically humdrum candor in an interview about the album, \xe2\x80\x9cI will probably not write any more true songs after this than I did before.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s likely already dreaming up his next project\xe2\x80\x94putting the past behind him and moving on, his catalog 50 songs richer as a result.'

column7: b"The Antlers singer's proper solo debut*\xc2\xa0*is the result of physical, mental and emotional therapy\xe2\x80\x94a zen-like journey of a man trying to re-enter his own life."
column8: b'Peter Silberman headed upstate for the same reason most New Yorkers do: to get some damn peace and quiet. Problem is that he took all the noise with him. Though his work with the Antlers never had anyone confusing him with J Mascis, years of touring left Silberman with a\xc2\xa0debilitating hearing ailment that started as piercing tinnitus and evolved into a constant sound of \xe2\x80\x9cNiagara Falls in my head.\xe2\x80\x9d Even if aural healing was Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s priority during his convalescence, there was no doubt what he was really working towards. His proper solo debut *Impermanence *is the result of physical, mental and emotional therapy, a man trying to re-enter his own life.' b'This is a guy who likened romantic failure to cancer and a dead dog, so the possibility of him turning this into a gut-wrenching metaphorical ordeal was very real. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost more understandable that Silberman wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t feel the need to dramatize his situation, given the timing of it all. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m disassembling piece by piece,\xe2\x80\x9d he moans on the record\xe2\x80\x99s first line, though that describes less his own rehabilitation than affirms\xc2\xa0Antlers\xe2\x80\x99 M.O. since their 2009 breakthrough. Hospice*\xc2\xa0now stands as the last true exemplar of \xe2\x80\x9c2000s indie,\xe2\x80\x9d touching on Radiohead\xe2\x80\x99s quasi-prog song structures,\xc2\xa0Sigur R\xc3\xb3s\xe2\x80\x99 amniotic ambiance, and\xc2\xa0Arcade Fire\xe2\x80\x99s skyscraping crescendos. But since then, they\xe2\x80\x99ve veered more toward the variously fanged and stoned Burst Apart, which\xc2\xa0turned out to be a tentative step towards the zonked-out laser-Floyd ambiance that defined their most recent work on Undersea\xc2\xa0*and *Familiars**. *And the process of Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s reassembly has resulted in something not too far from what Antlers themselves might have put together in 2017.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cNew York\xe2\x80\x9d is the most immediately fetching song on *Impermanence, something like Interpol\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNYC\xe2\x80\x9d if it was performed like the Grace\xc2\xa0*version of \xe2\x80\x9cHallelujah.\xe2\x80\x9d Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s falsetto hovers over a\xc2\xa0translucent guitar, homesick for a place where he already lives: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen my nerve wore down/I was assailed by simple little sounds/hammer clangs, sirens in the park/like I never heard New York.\xe2\x80\x9d While he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t quite have the natural vocal hops of his immediate influences, Silberman is one of the last true believers of the Buckley/Yorke school of operatic angst and he\xe2\x80\x99s become just as effective as a lead instrument. For a lot of listeners, it\xe2\x80\x99s a short step from Radiohead to Talk Talk and *Impermanence *unsurprisingly evokes *Laughing Stock**, *the gold standard for mid-career, post-rock spiritual cleansing: \xe2\x80\x9cKaruna\xe2\x80\x9d begins with a few seconds of low amp buzz and a loosely knotted guitar chord that *has to be *an overt homage to \xe2\x80\x9cMyrrhman.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"It\xe2\x80\x99s a spare album that asks for a lot of patience, if only a fraction of what Silberman needed to rehabilitate his ears in isolation. Impermanence isn\xe2\x80\x99t meant to sound lonely, however; there are nearly a dozen contributors if you include Big Sur and Block Island, RI for their provision of field sounds. The most important is engineer and mixer Nicholas Principe, a frequent collaborator whose Port St. Willow project often felt spiritually akin to Silberman's work. Principe is part of a quartet that providing doo-wop vocals during \xe2\x80\x9cGone Beyond,\xe2\x80\x9d a supremely stoned jazz riff that ends with a presumptive cue for a vinyl flip. Yet the bulk of *Impermanence *suggests that burning these songs to a tangible item is a necessarily evil: the credits include Tibetan bowls and *ujjayi breath, *and the song titles (\xe2\x80\x9cKaruna,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAhimsa\xe2\x80\x9d) themselves are taken from basic principles of eastern philosophy in accordance with Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s continuing desire to atone for the mean-spirited Burst Apart." b'Though *Impermanence *is unmistakably a record about Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s physical ailments, the lyrics attempt to find a balance between being *just *about that (\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m listening for you, silence\xe2\x80\x9d) and giving the listener something they can apply to their own lives (\xe2\x80\x9cOur bodies are temporary\xe2\x80\x9d). Likewise, the six songs take a long time to assess whether they\xe2\x80\x99re meant to offer serenity or a path to transcendence and whether Silberman\xe2\x80\x99s self-imposed musical limitations can support his most philosophically ambitious work yet. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a slight to call *Impermanence *functional music: If it helps someone else simply cut through the noise in their head, Silberman has gotten his point across.'

column7: b'The young Swedish house producer DJ Seinfeld applies an opaque dose of irreverence atop every surface\xc2\xa0of his project. He makes effective club tracks, but his acts of\xc2\xa0appropriation\xc2\xa0are\xc2\xa0dubious.'
column8: b'Veteran L.A. beat producer Daedelus recently remarked on Twitter,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cYoung producers. Someday your alias won\xe2\x80\x99t sound ridiculous. Keep going.\xe2\x80\x9d A comforting gesture, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t think Daedelus had DJ Seinfeld\xe2\x80\x99s name in mind. Since last year, the young Swedish house producer\xe2\x80\x94who also goes by Rimbaudian, referencing the 19th century French poet Arthur Rimbaud\xe2\x80\x94has been caught in the crossfire of an ongoing debate on the topic of authenticity in house music.' b'Along with such producers as DJ Boring and Ross From Friends,\xc2\xa0DJ Seinfeld has helped usher\xc2\xa0in a new era of house music that prioritizes pleasure over precision; feeling over substance. With that\xe2\x80\x94love it or hate it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clo-fi\xe2\x80\x9d dominated the scene in 2016. Satisfaction is their M.O., and the internet is their oyster. In only a few months, DJ Boring\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWinona\xe2\x80\x9d and Ross From Friends\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cTalk to Me You\xe2\x80\x99ll Understand\xe2\x80\x9d both garnered over a million hits on YouTube\xe2\x80\x94astonishing achievements for unknown bedroom producers. DJ Seinfeld\xe2\x80\x99s own track \xe2\x80\x9cU\xe2\x80\x9d has accrued over 300,000 plays on the same platform since October.' b'The music DJ Seinfeld makes isn\xe2\x80\x99t all that divisive on its own. His debut *Season 1 *EP, released last year, presented a freewheeling collection of five jacking beats dipping between vaporwave funk, scorched-earth acid, and tribal house. It\xe2\x80\x99s emotive party music with a youthful, no-fucks-given approach. Aside from the cover art\xe2\x80\x99s portrayal of Jerry and George in a decidedly Macintosh Plus aesthetic and a track entitled \xe2\x80\x9cJerry,\xe2\x80\x9d DJ Seinfeld\xe2\x80\x99s namesake is nowhere to be found in the tunes themselves.' b'The \xe2\x80\x9cSeinfeld\xe2\x80\x9d graphics have vanished for\xc2\xa0the three-track\xc2\xa0*Sunrise *EP,\xc2\xa0replaced with appropriative imagery of another kind\xe2\x80\x94a cheeky smiley face recalling the ubiquitous symbol of acid house and a dog happily sniffing its own ass, like an ouroboros (the ancient\xc2\xa0symbol\xc2\xa0of a serpent\xc2\xa0eating its tail). The acid house reference is undeniable, and on \xe2\x80\x9cChat Shit Get Luved,\xe2\x80\x9d DJ Seinfeld draws up a gnarly 303 bassline from subterranean depths as the claps reverberate through a cavernous space. It\xe2\x80\x99s an effective club track, but it reaches top velocity fairly quickly, and stays there for five minutes of clenched-fist tension. It forgoes the archetypal EDM \xe2\x80\x9cbuild\xe2\x80\x9d and offers little variation other than a few predictably satisfying bass drops.' b'DJ Seinfeld evokes the cyclical nature\xc2\xa0of the ouroboros on\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cBeginning of an End,\xe2\x80\x9d where he transports us to a shimmering synthscape with a 4/4 pulse less ferocious than the rest of the EP. Meanwhile, a voice recites the 1932 poem\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDo Not Stand at My Grave and Weep\xe2\x80\x9d by Mary Elizabeth Frye. As Frye\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0voice is swallowed up by DJ Seinfeld\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0gently lapping waves, her\xc2\xa0words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDo not stand at my grave and cry/I am not there; I did not die\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94emphasize morbid introspection.' b'The highlight here is \xe2\x80\x9cFlyin\xe2\x80\x99 Thru Sunrise,\xe2\x80\x9d a stomping slice of nouveau-deep-house. Again, DJ Seinfeld doesn\xe2\x80\x99t hide anything, as he recasts\xc2\xa0a snippet from the matriarch of the deep house vocal, Sade Adu. The sample comes\xc2\xa0from her 1992\xc2\xa0Love Deluxe slow-burner \xe2\x80\x9cPearls.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Her words aren\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cFlyin\xe2\x80\x99 thru sunrise,\xe2\x80\x9d as the title suggests, but rather \xe2\x80\x9cdying to survive.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s effective inasmuch as it plays up the moody ecstasy of Moodymann or Larry Heard, but \xe2\x80\x9cFlyin\xe2\x80\x99 Thru Sunrise\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s blatant emotion is also its greatest weakness. Sade\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPearls\xe2\x80\x9d is an elegy to a woman in Somalia barely scraping by; it\xe2\x80\x99s a heartbreaking track about struggle and survival, literally \xe2\x80\x9cdying to survive.\xe2\x80\x9d For DJ Seinfeld, it\xe2\x80\x99s fodder for a bleary-eyed banger.' b"Reinterpretation and re-contextualization are cornerstones of house music, and DJ Seinfeld hasn't really done anything wrong here. But the blatant acts of appropriation in his choice of name, visual aesthetic, and samples make one wonder what exactly Seinfeld is getting at. While electronic music can offer the allure of anonymity or an alter-ego, DJ Seinfeld lacquers an opaque, kitschy dose of irreverence on top every surface\xc2\xa0of his project. He\xe2\x80\x99s not hiding from view\xe2\x80\x94he wants your attention."

column7: b'On their first full-length for Rough Trade, the clattering duo Sleaford Mods\xc2\xa0remain bards of a Great Britain that is not in fact great, but sloppy, self-important, and wholly lacking in taste.'
column8: b'English cuisine is hardly the horror show that it was in the 1970s\xe2\x80\x94the British Isles are no longer a Michelin Star free zone\xe2\x80\x94but the title of Sleaford Mods\xe2\x80\x99 new album still raises a smile of recognition. For ENGLiSH TAPAS,\xc2\xa0they\xe2\x80\x99ve upsized from Nottingham imprint Harbinger Sound to one of the most storied independent labels\xc2\xa0in history, Rough Trade. But vocalist Jason Williamson and producer Andrew Fearn still keep their gaze fixed in the direction of the discount aisle, bards of a Great Britain that is not in fact great, but sloppy, shallow, self-important, and wholly lacking in taste.' b'When Sleaford Mods broke out around 2013, Britain was in the grip of austerity, an economic philosophy applied by the Conservative-led government that seemed to inform both the duo\xe2\x80\x99s downtrodden lyrical content and the pared-back clatter of their music. Those days, though, feel insipid compared to 2017\xe2\x80\x99s geopolitical realities, this slow mudslide into state-sanctioned\xc2\xa0cruelty and small-minded authoritarianism. ENGLiSH TAPAS contains\xc2\xa0a few fleeting references to the state we are in, like nods to Brexit in \xe2\x80\x9cCuddly\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDull.\xe2\x80\x9d A\xc2\xa0breathless rockabilly lurch, titled \xe2\x80\x9cCarlton Touts,\xe2\x80\x9d finds Williamson mock-mourning the dislodged elites that his lyrics once vilified: \xe2\x80\x9cBring back the neolibs, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry/I didn\xe2\x80\x99t fucking mean to pray for anarch-eh!\xe2\x80\x9d But it would be an overstatement\xc2\xa0to call this Sleaford Mods\xe2\x80\x99 Brexit LP. Instead,\xc2\xa0ENGLiSH TAPAS\xc2\xa0mostly finds Williamson further honing the contours of his singular East Midlands vernacular, with special attention paid to the lifestyles of the tragic and washed-up modern male unable to meet even the low expectations that have been set for him.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cArmy Nights\xe2\x80\x9d sets the tone, a bumptious opener sending up the special brand of idiocy that occurs in mess halls, stag dos, locker rooms\xe2\x80\x94any place that men congregate without women. Elsewhere, Williamson returns over and over to the topic of alcohol and substance abuse\xe2\x80\x94specifically, to the impulse to get out of one\xe2\x80\x99s mind as a way of ignoring the misery of existence. \xe2\x80\x9cMessy Anywhere\xe2\x80\x9d is a lads-on-the-town chant that ironically undercuts itself at every stride. \xe2\x80\x9cDrayton Manored\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94rhymed with \xe2\x80\x9cspannered,\xe2\x80\x9d meaning \xe2\x80\x9cextremely drunk\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94is a lurid tale of home drinking, punctuated by the occasional taxi journey\xc2\xa0to restock, which Fearn mischievously illustrates with a supermarket checkout bleep. Williamson doesn\xe2\x80\x99t hold back in his writing\xe2\x80\x94quite the opposite. But he is never merciless, and his character sketches are shot through with a been-there wisdom, a sense of there-but-for-the-grace-of-God-go-I.' b'Williams is often typecast as a ranter, but\xc2\xa0ENGLiSH TAPAS\xc2\xa0is at least as funny as it is angry. Words erupt\xc2\xa0out of him with stray lines that stick: \xe2\x80\x9cYa so dead in the head you got a job-facing life\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cMessy Anywhere\xe2\x80\x9d); \xe2\x80\x9cCar crash into the void of the Magna Carta\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cSnout\xe2\x80\x9d); \xe2\x80\x9cI had an organic chicken it was shit\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cCuddly\xe2\x80\x9d). \xe2\x80\x9cCarlton Touts\xe2\x80\x9d boasts a chorus that somehow crams four good jokes into as many lines. But for all the humor, there is a palpable sense of desperation, a yawning emptiness that lies just beneath the surface. \xe2\x80\x9cTime Sands\xe2\x80\x9d muses on the drudgery of existence, the \xe2\x80\x9cquiet hell/Of cigarettes and trains and plastic and bad brains,\xe2\x80\x9d while \xe2\x80\x9cDull\xe2\x80\x9d is utterly chilling, its dubby murk evoking cold English suffering as bleak as anything on PiL\xe2\x80\x99s Metal Box.' b'Has success changed these perennial underdogs? A little, perhaps. \xe2\x80\x9cJust Like We Do\xe2\x80\x9d is one of the weaker tracks here, a swipe at experimental music snobs who hate the Mods just \xe2\x80\x98cos they\xe2\x80\x99re famous (although Williamson does have the grace to acknowledge that he \xe2\x80\x9cused to be one of \xe2\x80\x98em\xe2\x80\x9d). But there remains\xc2\xa0an essential morality that runs throughout Sleaford Mods\xe2\x80\x99 music, a reflexive siding with the oppressed. The album\xe2\x80\x99s lead single \xe2\x80\x9cB.H.S.\xe2\x80\x9d addresses the disgraced tycoon Philip Green, who asset-stripped the department store he owned and fled to the Med leaving his staff without pensions. Williamson and Fearn conduct it as a jerky chicken dance, the sort of thing Pan\xe2\x80\x99s People might have jigged around to on an old \xe2\x80\x9cTop of the Pops.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Sleaford Mods remain literally unique. By turns,\xc2\xa0ENGLiSH TAPAS\xc2\xa0reminds you of acts as remote as\xc2\xa0Happy Mondays, Pet Shop Boys, and Crass, while never sounding anything like any of them. The closing \xe2\x80\x9cI Feel So Wrong\xe2\x80\x9d finds Williamson switching things up, his scattershot rant softening into a lightly weathered croon. It harkens back to some of the stylistic departures on 2015\xe2\x80\x99s *Key Markets**\xe2\x80\x94*probably Sleaford Mods\xe2\x80\x99 high watermark to date, a record that opened up a few avenues that remain unexplored here. Still, if\xc2\xa0ENGLiSH TAPAS\xc2\xa0at times veers towards formula, it\xe2\x80\x99s at least Sleaford Mods\xe2\x80\x99 own formula, and one that continues to serve them well.'

column3: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot'
column7: b'The debut album from DMX is the Dante\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Inferno\xc2\xa0of rap. His infamous stage presence and aggression gave a voice to the voiceless in the streets of New York and overnight changed the course of hip-hop.'
column8: b'Earl Simmons suffered a lonely and abusive childhood where as a troubled kid he would sometimes wander the streets and befriend stray dogs. Uprooted from his native Baltimore at a young age, the Yonkers transplant did several stints in New York\xe2\x80\x99s Children\xe2\x80\x99s Village group home, where he first started fiddling with drum machines and beatboxing as a means of escape. He segued from DJing to rapping as a young adult, taking the name DMX from the drum machine he used. The young rapper made a name for himself on New York\xe2\x80\x99s battle circuit with a commanding voice and overwhelming tenacity. Aggressiveness would become his calling card as an MC, a defense mechanism held over from when the days when armed robbery helped him survive on the streets. His battles to live and cope both in and outside of rap would lead to 1998\xe2\x80\x99s It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot, his haunting debut, a tragically clear-eyed criminal manifesto that dared to greet damnation with defiance and a psalm.' b'Rocking a skull-embroidered hat, DMX the Great appeared in The Source\xe2\x80\x99s Unsigned Hype column in January 1991, garnering comparisons to LL Cool J, PMD, and Hit Squad\xe2\x80\x99s K-Solo (whom DMX had met in prison). The earliest DMX demos were tedious, without the defining presence he\xe2\x80\x99d grow into. But it was in the ring that he truly built his rep, making an indelible mark on the underground scene with heavily rhythmic flows and a battler\xe2\x80\x99s bluntness. When he traded bars with Jay Z in a cramped Bronx pool hall in the late \xe2\x80\x9990s, head bobbing violently, cigarette in hand, he proved himself to be a raw, almost boorish alternative to Hov\xe2\x80\x99s shifty slick talk. The energy in the room clearly favored X\xe2\x80\x99s style. Jay would later ask industry maneuverer mutual friend Irv Gotti, \xe2\x80\x9cYou think he\xe2\x80\x99s better than me?\xe2\x80\x9d to which Gotti replied, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you look in the hood, there\xe2\x80\x99s less niggas like you and more niggas like him.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The Unsigned Hype column was known for producing deals. True to form, DMX signed to Columbia Records imprint Ruffhouse in 1992 and immediately cut a promotional single called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Born Loser.\xe2\x80\x9d The track introduced his depressive tone, an ominous and confessional space that would later bring life to his most discomforting scenes. But true to its title, it failed to generate any buzz or airplay, and his overbooked label let him off the hook. (DMX claimed he was under-promoted because of groups like Kris Kross and Cypress Hill.) A few years later, Puff Daddy, head of the burgeoning Bad Boy Records, took interest in X and fellow Yonkers corner boys the LOX, but in the end chose to sign the latter over the former, deciding that X had no commercial prospects. \xe2\x80\x9cOne thing I respect about Puff, at least he told me to my face what he felt,\xe2\x80\x9d DMX told \xe2\x80\x9cDrink Champs.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98His voice is too rough, he\xe2\x80\x99s not marketable.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d DMX returned to the underground scene, emerging on LL Cool J\xe2\x80\x99s 1997 album Phenomenon with a verse on the now infamous posse cut \xe2\x80\x9c4, 3, 2, 1.\xe2\x80\x9d Buzzing once more, he followed Gotti to Def Jam.' b'When Gotti pushed for Def Jam to sign DMX in his first meeting, he got laughed out of the room. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember when I left the office, [A&R executive] Tina Davis said, \xe2\x80\x98if DMX don\xe2\x80\x99t sell, your ass is fired,\xe2\x80\x9d Gotti remembered in an interview with Complex. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to fit with the rap moment. This was a year dominated by Puff Daddy and Bad Boy, who landed six of the seven highest-charting rap songs, delivered a huge critical and commercial success in Harlem World, and won Best Rap Album at the Grammys for the 7x-Platinum album No Way Out (famously and controversially defeating Wu-Tang Clan\xe2\x80\x99s Wu-Tang Forever). Putting money behind DMX would run counter to Bad Boy\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cshiny suit\xe2\x80\x9d era of glam rap.' b'But X brought Def Jam executive Lyor Cohen up to Yonkers for an early Ruff Ryder session and convinced him to sign the MC. At the time, DMX\xe2\x80\x99s mouth was wired shut because of an altercation he\xe2\x80\x99d had with some guys he was accused of stealing from. In an interview with DJ Vlad, Ja Rule remembered the ferocity through which he ripped through the wiring: \xe2\x80\x9cHe had got into a fight or somebody got jumped... and he was rhyming with the fuckin\xe2\x80\x99 wires in his mouth. Crazy shit. Like the shit about to pop. I was like \xe2\x80\x98Okay, I like this dude.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d When they left, Cohen turned to Gotti and proclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cWe got the pick of the litter.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Through his connections at Bad Boy (namely, his friends the LOX and Ma$e), DMX began working on his debut album with a producer from Harlem named Dame Grease, a fellow Yonkers product named P.K. (or P. Killer Trackz), and Grease\xe2\x80\x99s unknown protege from the Bronx, Swizz Beatz. Under direction from Irv and Lyor, Grease, P.K., and X worked up a single called \xe2\x80\x9cGet at Me Dog\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9997, and released it in February of \xe2\x80\x9998. It functioned as an abrasive prelude, but was at least partially aimed at X\xe2\x80\x99s longtime rival K-Solo. They brought the song to Hot 97 DJ Funkmaster Flex, who aired it and added it to the first volume of his Big Dawgs mixtape. It soon took off, peaking at No. 39 on the Billboard Hot 100 that May. Gotti remembers the video as the turning point: \xe2\x80\x9cWe back to the hood, and X is the leader of this revolution.\xe2\x80\x9d Filmed at New York\xe2\x80\x99s Tunnel nightclub, packed, sweaty, and shot in black and white, X\xe2\x80\x99s crusade is articulated in its opening seconds: \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s take it back to the streets, motherfuckers!\xe2\x80\x9d' b'\xe2\x80\x9cGet at Me Dog\xe2\x80\x9d set the stage for It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot, which explores the furthest depths of the human experience. But there is no more fitting introduction to the album than the Swizz Beatz-produced \xe2\x80\x9cRuff Ryders\xe2\x80\x99 Anthem,\xe2\x80\x9d a confrontational, fang-bearing mark of ferocity. The song functions much like a warning shot: Cross this threshold at your own peril. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s about to get ugly/Fuck it dog, I\xe2\x80\x99m hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d he snaps. The song was a defining moment for both DMX and Swizz Beatz, but it almost didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen. Swizz made the song in Atlanta when he was just a DJ and then moved back to New York to join the Ruff Ryders. DMX didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the song initially, claiming it was some \xe2\x80\x9crock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll track\xe2\x80\x9d and he needed some hip-hop shit: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not doing that. It\xe2\x80\x99s not hood enough,\xe2\x80\x9d he told the producer. But Swizz and other members of the Ruff Ryders team pushed him to make the record, and it became the theme song of a movement.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot was not only the springboard for the Ruff Ryders campaign\xe2\x80\x94launching the careers of Swizz Beatz, Eve, Cassidy, and Jin\xe2\x80\x94it was the catalyst for a greater shift on the New York rap scene and beyond. It was a reset button for street rap, setting the stage for runs from 50 Cent and G-Unit and Cam\xe2\x80\x99ron\xe2\x80\x99s Diplomats crew. \xe2\x80\x9cHittin\xe2\x80\x99 niggas with gashes to the head/Straight to the white meat but the street stays red/Girls gave me head for free cause they see/Who I\xe2\x80\x99ma be, by like 2003,\xe2\x80\x9d X rapped on the intro. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t even take that long.' b'Like Dante\xe2\x80\x99s Inferno, DMX\xe2\x80\x99s It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot is a fiendish epic that explores the nature of sin, highlighting acts of violence, wrath, greed, treachery, and lust. The album exposes an internal struggle waged between a man and his demons\xe2\x80\x94a man searching for one light in an all-consuming darkness. He has a talk with god (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Convo\xe2\x80\x9d), but the devil is constantly whispering in his ear and wearing him down. He\xe2\x80\x99s unsure whether his rhyme skills are the product of a contract with the devil (\xe2\x80\x9cI sold my soul to the devil, and the price was cheap\xe2\x80\x9d) or the generosity of a loving creator. It\xe2\x80\x99s this duality that makes up one of the most gripping psychological studies in all of rap lore: What happens when a God-fearing man makes the devil his ally?' b'The centerpiece is \xe2\x80\x9cDamien,\xe2\x80\x9d a winding back-and-forth saga between X and his Hadean accomplice. The album builds to this moment, where X is seduced by his greatest admirer. In the throes of his own greed and pain, DMX embraces wickedness as a fair price for freedom from destitution. By the end, the song becomes a parable about the dangers of giving into desire when Damien coerces X into crimes he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to commit: \xe2\x80\x9cEither do it or give me your right hand, that\xe2\x80\x99s what you said,\xe2\x80\x9d he threatens. \xe2\x80\x9cI see now, ain\xe2\x80\x99t nothing but trouble ahead.\xe2\x80\x9d Traces of \xe2\x80\x9cDamien\xe2\x80\x9d can be heard throughout the \xe2\x80\x9cLucy\xe2\x80\x9d thread on Kendrick Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s To Pimp a Butterfly, which also examines the points where fame and sin meet. (Kendrick has cited It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot as a major influence.) But \xe2\x80\x9cDamien\xe2\x80\x9d is even more tightly wound, the relationship more clearly articulated and its energy more affecting. The dynamic \xe2\x80\x9cDamien\xe2\x80\x9d is a microcosm of It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot, which is either in constant motion or disclosing ongoing conversations\xe2\x80\x94whether internal, interpersonal (\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s It Goin\xe2\x80\x99 Down\xe2\x80\x9d), or divine (\xe2\x80\x9cPrayer\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot debuted atop the Billboard 200 in May and was certified platinum by June. DMX quickly released his sophomore album, Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood, in December of \xe2\x80\x9998, and it was double platinum by January. In between the two, he starred in Hype Williams\xe2\x80\x99 directorial debut, Belly, alongside Nas, and the film almost immediately became a cult hit among rap fans. So in a grand total of eight months, DMX became the biggest rapper on the planet. His moment was so colossal that in 1999 Jay Z boycotted the Grammy ceremony (the year he won Best Rap Album for Vol. 2\xe2\x80\xa6 Hard Knock Life) because DMX was not nominated.\xc2\xa0As Nas remembered in a 2013 interview with Pitchfork, \xe2\x80\x9cThat was the year DMX took over the world.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Nearly 20 years later, there is still no album like it. So many of the songs on It\xe2\x80\x99s Dark and Hell Is Hot document violent crimes and the flood of emotions they induce. They move swiftly, jerking around corners and through alleyways, simulating a rising heart rate and a racing mind. His peers were shooting stills, but X was dealing in savage action sequences (\xe2\x80\x9cATF\xe2\x80\x9d) and the shadows they cast (\xe2\x80\x9cLet Me Fly,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cX-Is Coming\xe2\x80\x9d). Everything about the music\xe2\x80\x94from the harshness of his voice, to the murkiness of his beats, to the bruising nature of his flows\xe2\x80\x94was in service of a supreme hardness. In \xe2\x80\x9898, the biggest MCs on the New York scene were narrators using radically different sounds to tell their stories. Busta erupted with pure energy. Big Pun enchanted with an effortless fluidity. As Wu-Tang swarmed, Tribe was in the midst of their love movement. Black Star were a conscious voice for hood theorists. Jay Z brought business acumen to the drug trade. All were reporting live, sharing their powerful perspectives from different city blocks.' b'But DMX wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a rapper in the trenches; he was a messiah in the gutter, painting a portrait of a community laid desolate by corruption, and the sociopaths its conditions were breeding. He was the voice of the street corners and the graveyards, telling stories of the lost and the damned. From on high, he demanded empathy for man, who were cold to murder and unapologetic for their crimes because he knew it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to be good in a world this broken. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a difference between doing wrong and being wrong, and that ain\xe2\x80\x99t right,\xe2\x80\x9d he says on \xe2\x80\x9cLet Me Fly.\xe2\x80\x9d He breaks the moral compass, then drags you into the abyss.' b'CORRECTION: The original version of this review included a quote by Nas that was misleading, misattributing some of his comments about a Lauryn Hill album.'

column7: b'With renewed confidence, focus, and contentment, Alec Ounsworth delivers a consistently satisfying Clap Your Hands album, the best since\xc2\xa0their debut.'
column8: b'Since their 2005 debut, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah have evolved from being an actual band into being just an idea of one. Once a proper quintet, they\xe2\x80\x99ve gradually shed members over the past decade, and after drummer Sean Greenhalgh bailed following 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Only Run, the group was down to one man clapping\xe2\x80\x94lead singer/songwriter Alec Ounsworth. Of course, Ounsworth has been the band\xe2\x80\x99s creative center since the very beginning, and even though he\xe2\x80\x99s released music under his own name, he\xe2\x80\x99s held onto the Clap Your Hands brand\xe2\x80\x94as much for its obfuscating qualities as recognition value. Always too cryptic and theatrical a raconteur to fit the traditional singer-songwriter mold, Clap Your Hands is Ounsworth\xe2\x80\x99s means of holding up a funhouse mirror to it, through restless, combustible songs as elastic and exaggerated as his voice.' b'But even though his original band has effectively fallen apart, Ounsworth has some quality Krazy Glue in the form of Dave Fridmann. The producer has a history of stabilizing bands in a state of flux, whether charting the Flaming Lips\xe2\x80\x99 course out of \xe2\x80\x9cJelly\xe2\x80\x9d-ville, or promoting himself from Mercury Rev\xe2\x80\x99s bassist to their studio-bound sonic architect in the mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s. Fridmann has worked on two very different Clap Your Hands records, both of which bore the pressure of the band\xe2\x80\x99s circumstances at the time: 2007\xe2\x80\x99s infamously cluttered and blown-out Some Loud Thunder was an unsubtle pin-prick to the inflated anticipation that followed their debut; the deconstructed, discombobulated Only Run captured the sound of a shrinking band trying to figure out where to go next. Like the latter record, The Tourist was self-produced by Ounsworth and mixed by Fridmann, but Only Run\xe2\x80\x99s sense of blank-canvas uncertainty has been replaced with renewed confidence, focus, and contentment.' b'The result is the most consistently satisfying Clap Your Hands album since their debut. Ounsworth\xe2\x80\x99s once-adversarial songwriting smarts and sonic ambitions are more in sync than ever before, and Fridmann\xe2\x80\x99s lustrous mix ranges between the intimate and the epic. The Tourist furthers Only Run\xe2\x80\x99s predilection for synth-smeared textures, but the songs here feel less like randomized experiments and more purposefully constructed for dramatic effect: \xe2\x80\x9cA Chance to Cure\xe2\x80\x9d begins in an ambient, after-hours R&B haze but erupts into a blast of psychedelic funk, powered by a hiccupping drumbeat that locks in with Ounsworth\xe2\x80\x99s rap-like repartee; \xe2\x80\x9cDown (is where I want to be)\xe2\x80\x9d is a delirious disco in the spirit of \xe2\x80\x9cSatan Said Dance,\xe2\x80\x9d spiked with Eno-esque harmonies and a surprising rock-out climax that transforms it into the first Clap Your Hands song to make you pump your fist.' b'Ounsworth has said The Tourist was written during a period of personal tumult, and his lyric sheet here is riddled with references to ambulances, drugs, \xe2\x80\x9cvisiting hours,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdark flowers.\xe2\x80\x9d But he works through his woes with sly humor. The charming, organ-poked waltz \xe2\x80\x9cUnfolding Above Celibate Moon (Lost Angeles Nursery Rhyme)\xe2\x80\x9d sees Ounsworth declare, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s no good trying to be someone you\xe2\x80\x99re not,\xe2\x80\x9d before building a couplet from quotes of the Velvet Underground\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll Be Your Mirror\xe2\x80\x9d and Broken Social Scene\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Still Your Fag.\xe2\x80\x9d And atop the glistening glide of \xe2\x80\x9cBetter Off,\xe2\x80\x9d he confronts an existential crisis (\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s better to keep moving/Better just to hold still\xe2\x80\x9d) with zen-like bliss, rendering a scene of interpersonal turmoil by cribbing the \xe2\x80\x9chit me with a flower\xe2\x80\x9d quip from Lou Reed\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cVicious.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'In spite of The Tourist\xe2\x80\x99s surface shimmer, Ounsworth still wields his frail voice like a weapon, dramatically punctuating his lines with hysterical tics like someone feigning a fainting episode to get out of an uncomfortable situation. But they\xe2\x80\x99re also natural responses to moments when he\xe2\x80\x99s just too overcome with emotion. The heart-rending \xe2\x80\x9cAmbulance Chaser\xe2\x80\x9d surges forth like an acoustic complement to \xe2\x80\x9cIn This Home On Ice,\xe2\x80\x9d its fidgety rhythm emblematic of the unsettling medical drama unfolding in Ounsworth\xe2\x80\x99s motor-mouthed lyrics (\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a limit to how much I can endure/I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my medicine and you\xe2\x80\x99ll just hope for the worst\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'The revitalizing vigor of The Tourist suggests that whatever troubles were plaguing Ounsworth are now behind him, with the post-punk thrust of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Vanity of Trying\xe2\x80\x9d putting the exclamation point on the album\xe2\x80\x99s liberation philosophy when he exclaims, \xe2\x80\x9cWe can be whatever, whatever, whatever, whatever, whatever, whatever, whatever we want!\xe2\x80\x9d A decade ago, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah were a modest, rickety band bearing the albatross of hype; today, they\xe2\x80\x99re an amorphous, musically adventurous entity basking in the freedom of no expectations.'

column7: b'Cameron Graves, the pianist for Kamasi Washington and a founding member of the West Coast Get Down collective, makes his own searing mark with an enrapturing and assured solo album.'
column8: b'The collective known as the West Coast Get Down may have made its emphatic mark on the jazz world in 2015, but the bandmates have been honing their sound and approach for nearly two decades together in Los Angeles. They\xe2\x80\x99ve put in their Gladwellian 10,000 hours, just not in New York or at Berklee.' b'If tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington\xe2\x80\x94with his sprawling, uncompromising record The Epic\xe2\x80\x94was the subject of the most column inches in 2015, this may be the year for some of his long-time collaborators like Cameron Graves, a beguiling pianist who just released Planetary Prince, his rousing debut as a bandleader. Fellow WCGD musicians Ryan Porter (trombone), Stephen \xe2\x80\x9cThundercat\xe2\x80\x9d Bruner (bass), drummer Ronald Bruner, Jr., and Kamasi Washington (as a sideman) return for this set, with the addition of trumpeter Philip Dizack and Hadrien Feraud, another bassist, both of whom are immersed in the L.A. jazz scene.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s at once an addendum to The Epic and an extension. It was recorded during an eleven-hour session, and at 80 minutes it has the feel of a concept album, channeling Graves\xe2\x80\x99 interest in astrology and The Urantia Book, the 2,000-page spiritual/science text of unknown provenance that served as inspiration for outr\xc3\xa9 composer Karlheinz Stockhausen\xe2\x80\x99s seven-day opera \xe2\x80\x9cLicht.\xe2\x80\x9d (Jimi Hendrix and Jerry Garcia also carried around copies in their rucksacks.)' b'The authorship of the music, though, is all Graves, who, it\xe2\x80\x99s been reported, enjoys death metal and Chopin, hip-hop and prog rock, and has played with Jada Pinkett-Smith\xe2\x80\x99s band Wicked Wisdom and pioneering fusion bassist Stanley Clarke. The eight tracks on the album reveal Graves\xe2\x80\x99 influences, which seem to come from everywhere and nowhere. There are whiffs of McCoy Tyner, especially from his early- mid-\xe2\x80\x9970s groups, Abdullah Ibrahim, and somehow Joe Sample, yet he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t particularly sound like any of them.' b'As a youngster, Graves studied classical piano, which is apparent from the gorgeous opening bars of the first piece, \xe2\x80\x9cSatania Our Solar System,\xe2\x80\x9d before it quickly transitions into an uptempo fusion-esque romp with a charging back beat.
