In the subsequent title track, Graves, who plays acoustic throughout the set, bursts out in percussive form\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s often thunderingly percussive, as in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lucifer Rebellion\xe2\x80\x9d later\xe2\x80\x94and follows with a busy, jabbing solo. Washington, with his singular, bravura tone, soon joins and verges on obfuscating the material, but stays just on the right side of his ecstatic-expressionism. \xe2\x80\x9cAndromeda\xe2\x80\x9d shifts to a quieter side, or as quiet as the WCGD can get. Feraud, a Parisian, recalls Jaco Pastorius on an inspired electric bass solo, and Ronald Bruner\xe2\x80\x94who also shimmers on \xe2\x80\x9cEl Diablo\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94coerces all sorts of vibrant colors out of just his cymbals. The theme, especially when played by the horns, has a dream-like touch, as if penned by Wayne Shorter.' b'On \xe2\x80\x9cIsle of Love,\xe2\x80\x9d the leader opens with vigor, before Kamasi returns for another towering solo. Graves takes us out softly and by himself, which is exactly how \xe2\x80\x9cAdam & Eve\xe2\x80\x9d begins. Kamasi lets loose one more time, but the three horns that finish the tune\xe2\x80\x94and Porter\xe2\x80\x99s trombone adds lovely texture here, as it did on The Epic\xe2\x80\x94underscores the unselfishness that marks the work of the WCGD. \xe2\x80\x9cThe End of Corporatism,\xe2\x80\x9d an uptempo piece, further captures the Collective\xe2\x80\x99s (and Graves\xe2\x80\x99) drive and spirit, one that is enraptured, assured, grandiose in moments, but never self-aggrandizing. Planetary Prince might not shift the tectonic plates the way *The Epic *did, but Graves, while earthly-bound, has his gaze set upward.'

column7: b"The latest from Toronto's self-professed hardcore purists\xc2\xa0animates eleven songs in a style that, what with its limited vocabulary, usually lends itself to sets of four or five."
column8: b'In the early to mid-2000s, Fucked Up and Career Suicide were cousin groups in the Toronto punk scene. They performed together and shared members Jonah Falco and Mike Haliechuk, and each sounded inspired by the lurch and throttle of 1980s American hardcore. But Career Suicide skewed bratty (sampling punk sendup Repo Man) where Fucked Up went didactic (sampling anti-fascist speeches). And on albums released in 2006, their paths sharply diverged: Fucked Up\xe2\x80\x99s expansive Hidden World*\xc2\xa0*foreshadowed the musical ingenuity and conceptual bombast to come, while Career Suicide\xe2\x80\x99s reverent hardcore sounded more bracingly combustible than ever on Attempted Suicide.' b'*Machine Response, *Career Suicide\xe2\x80\x99s first release since 2008 (aside from a prelude EP of the same name that appeared late last year), shows the rewards of their craftsman-like commitment to a familiar form\xe2\x80\x94hardcore not as a template to expand, or as a style to flee, but as a sort of aspirational ideal. That means the songs are punchy and concise, animated by Falco\xe2\x80\x99s blocky riffs and Martin Farkas\xe2\x80\x99 breathless bark. And it means that though the album careens in expected ways, its delight is akin to watching the staged implosion of a skyscraper: spectacular for its expenditure of energy in the service of wreckage, and no less impressive for occurring right on schedule.' b'Unusually stirring hardcore is more often ramshackle, the result of expression outpacing skill. Experienced players, meanwhile, frequently sacrifice individual personality to cultivate a sense of imposing might; that\xe2\x80\x99s why so much self-consciously extreme hardcore sounds so antiseptic. *Machine Response, *however, slots into neither category. The band members manage to give highlights such as \xe2\x80\x9cTighten the Screws\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBreak Away\xe2\x80\x9d a palpable groove, to swing despite inhospitably brisk tempos. They animate eleven songs in a style that, what with its limited vocabulary, usually lends itself to sets of four or five.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a somewhat contradictory position: exercise creative invention, but mind the strictures of what Machine Response\xe2\x80\x99s promotional material calls \xe2\x80\x9cpurist hardcore.\xe2\x80\x9d Not all of the songs adhere: A bleating horn on the mid-tempo \xe2\x80\x9cTaking You With Me\xe2\x80\x9d evokes Rocket From the Crypt, while the sauntering gait and singsong refrain of \xe2\x80\x9cNo Walls, No Curtains\xe2\x80\x9d sound\xc2\xa0indebted to late-1970s punk. They don\xe2\x80\x99t undermine the album, just the band\xe2\x80\x99s professed purity. For Falco, who writes the music, it\xe2\x80\x99s tempting to view Career Suicide\xe2\x80\x99s formal conservatism as a respite from the mercurial whims of Fucked Up.' b"Still, in certain circles, a new Career Suicide is more exciting than a new Fucked Up album. (Farkas supposed, in a recent interview, that the bands hardly share listeners anymore.) This has a lot to do with how critics tacitly devalue hardcore. The style is appreciated, even fetishized, as a background from which bands progress and deemed noteworthy once left behind. It's a paternalistic idea keeps hardcore locked in the past and illegitimate in the present. Career Suicide\xe2\x80\x99s *Machine Response *is one brazen rebuttal to all of that, a swaggering wager on a simple style\xe2\x80\x99s enduring, essential thrills."

column3: b'Outro Tempo: Electronic and Contemporary Music From Brazil, 1978-1992'
column7: b'This ambitious compilation features wild blends of electronics, jazz fusion, new age drifts, new-fangled digital drum machines, and traditional Brazilian percussion placed into new, curious sounds.'
column8: b'In 1985, Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s repressive junta finally allowed for direct elections for a president for the first time since their military coup of 1964. For artists and musicians of all stripes, the censorship and repression experienced during that military reign came to be known as \xe2\x80\x9cvazio cultural\xe2\x80\x9d (cultural void). The most well-known example came with the 1968 arrest and subsequent exile of two stars of Tropic\xc3\xa1lia, Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil. But for the artists who stayed in country, the regime\xe2\x80\x99s censorship became increasingly Kafkaesque to navigate. Some artists resorted to recording without words so as to elude such censorship\xe2\x80\x94see Milton Nascimento\xe2\x80\x99s Milagre Dos Peixes\xc2\xad\xe2\x80\x94but it was only as the military\xe2\x80\x99s stranglehold finally loosened that others began to rediscover their voices.' b'In the liner notes to Outro Tempo\xe2\x80\x94a beguiling and dizzying assemblage of fourteen Brazilian experimental and fusion artists from around the time of that country\xe2\x80\x99s thawing\xe2\x80\x94producer John G\xc3\xb3mez remembers happening upon Marco Bosco\xe2\x80\x99s 1983 album Metalmadeira in a British thrift shop and finding a handwritten note within: \xe2\x80\x9cDear Mr. Eno, I would like you to know about our work, we work with tapes and sounds of Nature.\xe2\x80\x9d Whether or not Mr. Eno ever happened upon this music, in the instance of taking over thirty years for this work to drift to ears, each track feels like a message in a bottle. As guitarist Nando Carneiro states in the notes, musicians during this time \xe2\x80\x9chad to stay caught in a cage.\xe2\x80\x9d Emanating from a country increasingly isolated from the rest of the world, these artists put wild blends of electronics, jazz fusion, new age drifts, new-fangled digital drum machines, and traditional Brazilian percussion into a new, curious sound.' b'A trace of Nascimento\xe2\x80\x99s wordless music echoes through Anno Luz\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPor Qu\xc3\xaa,\xe2\x80\x9d as pan flutes get stretched into a cloud and a bright, fingerpicked guitar figure moves in and out of an analog synth haze. Carneiro\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cG.R.E.S. Luxo Artesanal\xe2\x80\x9d also aims for a similar space, wedding his nimble samba phrases to a programmed rhythm and a synth line that slowly becomes unmoored from the beat. Some four minutes in, he splices the tape and the guitar drifts into \xe2\x80\x9cO Campon\xc3\xaas,\xe2\x80\x9d with Carneiro\xe2\x80\x99s non-verbal accompaniment capping the piece with a poignant coda.' b'One of the sets more thrilling juxtapositions is between the hand percussion that\xe2\x80\x99s underpinned Brazilian music for centuries and these stiff new electronic components. Most of these devices had to be smuggled into the country through bribed officials. But even culturally, there was hesitation to have such computers make facsimiles of the lithe Brazilian rhythms. It\xe2\x80\x99s the tangy interplay of hand drum patter and percolating electronics that gives Cinema\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSem Teto\xe2\x80\x9d a soda-pop fizz, suggestive of the similar samba hybrids envisioned a hemisphere away by bands like Antenna.' b'And as the military regime fell asunder and artists regained their voices, so did the music begin to expand and change. The other dialogue flowing through Outro Tempo is between Brazilian artists as they began to interact not just with one another, but with the indigenous tribes in Amazonia endangered by rampant deforestation going on during that decade. Some composers traveled to the jungle so as to better interact with these ancient sounds. Ben\xc3\xa9 Fonteles\xe2\x80\x99 haunted \xe2\x80\x9cO M M\xe2\x80\x9d chants that sacred Hindu syllable, strikes chimes, and shakes rattles until it resembles the clatter of the rainforest, while Maria Rita couples her powerful voice with tribal percussion and electric bass on \xe2\x80\x9cC\xc3\xa2ntico Brasileiro No.3.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The most stunning compositions come from Priscilla Ermel, represented by the two longest cuts on the compilation. During the \xe2\x80\x9980s, Ermel traveled into the rainforest to immerse herself in study of these vanishing indigenous forms, seeking to fuse it with her own sensibilities as a musician and composer. But rather than just conduct a simple integration of ancient and modern, she also reaches outside of her country for other timbres, suggesting a \xe2\x80\x9cworld music\xe2\x80\x9d more holistic than such a tag implies. Across the nine-minute \xe2\x80\x9cGestos de Equil\xc3\xadbrio,\xe2\x80\x9d she interweaves guitar, synth, oboe and clay pot drums, but also makes foreign objects like the banjo, kalimba and Indian stringed-instrument the dilruba all sound right at home on her gently undulating ambient piece. Even more formidable is her 15-minute masterwork, \xe2\x80\x9cCorpo do Vento.\xe2\x80\x9d Across a thundering battery of bombo and cultrun, Ermel breathes through ocarina, Chilean chirimia and Nepalese flute, giving the epic a ritualistic vibration. She judiciously adds piano and viola caipira and the middle section drifts into new age territory before returning to the drum-driven mesmerism of the final passage.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey are portals through which stories, people, and cultures can be revealed,\xe2\x80\x9d Ermel explains in the album\xe2\x80\x99s liner notes about how she perceives her music. And almost every track here resonates like a secret kept silent for decades. Outro Tempo opens up a portal for us in the present moment back to a time and place where \xe2\x80\x94under the suffocating weight of a totalitarian state\xe2\x80\x94a few brave musicians nevertheless could hear the sounds of a brighter world.'

column7: b'Over a well-played hand of wistful, bright-eyed, and reflective beats, HNDRXX strikes a near-perfect balance between a man still licking his wounds and a man emerging from a long, dark night.'
column8: b'Future has become the antihero for men who believe emotional torture is essential to masculinity. After a splashy, very public relationship with the singer Ciara, the two had a splashy, very public breakup that spilled from the courts and onto Twitter. In its wake, Future measured his pain into cups of codeine-spiked soda and poured it all over his music, most notably on 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Dirty Sprite 2. Dudes who lived vicariously through him dredged up all sorts of relationship trauma in order to wail alongside him, once more with feeling.' b'After DS2\xe2\x80\x99s 4 a.m. drive through the desert, Future cartwheeling back into the heart-clutching love songs and sweet-street persona of his 2012 debut, Pluto, might have been jarring. But nobody stays in beast mode forever, and FUTURE, the companion piece to\xc2\xa0HNDRXX, showed a few cracks in his hardened facade. Heartbreaks heal, especially when you\xe2\x80\x99re a Romeo rapper with an R&B bedside manner and an unending supply of Vicodin. Over a well-played hand of wistful, bright-eyed and reflective beats, HNDRXX strikes a near-perfect balance between a man still licking his wounds and a man emerging from a long, dark night.' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not to say there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a little bumpiness upon re-entry. For all of us who missed the old Future\xe2\x80\x94that \xe2\x80\x9cTurn on the Lights\xe2\x80\x9d Future, that love-you-down-in-the-sheets and buy-you-a-new-Range-for-the-streets Future\xe2\x80\x94HNDRXX\xe2\x80\x99s opener \xe2\x80\x9cMy Collection\xe2\x80\x9d is a bit of a mind fuck. Over a wispy lullaby of a beat that sounds like more like an outro than an intro, Future peels off bills before asking, \xe2\x80\x9cYou wanna come to Pluto?\xe2\x80\x9d Yes! Unfortunately, he lapses into light shaming of Ciara\xe2\x80\x99s sexual history before the cringe-worthy declaration, \xe2\x80\x9cEven if I hit you once, you part of my collection.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'A trio of standard-issue songs follows, filled with flossy verses flush with cash, cars, designer namedrops and a couple funny lines (\xe2\x80\x9cI wanna take you out to Paris and buy you better clothes,\xe2\x80\x9d he says in \xe2\x80\x9cLookin Exotic\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cBaby mama back drinking liquor/Now she tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to fuck my life up\xe2\x80\x9d in the DJ Mustard-produced \xe2\x80\x9cDamage\xe2\x80\x9d). The Weeknd\xe2\x80\x99s sniveling on \xe2\x80\x9cComin Out Strong\xe2\x80\x9d aside, these all blur together.' b"But redemption comes on the ghostly \xe2\x80\x9cUse Me.\xe2\x80\x9d One of Future\xe2\x80\x99s gifts is imbuing his voice with such emotion that lyrics become putty in his hands.\xc2\xa0As shadows flit across the wall, the plaintive refrain of \xe2\x80\x9cuse me\xe2\x80\x9d is made all the more gut-wrenching when he belts it. By the time an organ warbles onto the song, he\xe2\x80\x99s spent, his heart wrung dry. The shivery chorus begins to fade, and birds start chirping. It\xe2\x80\x99s chilly, but dawn has finally broken, and somebody's cooking Nayvadius breakfast this morning." b'\xe2\x80\x9cIncredible\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTestify\xe2\x80\x9d are sun-warmed island beats that smell and shimmer like tanning oil-slicked shoulders. Future sounds like he\xe2\x80\x99s on vacation, loose as his limbs after that hot yoga class. \xe2\x80\x9cI was havin\xe2\x80\x99 trust issues/But I\xe2\x80\x99ve been havin\xe2\x80\x99 way better luck since you,\xe2\x80\x9d he starts off \xe2\x80\x9cIncredible,\xe2\x80\x9d relieved to baby talk again instead of bragging about another random bad bitch. Plenty of lines on HNDRXX \xc2\xa0melt hearts and make up for all games and the lies: \xe2\x80\x9cI wanna hear your heart pump pound for pound \xe2\x80\xa6We conversin\xe2\x80\x99 back and forth like we real partners/Spiritually we bonded through the turmoil.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'If that\xe2\x80\x99s not enough, he comes bearing a gentle pop duet with Rihanna, \xe2\x80\x9cSelfish\xe2\x80\x9d (featuring delicate production from Detail, Major Seven, and Mantra), and a seven-and-a-half minute apology, \xe2\x80\x9cSorry.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s still airing out grievances and self-medicating with a fistful of \xe2\x80\x98scripts, but the run from \xe2\x80\x9cUse Me\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cI Thank U\xe2\x80\x9d is inspired. The sun burns the edges of the clouds without entirely breaking through, which feels more honest, anyway.' b"The old clich\xc3\xa9 is that artists produce better work when they're in pain, and it did seem like the deeper Future sank, the higher his star rose. Appreciating that without romanticizing or wallowing in his despair is key, as is allowing him freedom to create from a different emotional vantage point. As Charles Bukowski wrote in \xe2\x80\x9cLet It Enfold You\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cEither peace or happiness,/Let it enfold you/When I was a young man/I felt these things were/Dumb, unsophisticated.\xe2\x80\x9d" b'But Bukowski got that first part wrong. Peace and happiness do not simply \xe2\x80\x9cenfold\xe2\x80\x9d you. Sadness spreads like weeds, and channeling that into your music is a means of purging it so it won\xe2\x80\x99t choke you. It\xe2\x80\x99s joy that requires constant tending to grow. With HNDRXX, Future did just that, venturing back into the day for some fresh air with his woman who\xe2\x80\x99s frying bacon. The sand\xe2\x80\x99s like flour between their toes, and the music feels just fine.'

column7: b'Scum-rock, psychedelia, and drones collide on the latest full-length from NYC\xe2\x80\x99s PC Worship, but\xc2\xa0Buried Wish errs towards a more skeletal sound.'
column8: b'PC Worship are a few chromosomes shy of their own DNA strand. But the NYC band\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0shakiness has long\xc2\xa0been key to their shredded charm.\xc2\xa0Since 2009, frontman Justin Frye has led shifting lineups through genre calisthenics rigorous\xc2\xa0enough that their repertoire encompasses way-out freak-flag jams, garage punk shimmy, and a *Fraggle Rock *cover, among other oddities. PC Worship stumble and shamble the way collectives like Harlem\xe2\x80\x99s No-Neck Blues Band or Finland\xe2\x80\x99s Avarus might if Captain Beefheart were sitting in. The PC Worship Experience is uncertain, splintered, alive, and never lacking in bristling forward momentum.' b'This makes\xc2\xa0the first song on *Buried Wish *a bit of\xc2\xa0a head-scratcher. No-tempo \xe2\x80\x9cLifeless Rain on an Empty Moon\xe2\x80\x9d rubs together brass drones at peculiar\xc2\xa0angles before a zig-zagging sample burst. It\xe2\x80\x99s tranquil, if uneasily so. Revisit the opening cuts from 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Beat Punk, 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Social Rust, or 2015\xe2\x80\x99s *Basement Hysteria**\xe2\x80\x94*this is a sedate starting-point\xc2\xa0for PC Worship, signaling Frye\xe2\x80\x99s move towards a more spacious sound.' b'*Buried Wish *does find moments to rollick. Stoner metal dirge \xe2\x80\x9cBack of My $$$\xe2\x80\x9d crawls forward like lava under the weight of gnashing guitars. Grease fire psychedelia and 1980s Lower East Side scum-rock collide on the sneering, accessible \xe2\x80\x9cBlank Touch.\xe2\x80\x9d Almost everywhere else here, though, the band embraces the spare or the stripped back.\xe2\x80\x9cTranq,\xe2\x80\x9d a piano curio that morphs into a pummeling\xc2\xa0krautrock interlude, achieves the effect of its title.' b'The title track gently hoists a sitar-like frequency higher and higher up into the stratosphere before allowing it to plummet back down to earth in a storm of effects. Vertiginously anemic, the delirious \xe2\x80\x9cHelp\xe2\x80\x9d thumbtacks atonal string whinny with spoken word. \xe2\x80\x9cTorched\xe2\x80\x9d carpets spindled guitars with constantly erupting drum rolls, like *Standards-*era Tortoise sound-checking. The cumulative tone at work here\xe2\x80\x94aided by sharp production and stark arrangements\xe2\x80\x94is one of calm, wary digression.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cPerched on the Wall\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFlowers & Haunting\xe2\x80\x9d mark Buried Wish\xe2\x80\x99s most radical departures, foregrounding Frye\xe2\x80\x99s weary, blunt voice. Stung by glancing electric blues riffs, \xe2\x80\x9cPerched\xe2\x80\x9d stumbles and lurches languidly, a dazed quest for meaning that may or may not be there to be found. \xe2\x80\x9cFlowers & Hunting\xe2\x80\x9d strands Frye with an acoustic guitar and a pedestrian field recording to plaintively string together one daft couplet after another: \xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunate, and pleading/Incapable of breathing/Enraged and retreating.\xe2\x80\x9d The words mumble and tumble out, honest and pure in a way that mirrors, if inversely, his band\xe2\x80\x99s splayed-tone. On the darkest of days, they\xe2\x80\x99ll bear repeating.'

column7: b'The Iowa City doom trio\xe2\x80\x99s latest streamlines their approach. It lacks the subtleties that distinguished their previous work.'
column8: b'Though Aseethe identify as a doom act, the prominent noise samples on 2011 debut\xc2\xa0Reverent Burden showed that the Iowa City trio was trying to do more than just sludgeon its audience into submission. Aseethe have since recorded an improv\xc2\xa0album, a suite of re-worked riffs by avant-doom duo Barn Owl, an EP featuring synth accompaniment, and a rendition of Black Sabbath\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cRat Salad\xe2\x80\x9d stretched and slowed beyond recognition. Across that entire body of work, Aseethe maintained an\xc2\xa0atmosphere and textures verging on ambient drone.' b'On\xc2\xa0Hopes of Failure, Aseethe shed their sound\xe2\x80\x99s flaky outer layers in favor of ultra-dense riffs that creep by like boiling molasses. True, they built Reverent Burden on similarly solid riffing, but this time they offer less in the way of\xc2\xa0sonic detail. The new album\xe2\x80\x94four tunes ranging from eight-and-a-half to 14 minutes\xe2\x80\x94drones on without the subtleties that distinguished Aseethe in the first place. And because it lacks the space and sweep of their previous work,\xc2\xa0Hopes of Failure marginalizes the industrial-metal gloom furnished by drummer Eric Diercks\xe2\x80\x99 samples.' b'The new material doesn\xe2\x80\x99t reward the patience of letting the songs unfold nearly as effectively as this band always has. Diehard doom aficionados will likely appreciate Hopes of Failure as a purposeful trimming of extraneous fat. But it\xe2\x80\x99s puzzling that Aseethe would choose to recast themselves as something of a conventional doom band at this stage, after repeatedly demonstrating that there\xe2\x80\x99s more to what they do.' b'It would be one thing if the fidelity of the recording could approximate\xc2\xa0the sensation of standing in front of amplifier cabinets, having\xc2\xa0your chest rattled by the sheer density of sound. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not the case. It\xe2\x80\x99s not that the recording is necessarily flat, but Hopes of Failure doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say anything we haven\xe2\x80\x99t already heard after decades\xe2\x80\x99 worth of tone-obsessed artists getting better and better at capturing on mic the way speaker cones move air through a room. Compared to 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Burdens II, it\xe2\x80\x99s almost shocking how little Hopes of Failure conveys a sense of the band in a physical setting.' b'At times, the album does hint at the\xc2\xa0wrinkles Aseethe have added to doom. \xe2\x80\x9cBarren Soil,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, begins with a Danny Barr bassline so deep it seems to dip toward subsonic frequencies. That said, every note is audible and you can actually hum along to the melody\xe2\x80\x94no small feat when you\xe2\x80\x99re dealing with timbres that tend to smother pitch. And in a dramatic departure for the band, Barr also sings a clean verse on closing track \xe2\x80\x9cInto the Sun.\xe2\x80\x9d After Barr and his brother, guitarist and founder Brian Barr, have spent a half hour barking, the shift to relatively melodic vocals enhances the album\xe2\x80\x99s acerbic mood.' b'But the band opts not to emphasize\xc2\xa0these features. Stripped of its usual dimension, Aseethe\xe2\x80\x99s music consigns the Barr brothers\xe2\x80\x99 lyrics to the realm of unremarkable negativity. Clearly, Aseethe have made a concerted effort to streamline their approach, but Hopes of Failure only underscores how much better off they are when they stick to their guns. As such, it functions best as a gateway to a more colorful back catalog.'

column7: b'The hapless solo debut from the Vampire Weekend drummer is excruciatingly self-reflexive.'
column8: b'This solo debut of Vampire Weekend drummer Chris Tomson was born three years ago, when the band took a break after touring behind 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Modern Vampires of the City. Tomson, who had just turned 30, got married and got a mortgage. Less typically for someone his age, Tomson was also staring at what he called \xe2\x80\x9ca fairly large amount of time off.\xe2\x80\x9d He had his childhood piano moved from his parents\xe2\x80\x99 house in New Jersey to his basement in Brooklyn, and\xe2\x80\x94after \xe2\x80\x9cprobably two months watching sports and then two months staring blankly\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94started writing these songs.' b'He went with the name Dams of the West because of an article debating whether the dams in western America have outlived their usefulness and, \xe2\x80\x9cas a straight, white man playing generally rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll music\xe2\x80\x9d in 2017, \xe2\x80\x9cfelt a certain camaraderie with the crumbling infrastructure from the middle of the last century.\xe2\x80\x9d He uses this acute awareness of his place in life as a vehicle to muse about the droll scenes that play out in his narrow range of vision. Its effect on almost every level\xe2\x80\x94political, social, artistic\xe2\x80\x94is essentially useless.' b'The muddle of Youngish American begins with the music. As the rhythmic force on three of the most critically adored albums of the past decade, Tomson knows his way around the drum kit. He also deftly plays almost all of the instruments on Youngish American. But his mellow voice is affectless, even with\xc2\xa0Black Keys\xe2\x80\x99 Patrick Carney as producer. Carney\xe2\x80\x99s touch on the record is serviceable, keeping the reverb gauzy and the percussion brawny, similar to his work with bands like Tennis and Black Lips. However, at some point, it was mistakenly suggested these songs should include swooping violin runs behind Tomson\xe2\x80\x99s showy, clumsy lyrics.' b'Those lyrics dream oh so big of mixing Courtney Barnett\xe2\x80\x99s knack for detail with Father John Misty\xe2\x80\x99s ironic self-awareness. As a rule, the less comically winking they are, the better Tomson comes off. It\xe2\x80\x99s charming when he sings \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care where your heart is at/Even if it\xe2\x80\x99s right where Sinatra sat,\xe2\x80\x9d on the slower, statelier \xe2\x80\x9cPolo Grounds,\xe2\x80\x9d named after the long-gone home of baseball\xe2\x80\x99s New York Giants.' b'But other mundanities are delivered with such a dearth of meaning or poetry that they simply become mundane. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Inerrancy of You and Me\xe2\x80\x9d hops from cooking \xe2\x80\x9cpasta with the red sauce/When I know you\xe2\x80\x99re PMSing\xe2\x80\x9d to using the titular word Tomson says he recently just learned. The woozy ballad \xe2\x80\x9cFlag on the Can\xe2\x80\x9d repeats a half-baked question about Bud Light\xc2\xa0packaging, then adds, after what could only be a rip from some comically oversized bong, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is philosophy, anyway?\xe2\x80\x9d Wine and personal finance are actually recurring themes across the album.' b'Like the least charming aspects of Father John Misty or late-career Sun Kil Moon, Tomson\xe2\x80\x99s self-reflexiveness is exhausting. The fuzzed-out \xe2\x80\x9cPretty Good WiFi\xe2\x80\x9d describes noticing a person\xe2\x80\x99s legs and then having to realize, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, shit, the male gaze!\xe2\x80\x9d A fairly representative track lyrically is the spaciously arranged \xe2\x80\x9cPerfect Wave,\xe2\x80\x9d which mostly involves the protagonist talking about vintage Pittsburgh Pirates baseball with his father-in-law, but then realizing he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need \xe2\x80\x9cthe coldest fridge in the city\xe2\x80\x9d because the grocery store is so close. Tomson has said the line was inspired by a radio story that \xe2\x80\x9cmade me feel like I took both my fridge and proximity to infinite foodstuffs for granted.\xe2\x80\x9d It just goes on like this.' b'The real pathos comes from how affable and intelligent Tomson comes across in interviews, and the real tragedy is that he simply might\xe2\x80\x99ve benefited from testing the waters on a couple of EPs. The anxiety Tomson has acknowledged about becoming the last Vampire Weekend-er to go solo is understandable: VW frontman Ezra Koenig parlayed a Yeah Yeah Yeahs in-joke into a Beyonc\xc3\xa9 songwriting credit; Rostam, who officially quit the group early last year, left his bold stamp on songs by Solange and Frank Ocean when he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t collaborating with the Walkmen\xe2\x80\x99s Hamilton Leithauser. Bassist Chris Baio was releasing glinting synth-pop under his own surname for several years before he delivered his debut album, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s The Names.' b'Vampire Weekend have been working on a fourth album. When Tomson returns as a solo artist, it\xe2\x80\x99d be better if he first had something he felt an urgent need to say, and then decided to make a record of it. Youngish American is a hapless vanity album, sad for all the wrong reasons, and all the more frustrating because it couches wokeness in songs about the extra advantages afforded to Tomson\xe2\x80\x99s demographic.\xc2\xa0Issues of privilege and identity are complicated no matter your tax bracket, but it\xe2\x80\x99s better\xc2\xa0to seek inspiration from without rather than from within.'

column7: b'On her compact debut, L\xc3\xa6titia Tamko\xe2\x80\x99s inimitable take on DIY indie rock feels victorious. She\xc2\xa0explores ideas of home, community, and sharing space with others who don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily see eye to eye.'
column8: b'Just about 20 minutes into\xc2\xa0L\xc3\xa6titia Tamko\xe2\x80\x99s compact debut as Vagabon, Infinite Worlds,\xc2\xa0she sings\xc2\xa0a line so cutting that, upon first hearing it, I had to remove\xc2\xa0my headphones and take stock of my surroundings. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat about them scares you so much?/My standing there threatens your standing, too,\xe2\x80\x9d Tamko sings on \xe2\x80\x9cCleaning House,\xe2\x80\x9d broadcasting a simple but eminently resonant message\xc2\xa0that\xc2\xa0defines why these\xc2\xa0eight songs feel so important, especially now. It should be no secret that Tamko\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0thought runs through the minds of all those made marginal by prejudicial thinking\xe2\x80\x94and actual executive action. It could be your skin color, the way you dress, who you worship or love, but nonetheless that question flashes through the minds of those made to feel less. A simple, evocative guitar plucking in the background guides this sentiment\xc2\xa0with precision into the ear of a listener, and down into their gut.' b'Yet, Tamko\xe2\x80\x99s inimitable take on DIY indie rock is never downtrodden. It\xe2\x80\x99s victorious\xe2\x80\x94even when her\xc2\xa0feats\xc2\xa0feel pyrrhic. Her soaring, winsome, and mutable tenor is unlike any of her peers in the New York scene. She also shreds. More importantly, Tamko\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0first proper album is a stunning document of what indie rock can look like from a viewpoint that isn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily widespread in the genre. *Infinite Worlds *is an album interested in grappling with seemingly intractable and very personal questions about sharing space, finding a home, and fostering community in a world that can be caustic to those very actions.' b'Some of the songs that appear on Infinite Worlds started as rougher drafts on 2014 EP Persian Garden.\xc2\xa0Listening to the earlier work, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear\xc2\xa0how much Tamko has grown. She moved to New York as a teenager from Cameroon, and until she graduated from college in 2015, music was more or less a hobby. Her Bandcamp demos eventually led her to the Bushwick\xc2\xa0community art space Silent Barn, and a venerable DIY scene that includes artists like Frankie Cosmos and Crying (members of both bands contributed to Infinite Worlds).' b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Embers,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s opener, was originally a song called \xe2\x80\x9cSharks,\xe2\x80\x9d and it has transitioned from whispered confession to empowering paean. The song\xe2\x80\x99s anthemic, steady guitars and booming drums recall the sound of Modest Mouse or Built to Spill, but her voice is the anchor to all these songs. It\xe2\x80\x99s a powerful tool that can move from soft to loud, confrontational to relaxing, with an uncanny grace.' b"Tamko\xc2\xa0shows\xc2\xa0this in songs like \xe2\x80\x9cFear & Force\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMal \xc3\xa0\xc2\xa0L\xe2\x80\x99aise.\xe2\x80\x9d On the former, she sings about a failed relationship, isolation, and the search for a sanctuary. \xe2\x80\x9cI've been hiding in the smallest space/I am dying to go/This is not my home,\xe2\x80\x9d Tamko sings, alternating\xc2\xa0between breathy harmonies and straightforward delivery (Greta Kline, aka Frankie Cosmos, provides backing vocals). The latter is one of the most interesting songs on the album: a piece of gauzy, ambient pop, not unlike the Cocteau Twins. Sung completely in French, \xe2\x80\x9cMal \xc3\xa0\xc2\xa0L\xe2\x80\x99aise\xe2\x80\x9d is a sound collage made of a spectral chorus of voices, processed and multiplied\xc2\xa0(including sampled vocals from Julie Byrne/Makonnen collaborator\xc2\xa0Eric Littmann). These sounds shuffle around in an indistinct musical space, which is both haunted and relaxed. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost close to new age, conjuring up the work of Harold Budd or Grouper, but Tamko gives the airy vibe of this song weight with lyrics that touch on accepting social discomfort and embracing oneself." b'Throughout Infinite Worlds, Tamko interrogates what it means to occupy space with others who don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily see eye to eye, be it parents, peers, or strangers. Sometimes imagining that ideal world leads to bouts of doubt, or even magical realism (see \xe2\x80\x9c100 Days\xe2\x80\x9d). But Tamko\xc2\xa0keeps coming back to the same point: the community you want to live in is one you have to make. Guided by a more mature sound, *Infinite Worlds *is the rock music we need nowadays, when it seems like home, wherever it might be, is getting farther away.'

column7: b'The latest from the D.C. rapper is a focused beam of live-band and hip-hop soul that rattles loudly in our\xc2\xa0present political moment.'
column8: b"\xe2\x80\x9cI'd rather die than be complacent with the way that it goes,\xe2\x80\x9d Oddisee declares on \xe2\x80\x9cNNGE,\xe2\x80\x9d one of several tracks from his new album that aim to unravel listeners' tightly wound spools of indifference.\xc2\xa0At 32 years old, the rapper has been working at a steady clip without much fanfare for more than a decade. 2015's The Good Fight\xc2\xa0showed his fine-tuned, live-band sound; last year brought the instrumental Odd Tape, which highlighted his beat-making, and the anxiety-laden Alwasta EP, which foreshadowed The Iceberg. \xe2\x80\x9cLifting Shadows,\xe2\x80\x9d a song from that release where the Sudanese-American MC worries that the government might be tapping his phone, feels prescient in the light of recent actions by President Trump: \xe2\x80\x9cThat's what makes this country great, it's built by those who bleed/It's built by those who came on boats, it's built by those who flee\xe2\x80\xa6 So if you just try to chop us down you only hurt your knees.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"That song provides an easy bridge to *The Iceberg, *a\xc2\xa0focused beam of hip-hop soul that rattles loudly in our present political moment.\xc2\xa0On \xe2\x80\x9cNNGE,\xe2\x80\x9d Oddisee reckons with the election of the new President from the perspective of someone familiar with government-sanctioned antagonism. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is there to fear?/I'm from black America, this is just another year.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cLike Really\xe2\x80\x9d also calls attention to pervasive, systemic inequality. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy a brother get three for a sack while your brother go free for raping?\xe2\x80\x9d Oddisee wonders. \xe2\x80\x9cHow you made a film about Egypt with all lead roles caucasian?\xe2\x80\x9d Sexism gets a similar treatment in \xe2\x80\x9cHold It Back,\xe2\x80\x9d the idea of which \xe2\x80\x9cannoys [him] more than cargo shorts.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"The backdrop for Oddisee's cutting analysis is a continuation of the funky sound honed on his recent records. Limber runs from bassist Dennis Turner and quicksilver riffs from Olivier St. Louis flash through The Iceberg, and the programmed drums hit with a human player's snap. St. Louis is also a gifted vocalist\xe2\x80\x94during \xe2\x80\x9cRain Dance,\xe2\x80\x9d a glittering, four-minute head-nod symphony, he tumbles into the track from above, shaking the walls with a wail that nods to the Temptations in the early \xe2\x80\x9970s." b"Live-band hip-hop has cycled back into the mainstream again after more than a decade in the cold behind acts like Kendrick Lamar and Chance the Rapper. Though in modern pop, rising tides do not lift all boats. It's not clear if the success of the Kendricks and the Chances means that other rappers with a comparable approach can ride their coattails and\xc2\xa0enjoy the benefits of more listeners without needing to compromise their methods. Having support from gatekeepers helps with that process, and at least one gatekeeper is listening to Oddisee: \xe2\x80\x9cLike Really\xe2\x80\x9d premiered on Ebro's Beats 1 program. But Oddisee has bigger fish to fry. Frequently on The Iceberg, characters seem stuck in entrenched paths dictated by America's racist history, and the album ends at a stand-off. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can't agree on a thing,\xe2\x80\x9d Oddisee raps on \xe2\x80\x9cRights and Wrongs.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWe both are beyond the games/But we still play.\xe2\x80\x9d"

column7: b'Dub pioneer Adrian Sherwood reteams with dubstep pioneer Rob Ellis (aka Pinch) for a more refined and surprising album that falls just short of its desired concept.'
column8: b'Thankfully, the past few years have brought the exhilarating and acerbic production work of Adrian Sherwood back into earshot. In the midst of early \xe2\x80\x9980s London, he helped a slew of punks\xe2\x80\x94the Fall, Judy Nylon, and Maximum Joy\xe2\x80\x94find their inner dub sound, and he gave rastas like Bim Sherman and Prince Far I a heavily psychedelic bass tone that made them stand apart from their dreadlocked brethren. A tireless work ethic and decades of production work make it near impossible to keep a handle on the man, but a spate of reissues in the past few years, especially Sherwood at the Controls, show just how his sound anticipated the wooly electronic experimentation that now runs through the likes of Arca, the Fade to Mind crew and dubstep itself.' b'So having Sherwood team with dubstep pioneer Rob Ellis, aka Pinch, was surely inspired. But too often on their 2015 debut, Late Night Endless, felt cluttered and claustrophobic. And when they did take their foot off the gas, they wound up wallowing in a downtempo rut. The tempos remain quickened on their follow-up Man Vs. Sofa, but the two let the tracks breathe a bit more and there\xe2\x80\x99s a sense of refinement throughout. A jittery thump opens \xe2\x80\x9cRoll Call,\xe2\x80\x9d and while there\xe2\x80\x99s all manner of machine-gun handclaps, echoing hi-hats and arroyos of bass, there\xe2\x80\x99s also flecks of Blaxploitation guitar and cinematic strings. It might read like a laundry list of elements, but Pinch and Sherwood move deftly between it all.' b"\xe2\x80\x9cItchy Face\xe2\x80\x9d bears quick electro bass pulses and snare rolls. So when they introduce a graceful piano line and just let it luxuriate, it's like a sonic speedball. The two are so nimble and\xc2\xa0compatible\xc2\xa0now that they easily swing into echo chambers and white noise while keeping the speed up. That piano crosses over to the dubstep/classic dub stylings of \xe2\x80\x9cMidnight Mindset,\xe2\x80\x9d though it\xe2\x80\x99s not the same easy blend they displayed earlier. And the title track has piano and drums flicker in and out of darkness, but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t move so much as get swallowed up by static. And when the piano rises up again on the next track, the novelty of it in their mix wears thin." b'The best surprise comes when they bring Lee \xe2\x80\x9cScratch\xe2\x80\x9d Perry in for a\xc2\xa0guest vocal turn on \xe2\x80\x9cLies.\xe2\x80\x9d Despite decades of dub pedigree, Sherwood and Pinch forego it to instead put a tricky 2-step under him, a welcome shift in strategy. A furious lyric adds menace to the industrial haze of \xe2\x80\x9cGun Law,\xe2\x80\x9d showing the duo moving into noisier terrain that brings to mind Sherwood\xe2\x80\x99s gnarled mid-\xe2\x80\x9980s output.' b'Things get baffling when the duo throw in a cover of Ryuichi Sakamoto\xe2\x80\x99s evocative \xe2\x80\x9980s classic, \xe2\x80\x9cMerry Christmas Mr. Lawrence.\xe2\x80\x9d The first time through, they pay their respects to Sakamoto\xe2\x80\x99s sterling piano melody, one of the loveliest soundtrack themes of the era. But after establishing the motif, Sherwood and Pinch don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to know quite where to take it. A downtempo beat gets thrown underneath it, before the two grind the track to a complete halt and instead add squalls of digital glitch and some electric guitar noodling. It then goes up into the stratosphere for a moment before they bring it back down with a needlessly busy IDM drum line. Respectable as it is for both men to avoid falling back into their bag of dub tricks, a few of Man Vs. Sofa\xe2\x80\x99s attempts to expand their reach fall just a bit short.'

column7: b"After laying out the template for Common's latest album, the drummer/producer offers up another hour-long selection of more than two dozen expertly-made beats that are just waiting to be rapped\xc2\xa0on."
column8: b"The veteran beatmaker had a banner year in 2016, executive producing Common\xe2\x80\x99s Black America Again, providing the blueprint for Kanye West\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c30 Hours,\xe2\x80\x9d and collaborating with Kaytranada, Esperanza Spalding, and the Roots. Four years after Karriem Riggins' first solo endeavor, Alone Together**, put him on the map as more than just a standout session musician, Riggins\xe2\x80\x99 musical life seemed richer than ever." b"Alone Together's sequel, the new\xc2\xa0Headnod Suite,\xc2\xa0echoes the template laid out by its predecessor. The record is, again, a nearly hour-long selection of more than two dozen expertly-made beats, seemingly linked by very little other than the fact that Riggins considered them strong enough to make the album. There\xe2\x80\x99s one exception on *Headnod\xe2\x80\x94*about two-thirds of the way through the record, a set of tracks form a mini-suite that stands as a short detour before we return to regularly scheduled swing programming." b'These tracks, part of the \xe2\x80\x9cCheap Suite,\xe2\x80\x9d are the most cohesive section of the larger record. They are roomier, more experimental, and they lead Headnod Suite\xc2\xa0into more interesting territory, as Riggins explores rhythm-and-space-led compositions reminiscent of the work of Deantoni Parks. Though they are harsher and less soulful than much of what precedes them, these tracks work as a unified experience. Moreover, once you listen to them, you note the trail of breadcrumbs from earlier in the album (\xe2\x80\x9cInvasion,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDirty Drum Warm Up\xe2\x80\x9d) that heralded their arrival.' b'Elsewhere, Riggins focuses on rolling out gem after gem, with careful thought given to the little details that distinguish a cubic zirconia from a diamond. Riggins is such an expert drummer that it can be hard to identify him as having any kind of percussive signature. These features\xe2\x80\x94the perfectly chopped sample over the tiptoe-light beat on \xe2\x80\x9cSista Misses,\xe2\x80\x9d the atmospherics and perfectly placed guitar riff on \xe2\x80\x9cOther Side of the Track,\xe2\x80\x9d the clatters and snaps that open \xe2\x80\x9cBahia Dreamin,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d the complex bass work underlying the candy-sweet, teased-out melody on \xe2\x80\x9cCrystal Stairs\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94give him his voice as a producer.' b'Riggins\xe2\x80\x99 abiding love for hip-hop is showcased throughout Headnod Suite. On \xe2\x80\x9cNever Come Close,\xe2\x80\x9d a selection of Prodigy\xe2\x80\x99s verse from \xe2\x80\x9cShook Ones Pt. II\xe2\x80\x9d leads out of the track as if it were a final showstopping instrumental flourish, while on \xe2\x80\x9cKeep It On,\xe2\x80\x9d Common\xe2\x80\x99s ad-libs are swaddled in a steady beat and warm instrumentation, like a beloved child. Even the interludes that Riggins commits to exploring throughout the record come off as a tribute to the skits and exclamations that adorn rap albums\xe2\x80\x94little breaks where vocals communicate an attitude and sense of place.' b'Though there are few beats here that miss the mark, the big issue is that Riggins has trouble editing his cuts down to a standard length. They regularly sprawl beyond the two-minute mark and sometimes even make it to three. In an interview with XXL, he expressed that one of the big differences between Headnod Suite and Alone Together was that the new album contained more \xe2\x80\x9cstuff MCs will want to rap to.\xe2\x80\x9d True, some of the tracks seem gratuitously extended in order to coax rappers into adopting them, giving them a home on their own projects. You can\xe2\x80\x99t blame Riggins for wanting more spotlight. His turn on Black America Again\xc2\xa0gave Common the template for what was arguably his strongest record in more than a decade. Coming off that success, and his many other impressive collaborations, Headnod scans as a beat tape in the classic sense: welcoming to all listeners, but meant to convey something particularly special for those who might help Riggins take his career even further.'

column7: b'Power Trip embody a\xc2\xa0platonic ideal of heavy metal escapism. With more focus\xc2\xa0on detail, the Dallas thrashers push their second\xc2\xa0LP\xc2\xa0over the edge, balancing\xc2\xa0modern intricacy and old-school aggression.'
column8: b'No one throws a party like Power Trip. In the years since their 2008 inception, the Dallas crossover quintet has come to embody the platonic ideal of heavy metal escapism, in person and on record. Genre boundaries get blown to smithereens during their rambunctious, pretension-free concerts; they\xe2\x80\x99ll play with anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s willing to get noisy, be it New Orleans bounce queen Big Freedia, moody post-punk outfit Merchandise, or black metal darlings Deafheaven. Power Trip\xe2\x80\x99s excellent debut album, 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Manifest Decimation, further solidified this\xc2\xa0reputation by translating their live ferocity to wax. One album on, nine years in, Power Trip have mastered the rager. They now turn their focus to widespread revelry\xc2\xa0with Nightmare *Logic\xe2\x80\x94*a mission that goes off with a big, beautiful bang.' b'*Nightmare Logic *doesn\xe2\x80\x99t find Power Trip making any significant shifts to the no-holds-barred approach they showcased so powerfully on their debut. It\xe2\x80\x99s an LP crafted in its predecessor\xe2\x80\x99s literal spitting image, from the proliferative gang vocals and thrash beatdowns right down to the eight-track runtime and gory old-school artwork. Frontman Riley Gale still huffs, puffs, and howls like a rabid wolf, a feral intermediary through which the band issues blistering, occasionally loony\xc2\xa0indictments of corrupt politicians (\xe2\x80\x9cRuination\xe2\x80\x9d) and greedy, polluting CEOs (\xe2\x80\x9cIf Not Us Then Who\xe2\x80\x9d). Gale\xe2\x80\x99s bandmates match these screeds with litanies of their own: particularly guitarist Blake Ibanez, a hardcore titan (and occasional shoegazer) whose slithering riffs incessantly run amok. Even the audience can\xe2\x80\x99t escape Power Trip\xe2\x80\x99s leaden\xc2\xa0censure. On \xe2\x80\x9cWaiting Around to Die,\xe2\x80\x9d Gale delivers this sputtering, incendiary pep talk with a rage so palpable you can almost feel it shaking you by the shoulders: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re waiting around to die, how can you live with it?/Just waiting around to die, AND I CAN\xe2\x80\x99T FUCKING STAND IT!!!\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Thrash has always been a goofy genre with a morbid sense of humor: a direct consequence of the genre\xe2\x80\x99s primordial days in the Reagan era, when trolling the silent majority doubled as a pre-eminent past-time and a form of protest. Like their peers Iron Reagan and Skeletonwitch, Power Trip view the impending apocalypse as a cause for celebration, powered by schadenfreude. Evangelical Christians are treated to particularly hilarious roastings. \xe2\x80\x9cExecutioner\xe2\x80\x99s Tax (Swing of the Axe),\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s best song, sees Gale calling the bluff of all those Bible-Belters who\xe2\x80\x99d so passionately pleaded for the arrival of the man upstairs, only to come face-to-face with the titular killer-for-hire when the End of Days finally arrives. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve prayed for so long, and now you have your chance/The executioner\xe2\x80\x99s here, and he\xe2\x80\x99s sharpening his axe!\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Power Trip\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0new\xc2\xa0attention to detail pushes\xc2\xa0Nightmare Logic\xc2\xa0over the edge. It\xe2\x80\x99s abundantly clear that they\xe2\x80\x99ve spent hours at the dissection table with Manifest Decimation, amplifying\xe2\x80\x94but not recycling\xe2\x80\x94its best hooks and theatrics, trimming off the static scar tissue. They\xe2\x80\x99ve chopped a\xc2\xa0few seconds of extraneous riffing here, a repeated breakdown there; it\xe2\x80\x99s an impressive operation, considering their debut was plenty lean and mean. The nit-picking pays off, as Nightmare Logic outmatches the preceding LP across all verticals, from cohesion and catchiness to impact and atmosphere.' b'The band\xe2\x80\x99s secret weapon remains producer and Sumerlands guitarist Arthur Rizk, or as I like to call him, the Ariel Rechtshaid of heavy music;\xc2\xa0Code Orange\xe2\x80\x99s *Forever\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Prurient\xe2\x80\x99s Frozen Niagara Falls\xc2\xa0*are just two of the bevy of ambitious records he\xe2\x80\x99s worked on. A master of dynamic contrast and sonic feints, Rizk\xe2\x80\x99s the textbook definition of a board-wizard. Under his command, Ibanez\xe2\x80\x99s already-huge tremolo riffs on \xe2\x80\x9cExecutioner\xe2\x80\x99s Tax\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cFiring Squad,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0and the title track\xc2\xa0become hulking, like a stampede of hellish racehorses against the thundering backbeat. Meanwhile, in the back of the mix, the rhythm section ebbs and flows to accommodate the axework, ensuring sustained impact\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0easy passage from one ripper to the next. Rizk again runs Gale\xe2\x80\x99s yelps through a heap of effects, rendering every syllable an echo-laden boom from on high. And in spite of its sheer heft, Rizk\xc2\xa0makes\xc2\xa0Nightmare Logic\xc2\xa0a crisp, nuanced listen; like the band themselves, he strikes a rare balance between modern intricacy and old-school aggression, nodding to tradition without over-relying on tropes.' b'You don\xe2\x80\x99t need to be a metalhead to have a blast with Nightmare Logic. Screamed sardonics, persistent chug, and apocalyptic melodrama are all acquired tastes, sure. But Power Trip\xe2\x80\x99s fist-pumping choruses, ricocheting grooves, and ample charm are so animated that they leave\xc2\xa0us with something addictive and, well, fun. Just like Metallica, the Texans pitch a big tent, where the only prerequisite for entry is a\xc2\xa0willingness to splash around in the bloodbath for half an hour. With\xc2\xa0Nightmare Logic, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good chance you\xe2\x80\x99ll stick around for a good, long soak.'

column7: b'The British group\xe2\x80\x99s sixth album is a love note to aging indie idealism and to those who\xe2\x80\x99ve reveled in their careening pop-punk singalongs, scathing neuroses, and charmingly specific soccer references.'
column8: b'Gareth Campesinos! is our bard of throwing up. For a decade, nearly every word that has come out of the Los Campesinos! singer\xe2\x80\x99s mouth has presented itself with rash inelegance, candidness, and the need to be ejected from his body this very second. But sometimes, as anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s stared down the depths of a toilet bowl knows, vomit is just vomit. Like that time he sang of an awkward hookup that was blown when a girl upchucked all over his rented tuxedo; or when he recounted that early heartbreak when he got wasted, ate too many potato chips, and then deposited the greasy snack right back onto a soccer field. For Gareth, such trials are the punchline to humanity\xe2\x80\x99s cruel joke. They are essential experiences, embarrassments that turn into collective elation once they hit open air. Because, for all its indecency, throwing up makes us feel better.' b'Sick Scenes, the British group\xe2\x80\x99s sixth album, plays like a love letter to aging indie idealism; to the fans who have reveled in this band\xe2\x80\x99s careening pop-punk singalongs, scathing neuroses, and charmingly specific soccer references. There is yet another ode to semi-digestion here\xc2\xa0when Gareth advises: \xe2\x80\x9cSave your epiphanies\xe2\x80\xa6 for chucking up in your own hands.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s unconventional wisdom from a man who would know, and the line hints at a weathered sageness that lingers throughout. On the prescription ode \xe2\x80\x9c5 Flucloxacillin,\xe2\x80\x9d the drums drop out to spotlight the singer\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0oh-so-specific stasis as he laments, \xe2\x80\x9cAnother blister pack pops, but I still feel much the same\xe2\x80\x9431 and depression is a young man\xe2\x80\x99s game.\xe2\x80\x9d At that, stalwart musical leader Tom Campesinos! peals off a 15-second guitar solo to lift spirits enough for the next verse.' b'Given the financial gauntlet nearly every independent band must face in 2017, it seems like a\xc2\xa0minor miracle that Los Campesinos! still exist at all. And nobody knows this more than Los Campesinos! A large part of their enduring appeal\xe2\x80\x94remember, they began as a MySpace band\xe2\x80\x94has to do with the fact that they were never especially trendy. Too sugary for the emo diehards, too tart for the indie bandwagoners, too emo for the cool kids. Their target audience could be as particular as one of Gareth\xe2\x80\x99s excruciating tales of broken romance, but also just as passionate; strength in small numbers.' b'To fund the making of Sick Scenes, the band sold about a thousand soccer jerseys with the word \xe2\x80\x9cDOOMED\xe2\x80\x9d scrawled across the chest. Their message could not be clearer: This is a team, and you are part of it. The idea plays out in one of the record\xe2\x80\x99s most touching moments, near the end of manic-panic crack up \xe2\x80\x9cI Broke Up In Amarante,\xe2\x80\x9d when Gareth starts a hook on his own, but soon\xc2\xa0stalls out. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to need you to help me out here,\xe2\x80\x9d he mutters, and a full chorus of voices enter to winningly finish a song about the inevitability of defeat.' b"Recorded amid the harsh realities of Brexit, Sick Scenes\xc2\xa0faintly opens up its miserabilia\xc2\xa0to bring in the wider world. These are not anthems of woke-ness, but Gareth\xe2\x80\x99s disappointment and anger don't sound\xc2\xa0quite as rash; he\xe2\x80\x99s been around long enough to reflect upon many\xc2\xa0sad cycles. Nowhere is this more apparent than on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fall of Home,\xe2\x80\x9d this band\xe2\x80\x99s most beautifully heart-crushing song to date. Backed by little more than a cello, a violin, and some plinking piano notes, Gareth gets to the core of Western society\xe2\x80\x99s current cultural divides: between rural and urban, parents and children, those moving ahead and those staying behind. \xe2\x80\x9cLeft your hometown for somewhere new/Don\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised now it\xe2\x80\x99s leaving you,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings. It\xe2\x80\x99s a eulogy to youth that zeroes in with precision, each detail more wrenching than the last: \xe2\x80\x9cfuneral for a family pup\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cbattery dies on your monthly call\xe2\x80\x9d and, finally, \xe2\x80\x9cgave the fascists a thousand ticks.\xe2\x80\x9d But this song isn\xe2\x80\x99t a simple slam on the generalized \xe2\x80\x9csmall-town mentality,\xe2\x80\x9d considering Gareth essentially still lives in the same small English town he grew up in. Instead, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fall of Home\xe2\x80\x9d comes off like a sympathetic plea from someone familiar with\xc2\xa0both sides, who disagrees with the nationalist impulse but can fathom its root. And in its understanding, there is a glimmer of hope." b'A strange positivity can also be found on an ambling track called\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA Slow, Slow Death\xe2\x80\x9d that concludes with the lines: \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a slow, slow death if you want it/Yeah, I want it.\xe2\x80\x9d Instead of glorifying death or poking fun at it, though, this is a statement of stubborn resilience, of life. Especially in the streamed today/trashed tomorrow world of modern music, the possibility of a slow death can seem revolutionary. Los Campesinos! will never be the biggest, the best-looking, the most loved. But when their time comes, they will be able to look back, content.'

column7: b'Co-produced with\xc2\xa0Lydia Lunch, the new Pissed Jeans LP is the sludge-punk band\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0cleanest, most hi-fidelity album, and their deepest dive into the inglorious male psyche yet.'
column8: b'Sometimes the best thing you can do as a male feminist is shut up and listen to women who know what they\xe2\x80\x99re talking about better than you. That advice might hold doubly true for male musicians. For every \xe2\x80\x9cSuggestion\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and, really, there\xe2\x80\x99s only been one \xe2\x80\x9cSuggestion\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94there are countless self-identified good guys looking for an easy pat on the back simply for having their heart in the right place. There\xe2\x80\x99s a reason why feminist punk spun off into a kind of genre unto itself: This is not subject matter that men usually do well.' b'Between their territorial growls and bludgeoning\xc2\xa0guitars, Pennsylvania sludge-punks Pissed Jeans have\xc2\xa0made a brand out of unfiltered male aggression;\xc2\xa0each of their\xc2\xa0four albums has played like an American Splendor comic reenacted by grizzly bears. Yet more so than frontmen who profess to be infinitely more political, Matt Korvette understands what he can contribute to the conversation about gender relations. His songs offer insight into the forces that drive men: the privileges, compulsions, indignities, entitlements, and double standards. He\xe2\x80\x99s touched on this territory often\xe2\x80\x94most notably on \xe2\x80\x9cMale Gaze,\xe2\x80\x9d his rubbernecking apology from 2013\xe2\x80\x99s terrific Honeys\xe2\x80\x94but he\xe2\x80\x99s never run with the muse as righteously as he does on Why Love Now, the band\xe2\x80\x99s deepest dive yet into the inglorious male psyche.' b'The record could almost pass for a concept album, if not for all of Korvette\xe2\x80\x99s usual digressions. He balances out his social insights with asides about sugary snacks, laugh-tracked sitcoms, astrology, and the like, and those flashes of irreverence are more welcome than ever, since the core of the album couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be more pointed. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Bar Is Low\xe2\x80\x9d challenges the way society coddles men, rewarding them for the most modest demonstrations of decency, as if simply not being a violent monster entitles them to a medal. \xe2\x80\x9cHeld down a job/Even snagged a raise,\xe2\x80\x9d Korvette sings, \xe2\x80\x9cRight there you\xe2\x80\x99re due/For effusive praise.\xe2\x80\x9d On \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Your Knees,\xe2\x80\x9d he demonstrates how men neg women, picking at their insecurities to cut down their esteem.' b"And since it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a Pissed Jeans album without a healthy dose of sex and shame, there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of that, too. \xe2\x80\x9cCold Whip Cream\xe2\x80\x9d introduces a frustrated guy too embarrassed to ask his partner to indulge his kink. On \xe2\x80\x9cIgnorecam,\xe2\x80\x9d Korvette goes off over a Mot\xc3\xb6rhead-worthy riff about the absurdity of men paying cam girls to essentially ignore them: \xe2\x80\x9cSo you're sick of interacting with women, you wanna pay for something that's free?/Shut yourself up and load the ignorecam, getting off on letting her be.\xe2\x80\x9d The track ends in angry, carnal release, with Korvette so overcome with self-hating ecstasy he loses track of his spelling. \xe2\x80\x9cN-O-R-G-I-E me!\xe2\x80\x9d he chants orgasmically, \xe2\x80\x9cO-G-I-N-R-E me!\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s grotesque, funny, and unsettling\xe2\x80\x94the Pissed Jeans sweet spot, basically." b'As deft as Korvette is at describing what the patriarchy looks like from a man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, Why Love Now\xe2\x80\x99s sharpest insights come from outside himself\xe2\x80\x94by actually bringing in a woman. Author Lindsay Hunter penned and performs \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a Man,\xe2\x80\x9d a mid-album monologue about life as the office alpha male. Adopting her best Danny McBride voice, she assails a coworker with come-ons and double entendres: \xe2\x80\x9cYou take dic-tations?/You get it?/You ever been stapled?/\xe2\x80\xa6 You cold?/Put on that cardigan you got hanging over your chair/Do it slow.\xe2\x80\x9d Behind her committed comic performance, there\xe2\x80\x99s a threat of real violence.' b'On a less loaded song cycle, Why Love Now\xe2\x80\x99s relative tunefulness would be the narrative. No wave pioneer Lydia Lunch produced the album along with black metal practitioner Arthur Rizk, and while that seems like it should be a recipe for discord, the pairing somehow resulted in the cleanest, most high-fidelity Pissed Jeans record yet. None of the bands\xe2\x80\x99 primary influences ever made an album this approachable\xe2\x80\x94not Melvins, not the\xc2\xa0Jesus Lizard, certainly not Pigfuck. The glistening post-punk riff on \xe2\x80\x9cLove Without Emotion\xe2\x80\x9d could have come from any number of friendly, telegenic British buzz bands; it\xe2\x80\x99d be virtually unidentifiable as a Pissed Jeans track if not for Korvette\xe2\x80\x99s phlegmy ogre routine. The band was wise to offer more carrot than stick for this one, though. Their music has never gone down easier, but their commentary has never hit so uncomfortably hard.'

column7: b'The new Xiu Xiu LP\xc2\xa0consolidates several of the band\xe2\x80\x99s strengths\xe2\x80\x94mixing\xc2\xa0hooks, cacophony, and\xc2\xa0stellar\xc2\xa0production. Individual moments shine, but the album can lull you into a state of absentmindedness.'
column8: b'Xiu Xiu has always been a polarizing act, though some observations about the band are commonly accepted. Jamie Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s tremulous vocals can feel vulnerable and threatening at once. He\xc2\xa0likes\xc2\xa0concept albums. And he is a fan of lots of kinds of music\xe2\x80\x94gamelan, noise, dance, folk, punk\xe2\x80\x94which makes\xc2\xa0his arrangements wondrously varied. Xiu Xiu has managed the feat of combining hooks and cacophony without spoiling either ingredient. They can offer a good time under the art-rock tent.' b'They can also be exasperating. As a lyricist, Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s penchant for disturbing themes has become predictable over the last 16 years. No matter how far afield Xiu Xiu travels sonically, the emotional landscape is fixed. That trend continues on their latest album\xe2\x80\x99s opener, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Call.\xe2\x80\x9d The song starts\xc2\xa0with rapid-fire, nearly rapped lines about a \xe2\x80\x9cbitch,\xe2\x80\x9d and closes with a coda that goes: \xe2\x80\x9cClap bitches/Why why why bitch/Why why cunt why/...Clap bitches.\xe2\x80\x9d At a level of vocal texture, these lines don\xe2\x80\x99t sound like they\xe2\x80\x99re sung by Stewart. (Credits list Enyce Smith as a guest vocalist on the track.) But in conceptual terms, the words definitely sound like they come from the guy who once sang \xe2\x80\x9cI Luv Abortion.\xe2\x80\x9d The\xc2\xa0verses and choruses shed little contextual light, and the final effect of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Call\xe2\x80\x9d is one of disorientation\xe2\x80\x94a familiar Xiu Xiu tactic.' b'By now, a choice like this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem all that risky, or even commendably ugly. When he crafts a line like this, is Stewart just ticking boxes on the Xiu Xiu style-bingo sheet? Only he knows for sure. But both the pleasures and discomforts of FORGET\xc2\xa0involve the way the album invites\xc2\xa0that\xc2\xa0question. The set consolidates several\xc2\xa0of the band\xe2\x80\x99s strengths: The production is stellar, with plenty of room for noise-damage as well as melodies (which are numerous). Xiu Xiu has fielded a wide array of intriguing experimental records in the last couple years, but they haven\xe2\x80\x99t turned in pop-adjacent songs this memorable since 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Always.' b'On \xe2\x80\x9cWondering,\xe2\x80\x9d group backing vocals and distortion squall create a chorus of wild power. The otherwise self-pitying \xe2\x80\x9cGet Up\xe2\x80\x9d launches an ascending arpeggio at its conclusion, and\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99s catchy and startling. Even the songs that don\xe2\x80\x99t register as strongly have winning quirks\xe2\x80\x94as with the timorous breakdown that leads to a screaming climax on\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cJenny GoGo.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But as a collection, FORGET\xc2\xa0doesn\xe2\x80\x99t cohere in the same way that their best recent projects have. Plays the Music of Twin Peaks\xc2\xa0allowed the band to show an interpretive wisdom regarding another artist\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic, while remaining identifiable as Xiu Xiu. A recent collaboration with the contemporary classical group Mantra Percussion showed that Stewart can compose long-form works just as well as some of his ambitious experimental peers, like Deerhoof\xe2\x80\x99s Greg Saunier. (Saunier appears on \xe2\x80\x9cPetite,\xe2\x80\x9d and also co-produced FORGET, alongside John Congleton and band-member Angela Seo.) Those albums had a point of view, and made sustained stylistic arguments. But according to Stewart, the organizing conceit of FORGET\xc2\xa0has to do with the \xe2\x80\x9cduality of human frailty.\xe2\x80\x9d On the idea of forgetting, he says: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a rebirth in blanked out renewal but it also drowns and mutilates our attempt to hold on to what is dear.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s all true enough (if a bit overwrought). But it\xe2\x80\x99s also thin: a simple observation about a human trait having benefits and drawbacks. Nor is there much evidence of this concept operating inside the record itself. Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s lines are filled with the expected references to \xe2\x80\x9cthe rape of everything decent\xe2\x80\x9d and the like\xe2\x80\x94but not much that\xe2\x80\x99s direct regarding the problems of a solipsism, or a selective memory.' b'The guests all seem a bit stranded, too. On the album finale, \xe2\x80\x9cFaith, Torn Apart,\xe2\x80\x9d the carillon tones of New York minimalist legend Charlemagne Palestine sound grafted onto the mix. And while a closing soliloquy voiced by legendary drag artist Vaginal Davis is arresting, it\xc2\xa0doesn\xe2\x80\x99t connect with anything that\xe2\x80\x99s come before. (In interviews, Stewart has detailed the inspiration behind what Davis says, but its presentation\xc2\xa0on the album remains vague.) Individual moments shine throughout FORGET: a stunning chorus here, a stirring lick of pitched percussion there. But the album\xe2\x80\x99s strangest attribute is the way it can lull you into a state of absentmindedness regarding those same charms.'

column3: b'Common as Light and Love Are Red Valleys of Blood'
column7: b"Songwriter Mark Kozelek's 130-minute epic is indeed daring and self-reflective, but\xc2\xa0too often he prides long stretches of bitter humor and anger over the subtlety of his previous work."
column8: b'In retrospect, Sun Kil Moon\xe2\x80\x99s 2014 milestone Benji was less of a breakthrough than a breakdown just before Mark Kozelek\xc2\xa0became definitively mean and\xc2\xa0petty. Even with Benji\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0life-flashing-before-your-eyes earnestness (the repentance! the forgiveness! the laughs! the tears!), its lessons seem to have gone unabsorbed. Common as Light and Love Are Red Valleys of Blood\xc2\xa0comes in at 130 minutes. This is after two Sun Kil Moon albums\xe2\x80\x942015\xe2\x80\x99s Universal Themes, 2016\xe2\x80\x99s Jesu/Sun Kil Moon\xe2\x80\x94that left no one thinking, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish these were twice as long.\xe2\x80\x9d Kozelek knows that Common as Light isn\xe2\x80\x99t an easy sell.\xc2\xa0In a particularly forgettable number called \xe2\x80\x9cSeventies TV Show Theme Song,\xe2\x80\x9d he admits, \xe2\x80\x9cAll I know is this reminds me of the theme to \xe2\x80\x98Barney Miller\xe2\x80\x99/It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t intentional, just adding a song on the record for filler.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s not the only lyric on here that simply describes what the music sounds like, or dares you to stop listening. These are by-and-large the most confrontational songs Kozelek has ever put out, but strangely they\xe2\x80\x99re also some of the more exciting ones he\xe2\x80\x99s written since developing his post-Benji spoken word style.' b'While recent records have found Kozelek lambasting his vinyl-collecting fans and putting the fear of God in the minds of bloggers who miss his Red House Painters days, here Kozelek directs his fury more broadly. He makes three things absolutely clear: he hates iPhones, he hates Twitter, and he hates the twentysomethings who read Twitter on their iPhones. If there\xe2\x80\x99s a theme to this record (the way that, you know, acting in a Paolo Sorrentino film was the theme of the previous Sun Kil Moon LP), it\xe2\x80\x99s that the world is fucked, man, so get off your phone and respect your elders (especially Mark Kozelek). Many songs attempt to reflect Kozelek\xe2\x80\x99s anger following mass shootings to varying degrees of profundity. The awkwardly chipper music in \xe2\x80\x9cBastille Day\xe2\x80\x9d creates an effect not dissimilar to Smash Mouth playing the intro to \xe2\x80\x9cAll Star\xe2\x80\x9d on loop while their singer threatens the audience. This mode, as one might imagine, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t add up to a particularly moving collection of songs.' b'It does, however, make for some surprisingly great moments. In \xe2\x80\x9cPhiladelphia Cop,\xe2\x80\x9d which slowly evolves into a eulogy for David Bowie, Kozelek lands a bitter jab: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re a man in charge claiming you\xe2\x80\x99re a staunch feminist, then give a woman your job or shut the fuck up, Queen Bitch.\xe2\x80\x9d In the well-meaning \xe2\x80\x9cLone Star,\xe2\x80\x9d he helps save a suicidal woman\xe2\x80\x99s life and tries to convince North Carolina officials to amend their transphobic bathroom laws. The slow, ominous \xe2\x80\x9cSarah Lawrence College Song\xe2\x80\x9d finds him performing a small gig for a group of college students, which obviously leads to him berating them for how much their parents pay for tuition. He replies, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what Walmart pays me to use my music in commercials,\xe2\x80\x9d but quickly changes his tone: \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe I can go to their school one day too, \xe2\x80\x98cause they all seem like really nice people.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Many of these songs follow similar patterns: Kozelek snaps and sympathizes in the same breath. When he jokes with his colorblind building manager that he wants his tiles \xe2\x80\x9cgray\xe2\x80\xa6 like your hair, man,\xe2\x80\x9d he comments just a second later, \xe2\x80\x9cHey, I got a little gray too, I\xe2\x80\x99m not picking on you.\xe2\x80\x9d The reason why similarly quotidian story-songs like \xe2\x80\x9cGustavo\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cJim Wise\xe2\x80\x9d hit so hard was because they resulted in double portraits: You learned more about Kozelek through his observations of others. On Common as Light, Kozelek fills the whole frame, increasing the humor and anger, but sacrificing the subtlety. If the diaristic style he developed on his last few releases has been generously compared to novelists like Karl Ove Knausg\xc3\xa5rd or James Joyce, then these songs feel more like Larry David or, at their most vulgar, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Curiously, Kozelek plays a ton of synth here\xe2\x80\x94a foreign sound for any Sun Kil Moon record. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve found that when you put an instrument in someone\xe2\x80\x99s hands that they aren\xe2\x80\x99t used to playing, interesting things happen,\xe2\x80\x9d he noticed in a recent interview. A lot of this does sound new, which is becoming more difficult as he becomes more prolific and the world catches up with him. Phil Elverum cited him as an influence for his upcoming Mount Eerie album, and you can hear pieces of \xe2\x80\x9cCarissa\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9cRavens,\xe2\x80\x9d just like you can hear \xe2\x80\x9cSunshine in Chicago\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9cOkkervil River R.I.P.,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI Watched the Film the Song Remains the Same\xe2\x80\x9d in Father John Misty\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLeaving L.A.\xe2\x80\x9d Kozelek\xe2\x80\x99s work continues to ripple outward, even as he retreats further and further into himself.' b'Just last year, a pitch-perfect parody made the rounds, mimicking Kozelek\xe2\x80\x99s style to the point of tricking a few people into thinking a new EP of his had surfaced. The irony is that those pensive, guitar-based songs already sound completely outdated\xe2\x80\x94representative of a different Mark Kozelek from a different time. Such is the nature of his work. Kozelek has always been his own most restless listener, and part of his motivation is simply to keep himself interested in making art, whether that means changing his band name, starting his own record label, or turning his own songwriting process into his muse. \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe you\xe2\x80\x99ll hear it and think, \xe2\x80\x98I prefer your older songs,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d he sings in \xe2\x80\x9cSeventies TV Show Theme,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWell, maybe the world has changed and I\xe2\x80\x99m not that songwriter anymore.\xe2\x80\x9d In spirit, Common as Light resembles his classic work more than he\xe2\x80\x99s willing to admit. After all, his previous epics Rollercoaster and April were emotionally exhausting listens, unfolding with the intensity of a man trying to pack everything he knows into one record. As disorienting and overwhelming as any of Kozelek\xe2\x80\x99s defining albums, Common as Light\xc2\xa0patiently reveals more of the artist to anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s still paying attention.'

column7: b'The debut solo album from the breakout grime MC is a detailed portrait and full-throated\xc2\xa0riot, switching between clapping back at lesser rappers and serving up smoothed-out Quiet Stormzy.'
column8: b'Two years ago, Michael Omari stood on the stage at the 2015 Brit Awards, shoulder-to-shoulder with a who\xe2\x80\x99s who of UK rappers. Clad in all black, the MC known as Stormzy rocked along with Skepta, JME, Novelist, Jammer, Krept & Konan and dozens of others, flanking Kanye West as he performed his Paul McCartney collaboration \xe2\x80\x9cAll Day\xe2\x80\x9d amid a sea of white faces in tuxedos and cocktail dresses.' b'It was an important moment for British hip-hop and grime in particular. For years marginalized as too violent or \xe2\x80\x9cgang related\xe2\x80\x9d and mostly shut out from Britain\xe2\x80\x99s biggest pop music awards show, the heroes of the London underground had snuck in through a back door propped open by an American iconoclast. To say it had a profound effect on Stormzy\xe2\x80\x94and the entire underground scene\xe2\x80\x94would be an understatement.' b'It also marks the jumping-off point for Stormzy\xe2\x80\x99s bum rush on the pop charts. The overwhelming success of \xe2\x80\x9cShut Up\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the original video has now over\xc2\xa048 million views and the single bundled with \xe2\x80\x9cWicked Skengman 4\xe2\x80\x9d cracked the charts\xe2\x80\x94indicates a new paradigm in UK underground hip-hop. On radio shows and YouTube channels, in low-budget videos surrounded by the neighborhood squad, young MCs battle each other with pre-written \xe2\x80\x9cfreestyles\xe2\x80\x9d spit over well-known beats. And it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious why Stormzy has emerged from the scrum with a crown on his head: His booming voice and charisma are infectious and his 100-watt, silver-toothed smile lights up the screen.' b'Stormzy brings this battle rap mentality to Gang Signs & Prayer from the get-go. Opening track \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Things First\xe2\x80\x9d was intended \xe2\x80\x9cto be a punch in the face,\xe2\x80\x9d and the hyped-up grime rippers like \xe2\x80\x9cCold\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBig for Your Boots\xe2\x80\x9d are full of dire warnings to lesser rappers that might consider challenging his supremacy. But while he\xe2\x80\x99s made a name for himself battling, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that he\xe2\x80\x99s set his sights on something bigger: Stormzy fancies himself a crooner. He spends much of Gang Signs & Prayer going back and forth between clapping back at lesser rappers and serving up the \xe2\x80\x9cStiff Chocolate\xe2\x80\x9d of smoothed-out Quiet Stormzy.' b'He goes full-on gospel on \xe2\x80\x9cBlinded by Your Grace, Pt. 1,\xe2\x80\x9d forgoing a protective autotune armor for a gentle\xe2\x80\x94and pitchy\xe2\x80\x94prayer. He gives it another go on \xe2\x80\x9cVelvet,\xe2\x80\x9d which also features NAO, singing declarations of love to his \xe2\x80\x9cprincess.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s all painfully earnest, yet despite the cringes\xc2\xa0his croon inflicts, these moments feel essential to the ethos of Gang Signs & Prayer.' b'Both hard and soft, belligerent yet spiritual, Gang Signs & Prayer reveals a vulnerability belied by his 6-foot 5-inch frame and menacing glare. Even as he barks boasts on \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Things First,\xe2\x80\x9d he admits he\xe2\x80\x99s battled depression, and he follows up the horn blasts of \xe2\x80\x9cMr Skeng\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a scathing screed against doubters and dickheads\xe2\x80\x94with \xe2\x80\x9cCigarettes & Cush,\xe2\x80\x9d a tender recollection of a doomed relationship featuring Kehlani and Lily Allen. He presents these parts of himself unapologetically, juxtaposing the gang signs of his youth with the prayers from his Ghanian single mother, which quite literally grace \xe2\x80\x9c100 Bags\xe2\x80\x9d in a touching ode to her love and influence.' b'This dichotomy is fully realized on the album\xe2\x80\x99s final track, \xe2\x80\x9cLay Me Bare,\xe2\x80\x9d a syncopated confessional peppered with a chipmunk\xe2\x80\x99d vocal sample and mechanical trap hi-hat. He bleeds for five straight minutes, admitting his brief retreat from the spotlight in 2016 was a crisis of faith that left him depressed and isolated.
