He relives the pain of running into his absentee father, whose first words in years are to ask for a handout rather than forgiveness\xe2\x80\x94the one moment where his otherwise plaintive delivery is infused with rage. Even his catharsis is violent (\xe2\x80\x9cGrab this gun and aim it there/Shoot my pain and slay my fear\xe2\x80\x9d), taking a street-wise approach to conquering his demons.' b"Stormzy\xe2\x80\x99s biggest hits to date have all been testosterone-charged badman anthems, but he's also trying to reveal an artist with more than one dimension. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t always work\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to ignore the shortcomings of his singing voice, and the otherwise relatable lyrics on \xe2\x80\x9cCigarettes & Cush\xe2\x80\x9d are mired by a trite composition. But from the themes to the production choices to the sequencing, it\xe2\x80\x99s a remarkably well thought out debut from the ascendant 23-year-old MC." b'Even more impressive, Stormzy\xe2\x80\x99s rapid rise to relevance comes independent of the major label/commercial radio industrial complex. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine a major putting out a debut LP from a hardcore battle rapper with a song like the smoochy \xe2\x80\x9cVelvet,\xe2\x80\x9d but maybe that\xe2\x80\x99s the point\xe2\x80\x94he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need them. He\xe2\x80\x99s thus far made his\xc2\xa0living playing shows, releasing Spotify singles and low-budget YouTube videos, and hyping his favorite artists on his Beats 1 radio show, #Merky. And almost exactly two years after Kanye snuck him in the backdoor at the Brits, he strode into the 2017\xc2\xa0ceremony on the red carpet, glad-handing with Bradley Walsh and cheesing for the cameras in a crisp Burberry suit. And when Ed Sheeran brought him onstage to debut his verse on the \xe2\x80\x9cShape of You\xe2\x80\x9d remix, the crowd\xe2\x80\x99s fervent reaction proved he was anything but backup.'

column7: b'On his first Entrance LP\xc2\xa0in a decade, Guy Blakeslee\xe2\x80\x99s songs\xc2\xa0are\xc2\xa0newly exposed and intimate, telling a story\xc2\xa0of love and loss with folk, pop, and\xc2\xa0echoes of Laurel Canyon.'
column8: b'Guy Blakeslee\xe2\x80\x99s career has drawn no straight stylistic lines.\xc2\xa0After breaking from the knotty psych rock of his Baltimore band the Convocation Of\xe2\x80\xa6\xc2\xa0in 2002, Blakeslee reemerged in the early \xe2\x80\x9900s with a series of warped records and a new identity: a haunted Delta blues conjurer called Entrance. In the years since, he staggered and sometimes stumbled through brooding stoner rock with the Entrance Band and, more recently, alternated phases of anemic indie and instrumental escapism under his given name. He has seemed, through it all, inquisitive and impressionable, responding in real time to sounds that piqued his interest as a listener first and a musician second. But\xc2\xa0Book of Changes, his first full album in a decade under the Entrance moniker, is\xc2\xa0one of the most inviting sets of songs he\xe2\x80\x99s ever made.' b'At its best, Book of Changes feels like a natural resting point for a songwriter who has spent the better part of two decades searching restlessly for the perfect sound. Somewhat surprisingly, it is a rather conventional distillation of folk, pop, and rock, dipping its toes into the echoes of Laurel Canyon and occasionally lifting its head to the narcotic heights of Roky Erickson or Love. There are traces of Phil Spector\xe2\x80\x99s trademark Wall of Sound, Lee Hazelwood and Nancy Sinatra\xe2\x80\x99s anxious romantic kismet, and the Zombies\xe2\x80\x99 subtle psychedelia, all wrapped around songs that share the windfalls and pratfalls of a year lost to love, presented in chronological order. \xe2\x80\x9cTime will pass if you laugh or if you cry,\xe2\x80\x9d Blakeslee sings in full vibrato during \xe2\x80\x9cThe Avenue,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s pop-symphonic centerpiece of emotional uncertainty. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the best of friends have to part sometimes/So why not you and I?\xe2\x80\x9d Turns out, Blakeslee traveled a long way just to ask old questions in unexpectedly simple ways.' b'Book of Changes is quite the production, though. It was recorded over a year and in nearly a dozen different studios on two continents with the help of some high-profile friends. There\xe2\x80\x99s Pixie Paz Lenchantin and producer and engineer David Vandervelde\xe2\x80\x94who cut a series of sterling albums a decade ago that align with Blakeslee\xe2\x80\x99s ramshackle, anthemic aims\xc2\xa0here. There are passels of drummers, backup singers, and string players.' b'But Blakeslee is clearly in control, playing as many as a half-dozen instruments on some songs. That\xe2\x80\x99s him with the perfectly pealing xylophone-and-piano lines during \xe2\x80\x9cAlways the Right Time\xe2\x80\x9d and the mystic autoharp during the exasperated \xe2\x80\x9cLeaving California.\xe2\x80\x9d More importantly, he foregrounds his own love-and-loss story, dividing it into 10\xc2\xa0acts of wide-eyed enthusiasm, waiting-by-the-phone unease, severe depression, and hopeful perseverance. He shares those feelings most effectively when the songs become a sort of pop music pulpit, a place for him to relay his story in open, verse-chorus-verse splendor. That happens during \xe2\x80\x9cAlways the Right Time,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWinter Lady,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRevolution Eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d the three songs that do the emotional heavy lifting and share the saturated sounds of Spector\xe2\x80\x99s successes. \xe2\x80\x9cRevolution Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d even borders on heartland rock, like John Mellencamp forced into the studio with the War on Drugs. It is direct and disarmed in a way that Blakeslee\xe2\x80\x99s music has rarely been.' b'Book of Changes is a good record built with occasionally great songs, especially that suite\xc2\xa0of Spector-like pop, but it ends with the same vexing questions about Blakeslee that have marked his entire career: Who is he? And will his output ever be more than a series of sometimes-marvelous conjurings, where he channels\xc2\xa0the ghosts of his influences (whether they be Neu! or Harry Nilsson) for an album or two? After all, even on\xc2\xa0this set, he slips into bolero camouflage (\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d Be a Fool\xe2\x80\x9d), ambient musings (\xe2\x80\x9cWarm and Wild\xe2\x80\x9d), and western cover (\xe2\x80\x9cMolly\xe2\x80\x9d). At least these guises now feel like part of something bigger. Book of Changes is refreshingly exposed and intimate, as if Blakeslee has found a lingua franca for writing when it really matters. Perhaps Book of Changes is the start of Entrance in earnest, the beginning of a career that feels like more than a string of confidently executed echoes.'

column7: b'This new LP from psych-folk guitar hero Ben Chasny is his\xc2\xa0warmest, most accessible release\xc2\xa0yet. Its supporting cast of avant-rock all-stars includes Damon & Naomi, Ryley Walker, and Circuit Des Yeux.'
column8: b'For nearly 20 years now, Ben Chasny has been releasing a steady stream of records as Six Organs of Admittance, playing with other bands (Comets on Fire, Rangda) and participating in countless one-off collaborations. But 2015 found the psych-folk guitar hero embarking on a different kind of touring. The two Six Organs album he issued that year\xe2\x80\x94Hexadic\xc2\xa0and Hexadic II\xe2\x80\x94weren\xe2\x80\x99t just complementary electric/acoustic riffs on the same material. They were also veritable display models for a new, open-source model of composition that Chasny had developed, through specially notated and arranged playing cards. Explaining the concept\xe2\x80\x94known as the Hexadic system\xe2\x80\x94required Chasny to write an accompanying book, issue his own line of cards, draft up diagrams, and maintain an extensive section of related resources on his website. And for added clarity, he even hosted a series of lectures on the subject.' b'But as much as the Hexadic project seemed to announce a new phase in Chasny\xe2\x80\x99s career, its sheer scope and complexity has, for now at least, had the opposite effect\xe2\x80\x94that is, it\xe2\x80\x99s prompted Chasny to pursue simpler pleasures in his music. With Burning the Threshold, he reverts to the acoustic idyll last heard on 2011\xe2\x80\x99s Asleep on the Floodplain**.\xc2\xa0However, where that melodically-focused record could drift off into\xc2\xa0oscillating 12-minute odysseys, the new album puts a premium on clarity and concision. Quite simply, this is the warmest, most welcoming, and accessible album in Six Organs\xe2\x80\x99 canon\xe2\x80\x94which may come as a disappointment to fans who prefer Chasny\xe2\x80\x99s more extreme excursions. But for those who first encountered Chasny alongside Devendra Banhart and Joanna Newsom in 2004-era New Weird America magazine features, and\xc2\xa0haven\xe2\x80\x99t kept up with his prolific pace, this is the perfect place to rediscover his mesmerizing musicianship and sublime\xc2\xa0songcraft.' b'Chasny wrote Burning the Threshold while\xc2\xa0working on a musical based on the life of Wallace Stevens, and the though the two projects aren\xe2\x80\x99t directly related, the poet\xe2\x80\x99s magic realist approach shaped the album\xe2\x80\x99s thematic framework. Like his participatory approach to promoting Hexadic, Chasny has a way of translating weighty, obtuse ideas from science and theology into pure, easily relatable messaging. On \xe2\x80\x9cThings As They Are,\xe2\x80\x9d Chasny invokes Stevens\xe2\x80\x99 necessary-angel archetype to meditate on the relationship between natural wonder and human progress.\xc2\xa0On \xe2\x80\x9cAdoration Song,\xe2\x80\x9d he becomes possibly the first indie rock artist to namedrop French philosopher Gaston Bachelard in song when he intones, \xe2\x80\x9cour friend Gaston says we\xe2\x80\x99re made of lines,\xe2\x80\x9d before channeling that sentiment into a jubilant chorus. Over vigorous open-chord strums, he exhorts, \xe2\x80\x9cRise up now!/So Sun softly speaks/Adoration comes from our softened beaks,\xe2\x80\x9d transforming the song into an oblique protest anthem at a time when the very concept of compassion feels like it\xe2\x80\x99s under attack by the powers that be.' b'Though it ranks among Chasny\xe2\x80\x99s most gentle records, Burning the Threshold nonetheless accommodates a large supporting cast of avant-rock all stars who lend these intimately scaled songs a greater dimension. The gorgeous \xe2\x80\x9cUnder Fixed Stars\xe2\x80\x9d takes the hushed intro to the Rolling Stones\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cMoonlight Mile\xe2\x80\x9d and spins it out into a mantra, with Damon & Naomi\xe2\x80\x99s hypnotic hums swaddling some of Chasny\xe2\x80\x99s most tender lyrics to date (\xe2\x80\x9cI kept your letters inside my sleeve/Between my heart and my hand they breathe\xe2\x80\x9d). The instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cAround the Axis,\xe2\x80\x9d by contrast, sees Chasny squaring off against finger-picking phenom Ryley Walker in a left channel/right channel duel, their tense, tangled interplay blurring the line between harmony and discord. And in the album\xe2\x80\x99s lone act of aggression, \xe2\x80\x9cTaken by Ascent,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Chasny busts out his electric to shred overtop a taut, Chris Corsano-powered groove, with haunting guest vocals from Haley Fohr (a.k.a. Circuit Des Yeux) intensifying the song\xe2\x80\x99s ominous thrust.' b'But that proves to be a fleeting black-could intrusion on an album that otherwise brims with sunrise-summoning optimism, where every glistening guitar pluck seems to shake off the morning dew. Beyond the Threshold hits its rapturous peak on \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Eustace,\xe2\x80\x9d which resembles a Zeppelin III\xc2\xa0folk jam given a kosmische spin courtesy of Cooper Crain\xe2\x80\x99s splendorous synth drones. The song is named for the second-century Roman warrior who gave himself over to Christianity after seeing a vision of a crucifix hovering between the antlers of the deer he was hunting. Likewise, Beyond the Threshold is a means to coax ecstatic experiences from everyday occurrences\xe2\x80\x94whether through communion with God or just a bottle of Jager.'

column7: b'The Australian producer built his career on pop accessibility, but his latest EP\xe2\x80\x94featuring Pusha T\xc2\xa0and Moses Sumney\xe2\x80\x94lacks the spark to make his pop music memorable.'
column8: b"The chasm that once separated mainstream electronic music and Top 40 has all but vanished. A few years ago, a captive festival goer might have been a producer's target audience; now the casual radio listener is the true prize. It's the difference between Skrillex, one of electronic music's most prominent artists, making \xe2\x80\x9cBangarang,\xe2\x80\x9d a 2x-platinum-certified single from 2012 that didn't register with the average commuter, and forging \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Are \xc3\x9c Now?\xe2\x80\x9d a Justin Bieber number that\xc2\xa0guaranteed a primo spot in the great hall of pop." b"The Australian producer Flume (born Harley Edward Streten), built his career on a different type of accessibility. His songs can be easy to fall into, but they don't usually lasso listeners and ensnare them like an undeniable airwave triumph. Flume's 2012 self-titled debut, an oasis of lite house and loungeable hip-hop, offered refuge from the fusillade of trap beats sweeping through electronic music at the time. His second full-length, Skin, released four years later, set aside big-room lullabies to emphasize big-name collaborations, but there was a reticent quality to it. Flume worked with rappers on the declarative, bruising end of the spectrum\xe2\x80\x94Vic Mensa, Vince Staples\xe2\x80\x94but didn't make the kind of songs that really knocked you on your ass. He enlisted singers\xe2\x80\x94Beck, Tove Lo\xe2\x80\x94to create pop songs that were neither sugary nor off-kilter. He spoke of\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cmak[ing] experimental music accessible\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfus[sing] the abrasive and the beautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d but seemed to sell both sides short." b"Flume patrols the same liminal zone on Skin Companion EP II. He leads with an uppercut, a track that's supposed to slug its way into your subconscious: \xe2\x80\x9cEnough\xe2\x80\x9d features rapping from the stolid veteran Pusha T, and the beat shovels a stream of noises\xe2\x80\x94hollow wood tones, staticky crumbles\xe2\x80\x94at the listener to stimulate a fight-or-flight response. But the song plays as an attempt to redo Lil Uzi Vert's \xe2\x80\x9cUzi\xe2\x80\x9d and extract the magic from its alluring rumble. The central riffs of the two tracks are similar, as are the liquidating blots of bass and the drum breaks that \xe2\x80\x9cUzi\xe2\x80\x9d-producer Charlie Heat also inserted into Kanye West's \xe2\x80\x9cAll Day.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cEnough\xe2\x80\x9d never surges beyond emulation, any abrasiveness blunted by the feeling that this is an academic beat-making exercise." b"The rest of Skin Companion II veers away from the rough stuff to return to the modes Flume explored on his first album. \xe2\x80\x9cDepth Charge\xe2\x80\x9d will do fine as a bridge towards the more peaceful side of a live set. \xe2\x80\x9cFantastic,\xe2\x80\x9d a collaboration with Dave Bayley of Glass Animals, is a colorless mid-tempo number with a clomping drum pattern designed to make heads bob. The most promising tune on the EP is \xe2\x80\x9cWeekend,\xe2\x80\x9d a reverie with extended beat-less portions. Though Moses Sumney's presence only registers as the song begins to wind down, his soothing tone is enough to summon the floating, comatose feeling. Flume\xc2\xa0doesn't want to be pinned down, and he's intent on proving his ability to make functional music for multiple scenarios. But malleability is only really powerful when it's accompanied by memorability, and the latter remains out of reach for Flume."

column7: b"The third album from bassist/songwriter Thundercat is whimsical and somber, funny and meaningful, sometimes all at once.\xc2\xa0Drunk's oddball soul confronts\xc2\xa0the challenge of just trying to live life."
column8: b'Thundercat gives himself a pep talk at the beginning of Drunk: \xe2\x80\x9cComb your beard, brush your teeth \xe2\x80\xa6 beat your meat, go to sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d At least he\xe2\x80\x99s in marginally better spirits these days. Following the death of his friend and collaborator Austin Peralta, his last two releases\xe2\x80\x942013\xe2\x80\x99s Apocalypse and 2015\xe2\x80\x99s The Beyond / Where the Giants Roam*\xe2\x80\x94*explored the concept of extinction and what the spirit might endure when the body expires. On these records\xe2\x80\x94along with Flying Lotus\xe2\x80\x99 2014 album You\xe2\x80\x99re Dead!, where Thundercat contributed bass or vocals to many of its songs\xe2\x80\x94the singer and preeminent bassist (born Stephen Bruner) tried to make sense of a devastating truth. Peralta was gone, and one day, he will be gone too.' b'All this cosmic morbidity leaned on Thundercat\xe2\x80\x99s music, which takes on many forms all at once: \xe2\x80\x9970s funk, R&B, punk with tinges of fusion. His art is undeniably black, yet the structures are loose enough to pull in all sorts of listeners. It speaks to those who love soul and ska equally, those who spazz just the same when George Duke or Bad Brains flash across the iPod. Thundercat is equal parts Nintendo generation, \xe2\x80\x9960s flower child, and hardcore skater bro. His live show is punk as hell; serene studio tracks are given loud, frenetic makeovers. On top of all that rests Thundercat\xe2\x80\x99s smooth falsetto, a transcendent voice that can usher you into some sort of demise (\xe2\x80\x9cDescent Into Madness\xe2\x80\x9d), sing lovingly to his pet cat (\xe2\x80\x9cTron Song\xe2\x80\x9d), or make drugs seem perfectly fine (\xe2\x80\x9cDMT Song,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOh Sheit It\xe2\x80\x99s X.\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'If Thundercat\xe2\x80\x99s recent work focused on the uncertainty of death, Drunk confronts the challenge of just trying to live life. It\xe2\x80\x99s a marathon through the mind of Bruner that uses his casually humorous and honest songwriting to detail that which is cool and that which sucks. Cool? Kenny Loggins and Dragon Ball Z wrist-slap bracelets. Sucks? Friend zones and the police state. Featuring Kendrick Lamar (\xe2\x80\x9cWalk on By\xe2\x80\x9d), Wiz Khalifa (\xe2\x80\x9cDrink Dat\xe2\x80\x9d) and Kamasi Washington (\xe2\x80\x9cThem Changes\xe2\x80\x9d) among others, Drunk plays like an anxious stoner album, the aural equivalent of late-night channel surfing. Its 23 tracks present a fluid narrative that begins on a somewhat bright note and gradually fades into darkness\xe2\x80\x94a concept record that takes you through a bleary night of drinking, drugs, funk, and heartbreak with Thundercat himself.' b"He\xc2\xa0is whimsical and somber, funny and meaningful, sometimes all at once. Each song hovers around the two-minute mark, defying those \xe2\x80\x9870s fusion forebears whose tracks could drag on over dense harmonies and time signatures. Drunk hits all the melodic and emotional themes Thundercat aims for without belaboring the point. On openers \xe2\x80\x9cRabbot Ho\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Stupido,\xe2\x80\x9d he comes off a bit goofy and red-eyed, leaving his wallet at the club after a night of partying. \xe2\x80\x9cBus in These Streets,\xe2\x80\x9d which resembles the theme of 1980s children show \xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Space Coaster,\xe2\x80\x9d uses a sarcastic nursery rhyme flow to chide our collective social media dependence (\xe2\x80\x9cThank God for technology \xe2\x80\x98cause where would we be if we couldn't tweet our thoughts,\xe2\x80\x9d Thundercat quips). \xe2\x80\x9cJameel\xe2\x80\x99s Space Ride,\xe2\x80\x9d a transitional song near the album\xe2\x80\x99s end, uses a chiptune-inspired beat while he sings of the struggle between minorities and law enforcement: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m safe on my block, except for the cops/Will they attack, would it be \xe2\x80\x98cause I\xe2\x80\x99m black?\xe2\x80\x9d This, of course, is after he literally meows about how cool it must be to be a cat." b"All this oddball soul feels more anchored to Thundercat's humanity than his previous releases. We see him here as both a heartbroken insomniac, someone who looks at the world alongside Pharrell on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Turn Down\xe2\x80\x9d and wonders if \xe2\x80\x9ceverything we do is weak,\xe2\x80\x9d and a juvenile jazzbo who wants to \xe2\x80\x9cblow all [his] cash on anime.\xe2\x80\x9d Much like The Golden Age of Apocalypse*\xc2\xa0*and Apocalypse, which leapfrogged several different genres with dizzying results, he\xe2\x80\x99s able to keep it all together, offering a puzzling ride that feels coherent despite its moving parts. Unlike his past work, which put his musicianship on great display, Drunk presents the defining picture of Thundercat as a person: quirky, political, thoughtful, weird\xe2\x80\x94and sometimes drunk. These descriptors aren\xe2\x80\x99t surprising if you follow him on Twitter, but here, Thundercat comes off like the guy who you can hit up at the bar and riff on pretty much anything. Given all he\xe2\x80\x99s gone through personally, it\xe2\x80\x99s an honor to hear Thundercat feeling like himself again."

column7: b'The new Feelies album is\xc2\xa0both mellow and intense in ways only the New Jersey band can pull off. With the increased use\xc2\xa0of acoustic guitar, it feels like a spiritual sequel to 1986\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0The Good Earth.'
column8: b'In 2011, when the Feelies released their first album in 20 years, it came with hints of indecision. It was called *Here Before\xe2\x80\x94*possibly as in \xe2\x80\x9cbeen there, done that\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and began with the lyric \xe2\x80\x9cIs it too late to do it again?/Or should we wait another 10?\xe2\x80\x9d The music certainly sounded confident, in the breezy but determined style that the New Jersey quintet patented around the time of their second album, 1986\xe2\x80\x99s The Good Earth. But you could forgive diehards for wanting clearer signs that the Feelies were back to stay.' b'With\xc2\xa0this new Feelies album, there remains no explicitly outlined future for the band. But the record\xc2\xa0is called\xc2\xa0In Between\xe2\x80\x94presumably there\xe2\x80\x99s more to come\xe2\x80\x94and it offers hope in titles such as \xe2\x80\x9cStay the Course\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTime Will Tell,\xe2\x80\x9d and\xc2\xa0in lines like,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cTake your time, not going anywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d Beyond these small\xc2\xa0signs, there are increased levels of musical commitment and design. The record is\xc2\xa0more purposefully-sequenced than its predecessor, with tracks that build on each other through subtle motifs. In press materials, guitarist and singer Glenn Mercer describes the record as \xe2\x80\x9claid back,\xe2\x80\x9d and he\xe2\x80\x99s right. But it\xe2\x80\x99s as precise and efficient as it is casual and comfortable.' b'In its best moments, In Between sounds both mellow and intense in ways only the Feelies can pull off. That\xe2\x80\x99s helped along by\xc2\xa0the increased prominence of acoustic guitar compared to Here Before (making the album a kind of spiritual sequel to The Good Earth). Acoustic guitars naturally exude calm, but Mercer and Bill Million imbue them with a sharpness. The quick strums in the pithy \xe2\x80\x9cTurn Back Time\xe2\x80\x9d and aforementioned swayer \xe2\x80\x9cStay the Course\xe2\x80\x9d both soothe and energize. Acoustics even tighten the otherwise placid ballad \xe2\x80\x9cMake It Clear.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Still, the Feelies remain a democratic machine, with each sound snugly complementing the other. They\xe2\x80\x99re masters at weaving their moving parts into a kinetic whole: Take \xe2\x80\x9cGone Gone Gone,\xe2\x80\x9d an insta-classic that\xc2\xa0escalates simple\xc2\xa0chords into a cycle of tension\xc2\xa0and release. While Mercer intones open-ended lyrics (\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want to know?/What do you want to do?\xe2\x80\x9d), the tune\xc2\xa0peaks when bassist Brenda Sauter redirects the band\xe2\x80\x99s momentum like a ship\xe2\x80\x99s rudder.' b'All the instrumental symbiosis on In Between connects its songs\xc2\xa0into an arc. That\xe2\x80\x99s emphasized by how the album\xc2\xa0begins and ends. On previous records, the Feelies liked to conclude\xc2\xa0with a cover: the Velvet Underground\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Goes On\xe2\x80\x9d on 1988\xe2\x80\x99s Only Life, the Stooges\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cReal Cool Time\xe2\x80\x9d on 1991\xe2\x80\x99s Time for a\xc2\xa0Witness. Here, they cover themselves, reprising the sparse opening title track as a long, dense closing\xc2\xa0jam. Explicitly framing the album as a cycle is a typically\xc2\xa0Zen move, suggesting that this evergreen\xc2\xa0band\xc2\xa0plans on more trips around the sun.'

column7: b'Finally full of purpose, rapper Jonwayne navigates his own downward spiral, seeking the answer to his most important question: What do you do when rap is both your living and a fuel for your vices?'
column8: b'In 2014, Los Angeles rapper/producer Jonwayne had a crisis of faith. His suddenly-realized rap dreams were the impetus for his own implosion. A battle with alcoholism\xc2\xa0waged in part because of a crippling fear of flying, and the harshness of his lifestyle threatened to ruin him. He canceled his shows, parted ways with his label Stones Throw, and retreated from the rap scene. The next year, he released an EP called Jonwayne is Retired. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I\xe2\x80\x99m grieving I stay up writing these masterpieces,\xe2\x80\x9d he rapped. His second full-length rap album seems to prove that assertion. It\xe2\x80\x99s an introspective journal that uses self-critique as a lens through which to examine the fragility of rap celebrity on any scale. It considers what it means to be a rapper and it considers the cost. Rap Album Two deconstructs Jonwayne to build him back up.' b"Jonwayne has always been a master craftsman and talented technician, but in the past, his raps didn\xe2\x80\x99t really have any function. It was rapping for the sake of it. He had plenty of knotty, syllable-twisting wordplay pivoting on slant rhymes and internal schemes, but much of the content was filler. His full-length debut as a lyricist, Rap Album One, was bogged down by his inability to get out of his own head, rattling off series after series of pointless puzzlers and long-winded (albeit fun) workarounds for rap cliches aiming to show how clever he was. Instilled with purpose, Rap Album Two weighs every sentence carefully. He isn\xe2\x80\x99t interested in constructing complex lyrical miracle word exhibitions. He's too busy wondering if rap is even worth it." b"Much of Rap Album Two is about rap as both an instrument of destruction and a vehicle for redemption. It finds Jonwayne navigating his own downward spiral, seeking the answer to his most important question: What do you do when rap is both your living and a fuel for your vices? His writing, which was once so heady, is now sobering. He\xe2\x80\x99s rapping more deliberately, and the bars all mean more, carrying bigger burdens but bringing bigger rewards. There\xe2\x80\x99s literally a song called \xe2\x80\x9cThese Words Are Everything.\xe2\x80\x9d Songs like the existentialist daydream \xe2\x80\x9cHuman Condition\xe2\x80\x9d and the punching \xe2\x80\x9cCity Lights\xe2\x80\x9d explore the consequences of addiction, especially when pursuing a rap career (\xe2\x80\x9cThere's a price to it youngin\xe2\x80\x99/You most likely don\xe2\x80\x99t invite the kind of vices we brung in/Be it poison of the body or the kind you can\xe2\x80\x99t see \xe2\x80\x98cause it's creeping up behind\xe2\x80\x9d). The album uses a beatpack with snappy, slow-rolling drums, minor piano chords, soul hymnals, and sunless tones to depict an ongoing recalibration, as Jonwayne finds his way back to rap." b"On \xe2\x80\x9cLIVE from the Fuck You,\xe2\x80\x9d one of the album\xe2\x80\x99s keenest moments, a stranger approaches the rapper in public asking for an impromptu concert for a girl he\xe2\x80\x99s with (\xe2\x80\x9cShe says she knows who you are, I think she's a big fan\xe2\x80\x9d) before tagging on a dismissal: \xe2\x80\x9cShe says you rap and I\xe2\x80\x99m not really seeing it, dog.\xe2\x80\x9d Jonwayne finally indulges his request for on-the-spot raps with a verse dismantling the \xe2\x80\x9cfan\xe2\x80\x9d and his actions: \xe2\x80\x9cSo here\xe2\x80\x99s a little story bout the way I make it hurt/The way I make you learn how not to approach a man who\xe2\x80\x99s suffering for his work like a monkey in the circus.\xe2\x80\x9d The observations aren\xe2\x80\x99t exactly revelatory but they are cleverly articulated, and the sharpness with which they\xe2\x80\x99re delivered makes them potent. The most telling moment on Rap Album Two is \xe2\x80\x9cThe Single,\xe2\x80\x9d a chest-beating song he botches several times before scrapping. The title of the song and his inability to complete it best exemplify the album\xe2\x80\x99s primary lesson: the pursuit of stardom can be punishing, both on mind and body." b'Rap Album Two is easily the most fulfilling project Jonwayne has ever made loaded with the most thoughtful writing of his career. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t just the gravity of subjects, it\xe2\x80\x99s the carefulness with which he\xe2\x80\x99s willing to examine them. Every candid, incredibly personal line contains some form of catharsis. Alcoholism drove him into isolation and loneliness only led to further self-sabotage. But this record is a triumph over that. These raps don\xe2\x80\x99t just exist for posterity; they, too, are a part of the healing process. As Jonwayne rethinks his \xe2\x80\x9corder of operations,\xe2\x80\x9d he becomes closer to whole.'

column7: b'The overlooked Brit-rock stars reissue their sophomore\xc2\xa0album on its 17th anniversary. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to say underappreciated bands were ahead of their time, but Six by Seven were totally of their time.'
column8: b'Six by Seven were but one of many British bands to carry the \xe2\x80\x9cnext Radiohead\xe2\x80\x9d albatross in the late \xe2\x80\x9990s. Despite endorsements from tastemakers like Jools Holland and John Peel, their 1998 debut album, The Things We Make, didn\xe2\x80\x99t yield a \xe2\x80\x9cCreep\xe2\x80\x9d-sized crossover. It did boast a pretty great \xe2\x80\x9cStop Whispering\xe2\x80\x9d in the yearning \xe2\x80\x9cFor You,\xe2\x80\x9d but the rest of the record wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so eager to please, as it wrapped singer-guitarist Chris Olley\xe2\x80\x99s plaintive melodicism in slow-roiling surges that owed more to the stalking gaits of post-rock than Britpop. That tension between their congenial and contrarian instincts likely scuttled Six by Seven\xe2\x80\x99s chart potential, but on their follow-up album, the Nottingham band turned their frustrations and square-peg/round-hole relationship with popular culture into a badge of honor.' b'On the surface, the reappearance of The Closer You Get\xc2\xa0is an oddly timed archival project\xe2\x80\x94rather than wait until next year to mark the 20th-anniversary of their debut album, Six by Seven are jumping the queue to do a 17th-anniversary deluxe vinyl repackaging of their second (complete with a bonus collection of Peel sessions). Though Olley rebooted the Six by Seven name in 2013 after a half decade hiatus, next month, he\xe2\x80\x99ll be reforming with the band\xe2\x80\x99s original line-up to perform The Closer You Get in its entirety at a couple of shows in the UK\xe2\x80\x94a reunion spurred by group of fans who lobbied to make the album\xe2\x80\x99s lead-off track \xe2\x80\x9cEat Junk Become Junk\xe2\x80\x9d a party-crashing contender in the UK\xe2\x80\x99s annual Christmas No. 1 sweepstakes back in 2015. But that stunt campaign speaks to a genuine need\xe2\x80\x94The Closer You Get has resurfaced not out of knee-jerk nostalgia, but because it feels so vitally, viscerally now.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s common to say underappreciated bands were ahead of their time, but Six by Seven were totally of their time. It\xe2\x80\x99s just that, in that brief post-Blair, pre-9/11 golden age, most people didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to hear songs about unfettered consumerism, class conflict, media addiction, and social isolation. The Closer You Get resembles the kind of record Radiohead may have put out in 2000 had Thom Yorke chosen Mark E. Smith instead of Richard D. James as his spirit animal\xe2\x80\x94an album for people who like the idea of Muse, but can\xe2\x80\x99t stomach the pretension of the real one. Rather than attempt to make electronic music, Six by Seven filtered its\xc2\xa0influence through standard guitar-band instrumentation: the patient builds and trembling leads of their debut gave way to frenetic, skittering rhythms and tweaked-out distortion-pedal squalls, transforming the band from art-rock aesthetes to noise-punk preachers.' b'And in 17 years, Olley\xe2\x80\x99s targets have only become more firmly entrenched. The lacerating invectives of \xe2\x80\x9cEat Junk Become Junk\xe2\x80\x9d leave fresh wounds at a time when a trash-TV huckster has moved into the White House, and while \xe2\x80\x9cSawn Off Metallica T-Shirt\xe2\x80\x9d may deal in white-trash caricature, its dirtbag protagonist\xe2\x80\x99s delusions of grandeur (\xe2\x80\x9cLenny Bruce Lee Marvin Gaye\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve got style, and I\xe2\x80\x99m misunderstood!\xe2\x80\x9d) ring all too familiar in an era of toxic, #GHBTP-grade masculinity and #alternativefacts. (Though the two groups are aesthetic opposites, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised if fellow Nottinghammers Sleaford Mods learned a few lessons in bile-spewing from this record.)' b'But as much as The Closer You Get unleashes Six by Seven\xe2\x80\x99s latent aggression, there\xe2\x80\x99s a part of Olley that\xe2\x80\x99s holding out hope to commune with the masses\xe2\x80\x94and for all its buckshot cultural critique, the album doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sacrifice Olley\xe2\x80\x99s flair for melancholy and impassioned appeals to the heart. The desperate sentiments of \xe2\x80\x9cNew Year\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cgive me something I can live for/Give me something to believe in\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94come couched in a psych-pop sway before a string-swept chorus shoots the song skyward, while the fuzzed-out mid-album double shot of \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Wanna Stop\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSlab Square\xe2\x80\x9d burns like the sound of a band raging against the dying of the light.' b'By contrast, The Closer You Get\xe2\x80\x99s tent-pole ballads\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cEngland and a Broken Radio\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c100 and Something Foxhall Road\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94are more like flickering, short-wicked candles that nonetheless illuminate a path out of the darkness. The former communicates its music-as-salvation message through mellow, Mogwai-esque atmospherics; the latter is both a love letter and farewell note\xe2\x80\x94to an old flame, to Nottingham, to the possibility of happiness itself. As Olley\xe2\x80\x99s more famous peers\xc2\xa0once wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t get sentimental/It always ends up drivel.\xe2\x80\x9d But what makes The Closer You Get more than just a delirious dive through modern life\xe2\x80\x99s rubbish is Olley\xe2\x80\x99s desire to forge an emotional connection with those who feel weighed down by it. And if that means occasionally getting sentimental, then, for Olley, it\xe2\x80\x99s a risk worth taking.'

column7: b'Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s 1994 debut, filled\xc2\xa0with geeky humor, dense cultural references, and positively gargantuan hooks, took alt-rock in a striking new direction.'
column8: b'Weezer mastermind Rivers Cuomo\xc2\xa0was such a somber kid that\xc2\xa0his second-grade teacher trained the other students to tell him, in unison, \xe2\x80\x9cLet me see the smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Childhood in Yogaville, the ashram and Integral Yoga HQ led by \xe2\x80\x9cWoodstock guru\xe2\x80\x9d Swami Satchidananda in eastern Connecticut, was isolating, devoid of much pop culture and adventure\xe2\x80\x94until Cuomo heard Kiss. When a family friend brought their fifth album, 1976\xe2\x80\x99s Rock and Roll Over, to the Cuomo house, it sent Rivers and younger brother Leaves launching off furniture in a way only formative music can. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve pretty much based my life around that record,\xe2\x80\x9d he has said. With their comic-book personas and distorted riffs, Kiss cracked Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s young brain wide open and rewired it for good. He had little idea what debauchery they were singing of, but from that point on, Cuomo began having intense dreams about becoming a rock star, and he began obsessively studying the work of his songwriting heroes.' b'For\xc2\xa0Rivers, music offered both a coat of armor and an identity. As a pre-teen enrolled in public school for the first time, Cuomo went by a different first name and his stepfather\xe2\x80\x99s last name (Kitts); his chosen moniker\xe2\x80\x94Peter Kitts\xe2\x80\x94was awfully close to that of Kiss drummer Peter Criss. And while Cuomo was still picked on as he made his way through puberty, he eventually found his people: the metalheads. In 1989, Cuomo moved from Connecticut with his high school band to Los Angeles, ground zero for the AquaNetted and Spandexed. There, he found himself in the midst of shifting tastes, both culturally and personally. He started working at the Sunset Boulevard Tower Records, where he was schooled on quintessentially \xe2\x80\x9ccool\xe2\x80\x9d music like the Velvet Underground, Pixies, and Sonic Youth.' b'Also in the mix\xc2\xa0at this time was a new band called Nirvana. When Cuomo first heard \xe2\x80\x9cSmells Like Teen Spirit\xe2\x80\x9d on the radio in late 1991 while washing dishes in an Italian restaurant, he was sorta pissed he didn\xe2\x80\x99t write it himself. \xe2\x80\x9cRivers says, \xe2\x80\x98I should have written that,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d remembered early Weezer guitarist Jason Cropper in John D. Luerssen\xe2\x80\x99s band biography,\xc2\xa0River\xe2\x80\x99s Edge. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99m like, \xe2\x80\x98Yeah. That\xe2\x80\x99s totally true.\xe2\x80\x99 Because the music he was writing was improving in quality every day.\xe2\x80\x9d Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s interest in Nirvana became an obsession. He\xe2\x80\x99d taken notes from\xc2\xa0Brian Wilson, the Beatles, Scorpions, Yngwie Malmsteen, and, of course, Kiss. But for all his knowledge of rock history, he still cared deeply about writing anthems that spoke to his generation, even if he had trouble looking his peers in the eyes.' b'Weezer\xc2\xa0anthems were destined to be different. In 1994, the acts dominating the modern rock charts were pushing against something, from the British aesthetes (Depeche Mode, New Order, Morrissey) to the singular weirdos (Beck, Tori Amos, Red Hot Chili Peppers) to the disenfranchised youth (Nirvana, Green Day, Pearl Jam). With rebellion came a facade of cool, and that was something Weezer could never manage, at least not in the traditional way. Cuomo\xc2\xa0always tried a little too hard. He would become the fidgety anti-frontman with a thousand \xe2\x80\x9crevenge of the nerds\xe2\x80\x9d taglines\xc2\xa0and a Harvard degree to prove it. That dichotomy\xe2\x80\x94the big-time rockstar in khakis and Buddy Holly glasses, who never seems totally comfortable in his own skin\xe2\x80\x94is what launched his cult and anchored his unlikely sex appeal. And his band\xe2\x80\x94drummer Patrick Wilson, bassist Matt Sharp, and guitarist Brian Bell\xe2\x80\x94played along, accentuating their innate geekiness to make Weezer feel like a unified front.' b'By the summer of 1993, Cuomo had written a number of songs strong enough to convince the alt-rock major DGC to sign Weezer (this despite a lack of buzz around the L.A. scene) and have the Cars\xe2\x80\x99 frontman Ric Ocasek produce their first album. When the group\xe2\x80\x99s self-titled debut\xe2\x80\x94typically known as The Blue Album\xe2\x80\x94arrived in May 1994, Cobain had been dead for a month. A feeling of dread hung over the alternative rock world whose prominence was ushered in by the Seattle sound. With their wired energy, effortless power-pop-punk hooks, and Beach Boys harmonies, Weezer took the alt-rock explosion in a new direction.\xc2\xa0You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t quite tell if Cuomo was mocking his song\xe2\x80\x99s regressive narrators or sympathizing with them. But once you got past his defense mechanisms and sorting through the humor and cultural references, you found a portrait of a young man\xe2\x80\x99s psyche, riddled with angst and insecurity. And it arrived on the wings of massive riffs and gnarled guitar solos that sounded like they were emanating from a Flying V\xe2\x80\x94on every single song.' b'The Blue Album\xe2\x80\x99s exploration of the fragile male ego is in full swing by the record\xe2\x80\x99s second track, \xe2\x80\x9cNo One Else.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Taken at face value, this is likely the most misogynistic song Weezer has ever released. \xe2\x80\x9cI want a girl who will laugh for no one else,\xe2\x80\x9d Cuomo sings while the band rushes through the fuzzy pop-punk changes, evoking the hyperbole of masculinity. But there\xe2\x80\x99s more beneath the surface. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No One Else\xe2\x80\x99 is about the jealous-obsessive asshole in me freaking out on my girlfriend," Cuomo has said. The song acquires even more resonance in the context of its sequencing on the record. Cuomo described the following song, \xe2\x80\x9cThe World Has Turned and Left Me Here,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0as \xe2\x80\x9cthe same asshole wondering why she\'s gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0In actuality, he\xc2\xa0spends most of \xe2\x80\x9cThe World Has Turned and Left Me Here\xe2\x80\x9d muttering to his ex\xe2\x80\x99s wallet photograph and masturbating to her memory, getting in a joke along the way, saying she enjoyed the sex \xe2\x80\x9cmore than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s an absurd scene, but imagine the sentiment coming from the wrong person and it\xe2\x80\x99s suddenly not so funny. Weezer were masterful at walking this line between knowing jokiness and legitimately creepy dysfunction.' b'This base kind of arrested development shifts back and forth between the narrator\xe2\x80\x99s relationship with girls and his views on himself. If \xe2\x80\x9cNo One Else\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe World Has Turned and Left Me Here\xe2\x80\x9d are mirror twins, so are \xe2\x80\x9cSurf Wax America\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage.\xe2\x80\x9d Given that Weezer were named after a common term for asthma sufferers, no one expected them to be out on a board riding the waves. That tension animates \xe2\x80\x9cSurf Wax America,\xe2\x80\x9d a well-crafted jumble of harmonic puzzles and barreling punk guitars where the hedonistic surfer lifestyle is both celebrated and chided for its simplistic worldview. Even while the song sneers, the ferocity of Cuomo screaming \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go!\xe2\x80\x9d juxtaposed with the solemnness of the band\xe2\x80\x99s Wilsonian harmonies make you believe, once again, in Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s sincerity. Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage\xe2\x80\x9d is an homage to that happy place where no one judges you for your comic books, D&D figurines, and Kiss posters. It seems like over-the-top self-parody, but the garage was indeed a real place where early Weezer practiced and recorded when Cuomo, Sharp, and original guitarist Justin Fisher lived together in the \xe2\x80\x9cAmherst House\xe2\x80\x9d near Santa Monica. The hopeless ambition of\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0would make it the defining song of nerd-rock.' b'In between \xe2\x80\x9cSurf Wax America,\xe2\x80\x9d a fantasy about someone completely different, and \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage,\xe2\x80\x9d a hyper-detailed song about himself, lies a song about his father. There are two more nakedly emotional songs on Blue, which are set off further by Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s rare embrace of laid-back guitars. Atop a bluesy jangle, \xe2\x80\x9cSay It Ain\xe2\x80\x99t So\xe2\x80\x9d details the moment when Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s deepest worries\xc2\xa0are realized: He sees a beer in the fridge and, remembering how his father drank before he walked out, he senses his stepfather is doing the same. He fears now that he, too, is destined for this fate. Pinkerton, Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s sophomore album, is often described as the tortured confessional to end all tortured confessionals, essentially a diary of Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s notorious Asian fetish. But \xe2\x80\x9cSay It Ain\xe2\x80\x99t So\xe2\x80\x9d is just as raw, and arguably has more that its listeners can use, throwing its arms wide open to anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s known the trauma of dad issues. The music is constructed perfectly, building and building until what\'s left of Cuomo\'s vulnerability comes out as a bitterly frayed "yeah-yeah," all capped by a guitar solo worthy of the\xc2\xa0Scorpions.' b'The desire to write a perfect song can drive some songwriters mad, as their belief in music as a vehicle for emotional expression reconciles itself with the belief that pop is a puzzle that can be solved. On Blue, Cuomo found the ideal balance, as he rarely has since. He understood the rules so well that he also knew when to break them, from Sharp\xe2\x80\x99s super silly new-wave keyboard in \xe2\x80\x9cBuddy Holly\xe2\x80\x9d to the mumbled dialogue that runs through \xe2\x80\x9cUndone\xe2\x80\x9d (the band and their friends chatting were a backup plan after DGC refused to clear dialog from an old sci-fi film, \xe2\x80\x9cPeanuts\xe2\x80\x9d) and more.' b'The fact that \xe2\x80\x9cOnly in Dreams\xe2\x80\x9d is eight glorious minutes long is Blue\xe2\x80\x99s greatest example of self-indulgence gone right. It confronts the two most perilous teen-boy anxieties\xe2\x80\x94talking to a girl you really like and dancing in public. It\xe2\x80\x99s fiery, gorgeous, well-played, and devastatingly sad. Sharp\xe2\x80\x99s trudging bassline\xc2\xa0guides the way forward for the narrator, whose fear of stepping on his crush\xe2\x80\x99s toenails is temporarily silenced by the band\xe2\x80\x99s total calamity. Rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll teaches us that extreme volume can quiet the voices of doubt inside our heads and numb the pain of living inside our awkward bodies. In this sense, the climaxes on \xe2\x80\x9cOnly in Dreams,\xe2\x80\x9d starting around the song\xe2\x80\x99s midpoint, are rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll lessons of a lifetime. But it\xe2\x80\x99s the big\xc2\xa0build at the 6:45 mark that plays like a beta male transfiguration. Having re-recorded Cropper\xe2\x80\x99s guitar parts in one take after essentially firing him following Blue\xe2\x80\x99s 1993 recording at Electric Lady, Cuomo ends up axe-battling himself until he\xe2\x80\x99s soloing like the metal gods he grew up worshipping. Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s drumming\xe2\x80\x94an underrated and idiosyncratic force throughout Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s discography\xe2\x80\x94drives home the catharsis. His cymbals crash from every angle and his tricky rolls play like percussive triple axels. By the end of the song, you\xe2\x80\x99re back to reality, exhausted but ready for a fight\xe2\x80\x94even if it\xe2\x80\x99s just against your own doubting voices.' b'For all the talk about Rivers Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s anemic masculinity, The Blue Album has a unifying thread of identity that supersedes gender. An essay on the Smiths pointed out that, \xe2\x80\x9cAsking people about their interest in the Smiths is another way of asking this question: \xe2\x80\x98How did you survive your teenage years?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d The same could be said of Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s debut. Blue\xc2\xa0quivers with isolation if you look past the pastiche, the deflective humor, and the guitar lines that make you sit up tall. The emotion\xc2\xa0Weezer tapped into is echoed in music sometimes considered distinctly millennial due to its high levels of anxiety, from Death Cab for Cutie and Car Seat\xc2\xa0Headrest to\xc2\xa0Mitski\xe2\x80\x99s Puberty 2\xc2\xa0and even\xc2\xa0Drake at his most neurotic.' b'For as classic as the album is considered now,\xc2\xa0Blue didn\xe2\x80\x99t make the 1994 Pazz & Jop year-end critics\xe2\x80\x99 poll. Back then, Weezer were considered alt opportunists or even Pavement ripoffs\xe2\x80\x94a comparison that seems silly now, looking at the distinct rock strains since indebted to Cuomo. But MTV and radio airplay for \xe2\x80\x9cBuddy Holly\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cUndone \xe2\x80\x94 The Sweater Song\xe2\x80\x9d made Weezer huge, and\xc2\xa0The Blue Album went double-platinum within 15 months of its release. Over the next three years, as Weezer 1.0 slowly imploded (bye-bye Matt Sharp, hello rotating door of bassists), the record would sell a million more and be well on its way to canonization. By 2003, Pitchfork named it one of the best records of the 1990s; two years later, Rolling Stone heralded it as the 299th greatest album ever. And so Blue now sits in a sweet spot of commercial accessibility and critical adoration, a combination that guarantees the album will make its way into the hands of a certain kind of bespectacled teenager for decades to come\xe2\x80\x94the ones who really need it. Cuomo never wrote a song as indelible as \xe2\x80\x9cSmells Like Teen Spirit,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0but he did reach generations of rock kids, proving that coolness is optional if you study hard enough.'

column7: b'Ezra Rubin\xe2\x80\x99s debut LP\xc2\xa0is an earnest and subdued attempt at making his soulful, ominous, post-club\xc2\xa0productions agreeable to a general audience.'
column8: b'Ezra Rubin (aka Kingdom) is an architect of the post-club sound\xe2\x80\x94a new profile cleaved from caustic synthesizers, herky jerk percussion, and crying on the dancefloor. The melting pot of sounds he and his collaborators in Fade to Mind (Nguzunguzu, Total Freedom) and Night Slugs (Bok Bok, L-Vis 1990) offered pulled from UK garage, dancehall, and diva-driven house that still seems prescient. Rubin, in particular, helped shaped a postmodern vision of R&B alongside Kelela and Dawn Richard that\xe2\x80\x99s influenced everyone from FKA twigs to Justin Bieber. Rubin was staged to make a pop crossover. His debut LP, the delightfully titled Tears in the Club, is an earnest and subdued attempt at making his panoply of sounds agreeable to a general audience.' b'This is immediately clear from the album\xe2\x80\x99s opening moment, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Is Love,\xe2\x80\x9d a collaboration with SZA. Rubin is no stranger to producing for powerhouse vocalists, but with *Tears in the Club *he dips his toe into the world of major label team-ups, and the result has neutered the outr\xc3\xa9 aspects of his sound. On \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Is Love,\xe2\x80\x9d certain trademarks still pop up\xe2\x80\x94vaporous synth pulses and staccato percussion\xe2\x80\x94but he\xe2\x80\x99s slowed down the normally breakneck pace of his music to somewhere sleepier and almost lackadaisical. In the past, Rubin\xe2\x80\x99s slow jams (Dawn Richards \xe2\x80\x9cPaint It Blue\xe2\x80\x9d for example) had a seething atmosphere just bubbling beneath the surface. With SZA, that feel is gone. This is also true of some of his solo tracks. \xe2\x80\x9cNurtureworld\xe2\x80\x9d is a confusingly out-of-focus dance track that spends most of its three minutes finding its proper footing, and the album\xe2\x80\x99s title track is a defanged version of the controlled chaos he once offered.' b'Yet, Kingdom recovers from these missteps. \xe2\x80\x9cEach & Every Day,\xe2\x80\x9d his collaboration with Vine star Najee Daniels, adds a shot of bubblegum into his otherwise ominous productions. It resembles what Charli XCX would sound like singing over a DJ Rashad beat. His second song with SZA, \xe2\x80\x9cDown 4 Whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d benefits from the more vigorous, energetic beat Rubin provides. A solo track called \xe2\x80\x9cInto the Fold,\xe2\x80\x9d offers a\xc2\xa0picture of what pop-ified post-club music could sound like\xe2\x80\x94bright whacks of drums and smokey looped vocals mingle well with more experimental elements like a dissonant hiss in the background. But his thesis statement for this album comes on a song with the Internet\xe2\x80\x99s Syd, who might be the perfect vocalist for Kingdom\xe2\x80\x99s attempt at a crossover style. Her slinky voice follows Kingdom\xe2\x80\x99s syncopations beat for beat, and the protean, mercurial change in pace befits Syd\xe2\x80\x99s ability to pitch shift on the fly. It\xe2\x80\x99s a promising peek into what Kingdom could do for a radio-ready artist.' b'On a recent release, Vertical XL EP, Rubin filled inhuman sounds with soul, and *Tears in the Club *attempts to take that idea to a mass audience. One wonders if he is unintentionally softening his music for the sake of a breezier product. It\xe2\x80\x99s less a statement of purpose and more of an experiment with an inconclusive hypothesis. Instead of heightening, or focusing the pandemonium he could unleash on the dancefloor, his work is denatured by a fairweather disposition. Even if he never means to, *Tears in the Club *is a disappointingly genteel work, from an artist known for anything but.'

column7: b'On this sprawling new album, the Australian psych-rock band hoists its freak flag a few inches higher up the pole. It flutters in a more gentle breeze.'
column8: b'King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard are a testament to the liberating power of giving yourself restrictions. Whether making every song on a record the exact same length (2015\xe2\x80\x99s Quarters!), or constructing an entire album to connect into an infinite loop (last year\xe2\x80\x99s Nonagon Infinity), the Aussie armada thrive on the symbiotic relationship between governing principles and disorder. The result is psychedelic rock that\xc2\xa0plays like a pinball game\xe2\x80\x94the action may be confined to an enclosed playing field, but it\xe2\x80\x99s always moving, ping-ponging in unexpected directions and encouraging synapse overload.' b'The band\xe2\x80\x99s latest\xe2\x80\x94reportedly, the first of five albums they\xe2\x80\x99re planning to pump out this year\xe2\x80\x94is likewise bound to a motif, though this one is as much sonic as structural. Flying Microtonal Banana was the product of Gizzard king Stu Mackenzie acquiring a custom-made guitar modified for microtonal tuning, which allows for intervals smaller than the semitones that govern Western music. And since the new guitar could only be played with similarly tuned instruments, he reportedly paid his bandmates $200 each to also get their gear tricked out with microtonal capabilities. Translation for those who don\xe2\x80\x99t hold a degree in music theory: Australia\xe2\x80\x99s wiggiest band has found a way to hoist its freak flag a few inches higher up the pole. But this time, it flutters in a more gentle breeze.' b'If the unrelenting Nonagon Infinity turned rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll into an Iron Man competition, Flying Microtonal Banana is that cool-down grace period your elliptical machine gives you after an hour\xe2\x80\x99s workout. While opener \xe2\x80\x9cRattlesnake\xe2\x80\x9d immediately reestablishes the preceding album\xe2\x80\x99s motorik momentum, the pace is tempered\xe2\x80\x94more late-night cruise than rocket to the moon. But even as it maintains a steadier course, the changes in scenery are more dramatic\xe2\x80\x94in between Mackenzie\xe2\x80\x99s chirpy verses about reptilian attacks, the song powers through a fog of stormy synths, staccato guitar pricks, and the brain-scrambling squawks of a Turkish horn-type instrument known as a zurna.' b'On Nonagon Infinity, the action moved so fast that Mackenzie\xe2\x80\x99s words whizzed by like an out-of-control news ticker spitting out the haziest cosmic jive. He still drops randomly recurring melodies like a pull-string doll with a limited repertoire of phrasing, but Flying Microtonal Banana\xe2\x80\x99s more relaxed vibe and greater sense of space bring his words into sharper focus. As per psych-rock tradition, Mackenzie deals in surrealist imagery, though in this case, those images aren\xe2\x80\x99t the mere product of a chemically clouded mind. \xe2\x80\x9cMelting\xe2\x80\x9d combines rhythms from \xe2\x80\x9970s Nigeria with observations on the present-day Arctic (\xe2\x80\x9cToxic air is/Here to scare us/Fatal fumes from/Melting ferrous\xe2\x80\x9d). \xe2\x80\x9cOpen Water\xe2\x80\x9d channels anxieties over disappearing coastlines into a marauding, seafaring-fantasy epic, like an updated \xe2\x80\x9cImmigrant Song\xe2\x80\x9d for Vikings who drive their ships to new lands only discover they\xe2\x80\x99ve been swallowed by rising ocean levels.' b'Flying Microtonal Banana peaks early with these extended odysseys, before giving way to more conventionally scaled rockers like \xe2\x80\x9cSleep Drifter,\xe2\x80\x9d the rare Gizzard track that uses its melody as the foundation for a krautrockin\xe2\x80\x99 jam, rather than the other way around. But as the record rolls on, it starts to resemble an FM dial spun awry. Flying Microtonal Banana\xc2\xa0serves\xc2\xa0up brief blasts of spaghetti-western balladry (\xe2\x80\x9cBillabong Valley\xe2\x80\x9d), acidic Southern blooze (\xe2\x80\x9cAnoxia\xe2\x80\x9d), and gritty Afro-funk (\xe2\x80\x9cNuclear Fusion\xe2\x80\x9d) that are connected only by the chaotic harmonica and zurna bursts that punctuate Mackenzie\xe2\x80\x99s musings. And it becomes increasingly clear that the only difference between a three-minute King Gizzard track and a seven-minute one is where they arbitrarily decide to fade out (sometimes mid-chorus). But if Flying Microtonal Banana\xe2\x80\x99s randomized approach is ultimately less transfixing than Nonagon Infinity\xe2\x80\x99s maniacal focus, it nonetheless shows that, after eight previous\xc2\xa0albums, this band\xe2\x80\x99s creativity and curiosity knows no bounds, and their singular balance of anarchy and accessibility is still in check. So even if you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand the first thing about microtonality, there\xe2\x80\x99s still plenty of flying banana here to keep you amused.'

column7: b'On the follow-up to 2011\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Deep Politics, the Portland post-rock trio have subtly expanded\xc2\xa0their approach, building moods of\xc2\xa0somber reflection, energized optimism, and cathartic release.'
column8: b'If \xe2\x80\x9crock\xe2\x80\x9d can be a verb, then so can \xe2\x80\x9cpost-rock,\xe2\x80\x9d and Grails know how to post-rock. The Portland group began after the genre\xe2\x80\x99s first wave, but they\xe2\x80\x99re so well-versed in dramatic, soundtrack-ready instrumentalism that they could pass for originators in a blindfold test. Through seven\xc2\xa0albums over 15 years, they\xe2\x80\x99ve made a convincing case for the potential and durability of post-rock, covering diverse terrain\xe2\x80\x94metal, psych, krautrock, ambience, soft rock\xe2\x80\x94while maintaining a consistent musical language.' b'In fact, Grails\xe2\x80\x99 language is so strong that the six year gap between their last album, 2011\xe2\x80\x99s Deep Politics, and their new effort Chalice Hymnal feels like a mere blip. The group\xe2\x80\x94sometimes a sextet, for now a trio\xe2\x80\x94continues their wordless conversation so smoothly that one song, \xe2\x80\x9cDeep Snow II,\xe2\x80\x9d actually picks up almost exactly where Deep Politics\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cDeep Snow\xe2\x80\x9d left off. In line with their career trajectory, this album differs from its predecessor only because Grails have subtly deepened\xc2\xa0their sonic scope, committing even more\xc2\xa0to each of the many styles they\xe2\x80\x99ve explored in the past.' b'Yet there\xe2\x80\x99s no gratuitous novelty in Chalice Hymnal\xe2\x80\x99s 11 tracks. Expansion is a goal, but it\xe2\x80\x99s never the main point. As compositionally complex and technically adept as their songs are, Grails are always most interested in building moods and evoking emotions: somber reflection, energized optimism, wistful nostalgia, and most often, cathartic release. At times they prioritize mood-building\xc2\xa0to a fault, like when the misty \xe2\x80\x9cRebecca\xe2\x80\x9d veers toward easy listening. But if they\xe2\x80\x99re going to err, better that they lean toward the overly sentimental than the wankily proficient.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s not many errors on *Chalice Hymnal, *though, since Grails are too experienced and familiar with their own strengths to let anything egregious slip past. Each track establishes a tone firmly and executes it confidently. Hence the chugging groove of \xe2\x80\x9cPelham,\xe2\x80\x9d the sludgy riffery of \xe2\x80\x9cNew Prague,\xe2\x80\x9d and the theatrical swells of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Moth & the Flame\xe2\x80\x9d feel like tonal siblings even though they\xe2\x80\x99re stylistically disparate. Some tracks even contrast themselves: \xe2\x80\x9cTough Guy\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s majestic march gives way to clouds of ambience before returning to forward motion.' b'None of that variety would matter if Chalice Hymnal wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so emotionally resonant. Grails understand that post-rock is largely about structure\xe2\x80\x94the way sounds gather and escalate, the way each part reflects what came before and points toward what\xe2\x80\x99s next\xe2\x80\x94and their mastery comes from treating music as sonic architecture. On Chalice Hymnal, they\xe2\x80\x99ve added another solid story to their growing skyscraper.'

column7: b"Her first solo record since 1999 is mildly ambitious and sounds spectacular, but\xc2\xa0Windy City is not a great showcase of Allison Krauss' crossover sound."
column8: b'The easy listening criticism has dogged Alison Krauss for more than twenty years, and she does nothing to dispel it on Windy City, her first solo record since 1999. Her music is thoughtfully poised between the bluegrass she grew up playing as a fiddle prodigy and the jazzy mainstream adult pop popularized by Norah Jones. At least since the O Brother Where Art Thou? soundtrack made her voice so famous, she has focused more on singing than playing the fiddle. That\xe2\x80\x99s not necessarily a bad thing, as Krauss has a bright, soft soprano that at its best blends Dolly Parton\xe2\x80\x99s cheery expressiveness with Willie Nelson\xe2\x80\x99s dexterous phrasing. The downside, however, is that her music, while expertly performed and recorded, is often blanched of any distinguishing twang or genre character. The listening becomes too easy.' b'As though addressing that criticism directly, Windy City includes a cover of the 1967 crossover hit \xe2\x80\x9cGentle on My Mind,\xe2\x80\x9d written by John Hartford but made famous by Glen Campbell. The song lives right at the intersection of pop and country, its lyrics even describing how the music should operate: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re movin\xe2\x80\x99 on the back roads by the rivers of my memory/And for hours you\xe2\x80\x99re just gentle on my mind.\xe2\x80\x9d Krauss isn\xe2\x80\x99t the first female singer to take a shot at the song\xe2\x80\x94Aretha, Patti Page, and the Band Perry have all recorded versions\xe2\x80\x94but she does unintentionally show just how tricky the song can be. While her voice is perfectly suited to the song\xe2\x80\x99s rosy nostalgia, she can\xe2\x80\x99t quite navigate the narrative twist in the last verse, when the narrator is revealed to be not just a wanderer but literally homeless, haunting trainyards and barrel fires with a coal-dark beard and a dirty hat.' b"Krauss doesn't conjure that kind of character of setting, but then again, Campbell himself barely could. Still, he knew enough to play up the contrast between the grittiness of the circumstances and the gentleness of the memory. This version is all gentle: technically sharp but emotionally blunted. That\xe2\x80\x99s a problem throughout Windy City, as her pursuit of a viable crossover sound opens up new musical possibilities even as it burnishes away the genre edges of these songs. Working with Nashville producer Buddy Cannon, Krauss displays a broad palette, covering left-of-center choices from the Osborne Brothers and Roger Miller, Brenda Lee and country songwriting legend Cindy Walker. But the arrangements on opener \xe2\x80\x9cLosing You\xe2\x80\x9d and the title track don\xe2\x80\x99t even bother to evoke the messiness of actual loss. They\xe2\x80\x99re stately and elegant, but also cold and detached." b'Windy City sounds liveliest whenever Krauss gets away from crossover pop. She navigates the twisting rhythms of the honky-tonk hit \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Good-Bye and So Long To You\xe2\x80\x9d with a jazzy agility and actually sounds like she\xe2\x80\x99s having fun with it. Likewise, her version of the bluegrass chestnut \xe2\x80\x9cPoison Love\xe2\x80\x9d has a calypso pulse that seems to defy gravity. Even \xe2\x80\x9cRiver in the Rain\xe2\x80\x9d retains its showtune determinism: If this Roger Miller obscurity, penned for a Huck Finn musical, is the album\xe2\x80\x99s centerpiece, it\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0because Krauss keeps it anchored to the stage. She sounds more at home with that kind of theatrical drama than she does with a story-song like the title\xc2\xa0track or \xe2\x80\x9cGentle on My Mind.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Windy City is not the best place for newcomers to start with Krauss. The curious should search out the 1995 retrospective Now That I\xe2\x80\x99ve Found You, which features a savvier, more imaginative crossover sound. Windy City never quite reconciles her genre history with her populist ambitions, creating an album that toggles back and forth between the two poles and then ends abruptly. Krauss conveys a stately heartbreak in her closing cover of the Cindy Walker/Eddy Arnold classic \xe2\x80\x9cYou Don\xe2\x80\x99t Know Me,\xe2\x80\x9d striking the ideal balance between elegant countrypolitan backing, eccentric piano and pedal steel flourishes, and vocals that convey both power and personality. It\xe2\x80\x99d be a fine starting point for a follow-up.'

column7: b'In what is ostensibly a solo record with a few high-profile collaborations, Dave Longstreth masterfully peels away layer after layer of heartbreak across a strange, dizzying pop album.'
column8: b'Like most people going through breakups, Dave\xc2\xa0Longstreth wants you to believe he\xe2\x80\x99s doing just fine. The nine songs on *Dirty Projectors *delve into\xc2\xa0his separation from former bandmate and girlfriend Amber Coffman, whose arresting voice over the past decade was as vital to\xc2\xa0Dirty Projectors\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0sound as Longstreth\xe2\x80\x99s own yelps and howls. It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to ignore the context of the record, largely because Longstreth makes it impossible to forget. He\xe2\x80\x99s quick to admit that \xe2\x80\x9ca song isn\xe2\x80\x99t a newspaper\xe2\x80\x9d and that Dirty Projectors isn\xe2\x80\x99t entirely autobiographical, even if the album\xe2\x80\x99s narrator sings about writing a tune called \xe2\x80\x9cStillness Is the Move.\xe2\x80\x9d Memoiristic or not, he\xe2\x80\x99s found a way to express the lonely anthologizing of events that matter only to you and one other person, couched within a strange, dizzying pop record.' b'For a band who once felt like an army of mannered Brooklynites and is now ostensibly the solo project of one bearded Longstreth, Dirty Projectors have always brought pop music to their homemade sound. Since his last album, 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Swing Lo Magellan, Longstreth has worked alongside Rihanna, Kanye West, and Solange (who co-wrote this album\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCool Your Heart\xe2\x80\x9d). But much of Dirty Projectors takes its inspiration from further back, comfort food for someone who may very well be nostalgic for the halcyon days of 2009. The stop-and-start buzz of \xe2\x80\x9cDeath Spiral\xe2\x80\x9d is as delirious and slick as a Futuresex/Lovesounds interlude. \xe2\x80\x9cCool Your Heart,\xe2\x80\x9d with its fancy-car music video and massive chorus, is a feel-good R&B trade-off with D\xe2\x88\x86WN that calls back to the same era of weirdo pop duets as Moby and Gwen Stefani\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSouth Side.\xe2\x80\x9d The music on Dirty Projectors sounds like the propulsive, hyper-curated nostalgia you put on to forget your heartbreak.' b'Instead, Longstreth uses it to help reveal what hurts. In the stunning \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Bubble,\xe2\x80\x9d he lies around the house, cursing his \xe2\x80\x9cdumb and meaningless\xe2\x80\x9d dreams and longing for death. In \xe2\x80\x9cWinner Take Nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d he reflects on a broken relationship, unable to find anything positive to say in its wake. \xe2\x80\x9cThis has turned me against myself,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, \xe2\x80\x9cIn losing you, I lost myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0For anyone wondering what Kanye song he was listening to on the Taconic Parkway in \xe2\x80\x9cUp in Hudson,\xe2\x80\x9d my money\xe2\x80\x99s on \xe2\x80\x9cBlame Game,\xe2\x80\x9d when Kanye fragments his vocals to represent the myriad demons haunting him at once. Longstreth incorporates a similar tactic throughout the album, pitch-shifting his voice, distorting and layering it to mimic the hocketing sound that\xe2\x80\x99s long defined his songwriting. But what once felt whimsical and communal now sounds suffocating and paranoid. Longstreth is trying to escape himself.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe love is a competition that makes us raise the bar/We better ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on \xe2\x80\x9cWork Together,\xe2\x80\x9d a selfish way to define a relationship but a\xc2\xa0viewpoint\xc2\xa0that seems to have inspired a sense of confidence. Using this freedom to find new collaborators like Solange and Tyondai Braxton, Longstreth has refined and upgraded himself, becoming bolder\xc2\xa0in the process. In fact, Dirty Projectors, in its own warped way, might be the sharpest, tightest record he\xe2\x80\x99s made yet. Like Joni Mitchell\xe2\x80\x99s epic \xe2\x80\x9cPaprika Plains,\xe2\x80\x9d which layered a sweeping string arrangement over an autobiographical improv piano piece, *Dirty Projectors\xe2\x80\x99 *ornate arrangements can\xe2\x80\x99t hide the fact that these songs are as direct and unguarded as Longstreth allows himself to get.' b"The fatal flaw in this work, the same one that\xe2\x80\x99s haunted every Dirty Projectors album from the elaborate Black Flag rewrites of Rise Above to the faux-folksy love songs of Swing Lo Magellan, is the feeling of conceptual overload. But overthinking is a core part of Longstreth\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic and here it balances the drag of a post-breakup bloodletting, when even the album's title feels, to say the least, confrontational. You can hear Longstreth analyzing his thoughts in real time throughout these songs, sometimes finding a sense of resolution in the process. On the closing track, \xe2\x80\x9cI See You,\xe2\x80\x9d he reaches for a happy ending in the most characteristic song on the whole album\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing here that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t sound out of place on Bitte Orca. But the lyrics hint at a transformation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe projection has faded away,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings right after\xc2\xa0landing on a line that\xe2\x80\x99s extremely corny, slightly condescending, and maybe even romantic: \xe2\x80\x9cI believe that the love we made is the art,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings sternly. He knows it\xe2\x80\x99s not perfect, but for now, it\xe2\x80\x99s the best he\xe2\x80\x99s got."

column7: b'Crystal Fairy pits\xc2\xa0together At the Drive In\xe2\x80\x99s Omar Rodr\xc3\xadguez-L\xc3\xb3pez, Le Butcherettes\xe2\x80\x99 Teri Gender Bender, and Melvins members Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover. Their sounds prove\xc2\xa0strikingly\xc2\xa0complementary.'
column8: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s always a good idea to approach supergroup-type projects\xc2\xa0with caution, no matter how enticing they might look on paper. After all, when artists from well-known bands come together, they face the near-impossible challenge of sounding\xc2\xa0enough like their main acts while also breaking new ground\xe2\x80\x94and usually without much\xc2\xa0time to gel.\xc2\xa0The new group Crystal Fairy pits Melvins core members Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover alongside Le Butcherettes frontwoman Teri Gender Bender and Butcherettes collaborator/producer Omar Rodr\xc3\xadguez-L\xc3\xb3pez, most famous as the driving force behind the Mars Volta and At the Drive In.' b'Crystal Fairy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t put\xc2\xa0any new twists on the established sounds of Le Butcherettes or the Melvins, but it does prove the groups to be remarkably complementary. The\xc2\xa0quartet\xe2\x80\x99s self-titled debut grafts Gender Bender\xe2\x80\x99s dynamic vocal style onto the Melvin\xe2\x80\x99s rhythmic trudge\xe2\x80\x94apparent immediately on opener \xe2\x80\x9cChiseler,\xe2\x80\x9d a quick-and-dirty uptempo riff rocker. Coming from such a creative bunch, the straightforward character of Crystal Fairy\xc2\xa0is surprising, but the strong, pre-existing rapport between its two pairs of players helps.\xc2\xa0After 30-plus years together, Osborne\xe2\x80\x99s guitar riffs and Crover\xe2\x80\x99s drumming are pretty much conjoined, while\xc2\xa0Rodr\xc3\xadguez-L\xc3\xb3pez has helped upgrade\xc2\xa0Le Butcherettes\xe2\x80\x99 scrappy neo-psychedelia into a vivid backdrop for Gender Bender\xe2\x80\x99s outsized presence to roam free.' b'Crover and Osborne have worked with strong musical personalities before, including Jello Biafra, Mike Patton, and Lustmord. This time, though, Osborne\xc2\xa0may have found a\xc2\xa0long lost twin in Gender Bender. She comes across as more vulnerable and agitated, but Gender Bender also shares Osborne\xe2\x80\x99s penchant for stagy, absurdist delivery. Here, she practically plays the role of Osborne\xe2\x80\x99s alter-ego, only with a relish that charges the Melvins\xe2\x80\x99 sound with an urgency it typically lacks.\xc2\xa0And by introducing a harmonic breadth the Melvins have never captured before, she brings new contours to their ongoing fascination with re-appropriating Sabbath, Kiss, and other classic rock tropes.' b'Gender Bender has a flash of mad inspiration on \xe2\x80\x9cDrugs on the Bus.\xe2\x80\x9d Her Farfisa part meanders spiderlike across the sludgy main riff, and when she wails about a woman who cuts her own eyes out in the climax, the mood intensifies starkly. She\xc2\xa0gets to channel her inner Jello Biafra on a cover of \xe2\x80\x9980s hardcore outfit Tales of Terror\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPossession,\xe2\x80\x9d which recalls the springy cadence of the Dead Kennedys classic \xe2\x80\x9cCalifornia \xc3\x9cber Alles.\xe2\x80\x9d And while\xc2\xa0the funereal riff that anchors \xe2\x80\x9cMoth Tongue\xe2\x80\x9d is indistinguishable from countless other Melvins tunes,\xc2\xa0Gender Bender scrapes the back of her throat on her high notes, allowing a glimpse of what the Melvins might\xc2\xa0sound like if fronted by the banshee wail of Rush\xe2\x80\x99s Geddy Lee.' b'Crystal Fairy concludes on an anticlimactic note, as the final stop-start stutter of the short-fast \xe2\x80\x9cVampire X-Mas\xe2\x80\x9d simply fails to resume when the band has set you up to expect that it will. It\xc2\xa0sounds\xc2\xa0intentional, but the track also\xc2\xa0leaves a lingering feeling that the album ends\xc2\xa0unresolved. That\xe2\x80\x99s a minor\xc2\xa0quibble, though, after 40-minutes of hearing people play together with far greater affinity than anyone could have expected.'

column3: b'Oz Waves: Compiled by Steele Bonus'
column7: b'A new comp of charming, peculiar, and strangely timeless Australian DIY music released mostly on cassette-zines in the \xe2\x80\x9880s amid the macho pub rock sound of the decade.'
column8: b'During the \xe2\x80\x9980s, the Australian pop culture exports seemed to be comprised of Mad Max, Paul \xe2\x80\x9cCrocodile Dundee\xe2\x80\x9d Hogan, INXS, Midnight Oil\xe2\x80\x99s Peter Garrett, Yahoo Serious and of course, Jacko. It\xe2\x80\x99s a motley group that speaks to the spiky strangeness inherent in the continent\xe2\x80\x99s figures. But leave it to Michael Kucyk (host of Noise in My Head on NTS Radio) to unearth the sounds being made in Australia far off the radar. His Efficient Space label has already pulled out some blissful Australian house, weirdo new wave and last year\xe2\x80\x99s stark but haunting\xc2\xa0Sky Girl\xc2\xa0compilation.' b'The ten tracks on\xc2\xa0Oz Waves might be their most peculiar set yet. Culled by a DJ who goes by the handle of Steele Bonus (he also has a series of thrilling Soundcloud mixes), he\xe2\x80\x99s unearthed rare examples of Australian DIY rendered in the \xe2\x80\x9980s amid the macho pub rock sound of the decade. With most Aussie major labels wholly uninterested in such strange drum machine-laced sounds (though INXS did have a penchant for dub weirdness), most artists and short-lived bands opted instead to make artful cassette-zines instead. As the Oz Waves notes attest, many were dubbed in editions ranging from 5 to 100 copies.' b"Not that any of the acts had dreams of pop stardom when they plugged in their guitars, Groovebox drum machines, and primitive synths to make their lo-fi din. Bands bearing names like Ironing Music, He Dark Age and the Horse He's Sick don\xe2\x80\x99t really have Top of the Pops in mind. These bands revel in freedom, knowing that with no major labels, no crowds to perform in front of and, for the most part, no drummer, they were free to document the strangest noises that sprung from their heads. It\xe2\x80\x99s ostensibly punk rock, but 30 years on, time has a way of changing such meanings. The primitive beats and befuddling noises that bounce off the walls of each song make it come across as endearingly insular dance music." b'Much like New Yorkers in the early \xe2\x80\x9980s who identified more as art collectives than bands, the acts here also dabbled in video art, painting, and visual design.\xc2\xa0Irena Xero was on the Brisbane punk scene in the late \xe2\x80\x9970s but also into cross-discipline arts. She sounds like a one-woman automaton on \xe2\x80\x9cLady on the Train,\xe2\x80\x9d programming chilly handclaps and delivering lines with even less affect than Nico. Andy Rantzen\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWill I Dream?\xe2\x80\x9d went unreleased in 1989, but it makes sense considering he soon moved from doing industrial-styled noise to making rave tracks. Deeming it the most dancefloor-friendly track in the set seems like a misnomer, as it\xe2\x80\x99s a strange puddle of funky bass and peppy snare, flickering sinewaves, submarine alarms and mewling voices.' b"While Prod\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cKnife on Top\xe2\x80\x9d features a limber Can-like groove to it and Zerox Dreamflesh do woozy Augustus Pablo-esque dub on \xe2\x80\x9cSquids Can Fly,\xe2\x80\x9d most bands here prefer sputtering drum machines, which make for the set\xe2\x80\x99s most charming moments.
