They provide the stitching underneath the flanged accordion and Urszula Dawkins\xe2\x80\x99 plainspoken delivery on Software Seduction\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNew Collision\xe2\x80\x9d and the lo-fi sampledelica of \xe2\x80\x9cJesus Krist Klap Rap (Orthodox Mix).\xe2\x80\x9d The Groovebox that Ironing Music utilized makes them sound like the Down Under version of Young Marble Giants on the sparkling bedroom murmur that is \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Wish It Away.\xe2\x80\x9d A heavier beat gets sampled by the Horse He\xe2\x80\x99s Sick, but rather than try to move a dance audience, it instead gets strung out to a crawl. It's these micro-moments, operating in the shadow of their more popular contemporaries of the era, that allow\xc2\xa0Oz Waves\xe2\x80\x99 dusty charms to shine through four decades later."

column7: b'Mixing mid-fi \xe2\x80\x9990s influences with elements of slowcore, the Brooklyn trio Wild Pink evoke early Death Cab as they calmly process the chaos of the city around them.'
column8: b'The members of\xc2\xa0Wild Pink\xc2\xa0live in Brooklyn but really reside in their own minds. Whether it\xe2\x80\x99s mundane NYC landmarks (the Taconic Parkway, a\xc2\xa0giant clock over the John Smolenski Funeral Home) or hallowed\xc2\xa0monuments, Wild Pink seek the familiar in their dynamic surroundings.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cRiding out some psychotropics/In the shadow of the World Trade/Trying hard to understand the culture in my face,\xe2\x80\x9d John Ross sings in \xe2\x80\x9cGreat Apes.\xe2\x80\x9d Wild Pink\xc2\xa0lives in this wearied New York state of mind: standing on the subway, walking through crowds lost in thought, letting the mental chatter drown out every voice around\xc2\xa0you.' b'After two EPs that found the Brooklyn trio exploring an array of mid-fi \xe2\x80\x9990s influences, they\xe2\x80\x99ve honed a sound that suits Ross\xe2\x80\x99 perspective\xe2\x80\x94maybe not so much comfortably numb as \xe2\x80\x9cmanageably anxious,\xe2\x80\x9d reminiscent of early Death Cab for Cutie or American Analog Set, bands who took on characteristics of slowcore without being stylistically bound to it. Parallel to his band\xe2\x80\x99s evolution, Ross has ditched his\xc2\xa0searching yelp and distilled his entire emotional range into a single, unshakeable tone. It\xe2\x80\x99s not monotonous, per se; what Ross does is a variation on \xe2\x80\x9cshower voice,\xe2\x80\x9d a sort of a tuneful mutter. The\xc2\xa0ways his\xc2\xa0timbre peaks through sundazed ambience (\xe2\x80\x9cBroke On\xe2\x80\x9d), glistening jangle-pop (\xe2\x80\x9cGreat Apes\xe2\x80\x9d) or piercing fuzz\xc2\xa0(\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to Show\xe2\x80\x9d) can be\xc2\xa0remarkable or infuriating\xe2\x80\x94like hearing chatter in the library where you can *just *make out enough of the conversation that\xc2\xa0it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t become white noise.' b'At times, Ross can unnerve the listener enough to lean in closer for\xc2\xa0his lyrics, which are like quotables from non-contextual conversations: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a dad\xe2\x80\x99s breath/From cheap beer and cigarettes,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cYou are the beauty queen/You left piss on the seat,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0or most memorably, \xe2\x80\x9cThen I said something dumb/Like \xe2\x80\x98the Redskins hate the Cowboys because Kennedy died in Dallas.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Ross says the latter to defuse the tension of visiting a roadside vigil on the opening \xe2\x80\x9cHow Do You Know if God Takes You Back?,\xe2\x80\x9d and throughout *Wild Pink, *the jokes serve as his emotional armor. His\xc2\xa0picture of an isolated, yet contented youth is drawn with John Darnielle-esque detail (\xe2\x80\x9cMy whole world was in my room/Playing both sides of a Magic game/Black vs. Green/And a bootleg Maxell tape of Queen\xe2\x80\x9d) and on the devastating closer, he recalls to a friend, \xe2\x80\x9cOn 9/11 your mom took you to see Legally Blonde.\xe2\x80\x9d The names of these songs are, respectively, \xe2\x80\x9cWanting Things Makes You Shittier\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThey Hate Our Freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'For the most part, though,\xc2\xa0*Wild Pink *deals in the usual language of the overeducated and underemployed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re cultured and cursed/With dated ideas\xc2\xa0about what it means to have American Dreams,\xe2\x80\x9d Ross sings on \xe2\x80\x9cI Used to Be Small.\xe2\x80\x9d And other times, he just takes\xc2\xa0issue with cell phones. \xe2\x80\x9cPut your phone down/Put your phone down,\xe2\x80\x9d Ross sings, but\xc2\xa0none of his words feel judgmental\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re just a polite, noticeably exhausted request.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll hear about the war and know it\xe2\x80\x99s not yours,\xe2\x80\x9d Ross warns during a visit to a nursing home on \xe2\x80\x9cBroke On.\xe2\x80\x9d Throughout, there\xe2\x80\x99s a discernible yearning for something worth fighting for, something character-building, as the older generation might have put it: \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no war left to win\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9call my life I wish I had died bravely.\xe2\x80\x9d These lines\xc2\xa0carry a heavier, more political resonance now than they probably did when\xc2\xa0Wild Pink\xc2\xa0was recorded. Had it been released last year, it might have just been a solid indie rock record about everyday New York living. But Ross sounds like so many people whose nebulous concerns about the future have been sharpened.\xc2\xa0Wild Pink may not be a generation\xe2\x80\x99s bonfire, but it now sounds like the slow burn leading up to it.'

column7: b'The first of two albums released within seven days of each other,\xc2\xa0FUTURE is an ambitious Future exhibition, but replicating his brightest moments is often a hit or miss proposition.'
column8: b'Future is certainly a prolific artist, though\xc2\xa0it is getting a bit excessive. Since 2011, he has released at least two projects every year, often three or more. His work ethic, long a point of personal pride, paid big dividends across an excellent mixtape trilogy (Monster, Beast Mode, and 56 Nights) in the run up to his commercial peak with Dirty Sprite 2\xc2\xa0and his cash-in collaboration with Drake, What a Time to Be Alive. Since then, his music is either chasing those highs or stuck in cruise control. His Purple Reign\xc2\xa0tape introduced some moving new deep cuts to his catalog\xc2\xa0but was modest by his standards and he rushed out EVOL\xc2\xa0a month later for an Apple exclusive. His new self-titled album is the first in a pair of projects released in a seven-day span. Perhaps for Future, prolificity is about excess, not just because it\xe2\x80\x99s a flex, but because it always requires giving more of oneself\xe2\x80\x94almost too much. Both nonstop motion and overindulgence are in his DNA. FUTURE, in many ways, unmasks Future: he\xe2\x80\x99s a creature of habit.' b"The Atlanta rapper has funneled most of his music through three personas: Super Future, Fire Marshal Future, and Future Hendrix (he explained them as the hitmaker, the party packer, and the rockstar, respectively). The alter egos have characterized much of his output, giving names to his various aesthetics. FUTURE is meant as a Future exhibition, a portrayal of his many sides\xe2\x80\x94superstar, romantic, heartbreaker, hedonist\xe2\x80\x94which have previously only been showcased in flashes. But it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do anything past Future projects haven\xe2\x80\x99t done already, and ironically it doesn't tell us anything new about Future." b'Even under these circumstances, FUTURE is true to form for Future in both content (the first lines rapped are \xe2\x80\x9cGot the money coming in, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t no issues/I just a fucked a rapper bitch, I should diss you\xe2\x80\x9d), and the sounds he chooses to channel. A song like \xe2\x80\x9cPoppin Tags\xe2\x80\x9d is \xe2\x80\x9cCommas\xe2\x80\x9d-esque and \xe2\x80\x9cSuper Trapper\xe2\x80\x9d is forged in the image of 56 Nights\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cTrap Niggas\xe2\x80\x9d; both are indicative of Super Future, lining pounding 808 bass with clustered raps. \xe2\x80\x9cFlip\xe2\x80\x9d is reminiscent of 2013 one-offs like \xe2\x80\x9cFinessin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d with warping synths and cracked vocals. The ballad \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I Was Broke\xe2\x80\x9d harkens back to the romanticism of Honest or \xe2\x80\x9cTurn On the Lights.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'There are bits and pieces of nearly every part of his past here, but replicating his brightest moments is a hit or miss proposition. In bringing all these previous personas together, he creates an album that\xe2\x80\x99s mostly retreads. And there are a few moments that completely lack Future\xe2\x80\x99s patented dynamism and evocation, particularly \xe2\x80\x9cGood Dope\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cScrape.\xe2\x80\x9d But even on autopilot, Future can churn out some truly high octane flows (\xe2\x80\x9cPOA\xe2\x80\x9d), sweetly-sung gun ballads (\xe2\x80\x9cDraco\xe2\x80\x9d), and some pleasant surprises (like the hum-heavy throbber \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m So Groovy\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'The highlights come when Future journeys into uncharted waters or deep into his own memory bank. \xe2\x80\x9cI lost so many niggas to the streets this year,\xe2\x80\x9d he opens on the affecting cut \xe2\x80\x9cFeds Did a Sweep.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI ain\xe2\x80\x99t even talkin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98bout,\xe2\x80\x9d he pauses to clarify. \xe2\x80\x9cThey ain\xe2\x80\x99t even dead.\xe2\x80\x9d The song recounts days trafficking drugs to survive, police raids orchestrated to suppress said trafficking, and state-sanctioned oppression against black ghettos, all while using intensely lucid writing (\xe2\x80\x9cStarted cooking work and skipping Chemistry\xe2\x80\x9d). Like \xe2\x80\x9cFeds,\xe2\x80\x9d the ominous \xe2\x80\x9cMask Off\xe2\x80\x9d tells a similar tale of crime as a means to survive poverty, but it relinquishes the former\xe2\x80\x99s mournful tone, opting instead to be brazen\xe2\x80\x94doing a robbery without a mask is reckless and implies either carelessness or apathy. He takes drastic measures: \xe2\x80\x9cMy guillotine, drank promethazine/Tec and beams, go to those extremes.\xe2\x80\x9d The two songs have some symmetry\xe2\x80\x94in one, Future is the raider; in the other, the raided. These encounters provide a counterbalance to all the braggadocio and a sharper, behind-the-scenes look at the world that shaped him.' b'Sonically, FUTURE plays with a pretty interesting array of textures, from the Arcade Fire-sampling minimalist piano chord on \xe2\x80\x9cMight As Well\xe2\x80\x9d to the whiny, xylophonic chimes on \xe2\x80\x9cZoom\xe2\x80\x9d to the wobbly frets screeching on \xe2\x80\x9cOutta Time.\xe2\x80\x9d Some songs mimic the unpredictable strobe of a laser light show; others induce oriental flute music. Some are fixed, oscillating to and from a single point (like \xe2\x80\x9cPOA\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFlip\xe2\x80\x9d). Others are slightly off-balance (\xe2\x80\x9cMassage in My Room\xe2\x80\x9d). But its drum kit patterns are beginning to sound old hat, perhaps a result of overtaxing the same core group of producers (Metro Boomin, Southside, Zaytoven, and Tarentino) the last few years. The songs almost all have the same exact pulse, but they usually manage to intrigue with subtle tonal shifts.' b"Seventeen tracks is clearly a profusion, but it's a fitting display given Future\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to mass production. The glut of songs create a sampler that allows listeners to pick and choose a handful of favorites, and the cult classics will likely be the ones that make it into his sets. Future has a formula now. That means that we can expect less spontaneity and more sustainability. FUTURE is a fine mix of the stylings of past Futures layered in a rich blend of sounds from a now refined sonic palette. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t communicate the same intense and complicated emotional concoction that fills his songs when he\xe2\x80\x99s at his most vulnerable and compelling. But it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have to. It is prototypical of Future, who continues to overshare, often for better but sometimes for worse. He will continue to do the things that allowed him to reach this point: amp up the output, stay active, and feed a ravenous, culture-obsessed public. That is, until he\xe2\x80\x99s ready to surprise us again."

column7: b'The\xc2\xa0latest Strand of Oaks album\xc2\xa0has a sunnier outlook and a hedonistic streak, evoking Creation Records bands like Primal Scream and Oasis.\xc2\xa0But it\xc2\xa0never really adds up to a bold statement.'
column8: b'On 2014\xe2\x80\x99s HEAL, his fifth album as Strand of Oaks, Timothy Showalter emerged as his own most compelling lead character. Showalter was a grown-up adolescent still mired in dark thoughts and intense desires: for the opposite sex, for self-eradication through drugs or worse, for his favorite song to come on the radio. Making or simply listening to music was a lifeline out of the confusion of youth and the disappointments of adulthood, which informed a song cycle simultaneously bleak and optimistic, as big as an arena yet as personal as an inner monologue. Showalter reminisced about \xe2\x80\x9csinging Pumpkins in the mirror,\xe2\x80\x9d and it\xe2\x80\x99s not hard to imagine his fans finding similar salvation in \xe2\x80\x9cJM\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cGoshen \xe2\x80\x9997.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'And yet: \xe2\x80\x9cHEAL was bullshit, man.\xe2\x80\x9d In an exhaustive, candid Stereogum article, Showalter distanced himself from his breakthrough album, which he seems to think is too dark, too self-absorbed. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sick of being the sad white guy with an acoustic guitar\xe2\x80\xa6 We\xe2\x80\x99re done with that shit,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. There\xe2\x80\x99s not much acoustic guitar on the album, but that\xe2\x80\x99s besides the point: Newly committed to his marriage and to a sunnier outlook on everything, Showalter no longer wants to rip his soul out and play harrowing songs night after night. That\xe2\x80\x99s understandable: Who could fault the guy for wanting to be happy?' b'Consequently, Hard Love is more than a follow-up\xe2\x80\x94it sounds like\xc2\xa0a direct response to HEAL. These new songs are never quite as dark or as deep, never quite as probing, which is not to say they\xe2\x80\x99re superficial. Showalter seems to have made an effort not to sound quite as troubled. If his relationship to music once seemed desperate, he now sounds like a guy thrilled to be evoking\xc2\xa0Creation Records, one of the major touchstones on Hard Love. Featuring wobbly guitars and big drumbeats, \xe2\x80\x9cEverything\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Hill\xe2\x80\x9d nod to bands like Primal Scream, the Jesus & Mary Chain, and even Oasis without making too obvious a reference.' b'Instead of sulking in his car blasting Songs: Ohia, as he did on \xe2\x80\x9cJM,\xe2\x80\x9d Hard Love shows Showalter out in the world, engaging with other people through music and, notably, through drugs. This is a peculiarly hedonistic album, one that will doubtless play well on the summer festival circuit. \xe2\x80\x9cI have the good drugs now,\xe2\x80\x9d he boasts in that Stereogum article, but they\xe2\x80\x99re not especially potent sources of inspiration. Influenced\xc2\xa0by a mind-expanding episode at Boogie Festival in Australia, \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Hill\xe2\x80\x9d bounds forward with a big, brash sound, but it never really goes anywhere. Instead, it just stays on that hill, blissed out and barely relatable if you weren\xe2\x80\x99t at Boogie and on those good drugs with him.' b'More rewarding are the smaller moments, the songs that show Strand of Oaks morphing into a formidable rock band. \xe2\x80\x9cQuit It\xe2\x80\x9d is gloriously raw blues, \xe2\x80\x9cRest of It\xe2\x80\x9d a trash-glam stomp. Both sound tossed off in the best way: less burdened with concepts and therefore freer, more fun. They represent a more relatable form of hedonism, with Showalter simply rocking the fuck out. That less-is-more quality extends to those moments when everything falls away except for one or two instruments: The title track builds to a climactic chorus, but instead of pushing everything into the red, Showalter removes everything but the drums. It redefines and redirects the anthem, turning it into an overture for the album that follows.' b'Perhaps the oddest aspect of Hard Love is how far it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t stray from HEAL. Everything sounds weirdly familiar, as though Showalter hasn\xe2\x80\x99t figured out how to move on from that breakthrough. He still makes the most of his murky production, despite bringing in French producer Nicolas Vernhes (Speedy Ortiz, Deerhunter) and multi-instrumentalist Jason Anderson. \xe2\x80\x9cRadio Kids\xe2\x80\x9d sounds a bit too similar to previous songs about adolescent alienation, and \xe2\x80\x9cSalt Brothers\xe2\x80\x9d leans too closely toward better cryptic anthems, most notably the apocalyptic \xe2\x80\x9cSterling,\xe2\x80\x9d off 2010\xe2\x80\x99s enduringly strange Pope Killdragon. Hard Love never really adds up to a particularly clear or bold statement; there are some strong songs and big moments, but very little that moves the story forward or develops that rich character. It\xe2\x80\x99s a perfectly fine album by a guy who wants to be much more than perfectly fine.'

column7: b'Rhiannon Giddens emerges as a peerless and powerful voice in roots music on her second solo album,\xc2\xa0a record that traces the power of African-American song from 200 years ago to today.'
column8: b'In the middle of a record populated with sexual violence, police shootings, and church bombings, Rhiannon Giddens sings, \xe2\x80\x9cMy heart it is a-shakin\xe2\x80\x99 with an old, old song.\xe2\x80\x9d This has been the simple, guiding principle of her decade-long career in roots music. Her powerful interpretation of American folk reclaims its old vernacular and redistributes it among its oft-untold complex history. After years of soaking up American musical traditions with her long-standing string band the Carolina Chocolate Drops, Giddens has emerged as a peerless voice of roots-minded music as a solo artist on her new album, comprised of original compositions alongside a few relevant covers, including the Staples Singers\xe2\x80\x99 1965 title track.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s beauty and gravitas come\xc2\xa0from how Giddens collapses the last two centuries of American history, \xc2\xa0juxtaposing songs about antebellum slave plantations with 1960\xe2\x80\x99s Civil Rights anthems and narratives of 21st-century state violence. The record opens with \xe2\x80\x9cAt the Purchaser\xe2\x80\x99s Option,\xe2\x80\x9d a title taken from a 1797 slave advertisement. The song\xe2\x80\x94a tale of a mother considering the doomed fate of their child born into bondage\xe2\x80\x94immediately establishes the primacy of family across the album. Despite its historical pretensions, Freedom Highway is fundamentally a story of black mothers and their children, a record that traces black women\xe2\x80\x99s eternal labor as they sacrifice for and grieve over the uncertain future of their kin.' b'Giddens has always been interested in upsetting the continuum of African-American song. She began experimenting with more recent, mid-late 20th-century styles on her solo debut, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Tomorrow is My Turn, and she arrives at Freedom Highway with her most expansive and adventurous musical palette yet. Featured prominently are the banjo/fiddle string-band and Piedmont blues stylings she explored so deftly in the Carolina Chocolate Drops, but *Freedom Highway *weaves hip-hop, gospel, Dixieland jazz, folk balladry, and guitar-driven rhythm and blues into a coherent whole.' b'It remains challenging to find the right environment that fully modernizes Rhiannon Giddens\xe2\x80\x99 perfectly ornate soprano. But roots expert Dirk Powell, who produced the album, relies on understated, predominantly acoustic arrangements that end up humanizing her vocal approach more fully than the museum-piece elegance of T-Bone Burnett\xe2\x80\x99s production on Tomorrow is My Turn.' b'Likewise, the emotional intimacy of Giddens\xe2\x80\x99 first collection of original material is better served by the close collaborators and assorted family members who appear on Freedom Highway than the array of well-chopped session pros who populated her debut. Giddens\xe2\x80\x99 sister Lalenja Harrington, who co-wrote and shares vocals on \xe2\x80\x9cBaby Boy,\xe2\x80\x9d and her nephew, Justin Harrington, who raps a verse on the police brutality polemic \xe2\x80\x9cBetter Get It Right the First Time,\xe2\x80\x9d provide moments of dramatic interplay that firmly contemporize Giddens\xe2\x80\x99 creative vision.' b'As a songwriter, Giddens achieves immediacy by imbuing her stories with striking interpersonal drama and emotional depth. On the banjo tune \xe2\x80\x9cJulie,\xe2\x80\x9d one of several songs that take place during the Civil War, a heart-wrenching exchange between slave and mistress ends with a devastating narrative reveal. On the stomping \xe2\x80\x9cThe Love We Almost Had,\xe2\x80\x9d an otherwise unremarkable tale of romance-that-never-was becomes a tragic statement on the far-reaching bonds of white supremacy.' b"But the record's most affecting moment comes during \xe2\x80\x9cWe Could Fly,\xe2\x80\x9d a modern spiritual that traces a family\xe2\x80\x99s multi-generational search for enlightened freedom. The song delivers a rare gift from a piece of music: the sense that it\xe2\x80\x99s always existed, that it\xe2\x80\x99s always been sung, that it must have been written in 1854, and in 1963, and in 2016. That shared sense of African-American tradition is the driving force behind Giddens' art as she lays bare the ugly symmetry of America\xe2\x80\x99s history. Here is timeless, striking proof that what was once worth protesting in song 200 years ago remains every bit as vital today."

column7: b'On this\xc2\xa0unsettled solo album, Ought frontman Tim Darcy slowly dismantles the confessional crooner archetype, transforming himself from singer-songwriter to sound sculptor.'
column8: b'Saturday night has long been pop music\xe2\x80\x99s favorite part of the week\xe2\x80\x94a time for fighting, fevers, and over-excited group spelling bees. But if the cover of his first solo album is any indication, Tim Darcy likes to spend it alone with his plants. His Saturday Night isn\xe2\x80\x99t about going out on the town, but retreating inside his mind, following his wandering thoughts wherever they lead, even if they take him to some dark places. As frontman for Montreal quartet Ought, Darcy has, over the course of two records, emerged as one of indie rock\xe2\x80\x99s most wily and witty wordsmiths, channeling the daily absurdities and anxieties of modern urban life into twitchy post-punk screeds. By contrast, Saturday Night\xc2\xa0is more intimate in every way: in scale, in production, and most importantly, in its emotional vocabulary.' b'On the one hand, Saturday Night does exactly what you expect a solo record from a member of a raucous rock band to do: It\xe2\x80\x99s more off the cuff and rougher around the edges, and showcases a more introspective side than the day job normally allows. On the other hand, it\xe2\x80\x99s an assault on that very idea. Over its 11 songs (including one hidden one), Darcy slowly dismantles the confessional crooner archetype until he\xe2\x80\x99s just messing around with the raw materials, transforming himself from singer-songwriter to sound sculptor. And it becomes increasingly clear that, for Darcy, Saturday Night isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a reservoir for songs that don\xe2\x80\x99t quite fit his main band\xe2\x80\x99s m.o., but a portal to a world beyond rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll entirely.' b'From the outset, Saturday Night both plays to expectations and subverts them. Opening rave-up \xe2\x80\x9cTall Glass of Water\xe2\x80\x9d begins on familiar fidgety footing\xe2\x80\x94though it\xe2\x80\x99s a little more rickety than the typical Ought jam, the frenetic energy coursing through it makes the source easy enough to identify. But one minute in, Darcy brings the song\xe2\x80\x99s smash \xe2\x80\x98n\xe2\x80\x99 grab momentum to a dead stop and reboots it as a cool mid-tempo strut\xe2\x80\x94as if he was playing Lou Reed\xe2\x80\x99s Transformer\xc2\xa0at 45 rpm and suddenly flipped it to 33. \xe2\x80\x9cWell the questions are being asked,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it fate or is it popsicle?\xe2\x80\x9d The meaning may not be clear, but the message is: we\xe2\x80\x99re on his melted clock now, and things are about to get surreal.' b'Saturday Night frontloads its most melodic moments, though even the sturdiest songs are outfitted with booby traps and escape hatches. \xe2\x80\x9cJoan Pt 1, 2\xe2\x80\x9d is a hit of woozy distorto-pop that free falls into an empty-cathedral chorale. \xe2\x80\x9cYou Felt Comfort\xe2\x80\x9d wraps warm \xe2\x80\x98n\xe2\x80\x99 fuzzy guitar strums around frank lyricism (\xe2\x80\x9cYou felt comfort and release/For a trauma that was making you weak\xe2\x80\x9d) in classic Neutral Milk Hotel fashion, before the rhythm suddenly drops out for the final verse as if the drummer was coin-operated. But the swooning \xe2\x80\x9cStill Waking Up\xe2\x80\x9d is Darcy\xe2\x80\x99s shiniest diamond in the rough. It strikes\xc2\xa0a perfectly Morrissey-esque balance of aching melancholy and arch meta-humor: \xe2\x80\x9cWaking up alone was always a hard day\xe2\x80\x99s night/\xe2\x80\x99Cause my head is full of popular songs/Old ones I never sang along to/Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it funny how that happens?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But with the gleaming mid-album instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Final Days,\xe2\x80\x9d Darcy draws a line in the sand, closing the book on the album\xe2\x80\x99s more sanguine first act while anticipating the anti-pop provocations that await on side two. The title track is unlikely to join the pantheon of Saturday-night party songs, its claustrophobic psychosis rendered with a dirgey drumbeat, ear-piercing guitar scrapes, and Darcy\xe2\x80\x99s deadpan-to-panicked vocal. (\xe2\x80\x9cLet me out! And I\xe2\x80\x99ll run!\xe2\x80\x9d he pleads, as if a prisoner to his own song.) \xe2\x80\x9cFound My Limit\xe2\x80\x9d is less jarring, but its hypnotic avant-folk oscillations and Darcy\xe2\x80\x99s eerie, disembodied voice make it equally chilling. When Darcy gets back to more recognizable song forms on the psych-pop shanty \xe2\x80\x9cSaint Germain\xe2\x80\x9d and the drowsy piano-bar ballad \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99d You Release?,\xe2\x80\x9d they feel corrupted, as if infected by the preceding forays into free-form, found-sound disorder.' b'But if Saturday Night\xe2\x80\x99s drifting second act carries the sense of Darcy feeling and fumbling his way through the dark, he eventually finds the calm in chaos. The penultimate instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cBeyond Me\xe2\x80\x9d is Saturday Night\xe2\x80\x99s messiest song\xe2\x80\x94all trembling, corroded strings and random piano plinks\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s also the album\xe2\x80\x99s purest, most joyful expression, like the bleary-eyed moment of relief that hits you as the sun rises after a night of brutal insomnia. And with that, Darcy arrives at a place that\xe2\x80\x99s the complete inverse of Ought, both musically and philosophically: Rather than concern himself with navigating the outside world, with Saturday Night, he\xe2\x80\x99s produced a suitably unsettled soundtrack for just trying to keep your shit together on the inside.'

column7: b'A versatile dandy, Jidenna tries on many different musical styles with his debut album\xe2\x80\x94but all that changing quickly grows tiresome.'
column8: b'Jidenna cut a memorable figure when he emerged in 2015, looking like a roguish extra from a cancelled period drama: natty three-piece suit, slim cane with gilded accents, shiny cufflinks. He proved to be a shrewd repackager on \xe2\x80\x9cClassic Man,\xe2\x80\x9d which pulled from DJ Mustard\xe2\x80\x99s minimalist bounce and made it No. 22 on the Hot 100. But in his efforts to break out of one-hit-wonder-dom and demonstrate a wide range on his debut album The Chief, Jidenna sometimes comes off as shapeless.' b'You might have seen this coming: Jidenna has spent the past two years releasing a series of singles with the apparent goal of appearing on as many Spotify playlists as possible. \xe2\x80\x9cLong Live the Chief,\xe2\x80\x9d carried by a squeaky, nails-on-the-chalkboard synth tone, was a distant descendant of Jeru the Damaja\xe2\x80\x99s 1993 boom-bap classic \xe2\x80\x9cCome Clean;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cChief Don\xe2\x80\x99t Run\xe2\x80\x9d paired bluster with a beat that sounded like a more ornate version of Tyga\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cRack City;\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Bit More\xe2\x80\x9d seemed built for the express purpose of giving DJs something to play after Justin Bieber\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSorry.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"It turns out these singles offered just a sample of Jidenna\xe2\x80\x99s talents\xe2\x80\x94this is a man with a suit for every occasion. \xe2\x80\x9cTrampoline\xe2\x80\x9d channels festive brass, while \xe2\x80\x9cBambi\xe2\x80\x9d attempts an audacious combination of post-war crooning and of-the-moment drum programming. There\xe2\x80\x99s hammy singing with piano (or strings), more strains of pop-hip-hop, you name it, and the 31-year-old stacks a jumble of imagery on this changing bedrock. He loves animal metaphors\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA lion don't ever lose sleep when it comes to sheep\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cshit\xe2\x80\x99s getting wild\xe2\x80\x94safari!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and drawing from a well worn selection of cultural titans: Frank Sinatra and the Dalai Lama, the Rolling Stones and the Beatles, James Bond (\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a Roger Moore nigger/I\xe2\x80\x99m a Sean Connery\xe2\x80\x9d)." b'Between all the beasts of prey and Madame Tussauds-worthy famous figures, Jidenna also alludes to police violence and racial inequality, and these moments tend to be his sharpest. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll shoot you down without warning,\xe2\x80\x9d he laments on \xe2\x80\x9cHelicopters,\xe2\x80\x9d displaying the hoarsest\xe2\x80\x94and strongest\xe2\x80\x94part of his voice. The most potent song on The Chief comes second to last: \xe2\x80\x9cWhite Niggas\xe2\x80\x9d imagines a white family that is struggling with addiction to prescription drugs and facing the same sort of systematic police oppression that afflicts black communities. It\xe2\x80\x99s a simple premise with a big pay-off.' b'Jidenna tries on styles and allusions, but he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t always fill them out or imbue them with personality. At a time when many rappers shift tone from syllable to syllable, you\xe2\x80\x99ll find little of that excitement on The Chief. He often delivers rapped lines conversationally and sings cleanly, but neither register has much character. Given this, his turn to the dancefloor on \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Bit More\xe2\x80\x9d represents a canny understanding of his strengths. In the business of making immensely popular songs for warm-weather events, the vocals are meant to be smooth\xe2\x80\x94any sort of burrs represent an impediment to frictionless forward locomotion. Here, where anonymity is prized, Jidenna sounds most comfortable.'

column7: b'On his fourth album, Jens Lekman opens up in new ways. He narrates the vulnerability\xc2\xa0of others, works with a producer, and crafts pop songs\xc2\xa0that absorb disco, calypso, and samba to soften their ache.'
column8: b'\xe2\x80\x9cPostcard #17\xe2\x80\x9d is the penultimate track on Jens Lekman\xe2\x80\x99s fourth album Life Will See You Now,\xc2\xa0and also its darkest. A morose Mingus-sampling piano ballad with handclaps and a disco backbeat, there\xe2\x80\x99s no cute story to unfurl, no quirky character to imbue pearls of wisdom. The tune follows the internal monologue of a writer struggling to believe in himself (\xe2\x80\x9cIf I just put this pen to this paper/If I just change the labels on the salt and pepper shaker/If I just trick myself into pouring it all out\xe2\x80\x9d), desperate to conquer the demons gnawing at his own sense of self-worth. Arguably the most fully formed track from his 2015\xc2\xa0Postcards project\xe2\x80\x94the album version is nearly identical to the original\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPostcard #17\xe2\x80\x9d is a window into the headspace Lekman was in when\xc2\xa0he resolved to write and release a new song every week that year. It\xe2\x80\x99s a portrait of an artist, confused and fearful, trying to climb out of a hole of his own construction.' b'Lekman\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0descent into darkness can be traced back to 2008, when he sat in his teenage bedroom in Sweden to pen\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThe End of the World is Bigger Than Love.\xe2\x80\x9d It was the first time he\xe2\x80\x99d managed to write\xc2\xa0about the woman who\xc2\xa0had broken his heart that year, and it became the starting point for 2012\xe2\x80\x99s I Know What Love Isn\xe2\x80\x99t, the followup to his 2007 breakout Night Falls Over Kortedala. The album would eschew the sample-heavy chamber pop pastiche of his oeuvre to date in favor 10 sparse, \xe2\x80\x9caerodynamic\xe2\x80\x9d takes on heartache. The subsequent tour was rough on Lekman\xe2\x80\x94performing the most painful songs he\xe2\x80\x99d ever written, night after night, to half-empty rooms waiting to hear the hits. His\xc2\xa0new songs were dark, and devoid of hope.' b'Lekman conceived the Postcards project to work through his despair. Only two of the 52 songs would make this\xc2\xa0album (#17 and #29, which became \xe2\x80\x9cHow We Met, The Long Version\xe2\x80\x9d), but the songwriting bootcamp helped lay its foundation. When the project caught the ear of the Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center, he used its\xc2\xa0commission to turn other people\xe2\x80\x99s stories into songs. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was a part of me that was really sick of this Jens Lekman character, and I wanted to write myself out of my songs,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. The Ghostwriting project scratched that itch, but ultimately confirmed what Lekman\xe2\x80\x99s friends had already confessed to him: It\xe2\x80\x99s easier to become emotionally invested in a Jens Lekman tale\xc2\xa0when he\xe2\x80\x99s one of the characters.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s fitting that Lekman would find himself through narrating\xc2\xa0the lives\xc2\xa0of others. His best work has always been\xc2\xa0defined not by fantastical tales of intrigue, but tender moments observed with an empathetic eye. On Life Will See You Now\xe2\x80\x99s opener, \xe2\x80\x9cTo Know Your Mission,\xe2\x80\x9d a teenage\xc2\xa0Lekman\xc2\xa0relates to a Mormon missionary that all he wants out of life is to listen to people\xe2\x80\x99s stories. When he sings \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6in a world of mouths/I want to be an ear/If there\xe2\x80\x99s a purpose to all this/Then that\xe2\x80\x99s why God put me here,\xe2\x80\x9d it feels less like a prescient self-assessment from a precocious teen than it does the wizened perspective of someone reflecting on their life.' b'The bright, joyous tones of \xe2\x80\x9cTo Know Your Mission\xe2\x80\x9d permeate\xc2\xa0Life Will See You Now, which marries the cohesion of I Know What Love Isn\xe2\x80\x99t with the diverse palette of his sample-driven chamber pop. The lush production may be thanks\xc2\xa0to Ewan Pearson, whose work on the LP marks the first time Lekman has used an outside producer. Each of the album\xe2\x80\x99s 10 tracks are fully formed pop songs, absorbing elements of disco, calypso, and samba, with upbeat rhythms that often belie the ache at their core. Bouncy bossa nova horns soundtrack a bride\xe2\x80\x99s existential crisis (\xe2\x80\x9cWedding in Finist\xc3\xa8re\xe2\x80\x9d), a cancer survivor consoles his distraught friend amid a barrage of sunny \xe2\x80\x9cdoo doo doo\xe2\x80\x9ds (\xe2\x80\x9cEvening Prayer\xe2\x80\x9d), and Ralph MacDonald\xe2\x80\x99s steel drums flutter as Lekman tortures himself with the olfactory nostalgia of an ex-lover (\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s That Perfume That You Wear?\xe2\x80\x9d). He plays with the dissonance, softening emotional blows with melodic confection. As a friend (Tracey Thorn) begs him to avoid a melancholy retelling of their nocturnal mischief on \xe2\x80\x9cHotwire the Ferris Wheel,\xe2\x80\x9d he indulges her: \xe2\x80\x9cOkay, if I\xe2\x80\x99m gonna write a song about this I promise I won\xe2\x80\x99t make it a sad song/You\xe2\x80\x99ll go like this: \xe2\x80\x98Woo!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d' b'A recurring theme of vulnerability dominates Life Will See You Now. Lekman\xe2\x80\x99s narrator\xc2\xa0explores the way\xc2\xa0new lovers slowly reveal themselves to each other (\xe2\x80\x9cOur First Fight\xe2\x80\x9d), and the emotional distance he creates by expecting the worst to happen (\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really see/How I built a bomb shelter under every dream,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on \xe2\x80\x9cDandelion Seed\xe2\x80\x9d). But the most striking relationships depicted here are platonic ones among men, stained by toxic interpretations of masculinity handed down from generation to generation. On \xe2\x80\x9cEvening Prayer,\xe2\x80\x9d he wants to tell his sick friend that he cares for him, but isn\xe2\x80\x99t sure that they\xe2\x80\x99re close enough. On the\xc2\xa0crushing Kings of Convenience-esque \xe2\x80\x9cHow Can I Tell Him,\xe2\x80\x9d Lekman\xc2\xa0wonders if it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to tell his best friend he loves him. The song is a crash course in what makes Lekman so endearing: the mundane anecdotes and intimate moments that colorfully illustrate why he loves his friend, the elegant arrangement of an infectious melody and timeless croon.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s title imagines its characters\xe2\x80\x94the tentative bride, the nostalgic ex-lover, even the young Lekman\xe2\x80\x94as patients in a waiting room, waiting for their lives to start, for the nurse to pop in and say, \xe2\x80\x9cLife will see you now.\xe2\x80\x9d Lekman knows that waiting room well. It\xe2\x80\x99s the place he was trapped when he wrote \xe2\x80\x9cPostcard #17,\xe2\x80\x9d stuck inside his own head, paralyzed by fear and self-doubt\xe2\x80\x94feelings most writers can relate to. But the\xc2\xa0triumph of Life Will See You Now\xc2\xa0is how it suggests\xc2\xa0that the 36-year-old Lekman has never been more skilled at his craft, or had more stories to tell.'

column7: b"Danilo Plessow and Marcus Worgull's second full-length ambient project strips away percussion and focuses on the soul and timbre of classic analog synthesizers."
column8: b"It continues to be a long, dark winter for new ambient music. Warm fuzzies are in short supply; doubt and discontent prevail. Think of Huerco S.\xe2\x80\x99s lo-fi churn, Sarah Davachi\xe2\x80\x99s stark drones, or\xc2\xa0Egyptrixx\xe2\x80\x99s battered futurism. But there are some glorious summers hiding in Suzanne Kraft\xe2\x80\x99s recent *What You Get for Being Young\xc2\xa0*and\xc2\xa0Brian Eno\xe2\x80\x99s latest generative composition Reflection, which often evoked the stillness of an autumn evening. Also retreating from icy climes is the German duo Vermont, who've followed up their self-titled 2014 debut with an ambient album far warmer and more beautiful than its predecessor." b'Vermont was an unexpected development from Danilo Plessow and Marcus Worgull, the two artists behind the project. Plessow made his name in the late \xe2\x80\x9900s making crisp, finely crafted house and disco as Motor City Drum Ensemble, while\xc2\xa0Worgull has spent the past dozen years refining his minimalist house epics for the Innervisions label. And while Kompakt has made a cottage industry out of ambient thanks to the label\xe2\x80\x99s annual Pop Ambient compilations, *Vermont *sounded different. It grew out of a series of open-ended studio jams using a battery of vintage analog gear, which was both its biggest strength and weakness. The record sounded wonderful\xe2\x80\x94a feast for the ears\xe2\x80\x94but its cycling arpeggios and drifting pads occasionally lacked direction, often feeling less like the work of a single ensemble than a compilation by a number of artists who loved all things Can and kosmische.' b'On II, Plessow and Worgull are back behind iconic workhorses like the Moog Prodigy and Arp Odyssey, synthesizers renowned for their buttery tone. The results feel clearer this time; they\xe2\x80\x99ve honed in on a narrower set of sounds across the length of the album, leading to a much more cohesive listen. Additionally, they\xe2\x80\x99ve opted to go without any drums at all, and most tracks utilize just a three elements: bassline, midrange arpeggio, and contrapuntal leads weaving high overhead. Their spare arrangements and measured tempos allow each electronic voice to come into focus. While artfully layering simple lines and lavishing attention on timbre, panning, and legato, they stir up an enveloping sound that makes the most of its underlying waveforms.' b"Once again, krautrock\xe2\x80\x99s ambient electronic strains remain their primary inspiration; the plucked guitar of \xe2\x80\x9cNorderney\xe2\x80\x9d invokes Manuel G\xc3\xb6ttsching\xe2\x80\x99s Inventions for Electric Guitar; airy tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cDschuna\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGebirge\xe2\x80\x9d draw inspiration from Cluster and Brian Eno. Looking further afield, the burnished, detuned tones of \xe2\x80\x9cChemtrails\xe2\x80\x9d recall Aphex Twin\xe2\x80\x99s Selected Ambient Works, Vol. II. And in \xe2\x80\x9cKi-Bou,\xe2\x80\x9d a riff inspired by Larry Heard\xe2\x80\x99s bright, agile basslines amplifies the music\xe2\x80\x99s field of vision. Mostly, though, these aren't stylistic exercises but carefully distilled mood pieces. In \xe2\x80\x9cHallo von der Anderen Seite,\xe2\x80\x9d a rippling synthesizer melody wraps circles around a plucked mbira, and given the music\xe2\x80\x99s fanciful qualities, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to imagine it as an animated still life, or a conversation between potted plants. \xe2\x80\x9cWenik\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94named after the birch rods that sauna-goers use to stimulate the circulation\xe2\x80\x94suggests two colored liquids mixing together in slow motion." b'Though the average track length hovers around the four-minute mark, many of these sequences could, like most ambient music, go on indefinitely. But Vermont have figured out how to make these comparatively short, sketch-like pieces work for them. They stretch out just long enough to draw you in and wrap you up in their atmospheres, but they never wear out their welcome. Like most *kosmische *musicians, Vermont dream big\xe2\x80\x94but never at the expense of the small, tactile details at their fingertips.'
